DOC.HEAD: Spring Arrives But Northeast Blanketed By Snow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `In upstate ...,' to UPDATE with number of injured at 11, one seriously injured.
DOC.TEXT: Spring began Tuesday, but it looked more like winter in the Northeast and the Appalachian Mountains as up to 22 inches of snow fell, causing power outages and closing sections of an interstate. Snow fell on eastern Ohio, much of New York state, nearly all of Pennsylvania, Vermont, southern New Hampshire, the Maryland Panhandle, eastern West Virginia and Virginia. Rain fell on the coast. In upstate New York, 11 elementary school students were injured when their bus rolled over on a rural road in poor weather in Columbia County, said Trooper Don Bailey. A 6-year-old girl was hospitalized in serious condition with a ruptured spleen, officials said. Vermont got the heaviest snow, with 18 inches at Braintree by mid-afternoon, 14 inches at Randolph Center and 19 at Williamstown. The Killington Ski Area reported 22 inches of snow by late afternoon and hoped for an additional 10 inches by morning. The heavy, wet snow clung to power lines, weighing them down and causing power outages across the state. About 6,000 Vermonters were without power in the southern section of the state and some would not have electricity throughout the night, said Chuck Satterfield of the Central Vermont Public Service Corp., which supplies more than half the state. The Vermont Highway Department closed sections of Interstate 89 for a time between Montpelier and Barre because of treacherous conditions, said highway dispatcher Ray Burke. He said part of Interstate 91 south near Thetford was closed by a weather-related rock slide. ``The funniest thing I've seen today,'' Burke quipped, ``is a robin with snowshoes, digging for worms on the Statehouse lawn.'' Vermont state government offices in Montpelier shut down at 3 p.m., shortly after National Life of Vermont insurance company, one of the area's largest employers, sent its workers home. In Pennsylvania, 6 to 7 inches fell at higher elevations near Wellsboro, with 6 inches in northern Bradford County. Up to 10 inches fell on hilltop areas of New York's Delaware County. Up to 8 inches fell at higher elevations of Virginia's Shenandoah Valley. Syracuse, N.Y., had 5.2 inches of snow by 8 p.m., giving it a total of 147.1 inches this winter, the third snowiest on record for the central New York state. ``It is not a freak snowstorm. Late-season snowstorms are not that uncommon,'' said Virginia state climatologist Pat Michaels. About 1,200 Virginia Power customers north and west of Charlottesville were without power for several hours because more than 50 fsnow-laden trees had fallen on power lines, said Virginia Power spokeswoman Claire Gillespie. Several weather-related traffic wrecks, including a 15-car pileup, and school delays and closings were reported in North Carolina, which had snow in the mountains and freezing rain elsewhere. Heavier snowfall in the six hours ending at noon included 7 inches in Montpelier, Vt., 3 inches in Williamsport, Pa., and 2 inches in Syracuse, N.Y., and the Wilkes Barre-Scranton, Pa., area. Freeze warnings were posted overnight for much of Georgia, interior South Carolina, the interior of North Carolina, central and western Virginia, West Virginia's Eastern Panhandle and western through central Maryland. The cold threatened many trees and other plants that have started spring growth early because of recent unseasonably warm weather. ``It looks crazy, stuff in bloom with snow all over it'' said Henry Chiles, owner of Crown Orchard in Batesville, Va. He said his orchard workers planned to use blowers during the night to protect apple, peach and nectarine trees. Rain fell over eastern Maryland, New Jersey, southeastern Pennsylvania, eastern New York and southern New England. In the West, warmer weather was making a resurgence. Casper, Wyo., had a record high of 63 degrees and Tucson, Ariz., posted a record high of 62. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 24 at Bradford, Pa., to 94 at Palm Springs, Calif. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 8 at Marquette, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Western Afghan Rebels Protest Distribution of US Aid
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Western Afghan rebels say they are in grave need of U.S. weapons and food, and they have attracted backers in Congress. ``We're very desperate,'' said Mohamad Saljuqi of the National Islamic Front of Afghanistan, or NIFA, a moderate Sunni faction among the coalition of mujahedeen rebels. ``I don't know how long we can go on.'' Saljuqi's comments in a telephone interview Monday from Tehran, Iran, came as U.S. and Soviet diplomats prepare to discuss the stalemated war in Afghanistan. They will explore a possible political solution to remove the Soviet-installed Kabul government from power during a meeting in Helsinki, Finland, on Wednesday. Saljuqi's complaint highlights the growing controversy over the 10-year U.S. aid program to the mujahedeen. Support in Congress has been eroding following the Soviet military pullout from Afghanistan last year. While conservatives believe the United States should increase supervision of its aid and make sure it gets to the right groups, liberals advocate a U.S. cutoff of aid for the rebels coupled with an end to Soviet aid for the Afghan government. Robert Peck, until June 1989 the Bush administration's top analyst on Afghanistan, said in recent congressional testimony that the United States had become entangled in factional fighting among the mujahedeen and should disengage. Other experts say Pakistan's secret service, which is in charge of distributing U.S. weapons to the guerrillas, discriminates against NIFA and other pro-Western factions in favor of fundamentalist Moslem groups. Saljuqi said NIFA guerrillas have not received any ammunition or other supplies from the United States since last summer. The State Department rejects the complaint, saying each of the seven mujahedeen groups receives what it should. But some members of Congress are championing NIFA's cause. In two recent letters to President Bush, a group of lawmakers led by Rep. Don Ritter, R-Pa., urged the administration to investigate. In response to the lawmakers' first letter, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft wrote in December that the allegations of discrimination against certain factions had been investigated and ``to the extent they existed, (were) corrected.'' The lawmakers disagreed. The ``picture we are receiving from official U.S. government channels ... appears to be different than the many reliable reports, fresh from the field, that are coming from important segments of the Afghan resistance,'' they wrote back. They urged an end to the Pakistanis' control over the weapons ``and an equitable distribution of military supplies to the most strategic, combat-effective and moderate elements of the Afghan resistance.'' Saljuqi said that in order to break the stalemate in the fighting against the Kabul government, his guerrillas need ammunition, mortar shells and shoulder-fired, Stinger anti-aircraft missiles. Administration officials say they prefer to look for a political solution to the stalemate. Barnett Rubin, an Afghanistan specialist at the congressionally funded U.S. Institute of Peace, said NIFA has been getting a bad deal both from the Pakistanis and the Saudis. He said Saudi Arabia, which provides about two-thirds of the estimated $700 million the mujahedeen got last year, does not like NIFA because the Saudis believe it is too close to Iran _ the Saudis' archenemy. The situation is further complicated by the continued suspension of U.S. food aid to NIFA and other guerrillas in western Afghanistan. U.S. officials said Monday they are still trying to reach agreement with the rebel leaders on an effective monitoring system for the program, which last year provided about $33 million worth of food. The program, administered by the Agency for International Development, was suspended last November and resumed once in January, only to be stopped again last month, the officials said. The United States is concerned that without effective monitoring, the food _ mostly sacks of wheat _ could be diverted by rebel leaders and sold for profit.

DOC.HEAD: A National Obsession Nears Crescendo
DOC.TEXT: If Japan has a national obsession, it's the cherry blossom. During the first days of spring, when the cool of winter still envelops much of the nation, the coming of the ``pink mist'' is impatiently awaited. Its progress up the archipelago from subtropical Okinawa to snowy Hokkaido is closely watched. When the cherry trees bloom, millions of Japanese, young and old, head to the parks to practice the ancient art of ``flower-viewing,'' a spirited mixture of song, sake and, with luck, sunshine. Many companies arrange large, and sometimes lavish, outdoor parties for their employees. Stalls in the parks sell tasty treats _ from squid-on-a-stick to cotton candy. Since the cherry blossom's beauty is a fleeting pleasure, lasting only a few days, careful attention to weather trends is required to catch them in their full splendor. This year's official announcement came today: the state Meteorological Agency declared that the wait this year should be shorter than usual. Flower viewers, said one agency official, may even be able to savor their rice wine before April Fool's Day. ``Several cherries are already in bloom because the weather has been relatively warm,'' he said, requesting anonymity. ``In fact, this year is tied with 1989 and 1966 as the earliest for blossoms.'' Rumors to that effect had been circulating for quite some time. Evening television news broadcasts already have begun their periodic updates on the ``sakura zensen,'' or cherry blossom front line, giving special attention to those harbingers of spring that burst into bloom earlier than the rest. Signs have been posted at rest areas along the nation's highways informing motorists of when to expect the local blossoms to be at their peak, and the public Japan Highway Corp. has set up a hotline for cherry information. Some 150,000 cherry trees grace the 100 or so service areas nationwide, said Motoki Mori, a corporation spokesman. ``The Japanese have a very strong fondness for the cherry blossom,'' he said. ``It's just something about our national character.'' Mori said the ``front line'' was still down in the southwestern island of Kyushu, but probably would hit Tokyo suddenly. Police, meanwhile, geared up for the onslaught of picnickers on Japan's normally sedate parks. The heaviest-hit is likely to be Tokyo's Ueno Park, where 450,000 people _ or 505 people per tree _ viewed the blossoms on a sunny April 2, 1989. A park official said flower viewers already had begun setting up for picnics today, though only a few trees had blossomed.

DOC.HEAD: Educator: Draft College Grads as Teachers
DOC.TEXT: For a man whose animated classroom lectures include leaping onto desktops, it's no wonder that Rice University Professor Dennis Huston offers an unorthodox solution to an impending teacher shortage. ``I think that the answer is some kind of system for drafting young people just out of college who are in the process of deciding what they want to do,'' said Huston, an English professor at the Houston university who was named national ``professor of the year'' by an education group. Huston shared his ideas during an interview after meeting with President Bush earlier this year. ``We need to put a lot of these kids into the high schools and let them teach for one or two years as a kind of service to the country,'' said Huston. The Education Department predicted the annual demand for new public school teachers will rise from 128,000 in 1988 to 174,000 in 1995. But only 8.8 percent of the 1988 first-year college students plan to pursue careers in elementary or secondary education. Linda Darling-Hammond, professor of education at the Teachers College of Columbia University, said only about three-fourths of those who prepare to teach actually enter teaching after graduation. Of those who do enter, about half leave during their first five years, she said. To get more teachers into the classroom, Huston said new college graduates should be selected in a military-type draft or ``encouraged through propaganda like we once did for the Peace Corps.'' They would teach their college major solely as a service to the country, he said. ``If President Bush emphasized how important (the draft program) was to the nation,'' it would work because ``lots of students feel a missionary zeal,'' Huston said. The new graduates would be trained in a special program that is ``only a few weeks long because that's all you need when you know the subject matter,'' said Huston, who joined the Rice faculty in 1969. He said his teacher draft idea would provide ``really qualified inexpensive labor'' to schools. ``The president is fond of talking about wars on drugs, wars on this ... This is a place where we need a draft of a different group of people ... the people who have profited the most from their upbringing either by their own initiative or by the fact that they were fortunate enough to come out of a successful family,'' said Huston. ``Those people owe this society. They owe this country the most. Seems to me the least we can expect of them is two years of service in a much more important cause right now than war _ the cause of education. And it is, of course, finally in the end self-serving.'' The recruits ``would have the energy and optimism of youth and the knowledge of a wonderful education to convey to students in high school,'' said Huston. And, he added, classroom size could be reduced ``because we'd suddenly have a lot more teachers.'' The professor of the year program is sponsored by the Council for Advancement and Support of Education, the nation's largest education association in terms of institutional membership, including about 2,850 colleges, universities, and independent schools. Huston won the title from 500 nominations nationwide. He received a $5,000 cash award sponsored by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. The council launched the competition in 1981 to recognize undergraduate faculty members for their contributions to the lives and careers of students. Since its inception, eight other national professors of the year and more than 160 finalists have been honored.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Asks Congress for Aviation Tax Hikes
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is asking Congress to raise taxes on aviation fuel and airline tickets and allow a new airport tax as part of a five-year plan for commercial aviation. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner included the $22 billion proposal in the Federal Aviation Administration's reauthorization bill sent to Congress on Monday. The plan would add up to $12 in airport fees to a roundtrip airline ticket, increase the tax on tickets from 8 percent to 10 percent and hike aviation fuel taxes by 25 percent, which also likely would be passed along in higher fares. Congress is likely to make modifications, however. It is the first proposal arising out of the administration's new national transportation policy, which calls for travelers to finance a greater share of national transportation systems. The administration makes a distinction between ``user fees'' and taxes, which President Bush has promised not to increase. Skinner acknowledged last week, however, that transportation budget proposals include boosts in both local and federal levies. The increases would add to an aviation trust fund that the FAA proposes to tap for 85 percent of aeronautical needs through fiscal 1995. Currently, 57 percent of federal aviation costs are covered by users via the tax-fed trust fund, with the remainder from general tax revenue. FAA Administrator James B. Busey said the reauthorization bill would help meet the growing demand for aviation, allow modernization of the air traffic control system and increase aviation safety. Overall, it would boost federal funding for aviation projects by 73 percent in the next five years, Busey said. In addition to the plan for improvements, the FAA expects to spend between $22 billion and $24 billion on operations and maintenance over the next five years, including salaries of air traffic controllers, agency budget officials said. ``I believe this administration has put forward a comprehensive proposal to deal with aviation in the 1990s,'' Busey told a meeting of airport officials. If approved by Congress, the plan would allow airports to impose taxes for the first time since the early 1970s. The maximum initial tax would be $3 per departure, with travelers who make connecting flights paying at no more than one additional airport each way. The legislation would give the transportation secretary power to increase the maximum tax after fiscal 1991. After the first year, collection of the tax would automatically decrease other federal funding available to airports. Some smaller regional airports might elect not to levy the fee, so it would not reduce funding under the federal Airport Improvement Program, said Mike Moffet, an FAA assistant administrator. Each $1 collected in departure taxes would reduce federal funds available to an airport by 50 cents. Improvement funds that were freed as a result of the new tax revenues would go into a discretionary fund to help airports that need additional money, Moffet said. If the nation's largest 45 airports imposed the ticket tax, collections would total an estimated $1 billion a year, he said. The collections could be used to obtain bonds for about $10 billion in airport projects over the five years. Federal support for airport improvements would total $7.7 billion over five years, a 28 percent increase over amounts made available during the past five years. Other funds under the reauthorization program would include $13.5 billion for facilities and equipment programs, a 130 percent increase over the previous five years; and $970 million for research and development, a 13 percent increase. The aviation trust fund is expected to have a $7.6 billion balance by the end of fiscal 1990 on Sept. 30. The spending plan would decrease the fund to about $3 billion by the end of the five-year period, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: A woman who once claimed David Letterman was a dominant figure in her life has broken into the talk-show host's home twice since she was released from prison for one of five earlier break-ins there, police said. Margaret Ray, 37, of Crawford, Colo., was released Friday from Niantic State Prison for women, and on Sunday, police found her in Letterman's house after he called to report a broken window, police Sgt. Nick Warren said. Police escorted her off the property and warned her not to come back, Warren said. But early Monday, the host of NBC's ``Late Night with David Letterman'' called police to report seeing Ray in the hallway of his home. Police found her near the tennis court on Letterman's property. Ray was charged with first-degree trespassing, held overnight on $1,000 bond and taken to Norwalk Superior Court on Monday afternoon, where a psychiatric evaluation was ordered, a spokeswoman in the public defender's office said. Ray was taken back to the Niantic prison. When Ray was released last Friday, she had served seven months of a nine-month sentence for trespassing at Letterman's home last August. An NBC publicist, Rosemary Keenan, said Letterman had no comment on the arrest.

Oprah Winfrey says her life has become a balancing act as she tries to find time to be host of her talk show, star in her new television series and run her $20 million production studio. On Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday mornings, she films her TV talk show. Wednesday afternoons through Friday evenings, she plays matriarch Mattie Michael of ``Brewster Place,'' set to debut on ABC next month. On weekends, she attends to business at her new Harpo production studio in Chicago. At night, she gets four, maybe five hours of sleep. ``I'm not trying to say it's been an easy thing,'' Winfrey said. ``But I think that I have managed to handle this all very well because I have insisted upon having control.''

Indianapolis Colts star Eric Dickerson, the seventh-leading rusher in National Football League history, says he has lost interest in football, and intends to retire. ``I'm through with football, and (the Colts) know it. So I'm telling you, I'm finished,'' Dickerson, 29, said in an interview taped Thursday at his Lost Angeles home and broadcast Monday on on WFYI-TV's ``Indiana Tonight'' show. ``Right now I really don't love the game that much,'' Dickerson said. ``But rather than stay in Indianapolis and take the pounding that I'm taking, I'd rather quit.'' Jim Irsay, the Colts general manager and son of owner Robert Irsay, said through a spokesman on Monday that the team expected Dickerson to fulfill his contract obligations. Team spokesman Craig Kelley declined to say what Dickerson's obligations are. Dickerson came to the Colts in October 1987 in a trade from the Los Angeles Rams. He has gained 11,226 yards, 10 behind O.J. Simpson, and has rushed for more than 1,000 yards in each of his seven NFL seasons. He holds the single-season record of 2,105 yards, set with the Rams in 1984.

Filmmaker Robert Hendrickson, suing talk show host Geraldo Rivera for alleged copyright infringement, lost a bid to subpoena mass murderer Charles Manson to testify. Hendrickson contends that Manson is the only available witness who can testify about his 1972 documentary ``Manson,'' parts of which the filmmaker claims Rivera used without permission. In a ruling released Monday, U.S. District Judge Ronald S.W. Lew declined to subpoena Manson, 55, who is in state prison in Corcoran, 190 miles north of Los Angeles. Lew said Hendrickson cited no authority empowering the court to issue the subpoena. Hendrickson, 45, of Woodland Hills, filed the copyright infringement suit in May, a month after Rivera aired excerpts from ``Manson'' in the TV special, ``Murder _ Live from Death Row.'' The trial is set for April 10. Manson was convicted in 1969 of masterminding the murder of actress Sharon Tate and six others.

Elie Wiesel, winner of the 1986 Nobel Peace Prize, will bring together other Nobel laureates, human rights champions and statesmen in a high-powered conference to evaluate the darker side of the spread of democracy. Wiesel organized the conference to assess the risk of long-supressed hatreds surfacing in societies that abruptly became free. The gathering, set for Aug. 26-29, will be arranged with the Norwegian Nobel Instutute, a Wiesel spokesman said Monday. Among 35 leaders to accept invitations so far are 1983 Peace Prize winner Lech Walesa of Poland, French President Francois Mitterrand, Czech President Vacel Havel, former U.S. President Carter and Harvard economist John Kenneth Galbraith. Wiesel won the Nobel Prize for his writings examining the Holocaust.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Quickly Administering Clot Drug Stops Heart Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Speedier injections of clot-busting drugs to heart attack victims improves their chances of escaping permanent damage, suggesting that ambulance crews can save lives by administering this medicine on the way to the hospital, a study concludes. Even when hospitals are prepared to offer this treatment, hours may pass before patients reach the emergency ward, are evaluated by heart specialists and eventually hooked up to lines that drip the medicine into their bloodstreams. The new research supports the growing belief that for this approach to work well, it must be offered fast, perhaps even before heart attack victims leave their homes. The research found that 92 percent of clogged arteries could be reopened if the medicine was given immediately as a shot. Currently hospitals administer the medicine as a continuous drip infusion, which takes longer to set up and is impractical for use by paramedics. In past studies, clot-dissolving drugs have been about 60 percent to 70 percent effective in opening up clot-blocked heart arteries. The new study, meant to simulate ambulance administration of the drug tissue plasminogen activator, or TPA, was conducted by Dr. George R. McKendall of Rhode Island Hospital. He presented the findings Monday at a meeting of the American College of Cardiology. ``They achieved what appears to be a startling patency,'' or reopening of closed arteries, of more than 90 percent, said Dr. Carl J. Pepine of the University of Florida. ``This is striking.'' McKendall said that ambulance crews in Providence will begin carrying TPA within a few weeks. Emergency teams in at least seven other cities are already doing this or planning similar programs. Dr. C. Richard Conti, president of the college of cardiology, said that in light of the lastest research, ``we ought to think about giving the first dose in the home by paramedics.'' In the latest study, patients with heart attacks were given an injection of TPA as soon as they arrived at the hospital. Doctors waited a half hour to mimic an ambulance trip and then set them up on a continuous drip to deliver the rest of a standard dose of TPA. ``We wanted to see what happens if you give a quick shot and then take the patient to the hospital,'' McKendall said. ``It suggests that this may be a more effective way of achieving patency.'' Heart attacks usually occur when an obstruction, typically a blood clot, gets stuck in an artery that feeds the heart muscle. Unless the blockage is removed within a few hours, a section of muscle is starved of oxygen and dies, permanently weakening the heart. While TPA and similar drugs are effective, they also are risky because they can cause uncontrolled bleeding. If the bleeding occurs in the brain, the result can be a crippling stroke. To make sure that during emergencies the medicines are given only to people who truly are having heart attacks, the ambulance crew typically sends electrocardiogram readings back to the hospital over a cellular telephone. A doctor there gives instructions about what medicines to administer. Several clot-dissolving drugs are now on the market, and others are being tested. Many studies are under way to determine which is the best. In the United States, many physicians consider TPA to be the preferred drug. This medicine, produced through genetic engineering, costs a hospital about $2,300 for a single dose. A competing drug, streptokinase, which is made from bacteria, costs $87. A recent Italian study concluded that the far cheaper stroptokinase works just as well as TPA. However, another new study, also presented at the meeting Monday, suggests that a combination of the two may be the best approach. Dr. Cindy L. Grines of the University of Kentucky compared the combination with straight TPA in 111 heart attack patients. She found that clogged arteries reopened in 70 percent of those who got the combination, combined with 58 percent in those getting TPA alone. She said that the combination approach costs only about half as much as pure TPA and appears to work better.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Court Jails People Who Helped Refugees Flee
DOC.TEXT: A Vietnamese court has sentenced to 20 years in prison the head of a group that helped hundreds of boat people flee the Communist country, Hanoi Radio reported. It said other group members were also sent to prison, including one sentenced to 18 years. From 1984 to March 1989, Phan Van Thanh organized 19 illegal departures from Vietnam involving about 1,000 people, the Sunday radio report said. These included one trip in October 1988 in which one boat sank and 16 people died, said the report, which was monitored in Bangkok on Monday. Thanh and his group, which operated in Ho Chi Minh City (formerly Saigon), collected fees in gold from the families of escapees once their safe arrival was confirmed by mail, the report said. It said an accomplice, Tran Van Chi, bribed an Interior Ministry official and also ``pressured '' security forces into releasing another group member in 1988. Though Thanh surrendered to authorities at the beginning of 1988, he then ``abused his acquaintance with a number of leading cadres (Communist party officials) to organize additional trips on a larger scale,'' the radio said. He was sentenced on March 11, the report said. Tran Van Chi received a sentence of 18 years, the radio said. Jail terms of other group members ranged from three to 12 years, the report said. The radio said Thanh had 13 accomplices, but it did not say if they were all sentenced.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Say Democrats Too Hasty in Considering Child Care Bill
DOC.TEXT: House Republicans are accusing Democrats of rushing to the floor for a quick vote this week on a tentative compromise over competing versions of new child-care legislation. ``They've gone behind closed doors, they've cut their deals,'' Rep. Bob Walker, R-Pa., charged Monday. ``Now they're ready to rush it to the floor.'' The child-care legislation, which has been stalled for months because of differences among Democrats, was the object of weeks of private negotiations that were continuing today. Democratic leaders, who control the House agenda, scheduled the bill for floor debate Wednesday and Thursday. But Rep. David Nagle, D-Iowa, one of the sponsors, told the House on Monday that not all issues had been resolved and that Democrats didn't have copies of the bill either. Democratic leaders hoped to work out details of their bill in time to seek a special rule from the Rules Committee today limiting floor amendments. Opponents wanted no limit. The tentative version worked out among Democratic leaders would combine elements of competing child-care proposals. It would expand tax credits for low-income families and increase funding for block grants under Title XX of the Social Security Act, as well as expand Head Start and create a school-based program for before- and after-school care. It would drop a proposed new program of grants to the states to subsidize child care, which had been pushed by liberals including Rep. Gus Hawkins, D-Calif., chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee. The compromise was expected to face challenges on the House floor, however, from some Republicans and conservative Democrats. Total cost of the Democrats' version has been estimated at as much as $5 billion a year. Nagle said Democrats were seeking resolution of final differences over how to provide financial aid to religious institutions that provide child care. Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia predicted that President Bush would veto the Democrats' plan if it wins passage. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., has promised floor action and has long said he hoped for a vote by the end of March. His deadline put pressure on Democrats to resolve their differences or risk losing entirely on the floor.

DOC.HEAD: Forecasters Fairly Optimistic About '90 Farm Outlook
DOC.TEXT: With today's arrival of spring and the observance of National Agriculture Day, it's also time for some serious economic forecasting. Just in time, the Agriculture Department's seers have unveiled a new set of numbers for the nation's farmers in 1990. Generally, things are looking pretty good. Not everything will be rosy, but USDA's latest economic outlook made it a lot easier for President Bush, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and other leaders to smile as they pay tribute to the nation's farmers at a scheduled White House ceremony today. The picture is subject to change, of course. There's always the possibility of unexpected catastrophe when crops and livestock are involved. ``Combined with continuing strong demand for agricultural products, currently higher prices due to tighter corn stocks and smaller hog inventories have brightened the outlook,'' the outlook report said. The report, a digest of one to be issued later in USDA's Agricultural Outlook magazine, also had some encouraging news for consumers this spring. ``Increasing poultry supplies may push retail prices below last summer, giving consumers relief from rising pork prices,'' it said. ``Retail beef prices likely will remain near last year's highs through the second and third quarters. Milk and egg prices probably will decline in 1990 as recent favorable returns stimulate production.'' Analysts also said the bulk of federal payments _ which figure prominently in annual farm income statistics _ continue to go to a relative handful of larger farming operations. Overall, the ``net cash income'' of farmers was forecast at $54 billion to $58 billion this year, up from $53 billion in 1989 but likely below the record of $57.2 billion in 1988. Previously, USDA's Economic Research Service had put 1990 income in the range of $52 billion to $57 billion. As used by the agency, net cash income ``measures the value of commodities sold in a calendar year plus government payments, less out-of-pocket costs.'' Commodities sold may actually have been produced in earlier years and stored until marketed. In another method of accounting, the report said ``net farm income'' is expected to be in the range of $45 billion to $49 billion, steady to down 8 percent from last year's $49 billion. Previously, it was forecast at $44 billion to $49 billion. Economists use net farm income to measure the value of agricultural production _ whether sold or stored _ in a calendar year plus government payments, minus all costs, including depreciation and other factors. ``Net farm income may drop as feed grain prices ease from the spikes caused by the 1988 drought,'' the report said. ``The lower prices will dampen the value of the fall harvest. Much of the fall 1990 harvest will be sold in 1991.'' The report said an analysis of USDA's 1988 Farm Costs and Returns Survey showed that direct payments to farmers have been ``distributed on the basis of production'' as prescribed by current farm law. ``Of farms receiving direct government payments, 32 percent received 90 percent of the payments,'' the report said. ``Since 64 percent of all farm receive no direct payments, 90 percent of the payments go to only 12 percent of all farms.'' Greg Gajewski, senior editor of the report, said there was ``no surprise'' in the breakdown of federal subsidies and that the pattern fit the trend. Direct federal payments to farmers peaked at about $16.7 billion in 1987, according to the study, then dropped to $14.5 billion in 1988 and to around $11 million in 1989 as market prices improved, thus reducing many of the subsidy rates. A further reduction to as low as $8 billion is expected this year. The report also said that ``improved weather has brightened prospects'' for the U.S. winter wheat crop. ``Early indicators in Western Europe, Canada and Australia point to wheat production gains there as well,'' it said. ``Wheat prices are falling.'' In Asia, a bumper 1989-90 rice crop is being harvested, with record or near-record output forecast for China, Bangladesh, Vietnam, Thailand and India. ``But U.S. stocks are low, and the Thais are holding stocks back for sale later in the year,'' the report added. ``So, prices remain strong and U.S. exports are slowing.''

DOC.HEAD: Rowny Pushes Strategic Defense Program
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. anti-missile program ``is destined to play a major role'' in preventing a nuclear war even as the superpowers prepare to slash their weapons arsenals, a senior presidential adviser said today. The Strategic Defense Initiative, known popularly as Star Wars, has been under attack by arms control experts as farfetched ever since it was unveiled by former President Reagan. But Edward L. Rowny, a retired Army general who advised Reagan and now President Bush on arms control, challenged those critics as ``wizards of Armageddon.'' In a speech prepared for a defense association, Rowny said the critics foolishly rely on an outmoded approach to deter Soviet nuclear attack. That doctrine, known as MAD, for mutually assured destruction, is based on the theory that a potential aggressor would not launch a first strike if its lack of a defense exposed itself to massive retaliation. Rowny said the technology of SDI offers a better guarantee against Soviet or accidental nuclear attack. It would use nuclear weapons and other advanced technology to intercept and destroy ballistic missiles aimed at the United States. Bush is asking Congress to boost research spending on SDI by $1 billion beginning in October to $4.1 billion. In the meantime, the United States and the Soviet Union are moving closer to treaties to reduce their long-range nuclear weapons and their arsenals of tanks and other conventional arms in Europe. Rowny said a strategic defense gradually becomes more critical as these weapons are scaled down. He called SDI an insurance policy for a treaty to cut long-range missiles by 30 to 50 percent. ``With SDI,'' he said, ``a fateful Soviet decision to initiate a first strike, for whatever reason, will almost certainly never be made. Should deterrence fail, though, strategic defense will help protect our society.'' U.S.-Soviet negotiations in Geneva on strategic defenses have not kept pace with progress in other arms control areas. In fact, Rowny said, the Soviets were using the negotiations to try to block the U.S. program. He said the Bush administration had proposed that both sides have a strategic defense. After signing a treaty, they would have three years to decide whether to deploy systems that are not permitted under the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty. Rowny was speaking to the American Defense Preparedness Association.

DOC.HEAD: 10,000 Oil Spills Since Exxon Valdez Accident
DOC.TEXT: Millions of gallons of oil will be spilled on land and water year after year unless the United States changes its approach to oil, says the Wilderness Society in a report called ``100 Spills, 1,000 Excuses.'' The report released Monday details the 100 worst spills since the Exxon Valdez accident broke all records when the tanker ran aground March 24, 1989, dumping 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound, Alaska. ``The sad fact is that while the past 12 months have featured a number of large and widely publicized spills, this has been, in most respects, a typical year,'' said George Frampton, president of the society. ``No one has final figures, but experts estimate that there have been roughly 10,000 spills since the Exxon Valdez tore open,'' said the report. Those spills have caused the loss of 15 million to 20 million gallons of oil, it said. The past year's spills include three in one weekend in June when a Liberian tanker left a 20-foot by 2-mile sheen in Delaware Bay, Del.; an Amoco pipeline spilled 96,000 gallons of gasoline at Knox County, Ill., and 34,700 gallons of diesel fuel were dumped from a pipeline near Newtown, N.D. On New Year's Day an Exxon refinery pipeline ruptured, sending 567,000 gallons of heating oil into the Arthur Kill Waterway near Linden, N.J. On Feb. 7, a tanker ran into its own anchor and spewed 397,000 gallons of crude into the waters of Huntington Beach, Calif. The Wilderness Society said the report is based on its own records and those of the Coast Guard, the Alaska Department of Conservation, the National Park Service, the U.S. Bureau of Land Management and World Information Systems of Cambridge, Mass. ``Oil is inherently messy business. Accidents, lots of accidents will happen,'' said the report. It said there should be stronger incentives for oil and shipping industries to extract, transport and refine oil more safely; stepped up government enforcement of laws relating to oil production and the environment; and an end to U.S. ``addiction'' to oil. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., chairman of the House Interior subcommittee on water and power resources, starts hearings Thursday to continue Congress' investigation of the Exxon Valdez spill's impact. Miller said the hearing will consider the extent of oil pollution in Alaska due to the Valdez, future cleanup options and whether industry can handle another spill of the same magnitude. Miller plans another hearing next week to look into environmental problems associated with operation of the trans-Alaska pipeline, including corrosion of the pipeline. Congress is working on a liability bill that will determine who should pay for future spills. The legislation, now in a House-Senate conference committee, also would establish regulations for handling oil. The most hotly contested issue is a House proposal to require all tankers calling on U.S. ports to have double bottoms within seven years and double hulls within 15 years. All new tankers would have to be built with double hulls. Senate conference committee members want new tankers and barges to have double hulls or any alternative that the National Academy of Sciences decides would provide protection. They also have proposed a phaseout of the existing single-hull tanker and barge fleet. About one-fifteenth of the fleet would be retired each year, with the oldest and largest going first.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 30,807.19, down 456.05 points, or 1.46 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Former HHS Secretaries Back Anti-Smoking Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan should keep up his aggressive anti-smoking campaign and ``get even tougher,'' seven of his predecessors agree. Sullivan met in private Monday with the seven former secretaries of HHS and its predecessor agency, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, for a wide-ranging discussion. The former officials later were joined by Vice President Dan Quayle for an unveiling of former HHS Secretary Otis Bowen's official portrait. Sullivan said after the ceremony the discussion with his predecessors was ``very meaningful, very helpful.'' ``We talked about some of our current priorities, such as health care reform and programs to strengthen the family, and how former secretaries dealt with moving their agendas,'' he said. Joseph Califano Jr., who headed HEW from 1977-79, and Margaret Heckler, HHS secretary from 1983-85, said the former officials uniformly supported Sullivan's campaign against smoking and tobacco company advertising practices. Califano, the only Democrat among them, said they agreed ``that he ought to keep going and get even tougher.'' ``We gave him quite a lot of advice,'' Heckler said. ``In general, we like the course he's plotted. ... We also feel he can do a great deal more simply because he's captured the attention of the American people on the smoking issue and its relationship to minorities and women.'' Sullivan said he intends to use the smoking issue as a platform to emphasize the importance of health promotion and disease prevention. The other former secretaries at the meeting were: Bowen, 1985-89; Richard Schweiker, 1981-83; David Mathews, 1975-77; Robert Finch, 1969-70; and Arthur S. Flemming, 1958-61. HEW was broken up into the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Education in May 1980. Bowen's portrait will be hung in the Great Hall of the Hubert H. Humphrey Building, along with those of the other former secretaries of HHS and HEW. Bowen, a physician and former Indiana governor, served as HHS secretary from Dec. 13, 1985, to Jan. 20, 1989 _ the longest of anyone in that position. He lives in Bremen, Ind., with his wife, Rose, who also attended the ceremony. Quayle, a fellow Hoosier, said Bowen is ``a man of compassion, man of integrity, a man committed to his family ... and all the people of the nation.'' Sullivan praised Bowen's work addressing the AIDS epidemic, fighting illegal drugs and reforming the Medicare system with the catastrophic illness program. Though Congress repealed it last year, ``the discussion is far from over,'' Sullivan said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0435; breaks up first graf.
Poorly Paid Guards Protect Priceless Artwork
An AP Extra
LaserPhotos BX1,NY4
DOC.TEXT: Despite predictions of more thefts like the $100 million-plus raid of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, many museums and galleries have inexperienced, poorly paid guards and inadequate security systems, experts say. To make matters worse, there are only a handful of investigators trained to probe such crimes, officials said. Guards are considered the weakest link in the security chain. Most are young and receive little better than the minimum wage to protect million-dollar paintings and sculptures. ``We've got to begin to hire career security people,'' said Steven Keller, a security consultant who was brought in to supervise security at the Art Institute of Chicago after thieves stole three Cezanne paintings in 1979. In Israel and some European countries, security guards are typically highly-trained, well-paid professionals, Keller said. ``It's the exact opposite here. Security guards here are hired at the entry-level and leave their jobs to work at McDonald's or become janitors,'' Keller said. In the robbery early Sunday at the Gardner Museum, two men dressed as police officers persuaded the two guards on duty to let them into the museum, then bound them with tape and disabled the security system. The thieves made off with a dozen artworks, including priceless Old Master paintings, in the biggest theft in modern times since the looting of Germany's national bank at the end of World War II. Several of the pictures and at least one Rembrandt were cut out of their frames, which were connected to an alarm system. The pilfered works included two paintings and an etching by Rembrandt, three paintings and two charcoals by Edgar Degas; one painting each by Edouard Manet, Jan Vermeer and Govaert Flinck, and a bronze beaker dating from the Chinese Shang Dynasty, 1,200-1,100 B.C. The thieves also tried but failed to take a third Rembrandt, a self-portrait, said museum spokesman Barry Wanger. He would not give details. Museum director Anne Hawley said the guards, who had worked at the Gardner less than a year, were only doing their job and would not be disciplined. Many museums have a lax attitude toward security, said Robert Spiel, a private security consultant and former FBI agent specializing in art theft. ``You're seeing a mentality where people assume that because an artwork is either too obscure or too famous, no one will steal it,'' Spiel said. ``That leads to a low level of security.'' Curators and security experts said that as the value of art soars at auction houses like Sotheby's, thefts are bound to increase as the illegal art market grows to a billion-dollar international trade. ``The average person thinks an art theft is an exotic thing that happens once every few years,'' said Donald Mason, a private security consultant for museums. ``That's just not so.'' Mason, who headed art theft investigations for the FBI nationwide from 1965 to 1976, said when he began he was the only agent in the United States assigned to probe incidents of stolen art. Eventually he assembled a squad of five agents to probe art thefts, but the FBI has since disbanded the group. ``They said they wanted to concentrate on other things, like white-collar and organized crime,'' Mason said. ``But a lot of art investigations involve both of those.'' Some improvements may be on the way. Keller, chairman of the American Society of Industrial Security, said the security professionals' association has spent the past two years drawing up more than 100 guidelines on how to tighten museum security. The guidelines include such measures as tighter screening of potential guards and making alarm systems immune to power failures, Keller said. Compliance will not be mandatory, but pressure from insurance companies will force most major museums to adopt the measures, Keller predicted. Consultants agreed, however, that prevention of art theft will probably continue to get a low priority. ``There's a perception that people who have art stolen can afford it,'' Spiel said. ``But I think the public is the loser.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Search World For Uninsured, Priceless Artworks
With PM-Museum Security, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 12 works taken from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in one of the biggest thefts in history were not insured, and authorities were not optimistic the stolen masterpieces would be recovered. ``The sad part is this may wind up in a vault somewhere. Unfortunately, on valuable art objects, the track record (on recovery) isn't really good,'' said FBI agent Dennis O'Callaghan. The FBI searched the world Monday for the ancient Chinese vase and 11 paintings and drawings by artists such as Rembrandt, Degas and Vermeer taken early Sunday from the museum. Police put the value of the missing paintings at a minimum of $100 million. The museum said they were worth hundreds of millions of dollars, and most art experts agreed. No exact value can be put on the paintings because they have not been on the market for nearly 100 years. Mrs. Gardner's collection of paintings, books, religious artifacts, sculptures and rare books were only insured for restoration and conservation, museum officials said. There was no insurance for theft. ``The costs of such insurance would be prohibitive,'' said museum spokesman Barry Wanger.``It would be more than the operating budget of $2.8 million a year.'' Futhermore, Mrs. Gardner's will bars the museum curators from buying and installing replacements, he said. ``So if we lose a painting by theft or another way, we can't buy another one.'' The two thieves, dressed as policeman, talked their way into the museum by telling the two security guards on duty there was a disturbance in the area, police said. They bound the guards with tape, and spent the next two hours removing the works. The crime was discovered when the morning cleaning crew arrived. The pilfered works included two paintings and an etching by Rembrandt, three paintings and two charcoals by Edgar Degas; one painting each by Edouard Manet, Jan Vermeer and Govaert Flinck, and a bronze beaker dating from the Chinese Shang Dynasty, 1,200-1,100 B.C. O'Callaghan said no ransom demands had been received. He said he couldn't discuss any leads the FBI might have uncovered. ``There are sources around the world we would reach out for'' in the effort to recover the works, the agent said. The Gardner theft was exceeded only by the looting of Germany's national bank at the end of World War II. The Guinness Book of World Records lists the looting of Germany's national bank, the Reichsbank, in the spring of 1945 as the most lucrative robbery in modern history, worth $3 billion in contemporary dollars. Guinness also notes that the Philippines government has accused former President Ferdinand Marcos and his wife, Imelda, of pilfering $5 billion to $10 billion while in power. Probably the most celebrated art heist of all time was the 1911 theft of the Mona Lisa from the Louvre in Paris. It was recovered in Italy in 1913. Because no price has ever been established for the painting, the value of the theft has never been determined. In addition to a bid for ransom, speculation about the motive for the crime includes a collector paying the thieves to steal what the collector couldn't buy. The works are so famous they are worthless on the open market. But authorities said it was urgent that the works be found quickly. ``The first 48 hours are very crucial, and the next two weeks,'' said Robert Volpe, a former New York City detective who is a private consultant specializing in the recovery of art works. ``If nothing happens, then we have a very different situation going down.'' Volpe was confident the works could be recovered, however, because of what was taken and how. ``It's not a smart theft,'' Volpe said. ``The pieces are too well documented. They're too well known. ``The fact that they came in and used violence, this is a little out of the realm of the normal art thief,'' he said. ``Most art thieves fashion themselves that they know how to steal.''

DOC.HEAD: Retired Officers Join in Calling for Women-in-Combat Trial
DOC.TEXT: A retired Army brigadier general and a former Air Force colonel have enlisted in the fight for passage of legislation to open Army combat jobs to women for a four-year trial. ``If we do have a test within the Army, I think finally there will be documentation to prove that women can perform as competently as men in the infantry and other combat areas,'' retired Brig. Gen. Evelyn Foote said Monday at a news conference sponsored by the National Organization for Women. The Combat Exclusion Act, approved by Congress in 1948, bars women in the Air Force, the Marines Corps and the Navy from serving in combat positions. The Army has regulations similar to the law. Women comprise about 11 percent of the total armed forces of 2.1 million. The call for re-examination of the policy has grown louder since Army Capt. Linda Bray led troops fighting Panamanian forces during the U.S. invasion last December. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., and a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, proposed legislation in January that directs the Army to conduct a test study allowing women assignment to combat positions. Although the legislation faces an uphill fight in Congress, officials of NOW, Foote and retired Col. Diane Ordes called for a change in policy starting with passage of Schroeder's bill.
DOC.HEAD: Report Says Bailout Bill Lacks Sufficient Funds
DOC.TEXT: The savings and loan bailout enacted last year will fall at least $30 billion and possibly as much as $162 billion short of the amount needed to clean up the industry, says a congressional report. The bill passed last August provided $50 billion to close or sell failed thrift associations through 1992. However, $48 billion of that will be needed to cover losses at the 383 institutions seized by the government through March 5, concluded a report submitted by Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn. Vento is chairman of an 18-member House Banking Committee task force tracking the performance of the new bailout agency, the Resolution Trust Corp. Regulators expect the failure of an additional 225 to 295 S&Ls with losses of at least $32 billion to $40 billion, according to the report. In addition, 295 to 325 S&Ls are weak and may not recover on their own, it said. Depending on the severity of the losses, the shortfall could rise as high as $162 billion, Vento said. Bailout officials, however, say there is enough money to last into next year. If there's a shortfall after that, money intended to cover S&L losses after 1992 could be reallocated to cover earlier failures, they say.
DOC.HEAD: AT&T Unveils Plan to Cut Charges to Selected Area Code
DOC.TEXT: Customers will be able to save money on calls to their favorite out-of-state area code under a new long-distance plan by AT&T. The company said Monday that customers will pay $1.90 a month plus discounted per-minute prices on all direct-dialed calls to whatever area code they choose under the SelectSaver plan. There is no sign-up fee under a special introductory offer. Prices on most SelectSaver calls will be 12 cents a minute during evening, night and weekend calling periods. AT&T said the rate is 23 percent less than usual evening prices. Daytime calls, between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m., will cost 20 cents a minute, or 13 percent less than usual. SelectSaver customers also will receive a 5 percent discount on all other direct-dialed, out-of-state calls, the company said. The new service is scheduled to start May 3.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Gives Town $1 Million, But Offers Challenge
DOC.TEXT: A longtime resident left an estimated $1 million to this northwest Kansas town to build a municipal auditorium and city hall. But there's a catch. The town has to raise an equal amount of money within two years of Madonna Mae Morgan's March 4 death in order to receive the bequest. If Oberlin cannot come up with the money, the 88-year-old woman's gift goes to the Shriners' burn-treatment center for children in Houston. Mrs. Morgan died at a nursing home in Hoxie, about 30 miles to the south, where she moved about two years ago. She had lived in Oberlin since 1962. Her late husband, Robert, was a retired mail carrier who invested wisely in farmland, and Mrs. Morgan also inherited some land, said her attorney, Kenneth Clark. About 1,700 acres of farmland will have to be auctioned before the city knows for sure how much money it has to raise.

DOC.HEAD: On The Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A supermarket deli clerk who didn't want to miss work was busy taking orders when she got a surprise delivery: a 6-pound, 15-ounce girl. Lillie Mae Guillory, 30, went into labor with her third child and gave birth Sunday in a tiny room behind the supermarket's video rental counter. ``I'm an idiot,'' she said with a laugh later from a hospital bed. ``I knew I was close, but I didn't want to miss a day of work.'' Mother and daughter were doing fine Monday, said assistant store director Bobby Jackson. ``I said, `Lillie, you are not having that kid on my shift,''' Jackson recalled. He told her to go home, but it was too late. Jackson ran next door, and summoned paramedics. Meanwhile, assistant manager Judy Foronda and cashier Diane Williams helped with the delivery. ``I ran to the bakery to get some towels, and by the time I got back the baby's head'' was just becoming visible, Foronda said. ``Diane held the baby, and I held Lillie's hand, and it just popped out.'' Williams also works as a medical assistant for a Tampa doctor, and helped with a delivery years ago. Guillory was fine, ``a little scared,'' Williams said. ``She was more concerned about people walking in on us than anything else.'' When paramedics arrived they cut the baby's umbilical cord and took mother and daughter to the hospital. ``My legs have finally stopped shaking,'' Foronda said Monday. ``We're like a family in this store, but this is going too far.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Acquitted on 1 Count; Mistrial on 7 Others
DOC.TEXT: U.S. District Judge Robert Aguilar, the first federal judge charged with racketeering, was acquitted of one obstruction-of-justice charge. But a jury deadlocked on seven other felony charges after seven days of deliberations. Justice Department prosecutor William Keefer said Aguilar would be retried on the seven charges. One juror, Joan McErlean of San Francisco, said after Monday's verdict that ``the majority felt that the prosecution did not prove its case.'' ``There was no motive. They could not prove there was a meeting of the minds between the judge and anybody else.'' Aguilar was acquitted of a charge that he improperly approached another federal judge, Samuel Conti, to seek favorable treatment for a friend and creditor, Ronald Cloud, in a pending bank fraud trial. The jury reported it could not reach a verdict on the other charges. U.S. District Judge Louis Bechtle declared a mistrial and scheduled proceedings on a possible retrial for June 4. Aguilar did not change expression when the jury's verdict was read, but puffed his cheeks as if to release tension. He declined to comment afterward. Defense lawyer Patrick Hallinan said he was pleased that ``the jury did not buy the government's allegations of racketeering and corruption in our courts.'' But Hallinan said he was disappointed Aguilar was not completely vindicated. Ms. McErlean said the vote was 9-3 to acquit Aguilar of the charge that he used his office as a ``racketeering enterprise'' to obstruct justice. It was the first such charge against a federal judge. However, she said nine of the jurors felt Aguilar had committed one of the illegal acts that was a part of the alleged pattern of racketeering: helping Vera Hoff, his friend and former legal secretary, remain a fugitive in Mexico, where she fled in 1979 after being sentenced to two years in prison for tax evasion. The Hoff allegation was not charged as a separate count of obstruction of justice because the five-year legal deadline for filing the charge had expired when Mrs. Hoff was arrested in Mexico last year. But it was included in the racketeering charge, which required proof that Aguilar had misused his office to commit two specified criminal acts within 10 years. Aguilar remains free without bail pending a retrial. The 58-year-old judge from San Jose, who was appointed to the federal bench in 1980 by President Carter, can be removed from office only by Congress. Aguilar's lawyers have accused the Justice Department of targeting him as a liberal who had ruled against the government in important cases. The department denied any political motivation. Aguilar has issued rulings restricting factory sweeps by immigration agents, limiting aerial raids on suspected marijuana fields, and stopping the government from excluding people from the country because of homosexuality. The counts on which the jury deadlocked included two against Aguilar's fellow defendants, former Teamster leader Rudy Tham and Abe Chapman, an 83-year-old ex-convict who was formerly related to Aguilar by marriage. They and Aguilar were charged with plotting to use the judge's influence to seek a new trial for Tham on a 1980 embezzlement conviction by having Aguilar speak to U.S. District Judge Stanley Weigel, who was hearing Tham's case. Aguilar said he only asked Weigel about the status of the case, testimony that Weigel largely confirmed. Aguilar also said he was only bragging, without foundation, when he told a friend in a secretly taped conversation that Weigel was indebted to him and would never reveal their contacts. Aguilar also denied trying to influence Conti in Cloud's case, the charge on which he was acquitted.

DOC.HEAD: Meg Ryan, Billy Crystal and Julie Kavner Win Top Comedy Awards
DOC.TEXT: The movie ``When Harry Met Sally ...'' and actress Julie Kavner took top honors at this year's American Comedy Awards, and veteran troupers Betty White and Art Carney received lifetime achievement trophies. Kavner was a double winner in female supporting roles, getting awards for her role in the film ``New York Stories'' and the television series ``The Tracey Ullman Show.'' Meg Ryan and Billy Crystal each received a trophy for their starring roles in ``When Harry Met Sally ...,'' the story of the relationship between a man and a woman over the years. The award for funniest male in a series went to John Goodman, who plays Roseanne Barr's husband on the ABC show ``Roseanne.'' Ullman won for funniest female lead in a series. More than 800 people attended the March 10 awards ceremony at the Shrine Auditorium which telecast on ABC on Monday night. White, star of television's ``The Golden Girls,'' and Carney, who starred with the late Jackie Gleason in the ``Golden Age'' television show ``The Honeymooners,'' were lifetime achievement honorees. Veteran comedy writer Garry Marshall, who created the TV series ``Happy Days'' and directed the Disney feature ``Pretty Woman,'' was given the creative lifetime achievement award. A 15-minute tribute to Marshall included pre-taped comments by sister Penny Marshall, as well as comedian Robin Williams and ``Happy Days'' star Ron Howard. Carol Burnett won funniest female performer in a television special for ``Julie & Carol: Together Again'' and Williams won the male equivalent for ``Comic Relief III.'' Rick Moranis won for his supporting role in the movie, ``Parenthood,'' and Dana Carvey was honored for supporting male in a series for the medley of characters he plays on ``Saturday Night Live,'' including the puritanical church lady. Rita Rudner and Jeff Foxworthy were honored as the funniest stand-up comedians.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl a `Winner' in East German Elections, But at What Price?
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl guided his allies to victory in East German balloting he hopes the momentum will seal his re-election in West Germany's vote in December. But it could be a struggle. Kohl must balance the fervent hopes of East Germans eager for prosperity with the worries of West Germans, who fear they'll have to pay for reunification. The new leadership chosen by East German voters Sunday supports Kohl's plans for swift unification with West Germany, and its election handed Kohl a victory of his own. Kohl helped create the three-party Alliance for Germany that won in East Germany. He advised them in their campaign and barnstormed across East Germany, promising unification would bring East Germans Western affluence. Newspapers in both German states recognized Kohl's coup. ``The real winner is to be found there (in Bonn),'' said East Germany's Communist-run newspaper, the Berliner Zeitung. ``The electorate here is trusting promises made by Kohl and his friends from the big Bonn sister party.'' Kohl's political opponents in Bonn made the same observation. ``The decisive thought for East Germans may have been, `If we vote for Kohl, the money will flow,''' said Social Democrat Oskar Lafontaine, announcing that he'll challenge Kohl in West Germany's elections Dec. 2. Kohl hopes the momentum will last through the West German election. The chancellor said Monday he sees ``outstanding chances'' for his party when elections for a united Germany finally come. He indicated that would probably be sometime next year. The latest polls give Kohl's coalition government a lead of about 6 percentage points over the Social Democrats. But the polls indicate a close race if Kohl loses the support of Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher's Free Democrats, the coalition's junior partner. Political experts say that although Kohl won an important political victory by helping the East German conservative alliance get elected, there's a chance it could backfire. ``After all the happiness and dancing over the results of this election, we might also be seeing the opening of a Pandora's Box of complications,'' said Heinrich Vogel, head of the Federal Institute for Eastern and International Studies in Cologne. ``The real work starts right now. This is ground zero,'' Vogel said in an interview. He said the costs of unification could tarnish the West German voters' views of Kohl. Financial and political experts say the process of German unification will be complicated and expensive, with West Germans paying most of the bill. In addition, higher unemployment and rising prices for East Germans are seen as nearly inevitable as the country undergoes economic metamorphosis. Kohl has told East Germans his government will protect them from economic shock. Vogel has said this will be difficult. The Handelsblatt, West Germany's most respected financial newspaper, said the East German election has ``set the course for an investment boom and an economic upswing, but this upswing must be painstakingly acquired.'' East German expectations have put Kohl's government under great pressure, the newspaper said. ``A belief in miracles would be of little help.'' Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of West Germany's Social Democrats, said it is too early to count his party out for either the December elections or as possible leaders of a united Germany. ``Kohl had set a very high horizon of expectations,'' he said, by convincing East Germans that reunification can be fast, and by telling West Germans it is possible without burdens. ``But I think the sobering-up will come very quickly,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lung Cancer Surgery Looms for 22-Year-Old Trapeze Star
DOC.TEXT: Tight-wire acrobat Angel Wallenda takes the scariest walk of her life today when she steps into an examination room to await word on an operation that may leave her tied to an oxygen tank for the rest of her life. Surgeons at the City of Hope National Medical Center were scheduled to decide today when to start removing the tumorous sections of her lungs. It could be the next day. ``They're kind of worried because if I wait any longer they won't be able to do it at all,'' said Angel, who turns 22 today. ``If they take out too much I won't have any left to breathe.'' She was diagnosed with bone cancer in 1987. Soon after, doctors amputated her right leg below the knee. They cut away diseased parts of both lungs in 1988, leaving her with about half the normal capacity. Back then, though, she was able to carry on with an artificial lower leg. Soon, she was back on the wire with her husband, Steven, part of the clan that has performed since the 1600s. The most famous of all The Flying Wallendas, ``Karl the Great,'' died after a 1978 fall during a performance in Puerto Rico. Carrying on the tradition is their 3-year-old son, Steven Wallenda II, who first performed publicly on the trapeze at 11 months. The family spent Monday in a motel room near the hospital in Duarte, a largely residential suburb in the San Gabriel Valley east of Los Angeles. ``She turns 22 tomorrow,'' her 34-year-old husband said. ``We sure didn't plan it that way. It just happened.'' Angel and Steven met in New York almost five years ago. She was working in an ice cream shop at a Westchester County mall where he was performing, although she didn't learn about his career immediately as they chatted. Later, she was in the audience as he performed. ``He was asking for a volunteer out of the audience,'' she said. ``I volunteered.'' Their working relationship blossomed first, their romance later. ``I was more fascinated with the wire,'' Angel said. ``He asked me if I'd like to learn. But before I could, he went to Jamaica. ``When he left I didn't know if I'd ever hear from him again.'' He called, of course, and the years since have been a storm of practices and performances, marriage, the birth of their son, her illness, and now the latest trip to California for lung cancer surgery. What was billed as her final performance took place early this month at Mansfield University, near the family's home in Tioga, Pa. Angel said her mind was on screw-ups in the lighting that made it hard to perform, not on her problems. ``The rehearsal went perfect, and then everything went wrong,'' she said. ``It was like I'm sitting there saying, `Turn up the lights, guys _ come on!' ``But in the end it was funny. We improvised and it made it more homey. They thought it was part of the act.'' The family said at the time that the latest surgery would end her career as an aerialist, although her husband and son would continue the performing tradition. The best Angel can hope for now, she's told, is a life tied to an oxygen tank. On Monday, she wasn't so sure. So what if she has to breathe oxygen. She already performs with a prosthetic leg. ``Who says I can't do it?'' Angel Wallenda said.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Stock Average Down Sharply; Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell sharply to close below the 31,000-point mark Tuesday while the dollar inched up against the Japanese yen despite a raise in the Bank of Japan's official discount rate. The dollar closed at 153.65 yen, up 0.10 yen from Monday's close. It opened lower at 152.70 yen and ranged between 152.45-153.75 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 456.05 points, or 1.48 percent, ending the day at 30,807.19, its lowest level since Jan. 9, 1989. The index had regained some of its early-morning plunge by the end of the morning session, but it fell back in the afternoon as markets were discouraged by the yen's meager recovery following the Bank of Japan's discount rate hike, dealers said. Japan's central bank announced it raised its official discount rate by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent, effective immediately. On Monday, in its third-largest single-day crash of 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, the index ended at 31,263.24, its lowest since Jan. 20, 1989. Dealers attributed the plunge to a stronger dollar and the looming discount rate hike. The official discount rate, or the interest rate the central bank charges on loans to commercial banks and which has a strong impact on other interest rates, had been 4.25 percent. In currency dealings, the market was little affected by the discount rate hike as it had been already factored into the market, traders said.

DOC.HEAD: Back to School for West Virginia Teachers
DOC.TEXT: Schools throughout West Virginia reopened after a nearly two-week teacher strike. Some held counseling sessions to ease tensions between teachers who walked out and those who crossed picket lines. ``I suspect there's a degree of animosity and maybe even bitterness for those who walked across the picket line,'' Bob Brown, executive director of the West Virginia Federation of Teachers, said as teachers returned Monday. ``If they can live with themselves, we can live with them.'' The 3,000-member federation and the 16,000-member West Virginia Education Association began the state's first teacher strike on March 7. Another 3,000 teachers in the state are not represented by unions. The key issue in the strike was wages. The average teacher salary of $21,900 is higher than only South Dakota and Arkansas, the National Education Association says. Teachers voted overwhelmingly Sunday to return to work _ without settling the wage issue _ after legislative leaders promised to ask Gov. Gaston Caperton to call a special legislative session to consider a long-term plan for West Virginia's education system. The strike had spread to 47 of the state's 55 counties and affected more than 150,000 pupils. In some counties, all the teachers stayed off the job, but in others, some teachers crossed the picket lines. In Raleigh County in southern West Virginia, for example, about 30 percent of 900 teachers crossed picket lines, said Dwight Dials, the county school superintendent. State and union officials would not estimate how many teachers crossed picket lines. On Monday, in Berkeley County in the easternmost part of the state, the county Ministerial Association sent counselors to the schools to help teachers work out any feelings of animosity toward each other, said county school spokeswoman Susan Loveland. Most schools delayed classes for a few hours Monday so teachers could prepare for their students. No major problems were reported. ``It's over, but it's not over,'' said Lewis County school Superintendent Joe Mace. ``We'll do the best we can for the kids for the rest of this school year. You try to mend some fences and put back the pieces.'' Some of the biggest headaches were from teachers trying to reschedule student trips that were canceled and determining what time would have to be made up, school officials said. The June 8 end of the school year will be extended two days to make up last Thursday and Friday, when state School Superintendent Hank Marockie canceled all classes in the state for a cooling-off period. The average striking teacher will lose an estimated $660 in pay and the 6 percent of their pay that normally would be paid into the financially troubled Teachers Retirement System, Marockie said. The finance chairmen of the state Senate and House of Delegates said Monday there is no more money available for teacher pay raises. Delegate George Farley, D-Wood, said the special session ``is going to raise a lot of expectations.'' Teachers received a 5 percent raise in February and a two-day special legislative session last week found $27 million for an additional 4 percent raise. The teachers union said the latest legislative package was not enough. ``We skimped and scraped to put together a $27 million package that made nobody happy, and if we did that again it would not make them happy,'' Farley said. A statewide poll released Monday, meanwhile, showed the teachers enjoyed broad public support. The poll of 405 state residents taken during the strike showed nearly two-thirds opposed threats by state officials to fire striking teachers who did not return to work by Monday. The margin of error was 4.9 percentage points. ``I think (Caperton) sees how serious we can be and I don't think teachers will be hesitant to walk again,'' said middle school teacher Karen Ash in Bunker Hill, Berkeley County.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed As Bomb Goes Off In Punjab Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to CORRECT death toll, ADD details. Picks up 9th pvs, `United News ...' ^By HARBAKSH S. NANDA
DOC.TEXT: A powerful bomb carried by two suspected Sikh extremists exploded at a busy intersection today, blowing them apart and killing four bystanders, police said. At least 17 people were injured. There was no immediate indication what the bomb's intended target might have been. But Home Minister Mufti Mohammad Sayeed was due later in the day for a tour of Punjab, the rich farming state where Sikh militants are waging a violent secessionist campaign. The blast damaged vehicles and shattered windows of houses 300 feet away, police spokesman Ashok Kapur said. The dead included two schoolchildren and three of the injured were in critical condition, he said. The explosion occurred in the most densely populated residential neighborhood of this joint capital of Punjab and Haryana, northern states that abut each other. Most of the city's 500,000 residents are government workers. Kapur said the two Sikhs who were carrying the bomb on a motor scooter were believed to be ``hardcore terrorists.'' He said identification was difficult because the bodies were blown to pieces. Their motor scooter was destroyed and parts of their bodies were flung 90 feet away, he said. Press Trust of India said 15 vehicles were damaged. The last extremist attack in Chandigarh occurred in October 1988, when a senior government official was assassinated. United News of India said Sikh extremists had killed two people elsewhere in the state since Monday night. The killings came after a sharp rise in extremist-linked violence, with police blaming militants for the killings of 26 people across Punjab during a 24-hour period ending Monday night. The extremists, in their eight-year-old secessionist campaign, have usually targeted residents in remote villages and travelers on deserted country roads. Sikh militants have killed more than 400 people _ mostly Hindus and moderate Sikhs _ since January to dramatize their demand for a separate state they want to carve out of Punjab. The separatists claim the Sikh community is culturally and politically discriminated by the Hindu-dominated government. Sikhs are in a slight majority in Punjab, but nationwide they comprise just 2 percent of India's 880 million population. Hindus account for 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Twentieth Century Fox: No More Previews for Siskel & Ebert
DOC.TEXT: Twentieth Century Fox is banning film critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert from advance screenings of its movies over remarks they made during a TV interview about the company's flick, ``Nuns on the Run.'' ``From now on, they can catch up with our films in the theater,'' Bob Harper, the film studio's director of marketing, said in an interview published Monday in the Hollywood Reporter. Ebert, a Pulitzer Prize-winning critic for the Chicago Sun-Times, responded, ``I guess you could call it thumbs on the run.'' The move marks the first time that Ebert and Siskel, a Chicago Tribune film critic, have been barred from special screenings of movies released by major studios, said Andi Sporkin, spokeswoman for Buena Vista Television, which produces ``Siskel & Ebert.'' Buena Vista is a subsidiary of the Los Angeles-based Walt Disney Co. Ms. Sporkin said ``things got blown out of proportion'' after the duo light-heartedly said they didn't like ``Nuns on the Run'' during an appearance Friday on ``Live With Regis and Kathie Lee'' in New York to tout their upcoming pre-Academy Awards show.
