Siskel and Ebert both gave the film a ``thumbs down'' last week on their television show, and also panned the movie in syndicated columns, Ms. Sporkin said. ``Nuns on the Run'' is a film about two gangsters who come into possession of a large sum of money which various bad guys want. They dodge into a convent, slip into nun's clothing and try to pass themselves off as sisters. Fox contends Siskel and Ebert overstepped their bounds on Friday because they attacked not only the film but also the marketing campaign and reviewers who liked it. During the broadcast, Ebert held up a newspaper ad for ``Nuns on the Run'' with a prominent quote from the Village Voice calling it ``the funniest anti-clerical transvestite movie of the decade.'' He then bantered with Siskel about the fallacy in the ad. ``Yeah, this is 1990,'' Ebert said. ``How many other transvestite, anti-clerical comedies have there been so far in this decade?'' But Fox officials were not amused. ``We have no problem with them not liking the movie,'' Harper said. ``But they were on the show promoting their pre-Academy Awards show and, to our thinking, were acting in the capacity of entertainers _ not critics.'' Ebert said he isn't sure ``just what Fox meant by that.'' ``You might also wonder if this isn't a good way to get some extra publicity for the movie,'' he said in today's editions of the Sun-Times. ``Other than that, I have to ask: Where's their sense of humor?'' Both critics predicted the ban wouldn't really affect them and would eventually be rescinded. ``We'll just buy tickets and go to the movies for our newspaper reviews,'' Ebert said. ``The only difference will be on our TV show. We'll still review the Fox movies, but people won't be able to see any clips. That's not very smart for Fox, so I wouldn't expect the ban to last too long.'' ``Invariably, they are rescinded and no one learns anything.'' About eight million people watch the ``Siskel & Ebert'' program weekly, Ms. Sporkin said.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Stock Exchange Dives; Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index dived sharply again today as neither currency market intervention nor a interest rate boost by the central bank stopped the weakening of the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which plunged 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, on Monday in its third-largest single-day fall, tumbled another 456.05 points, or 1.48 percent, today. Its closing of 30,807.19 was the lowest since 30,678.39 on Jan. 9, 1989. So far this year, the index has dived more than 8,100 points, or almost 21 percent. Meanwhile, the dollar closed at 153.65 yen, up 0.10 yen from Monday's close of 153.55 yen. It opened at 152.70 yen and ranged between 152.45 yen and 153.75 yen. Its closing was the highest since 153.69 yen on March 12, 1987. Stock market investors were discouraged by the yen's failure to recover after the Bank of Japan announced a 1 percentage point increase in its discount rate, its charge for loans to commercial banks, said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. Generally, higher interest rates make a country's currency more attractive to investors. The stock index fell in the morning, regained some ground on word of the impending rate increase, then fell again in the afternoon, after the increase to 5.25 percent was announced. ``The index fell back again as the discount rate hike failed to boost yen buying,'' Inoue said. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno said today the Central Bank's ``pre-emptive'' discount rate increase would control latent inflationary pressures without appreciably slowing Japan's economic expansion. He said, however, the raise would not provide a quick fix for recent instability in the foreign exchange and stock markets, although he indicated the rate hike would help both in the long run. Inoue said the size of the raise was appropriate, and the end of the long wait for the action meant elimination of one factor for instability. ``But the stock market's stability is totally subject to currency movements from now on,'' Inoue said. The rate increase had been expected since after national elections on Feb. 18. The discount rate, which has a strong impact on other interest rates, had been at a historic low of 2.5 percent for nearly nine years, until May 1989, when the central bank made the first of three increases that brought it to 4.25 percent by last December. Traders said that surprisingly, market players bought the dollar even afdter the discount rate increase. ``The market reaction to the discount rate hike was minimal because the rate increase already had been factored into the market for such a long time,'' said Mitsui Bank trader Shinichi Kato. He said many market players who anticipated the raise by keeping short, or oversold, dollar positions bought back dollars as soon as the rate actually was raised. Traders estimated that the Bank of Japan sold some $200 million today in efforts to prop up the yen. The bank does not comment on its exchange market activity. ``Since many market players saw Japan's interest rate as having climbed as high as it could, it (discount rate increase) will help the yen and the stock market recover in the long run,'' Kato said. ``But there is nothing in the current economy to reverse the dollar-buying trend and prompt yen-buying.'' The price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond ended trading at 86.27 points, down from Monday's close of 86.50. Its yield was 7.29 percent, up from 7.24 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Said to be Preparing Drastic Economic Plan
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will implement a drastic economic reforms in July that include selling state-owned enterprises and overhauling government-set prices to reflect market forces, media reports said. The package of 17 measures, aimed at ending a dire economic crisis, is expected to be painful and unpopular, the Interfax news agency said. The agency also quoted a close aide to Gorbachev as saying the crisis is so prfound that the Soviet Union might no longer object to massive foreign aid. Soviet officials previously have appeared offended when Western officials raised the possibility of aid. ``I would like to underline that such aid would be in the interests of not only the Soviet Union, but of the entire world community, Western countries included. But they do not seem to be fully aware of that,'' said the aide, economist Nikolai Petrakov. Last month, Petrakov revealed that the Soviet leadership had dropped its long opposition to private ownership of factories. After his inauguration to the powerful new presidency on Thursday, Gorbachev said he was planning harsh economic reforms that would require great sacrifices. Western analysts speculated that Gorbachev felt he needed the enhanced power of the new post before going got ahead with a program that could provoke serious unrest. Economists say the Soviet economy suffers from too much money in the hands of the people, who have nothing spend it on. Central economic planning has proved a failure, and the people want for food and consumer goods of decent quality. Prices are set by central planners and many are unrealistically low, with state subsidies for housing, transport and essential consumer items. Interfax said in its report Monday that the reform package would take effect July 1 and provide for the selling off of many government-owned factories. It said another aspect was a plan for making the ruble convertible. Economists say real pricing and a move toward a ruble whose value is determined by world market forces would bring about immediate inflation, accompanied by high unemployment. But doing nothing could be more dangerous. Coal miners unhappy with the lack of improvement since their paralyzing strike last summer have threatened renew walkouts. Interfax said the plan was drafted by 60 Soviet economists and modeled on the one that took effect Jan. 1 in Poland, which decided to leap directly into a market system in hopes of shortening the painful period of transition after decades of Communist rule. Empty stores have been stocked, and Poles no longer have to stand in long lines to buy what they need. The zloty has become partially convertible thanks to a massive Western aid program, which probably is impossible to duplicate for an economy the size of the Soviet Union's. But unemployment is on the rise in Poland and experts say it reach 1 million or more as inefficient enterprises are closed. Petrakov said the Soviets hope to eliminate excess rubles by giving consumers the opportunity to buy goods that have been illegal or impossible, including shares of stock, houses, apartments and garden plots. Western sources say that in recent weeks Soviet trade organizations have not paid their bills, giving the impression that the country is running out of hard, Western currency. Petrakov also hinted there might be a shakeup in key economic ministries now that Gorbachev has become official leader of the government instead of Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. Petrakov did not say whether Ryzhkov's job was in danger, but the prime minister is responsible for the economy. ``Heads of ministries and departments are displaying sheer irresponsibility in all questions,'' Petrakov said. Gorbachev's economic plan will include decisive measures, deadlines and the names of the people in charge, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Keeps To The Hard-Line Socialist Line
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng opened China's annual legislative session today by proclaiming that China will never yield to attempts to undermine its socialist system and Communist rule. In a speech of more than two hours to the nearly 3,000 deputies of the National People's Congress, Li also said the state would exert more control over the economy but ease austerity measures that have stalled economic growth. Li's state of the nation address sets the tone of the 15-day meeting, which is expected to show unwavering support for the party's hard-line political and economic policies. Li began by noting the ``soul-stirring struggles'' of 1989, including the victory over the ``counter-revolutionary rebellion'' _ the government's term for the student-led pro-democracy movement crushed by military force in June. He said the pro-democracy movement was led by hostile forces trying to turn China into a bourgeois republic dependent on capitalist countries. ``Only socialism can save China,'' Li said. If China turns toward capitalism, ``a polarization of classes would inevitably arise, the overwhelming majority of people would sink into poverty and social unrest would prevail for a long time to come. Fraud, degeneration and crime, inherent in a society of exploiting classes, would spread unchecked.'' Li, wearing a Western suit, was only occasionally applauded as he plodded through the speech. Sitting behind him on the podium were about 150 senior officials, including Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin, President Yang Shangkun and members of the party Politburo. For the second straight year senior leader Deng Xiaoping did not appear at the opening session. Also missing was Zhao Ziyang, the former party chief who was purged from all party posts last year after being accused of supporting the pro-democracy movement. Zhao is still a deputy from Sichuan province. Li said China had also achieved victories last year in straightening out the economy and improving the ideological orientation of its citizens. He said austerity measures instituted in late 1988 had succeeded in halving inflation while bringing economic growth down to a manageable level. But he acknowledged that Chinese industry is beset by rising debt, factory closures and stockpiling of goods, and said steps will be taken to ``ameliorate the present contradictions.'' The steps include relaxing curbs on the money supply, increasing loans to enterprises, adjusting interest rates for loans and savings deposits, increasing investment in key industries and housing and engaging in water conservation and other public works projects. Gross national product should rise by 5 percent in 1990, up from 3.8 percent last year, he said. On the ideological front, he said ``the influence of bourgeois liberalization thinking and repulsive social phenomena still need to be done away with.'' Universities and colleges must stress education in Marxism-Leninism and Maoist thought, he said, adding that intellectuals should ``become one with workers and peasants'' and the arts and television ``must be oriented towards serving socialism and the people.'' He urged the government to boost agricultural production this year and to revive the stagnant economy. But there was little hint of the market-oriented reforms initiated by Deng in 1979 and responsible for China's rapid economic growth through the 1980s. China's open door policy will continue, Li said, but cautioned that China must ``maintain sharp vigilance and resolutely combat'' the trend of Western-style democracy with a multiparty system. On foreign affairs, Li said China is ``naturally concerned about the drastic political changes that have taken place in Eastern Europe'' but hopes to maintain normal, friendly relations with those countries where Communist rulers have been ousted in the past year.t He said China hopes for improved relations with the United States and the West. He criticized Western sanctions imposed after the Chinese troops killed hundreds of civilians last June in breaking up pro-democracy protests. China ``never yields to external pressure and ... No one can succeed in isolating China,'' siad Li. He warned that China ``will not ignore'' the pro-independence movement on Taiwan and said China is on guard against those trying to make Hong Kong a base for overthrowing China's socialist system. During the 15-day session, the congress will approve a basic law that Hong Kong would observe after it reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. It will also pass an amendment to a law guaranteeing that foreign enterprises in China will not be nationalized.

DOC.HEAD: Fans Rejoice With Return of Baseball
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `In that ...' to CORRECT that Mark Bailey's farm club affiliated with New York Mets, sted Giants. Picks up 7th graf, `And starting ...' Version also moved on sports wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PN1,XPSL1
DOC.TEXT: Morris Bailey leaned forward from his lawn chair to his walker, from the shade into the sun, so his eyes could take in both diamonds at once. ``Baseball,'' said the 74-year-old Bailey, breaking into a wide grin. ``Real baseball is on the way.'' And so it is. After 32 days, an agreement reached Sunday night ended the lockout that had delayed the start of spring training for major league players. Teams immediately began assembling at their training camps to prepare for the start of the season, which will begin April 9, a week later than scheduled. Exhibition games are scheduled to begin Monday. Many fans who have had to make do with less also made plans to be on hand today when major league training camps open across Arizona and Florida. In that regard, Bailey, 74, was ahead of most. He was assured tickets to the San Francisco Giants' home contests at Scottsdale Stadium because his grandson, catcher Mark Bailey, was invited to training camp after playing with the New York Mets Triple-A Tidewater affiliate last season. ``And starting tomorrow,'' said Morris Bailey, a Springfield, Mo., native who retired from his job as a production supervisor in a factory 15 years ago and took to wintering in Scottsdale some nine years ago, ``Mark will start drawing big-league pay.'' The agreement between major-league players and owners guarantees a minimum major-league salary of $100,000, a figure that only two decades ago was the subject of salary disputes by superstars such as Willie Mays. Another highlight of the pact was the owners' promise of salary arbitration eligibility for 17 percent of the players with between two and three years of service. With the lockout over, few could restrain their joy at the prospect of again hearing the crack of the bat or gasping over a shoe-string catch. On the other side from Bailey of those same diamonds at Indian School Park, Giants' manager Roger Craig crossed one lizard-skinned cowboy boot over the other, uncrossed them and cast a more dispassionate eye on the minor league prospects working out on either side of them. But like Bailey, he couldn't wait for the real thing when the major league stars took the field. ``Spring training is something special. You could mark time by it,'' he said, his voice lowering, ``until now. ``You hear the bats popping, the leather popping, you smell the grass. We had that,'' he said, ``but it didn't seem the same.'' Will Hill understood. He showed up at Municipal Stadium in nearby Phoenix with 10-year-old son, Marlos, in tow Monday to pick up tickets. The 42-year-old postal inspector and his son have made Oakland A's contests a rite of spring for the past five years, and discouraged as both were by the lockout, they weren't about to let it go now. ``Little league kept him busy,'' Hill said, ``but as soon as we heard this thing ended, I knew we'd wind up here today.'' About a dozen others dotted the stands for the same reason. And if the sounds of lawn mowers buzzing and sprinklers hissing wasn't quite as reassuring as the thwack of bat, it seemed like the next best thing. ``I'm still so mad I could burst,'' 71-year-old Bernie Bates said, her hand resting on husband Warren's shoulders. ``But we're suckers for baseball. That's why we're here.''

DOC.HEAD: Water Problems Sink Million-Dollar Cave House Retreat
DOC.TEXT: H.L. Peterson paid $2.6 million for a cave he wanted to turn into a lavish vacation retreat for the rich and famous, but a leaky roof has doused his dream. Recent property-tax assessments on Beckham Creek Cave indicate the place is virtually worthless, a state official says. Now Peterson has accused seller John Hay, a Boulder, Colo., businessman, of fraud in a $13.7 million federal lawsuit filed in St. Louis. U.S. District Judge Clyde Cahill is to hear the case on Aug. 27. Peterson bought the cave in the Boston Mountains range of the Ozarks in August 1988. He spent $500,000 renovating it and put on a Halloween party attended by nearly 300 guests that year. But since then, he has abandoned his plan to turn the unusual structure into a luxury hideaway for the elite ``because he doesn't think the leaky cave home would be a suitable hotel,'' Peterson lawyer Charles Medley said. Medley said he had advised Peterson against discussing the case. In June 1989, Hay called Peterson's lawsuit frivolous. He said Peterson had ``fallen out of love'' with the cave and that the suit was a case of ``buyer's remorse.'' More recently, Hay has refused to discuss the lawsuit. During the mid-1980s, Hay converted a series of caverns into the 10,000-square foot, five-bedroom, five-bath bomb shelter, with gold-plated fixtures on bathroom equipment, a kitchen with all the conveniences and other lavish digs. Outside are a man-made pond, a helicopter pad, and an expansive front deck with a Jacuzzi. But entering the cave, visitors are sprinkled by what appears to be raindrops from the overhanging rock eave, an indication of bigger problems inside. In winter, the droplets turn to icicles, caretaker Gerald Causse said. The cave is cold, damp, musty. Causse has set out dozens of plastic buckets and bottles of all sizes to trap the water that pours through the epoxy-lined roof. Huge sheets of plastic are hung to direct the flow and prevent flooding of the two-tier tiled great room during heavy rain. ``When you try to dry this place up it just gets worse,'' he said. ``My biggest headache is kicking buckets, emptying buckets and slipping. Emptying buckets is a daily chore and when its raining you might as well sit up here.'' In summer, the battle is with mildew, Causse said, and every cranny attracts lizards and creepy crawlers. Larry Crane, director of the state Assessment Coordination Division, said the cave house was valued at $1.7 million for tax purposes in 1989. But that the value could drop as low as $150,000 for 1990, Crane said _ and ``the reality is that there are major water problems and that the cave house itself has little value, if any.''

DOC.HEAD: Wintry Weather on First Day of Spring
DOC.TEXT: Snow, rain or plunging temperatures threatened to usher spring in like lion, not like a lamb, in sections of the South, the East and the Midwest today. A winter storm warning was posted today for the Susquehanna Valley and Catskill Mountains of New York state and north-central Pennsylvania. Snow fell early today in Buffalo, N.Y. Winter storm watches were in effect in the upper Susquehanna Valley and the northern Pocono Mountains of Pennsylvania, the Berkshire Mountains of Massachusetts and the northwest hills of Connecticut. Warnings for frost and freezing temperatures were posted in southeast Missouri, southern Illinois, Arkansas, Tennessee, extreme northern Louisiana, Mississippi and northern Georgia. A frost warning was up in central Louisiana, and freezing temperatures were expected across northern Alabama. Snow stretched from western New York state Monday night to western Pennsylvania, the Maryland Panhandle, West Virginia, eastern Ohio, northern Kentucky, northern Indiana, southern Michigan, eastern Upper Michigan and western North Carolina. At least 2 inches of snow fell in Charleston, W.Va., and at least 1 inch in Bradford and Dubois, Pa. Scattered rain fell Monday night in west-central Oregon, much of New York state, eastern Pennsylvania, western Maryland, northeast Virginia and southeast Florida. Spring officially begins at 4:19 p.m. EST today. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in quiet European trading late today morning. Gold prices fell. Traders said the markets were quiet as dealers digested Japan's interest rate increase and waited for the release later in the day of January's U.S. trade figures. Steve Marks, a currency analyst at Hill Samuel Bank Ltd., said the markets were also keeping a close eye on developments in Lithuania. He said any signs of excessive aggression on the part of the Soviet Union would likely to boost support for the dollar. The dollar is generally seen as a safe haven currency during times of international tension or unrest. Others said they expected the dollar to drop after the release of the trade figures. Analysts predict the data will show a widening in the U.S. merchandise trade gap. In London, currency dealers were also waiting to see what Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major would do in his first budget statement to be delivered in Parliament this afternoon. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.10 yen to a closing 153.65 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 153.00 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _1.6835 West German marks, up from 1.6829 _1.5060 Swiss francs, down from 1.5085 _5.6900 French francs, up from 5.6895 _1.8995 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8970 _1,245.50 Italian lire, up from 1,244.25 _1.1795 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1836 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6225, compared with $1.6110 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $401.25 a troy ounce, up from $402.45 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $400.80. In Zurich, the bid price was $401.00, down from $402.50 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.28 to close at a bid $400.76. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.11 dollars a troy ounce, from Monday's $5.13.

DOC.HEAD: Outcome of Presidential Election Certain, But Future Cloudy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with student protest, Lee offering national conference on political change, SUB grafs 3 grafs for grafs 16-19 pvs, `About 3,500 ... their power.' Picks up 20th pvs, `We don't ...' ^By DAN BIERS
DOC.TEXT: Although the outcome of Wednesday's presidential election is a foregone conclusion with the incumbent the only candidate, a strong sense of political uncertainty has gripped Taiwan. President Lee Teng-hui seems certain to win a six-year term from the electoral college, but the election may not end the political crisis that has enveloped Taiwan in recent weeks. Lee, 67, is facing pressure from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and the public to quickly scrap a political system largely dominated by elderly politicians from mainland China and give Taiwanese a greater say in choosing their leaders. Lee also is facing an intense struggle within his ruling Nationalist Party, where his rivals would like to dilute his power by changing from a strong presidency to a Cabinet-led government. He has ``fallen into a den of wolves and is in the wilderness. No wonder he often prays these days, what else can he do?'' the country's most respected political magazine, The Journalist, said in an editorial on the devout Christian president. Indeed, Taiwan has resembled a three-ring political circus in the weeks leading to the electoral college vote. This island of 20 million people witnessed an unprecedented challenge to Lee's candidacy from within his own party. The challenge was triggered by Lee's decision to nominate his personal aide as the party candidate for vice president instead of Chiang Wego, the sole surviving son of the late Nationalist strongman Chiang Kai-shek. Many aging Nationalist politicians who fled to Taiwan with Chiang Kai-shek after losing the civil war to Communist forces in 1949 view his son as the main standard-bearer of their unlikely dream to one day return victoriously to the Chinese mainland. The crisis was diffused only after eight Nationalist elders intervened and convinced the party's Old Guard to drop plans to offer a rival ticket at the electoral college meeting. But dissatisfaction with Lee remains strong within the party and many Nationalist leaders would like to increase the powers of the Cabinet at the expense of the presidency. Lee, a native Taiwanese, had no power base of his own when he was elevated to head of government two years ago after Chiang Ching-kuo, the eldest son of Chiang Kai-shek, died and four decades of family rule ended. Lee has managed to remain at the top largely because of his widespread public support. Meanwhile, the presidential vote has led to intense public opposition to the electoral college, which is dominated by politicians elected on the Chinese mainland in 1947 who have not faced re-election since. The elderly deputies remain in office in support of the claim that the Nationalists are still the legitimate government of all China. A majority of the lawmaking Legislative Yuan also is comprised of aging Nationalists. On Sunday, the main opposition party organized the largest protest in Taiwan since the lifting of 38 years of martial law in 1987. More than 20,000 people protested the continued dominance of the electoral college by the elderly deputies. About 5,000 students staged a rally today at a downtown park for the second straight day to demand the dissolution of the electoral college. Nearly 50 of them were on hunger strike to press the demands, and one was hospitalized with stomach problems. The protest was significant because Taiwan students rarely get involved in politics. Lee today responded to the outcry for democratic change by agreeing to convene an emergency conference of political and other leaders to discuss changing the country's political system. There was no elaboration on what changes he might have in mind and no date was specified. Top opposition officials said the conference would occur in May or June. Political observers said Lee could not act on change until after his confirmation by the electoral college, whose members are wary of any democratic change that would lessen their power. ``We don't know what Lee plans to do. He never speaks out,'' said Chang Chung-tung, professor of history at National Taiwan University. The president ``may not have clear ideas about the future redistribution of power and democratic reforms yet,'' Chang said. ``Even if he does, he cannot speak about it before he consolidates his power.''

DOC.HEAD: Foes, Advocates of Legalized Abortion Square Off in Guam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, ``In my...' to delete redundant first reference to Ada. FIXES category code. Arraignment scheduled for mid-morning EST.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Joseph Ada said a fetus is a human being in signing a bill creating the most restrictive U.S. abortion statute, but abortion rights advocates already are challenging the measure. Janet Benshoof, an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer, immediately violated the law by telling women in a speech where to go to have an abortion, and the territory's attorney general _ who personally opposes the measure _ pressed charges. Territorial Attorney General Elizabeth Barrett-Anderson says prosecuting the case will be ``a heavy burden,'' but a responsibility of her job. Benshoof made a court appearance Tuesday, Guam time, but Superior Court Judge Ramon V. Diaz said he could not hear the case because he did not feel he could render a fair and impartial decision. Benshoof is scheduled to be arraigned today. The law, which passed despite a ruling by Barrett-Anderson that it is unconstitutional, makes it a third-degree felony for a person to perform or help in an abortion. Seeking or having an abortion or soliciting someone to have an abortion are misdemeanors. The law also sets a referendum during the Nov. 6 general election for residents of this Pacific Ocean island about 1,500 miles east of the Philippines to decide whether to keep the law. ``In my heart, I believe that a fetus is a human being,'' Ada, the Republican governor, said in signing the bill, which prohibits abortion except when the mother's health or life are endangered. Benshoof said she immediately violated a provision of the law by advising women in a speech at the Guam Press Club later in the day to go to Hawaii to have legal abortions. ``I was very specific in my breaking of the law,'' Benshoof said. ``The information that I gave, which is now a crime, came from the Honolulu Yellow Pages.'' Barrett-Anderson filed a misdemeanor complaint charging Benshoof with violating the ban on soliciting someone to have an abortion. Benshoof faces up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine if convicted. ``It's a matter of public record that I advised the Guam Legislature ... that in my opinion the bill was unconstitutional by operation of the Supreme Court's decision in Roe v. Wade,'' Barrett-Anderson said later in a statement. ``My advisory role has now shifted to one of enforcement. This is a heavy burden, but ... I will enforce this statute to the extent that the law allows.'' Benshoof, who went to Guam to try to persuade Ada not to sign the bill, was not arrested but appeared in court voluntarily. Guam's 21-member unicameral Legislature unanimously approved the bill March 8 after Archbishop Anthony Apuron threatened in an interview with a television reporter to excommunicate any Roman Catholic senator who voted against it. All but one of the senators is Catholic, as is Ada. However, most of the senators said they were unaware of the threat. Among those hailing the new law was the National Right to Life Committee. ``This is great news,'' group spokeswoman Nancy Myers said in a telephone interview from her Washington office. ``The people of Guam are largely pro-life as reflected by the unanimous vote in the Legislature, and they have made a strong statement.''

DOC.HEAD: Sharansky Criticizes Israel's Censorship Of Soviet Immigration
DOC.TEXT: Human rights advocate Natan Sharansky today criticized Israel's censorship of reports on Soviet immigration, saying it was hurting efforts to settle the new arrivals. Sharansky, a former Soviet refusnik, was joined by an official of a resettlement agency in complaining about excessive censorship. The ban on publication of immigration figures was imposed March 1 amid mounting Arab protests the influx could lead to more Jewish settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, home to 1.7 million Palestinians. Sharansky, who heads the Soviet Jewry Zionist Forum, said today some self-censorship might be needed to ensure the security of the immigrants. But he said, ``We need more support from world Jewry and, to make bureaucrats work more effectively, we need more public pressure. We can't do it under conditions of censorship.'' Sharansky and other Israeli activists have said the Jewish state is not preparing enough housing and jobs for the arriving Soviets. Gad Ben-Ari, spokesman for the Jewish Agency, which shares responsibility with the government for resettling immigrants, said his group appealed to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to have the censorship guidelines limited to two issues _ long-term immigration projections and new transit routes. ``The process of fund-raising, especially in our Operation Exodus campaign for the Soviets, depends a great deal on a constant flow of accurate information about the immigration,'' Ben-Ari said. ``We are already having difficulties,'' Operation Exodus aims to raise $200 million in each of the next three years from Jews in the United States and Europe. In early March, Israel's military censor declared all material on the immigration of Soviet Jews had to be submitted to the censor prior to publication. Yossi Olmert, head of the Government Press Office, said today despite that the broad wording of the censorship rule, it was actually limited to two items, the number of immigrants and routes of getting to Israel. ``American Jewry knows full well we are speaking of a big drama, a big operation,'' Olmert said. ``Whether the number is `x' or `y' isn't necessarily the most important item right now.'' The immigration surge began last year, when 12,000 Soviet Jews came to Israel, spurred by eased exit policies in the Soviet Union and tighter U.S. immigration rules. Israeli leaders have said they expect up to 750,000 Soviet immigrants this decade. Arab groups have protested the influx, and the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine said last week it would target airlines and airports involved in the immigration. On Monday, the 46-member Organization of the Islamic Conference issued a statement in Saudi Arabia calling on Arab states ``to use all possible means and methods'' to prevent Soviet Jews from moving to the occupied territories. The Arab outcry began after Shamir said in mid-January the wave of immigration required ``the Land of Israel, a large and strong Israel.'' Palestinians interpreted the statement as meaning Israel intended to keep the occupied territories, which were captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. Shamir later said the immigrants were not being directed to the territories.

DOC.HEAD: Precedes EAST BERLIN
Official Says West Germany To Cut Benefits and Curb East German Influx
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with official saying some benefits will be ended by July 1, picks up 9th graf, ``A new ZDF, ...'
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Cabinet today agreed to begin scrapping special benefits for East German settlers in an attempt to stop them from flooding into West Germany, a government official said. The decision is aimed at encouraging East Germans to stay home and help rebuild their country and to relieve the burden East German resettlers are putting on West German social services. About 500,000 East Germans have settled in West Germany in the past 14 months and the Kohl government is under increasing political pressure to stem the continuing influx. The Cabinet move came two days after East Germany's first free election in which a conservative alliance allied to Kohl's party won. The winners are still negotiating on forming a coalition East German government that will help set the pace for unifying the two Germanys. The Bonn government official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said that as of July 1, West Germany will no longer have a special program for helping East Germans who move west. It was not immediately clear whether the decision means the settlers will receive absolutely no special benefits, but a closing of dozens of reception centers appeared to be in the offing. The government official said details would be released later in the day. As part of the current program, East Germans register for special benefits such as unemployment, and they also receive help in finding jobs and housing. They also are put up at special reception centers as they look for housing. The exodus has seriously bled East Germany's economy and is straining West Germany's own housing and job markets. In Sunday's elections, East Germans gave 48 percent of the vote to a conservative coalition actively backed by Kohl that promises quick unification. After the victory, Kohl appealed to East Germans to stay home. He repeated the message Monday night on West German television. ``Please stay home,'' the chancellor said in an interview with the ZDF network. ``Unpack your bags. Go back to the factories and offices, and help in building up the country.'' A new ZDF poll released hours after East Germany's election said only 13 percent of West Germans still welcome their compatriots from the East now that they have freely chosen a government. The poll showed 43 percent of West Germans have no understanding for the continued exodus, and more than half want to cut aid to the immigrants. Bremen, one of the 11 West German states, said Monday it would not help East Germans find housing. The local government said its camps for East Germans were overflowing and it would accept only thos who find their own housing. Bremen Mayor Herbert Schmalstieg urged the federal government to close reception centers for the refugees and send back all East Germans who cannot be housed by local communities. Last week, the governors of all 11 West German states asked the federal government to cut benefits to stop the influx. Kohl told ZDF that a monetary union between the two countries would come soon, certainly before the end of the year. He wants West Germany's powerful mark to replace East Germany's weak currency to prop up East Germans' buying power and induce them to stay home. The chancellor said he hoped East Germany's Parliament would vote to merge with West Germany under a provisison provided by West Germany's constitution. ``But I don't think the subject will be on tomorrow,'' Kohl said. The conservatives' victory was seen as a political triumph for Kohl, who campaigned hard on their behalf. The three-party coalition led by East Germany's Christian Democratic Union, a sister party of Kohl's own party of the same name, swept to victory by promising a quick monetary union and rapid unification. But the alliance failed to gain an absolute majority in the new 400-seat Parliament and will need to find a coalition partner to be able to govern. The conservative alliance ended with a total of 193 seats. Lothar de Maiziere, the Christian Democratic Union chief likely to become East Germany's new premier, on Monday offered to form an alliance with the left-leaning Social Democrats, a move backed by Kohl. But the Social Democrats, heavy losers in the election but still the second-strongest party with 87 seats, spurned the offer. A three-party centrist, Liberal alliance supported by West Germany's Free Democrats, the junior coalition partner in Kohl's government, indicated it was ready to negotiate an alliance. The Liberals hold 21 seats in Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: French Actress Capucine Dies, Suicide Suspected
DOC.TEXT: Capucine, the French movie actress whose leading roles included one with Peter Sellers in ``The Pink Panther,'' died after falling from a window. Police said she committed suicide. She was 57. The actress, born Germaine Lefebvre, died Saturday after plunging from her eighth-floor attic apartment and police inspector Claude Zbinden said an investigation left no doubt that she committed suicide. The Lausanne newspaper Le Matin said she shared the apartment with three cats. It quoted an unidentified friend as saying that she had been suffering from depression. A former model, the Toulon-born Capucine came to the United States in the late 1950's where she studied drama under Gregory Ratoff. She later continued her screen career in Europe, settling in Lausanne in 1961. In addition to ``The Pink Panther'' which came out in 1964, her films included ``Song Without End'' and ``Walk on the Wild Side,'' in 1962, ``What's New Pussycat'' in 1965, ``Fellini Satyricon'' in 1969, and ``Martin Eden'' in 1979. Among more recent roles was one in the French TV film, ``Quartier Negre,'' based on a novel by Georges Simenon.

DOC.HEAD: Regan Withdraws Duplicity Charge Against Wiesel
DOC.TEXT: Former White House chief of staff Donald T. Regan agreed to delete a passage from his memoirs after Nobel laureate Elie Wiesel threatened him with a $10 million libel lawsuit, lawyers for both men said. In his book, ``For the Record,'' Regan charged that Wiesel made a televised plea for then-President Reagan not to visit the Bitburg military cemetery in West Germany ``after assuring me he would do no such thing.'' Wiesel made the plea during a ceremony in Washington in April 1985 at which Reagan awarded him the Congressional Gold Medal. His lawsuit, never filed, maintained that he made no assurance to Regan of silence on Bitburg, lawyers said Monday. In exchange for Wiesel dropping the threatened suit, Regan instructed his publisher, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., to delete the disputed phrase from any future editions of ``For the Record.'' Regan also wrote Wiesel a two-paragraph letter, dated Jan. 29, in which he said of Wiesel's version of events: ``I hadn't remembered it that way.'' He said he was withdrawing the phrase ``since I did not mean to offend you.'' The suit said Regan's charge made it appear that Wiesel had agreed to be silent on Bitburg so he would receive the congressional medal. Reagan was criticized for visiting Bitburg because Nazi SS troops are buried there. Wiesel, a survivor of the Nazi slaughter of Jews during World War II, won the Nobel Peace Prize for his writings examining the Holocaust. The settlement, reported in the National Jewish Post and Opinion newspaper, was confirmed by lawyers for Wiesel, Regan and Harcourt.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MOSCOW
Lithuanian President: Moscow Warning Heralds Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with Landsbergis statement, details of meeting with legislators; Changes byline; Pickup 18th pvs, `Many Lithuanians...'
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's president denied Kremlin accusations that his Baltic republic plans to seize state enterprises and sell them to private owners, and called a harsh warning from Moscow a negotiating ploy. Vytautas Landsbergis, speaking before the republic's parliament on Monday, said he believed that the increasing tension between Moscow and Vilnius was part of the ``difficult beginning'' to talks on Lithuania's independence. In a nationally televised broadcast late Monday, the Soviet government warned Lithuania not to errect customs posts, introduce its own currency or take over Moscow-run factories without Kremlin permission. The announcement did not say what would happen if Lithuania ignored the warning, but Soviet troops in the past day have carried out military maneuvers in the republic that Lithuanians say are aimed at intimidation. Landsbergis said Moscow's statements were based on mistaken information, according to television editor Eduardas Potashinskas, who monitored the session. ``It is not true that we are going to pass state-owned enterprises to private owners,'' Landsbergis was quoted as saying. Lithuania's parliament voted on March 11 to secede from the Soviet Union and restore the independence it enjoyed before being forcibly annexed in 1940 along with the other Baltic states _ Estonia and Latvia. Four days later, the Soviet Parliament declared the decree invalid, but also did not specify measures Moscow might take to prevent Lithuania's succession. ``I regard the statement as a difficult beginning of negotiations, as an exchange of opinions that sometimes widely diverge and sometimes coincide,'' Landsbergis was quoted as saying. In Moscow, Egidius Bickauskas, a Lithuanian legislator, said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told him and other Lithuanian representatives about the warning when he met with them for 30 minutes late Monday. Bickauskas and Lithuanian legislator Vaidotas Antanaitis delivered a letter from Landsbergis rejecting Gorbachev's deadline _ which expired Monday _ for returning to the Soviet fold. Gorbachev has said he is willing to carry on a ``respectful dialogue'' with Lithuanian representatives. The Kremlin on Monday accused Lithuania of trying to ``undermine its links'' with the rest of the Soviet Union, which it said could have ``pernicious consequences'' for the national economy. The Soviet statement ordered police, the KGB, and customs agents to resist any attempts by Lithuania to change the existing customs regime. It also directed the management of Soviet enterprises and agencies in Lithuania not to hand over authority to local bodies. The announcement said the government was especially concerned about atomic energy plants in Lithuania, and ordered the guard over them increased. Moscow said it sympathized with Lithuania's strivings for greater sovereignty, but this should be pursued only with ``strict observance of Soviet laws and taking into consideration the mutual interests of the peoples of Lithuania and other republics.'' Landsbergis said his government agreed with aspects of Moscow's statement, including the benefits of retaining strong economic ties. Many Lithuanians say they expected Moscow to punish the republic by imposing an economic blockade and depriving it of fuel and raw materials. But the Kremlin on Monday did not threaten such measures. Moscow leaders have also said they have ruled out the use of troops to force Lithuania back into the Soviet Union. However, a spokesman for the Lithuanian nationalist movement Sajudis, Lionginas Vasiliauskas, said in Moscow that 10 truckloads of Soviet troops were moved Monday from Kaunas, about 60 miles from Vilnius, to a military post just outside the capital. Residents said Monday that the military maneuvers carried out over the weekend appeared over. But Radio Vilnius said it had ``reliable information'' that its broadcasts to foreign countries had been blocked by Radio Moscow. A loud hum could be heard during a Radio Vilnius broadcast monitored in Washington on Monday night. Lithuanian activist Eduardas Potashinskas said he thought most Lithuanians would take the Kremlin's warning calmly. ``We say the Soviet empire is showing its teeth,'' he said from Vilnius. ``But we think they can't threaten Lithuania. We'll be calm. We'll fall and get up, but we'll go on.'' Soviet television has shown several programs in the last two days focusing on discontent among Lithuania's ethnic minorities, who comprise about 20 percent of the republic's 3.8 million people. Late Monday, the nightly news program Vremya showed an anti-independence meeting in the Lithuanian port of Klaipeda, at which one speaker said: ``We don't want to live in bourgeois Lithuania.'' The Baltic port is valuable to the Soviet military. A Vremya anchorman also read an appeal from a demonstration Sunday in Vilnius that drew tens of thousands of ethnic Russians and Poles. The appeal, addressed to Gorbachev, said: ``Hypocritically and arrogantly, the interests of many thousands of people who are categorically against being torn from the peoples of the USSR are being ignored.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Investigators Say Garment Truckers Linked to Mobsters
DOC.TEXT: The district attorney's office bought a Chinatown clothing factory, used undercover police to run it and determined that organized crime has a stranglehold on the garment industry, The New York Times reported today. The police, who supervised 25 garment workers in the noisy loft factory, found that mob-affiliated trucking companies were shaking down clothing manufacturers. The investigators gathered evidence against two organized crime families, the newspaper said. No charges have been filed, but authorities said evidence will be presented to a grand jury. ``The evidence we have so far turned up shows that organized crime has a monopolistic stranglehold over trucking companies and the truckers are the lifeblood of the city's garment industry,'' Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau told the Times. Threats and extortion demands by trucking representatives were secretly recorded during the set-up, unidentified investigators told the newspaper. The trucking employees told the undercover agents which trucker would have the sole right to move their goods, the newspaper said. Prices were not negotiable. If the company used another trucking company, it would still have to pay the one designated by the organized crime figures, the Times said. Records of 10 garment district truckers were seized Jan. 30. Unidentified officials said seven of the 10 are controlled by Thomas Gambino, who has been identified by law enforcement officials as a captain in the Gambino crime family, and that two of the others are affiliated with figures in the Lucchese crime family. Thomas Gambino's attorney, Michael Rosen, said suggestions that Gambino was connected to criminal activity were ``hysterical accusations by people in law enforcement who have to justify their existence,'' the Times said. Thomas Gambino, 60, is the son of the late Carlo Gambino, reputed founder of the crime family that bears his name. The Gambino organization is said to be the most powerful organized crime group in the nation. Law enforcement officials believe it is now headed by John Gotti. Thomas Gambino is married to Catherine Lucchese, the daughter of the late Thomas Lucchese, who is said to have founded the Lucchese crime family. The district attorney's office paid $25,000 for the garment contracting company in Chinatown with sewing machines and other equipment, said Michael G. Cherkasky, an assistant district attorney in charge of the inquiry. The company, which operated for most of last year, sewed skirts and jeans and delivered them to jobbers or manufacturers who provided the fabric. The firm lost $10,000 last year. The firm's business was run by six state police officers. State investigators were used instead of city police officers to reduce the chances that an undercover agent would be recognized, Cherkasky said. Cherkasky said he expected a grand jury will hear evidence of extortion, price-fixing and racketeering in several months.

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Found Dead In Liferaft As Search For Missing Ships Continues
DOC.TEXT: Two men were found dead in a liferaft off the coast of Western Australian state today, but searchers found no trace of two missing ships carrying 51 crewmen. The two bodies might have come from the missing Panamanian-registered bulk iron ore carrier the Alexandre P, a 96,000-ton ship carrying a crew of 25, officials said. The bodies were those of two Asian men. They were discovered near where a large oil slick and other debris were sighted Monday, said a spokesman for the Sea Safety Centre in Canberra, speaking on condition of anonymity. A doctor aboard the oil search ship Energy Searcher, which recovered the bodies, examined the men and found they had suffered burns and lacerations before entering the liferaft, the spokesman said. Evidence indicated their ship caught fire before sinking, the spokesman said. The Alexandre P left Dampier in the north of Western Australia state on March 13 en route to South Africa and Spain. It has failed to make its required daily position report since March 15 and fears are growing its cargo may have shifted and the vessel sunk. The Sea Safety Center spokesman said the center had not positively identified the liferaft and bodies as being from the Alexandre P. The spokesman said a separate search for a missing Japanese tuna trawler was continuing about 500 nautical miles northwest of North West Cape. The Dahlia II was carrying 22 Indonesian and four Japanese crew members. Indonesian authorities picked up a distress call from the vessel on Saturday, as tropical Cyclone Alex battered the area where the Dahlia II had been fishing off the island of Java.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral Directors Dump Casket at State Office
DOC.TEXT: Two funeral directors left a casket with a body inside at a state social services office to protest government reimbursement rates for indigent burials. P.J. Kane and Mark Ferries, who work with different Sheridan funeral homes, said they meant no disrespect to the deceased. They said the ploy was needed to get the attention of the Department of Public Assistance and Social Services, which sets the limit for indigent burial expenses. The two men left the casket at the office for two hours Friday. Kane said the department will pay up to $995 for the burial of anyone who was receiving aid under the Wyoming Public Assistance and Social Services Act. He said $995 doesn't come close to covering the cost of a burial. ``We will not turn anybody away from a decent burial,'' he said, ``but, being in private business, we cannot buy a cemetery lot, pay for burial costs and a vault out of our own pockets.'' Many Wyoming counties cover the difference between the state limit and the actual expense. However, Sheridan County's indigent burial fund has apparently run dry, and county officials say there won't be any more money coming to cover the costs. State social service officials, the county attorney's office and the state attorney general's office all told the funeral directors to file a lawsuit to get the law changed. The Rev. Ray Moss, who accompanied the funeral directors and the casket to the office, said the woman whose body was in the casket had no family in Sheridan and her estate would not cover the cost of a burial.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Democracy Fund May Be Used In South Africa
With PM-Namibia
DOC.TEXT: The United States is considering a fund used to aid democracy in Poland and Nicaragua to support anti-apartheid groups in South Africa, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said. In Washington, a U.S. official confirmed that the Bush administration is seeking ways to aid the African National Congress through the National Endowment for Democracy. In a briefing Sunday to reporters traveling with the secretary to Namibia for its independence celebrations, Baker said the endowment may be employed ``to encourage democracy, non-racial democracy in South Africa.'' The fund was created in 1983 and used most recently in Nicaragua to support parties opposed to the Sandinista government. It also financed Poland's Solidarity movement in its struggle against the former Communist government. ``It's a little bit too early to tell'' how the endowment process would work in South Africa), Baker said. He added that the endowment itself would decide how to dispense funds in South Africa. A coalition of American black leaders has asked Baker to give financial aid to the African National Congress, the main black nationalist group fighting white-minority rule in South Africa. Baker's suggestion of the endowment's involvement appeared to be a response to the request to aid the ANC. The National Endowment for Democracy, created by Congress during the Reagan administration, is a publicly chartered, but publicly and privately funded organization whose leadership includes the heads of both the Republican and Democratic parties, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and the AFL-CIO. The group gives grants to organizations which can further democracy in other countries. It also sends Americans abroad to teach democratic processes and methods. Baker also said he would encourage South African President F.W. de Klerk to continue reforms in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Census Bureau Aims to Count as Many of Homeless As It Can Today
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 5, Members of, with protest.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: They are mostly male and single. The majority are minorities. They have little education and many have histories of mental illness. All are homeless. And the Census Bureau aims to count as many of them as it can today. ``The homeless are people and they deserve to be counted,'' the Rev. Del Maxfield of Denver said this morning on NBC's ``Today'' show. Maxfield was critical of some advocates for the homeless who have opposed the census effort. ``I think it is irresponsible of us as service providers and as advocates for the homeless to sit back now, after we try to keep these people in the forefront all year long, and now tell them to go back in the shadows.'' Mitch Snyder of Washington's Community for Creative Non-Violence has led the anti-census effort. Members of Snyder's group protested in front of the Commerce Department this morning, carrying signs saying ``Like Grains of Sand the Homeless Can't Be Counted'' and ``You Can't Count The Homeless.'' A pile of sand had been dumped in the street outside the department. ``A number of and by itself isn't helpful ... I think it is politically naive not to understand that coming in with a small number is going to be misused. It's going to be used to try and drive down appropriations,'' Snyder said on ``CBS This Morning.'' ``I think that the politicians will do whatever they want to do regardless of whether or not they have specific information. I think we, as care providers and especially local government, will do positive things with these figures...it's their (the homeless') right as American citizens to be counted'' Chicago shelter operator Rick Roberts said on the same broadcast. ``The government needs to know about everyone and this is a chance for the homeless to say, `Look, we exist, we're part of this country','' Cynthia Taeuber, special assistant for selected populations at the Census Bureau, said Monday. Tonight and early Wednesday morning up to 15,000 census workers will visit missions and shelters, walk the streets and look down alleys. They will even wait outside abandoned buildings to see if anyone emerges in the morning. Where possible, workers will ask some basic questions, too, but they won't disturb sleeping people or those in no state of mind to be interviewed. The plan is to take the measure of the homeless in a more thorough count than occurred a decade ago when census workers simply visited shelters and missions. Directing aid to the homeless has foundered on a lack of knowledge, as estimates of their number vary from 250,000 to 3 million. Because of problems in finding all the homeless _ and concerns about worker safety _ Taeuber admits that she expects the tally to be conservative. Officials already know something about the homeless, through a survey of 1,704 homeless people at soup kitchens in 20 cities taken by The Urban Institute. The survey, with a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points, found that 81 percent of the homeless surveyed were men, compared with just under half of the general population. About 46 percent of the homeless were black, 41 percent were non-Hispanic whites and 10 percent were Hispanic. In the general population, blacks make up about 12 percent and Hispanics 8 percent. About 55 percent of homeless had never married, compared with 22 percent of American adults overall. Fifty-two percent of all homeless had completed high school, compared with 81 percent of all American adults. Almost 20 percent of the homeless reported a history of mental hospitalization and one-third had been patients in a detoxification or alcohol or drug treatment center, the survey found. Today's $2.7 million special count involves looking for the homeless in every city of 50,000 people or more. The Census Bureau also asked smaller communities if they have a homeless populations. If local officials said yes, ceusns workers will go there and make a count. The bureau doesn't plan to announce a homeless population figure. Instead, it will report that it found so many people in shelters, so many in missions, so many in flophouses, so many walking or sleeping on the streets, and so forth. From about 6 p.m. to midnight, workers will visit public and private emergency shelters, hotels and motels used to shelter the homeless and other hotels costing less than $12 per night. From 2 a.m. to 4 a.m., census workers will travel the streets, checking places where homeless people may be found. After that, until about 8 a.m., workers will wait outside abandoned buildings where homeless people may live. Because of safety questions, the decision was made not to enter abandoned buildings even though people may be sleeping in them, Taeuber said.

DOC.HEAD: Wine Merchant Sought As East German Economics Minister
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The leading East German political party has asked a successful West German wine merchant to become East Germany's new economics minister. Elmar Pieroth urges speedily replacing East Germany's weak currency with the mighty West German mark to spur the conversion from centrally planned inefficiency to what he envisions as a free-market economy and prosperity. The East German Christian Democratic Union, which placed first in Sunday's elections, proposed that Pieroth serve in East Germany's first freely elected government. Pieroth, 55, says he does not expect to hold an East Berlin job for long because unity is sure to come soon. ``First we have to bring the economy in line with that of West Germany. I could imagine unification of the two German states within 12 months,'' he said. Pieroth is a politician in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, sister party of the East German CDU. Starting in 1953, Pieroth and his brother, Kuno, headed and expanded the family wine business in Bad Kreuznach, southwest of Frankfurt in Rhineland-Palatinate state. He held the economics portfolio in West Berlin's city government from 1981 until last year.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Approves Bill Allowing Free Travel Abroad
DOC.TEXT: A parliamentary committee today approved a bill that would allow all Soviet citizens to travel abroad freely, sending the measure to the Supreme Soviet for debate, the official news agency Tass said. Under provisions of the bill, permission will not be required for Soviets to leave and return, either for short trips or permanent residence abroad, Tass said. ``A passport for traveling abroad will be issued for a period of five years to whoever applies for it,'' Tass said. ``The time abroad will be determined by the citizen himself.'' Only state security considerations, criminal proceedings or incarceration could prevent a person from being issued a passport, the news agency said. Additionaly, access to classified materials would allow the Soviet government to deny an individual a passport for only five years, Tass said. ``A citizen may lodge an appeal with any authority, up to the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, against a refussal to issue a foreign travel passport,'' Tass said. The bill was introduced by Fyodor Burlatsky, a Supreme Soviet deputy and well-known political commentator, who called it ``a major indicator of democratization in the Soviet Union.'' Committee members said they would insist that the bill be adopted at the current session of the Supreme Soviet legislature, which ends in late April. Members also warned against delay in solving issues related to the passport bill, including rules on exchanging money and buying airline tickets. Unless flying on the state-run airline Aeroflot or its joint ventue partner Pan Am, Soviets seeking to travel abroad must pay in hard currency. Under newly introduced tourist exchange rates, a $1,000 airline ticket would cost a Soviet traveler about 6,000 rubles on a foreign airline. The Aeroflot and Pan Am flights are sold out for more than a year in advance. Last year, 235,000 people left the country for permanent residence abroad and that 2 million Soviets took short trips abroad, including 300,000 travelers to the West, Burlatsky said.

DOC.HEAD: Members Suing Union Entitled to Jury Trial if Seeking Monetary Compensation
DOC.TEXT: Union members who sue their union for allegedly denying fair representation are entitled to a jury trial if they also seek monetary compensation, the Supreme Court ruled today. ``We hold that the (Constitution's) Seventh Amendment entitles such a plaintiff to a jury trial,'' Justice Thurgood Marshall wrote for the court in the 6-3 decision. Justices Anthony M. Kennedy, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia dissented. Lawsuits accusing unions of breaching their duty of fair representation usually are tried before judges without juries. Such suits generally seek to end some asserted unfair treatment or to force a union into taking some action. But, ruling in a case from North Carolina last year, the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said a jury trial can be demanded when monetary compensation such as back pay is part of the relief sought. Other appeals courts had ruled differently. Today's decision, resolving the issue, is a victory for 27 truck drivers who in 1983 sued Local 391 of the Teamsters union. The lawsuit stemmed from the drivers' transfer from various locations to the McLean Trucking Co.'s terminal in Winston-Salem, N.C. After the transfers, the 27 were laid off and recalled on several occasions. The drivers contend that McLean breached a collective-bargaining agreement by manipulating recall procedures so it could give other drivers preference, and that Local 391 failed to represent them fairly in the resulting grievances. The suit seeks, among other things, compensatory damages for lost wages and benefits. As a result of today's ruling, the suit now will reach a jury. In a separate jury-trial decision, the court unanimously reinstated a lawsuit by a black machinist from North Carolina who said he was fired because of his race. John S. Lytle's suit also alleged that he was given an unfavorable job reference because he had filed a discrimination claim against his former boss. Today's ruling broadens the right to a jury trial in lawsuits by those who claim their civil rights have been violated. Lytle was fired in 1983 by Schwitzer Turbochargers in Arden, N.C., a subsidiary of Household Manufacturing Inc. He accused the company of racial bias in violation of two civil rights laws: a 19th Century statute first used to protect freed slaves and a 1964 law. A federal judge ruled for the company, and denied Lytle a jury trial. The high court today said Lytle's Seventh Amendment rights were violated. The cases are Chauffeurs, Teamsters and Helpers vs. Terry, 88-1719, and Lytle vs. Household Manufacturing Inc., 88-334.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Suspect Sought; DEA Says Security Has Limits
DOC.TEXT: Two federal agencies have put up a $100,000 reward for the capture of the bomber responsible for the destruction of the Fort Myers, Fla., office of the Drug Enforcement Administration. The explosion has prompted the DEA to alert its offices around the country, but agents say there's only so much they can do to protect themselves. The DEA and FBI, which posted the reward, haven't named a suspect in the blast. However, the FBI has issued a nationwide alert for Jeffrey A. Matthews, 23, a drug suspect who allegedly threatened the DEA after he was indicted Thursday. ``There have been no warrants issued yet for anyone in the explosion, but we are following some good leads,'' FBI spokesman Brian Kenscel said Monday. Matthews' half-brother, John Lewis Ciganek, 22, gave himself up Sunday in the Florida Keys and was questioned about the bombing. The FBI spokesman refused to say what, if anything, the suspect told agents. On Monday, Ciganek was arraigned in Fort Myers federal court on the drug indictment. ``I just want a fair trial,'' he said after declaring himself indigent and in need of a court-appointed attorney. He was ordered held without bond. In Washington, DEA spokesman Bill Ruzzamenti said agency offices around the world have been told about the bombing, but no new security measures have been taken. ``The situation in Fort Myers is an isolated incident,'' he said. The agent in charge in Minneapolis, Jim Braseth, says his office hasn't gotten any threats, nor has it stepped up security. In Indianapolis, David H. McDougal, the resident agent in charge, said that while the bombing appears local, ``this just shows that it is a war.'' In Yakima, Wash., DEA agent in charge Robert Dreisbach said his office had ``taken certain security precautions as a result of Fort Myers and continuing threats to all DEA offices from drug-trafficking organizations.'' He wouldn't elaborate. The bombing _ along with threats from Colombian drug dealers and the slayings of agents around the world _ shows the agency's limits in protecting itself, the DEA acknowledged. Agents probably will be more careful, Miami DEA spokesman John Fernandes said. But he said surrounding DEA offices with armed guards, for instance, wouldn't work. ``We can't shut ourselves off behind an iron wall,'' Fernandes said. ``We work with the public.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 1 p.m., EST
DOC.HEAD: Wilder Urges Democrats to Embrace Conservative Economic Policies
DOC.TEXT: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia called on his fellow Democrats today to embrace the conservative economic principles he has adopted as the nation's first elected black governor. ``In presidential elections, our candidates must take the plunge into the waters of America's New Mainstream,'' Wilder said in a speech prepared for delivery to the National Press Club. He said Democrats should return to their heritage of opposition to high taxes and spending and warned that they had let Republicans take those issues away from them. Wilder also urged Democrats to ``stop fighting each other'' long after primary battles are decided. ``We're doing the other party's dirty work for them _ and it must stop if we are to ever again be more than mere guests at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue,'' he said. Since his history-making election in November 1989, Wilder has been one of the hottest properties in the Democratic Party, much in demand as a speaker. He issued his call for unity at a party dinner in Chicago last week and is a featured speaker on the agenda of the Democratic Leadership Council meeting in New Orleans later this week. For many Democrats, Wilder represents a mainstream alternative to Jesse Jackson, who has twice run for the party's presidential nomination from a base of overwhelming support within the black community. But during his first months as governor, Wilder's politics have been as conservative as Jackson's are liberal. In his press club speech, Wilder's emphasis was on economic development and tough anti-crime measures. ``I was pleased that the legislature passed an administration supported bill calling for the death penalty in certain drug-related murders,'' he said, also citing legislation requiring criminal background checks for would-be buyers of automatic weapons. Wilder warned Democrats that they ``cannot afford to underestimate or ignore the economic and housing needs of citizens living beyond our cities and suburbs. ``Americans everywhere want to hold the line on spending and on taxes. There was a time when Democrats were elected by campaigning against big government and high taxes. But for too long we have let the other party take these issues away from us _ indeed we have allowed them to hammer us with these issues.''

DOC.HEAD: South Carolina Court: Cocaine Users Are More Likely to Lie
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court ruled that cocaine possession is a crime of moral turpitude that raises questions about a person's basic honesty. In its 4-1 ruling Monday, the court said a past conviction for cocaine possession might be used in legal proceedings to imply that a person would lie under oath. ``Any involvement with cocaine contributes to the destruction of an ordered society,'' the court said in taking cocaine possession off the short list of crimes it considers self-destructive but not harmful to others. Self-destructive crimes _ including simple possession of marijuana, bookmaking and public drunkenness _ cannot be used against people to convince juries in future court proceedings that they might be basically dishonest. The decision reversed a 1987 ruling that cocaine possession was not a crime of moral turpitude, and it could not be used to challenge a defendant's truthfulness on other matters. The change of heart on the state's high court was directly tied to the justices' view of cocaine: ``The drug cocaine has torn at the very fabric of our nation,'' Associate Justice Jean Toal wrote in the majority opinion. ``Families have been ripped apart, minds have been ruined, and lives have been lost. It is common knowledge that the drug is highly addictive and potentially fatal.'' Associate Justice Ernest A. Finney dissented, saying that the same reasoning could just as accurately be applied to alcohol, nicotine and marijuana in the hands of abusers. The legal point about cocaine did not affect the outcome of the trial that brought the issue before the court. All the justices conceded there were other reasons to question the basic honesty of Jimmy Major, a Florence County drug dealer convicted of selling crack and distributing the drug within a mile of a school ground in 1988. The court affirmed Major's conviction, overruling his claims that a prior conviction was improperly entered into evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Convenes in West Beirut, First Time in 15 Years
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon's parliament convened at its pre-civil war headquarters in downtown west Beirut today for the first time in nearly 15 years. Thirty-seven of the 72 surviving deputies attended the session, electing the unicameral legislature's 13 committees and voting a 40 percent wage increase for civil servants. Speaker Hussein Husseini, a Shiite Moslem, scheduled another session at the same venue Thursday to discuss several bills, including one promoting officers of the 22,000 mostly Moslem troops loyal to President Elias Hrawi. In another development, police said one person was wounded when a small bomb exploded near the Carton Hotel in the Ras Beirut district of the city's Moslem western sector late Monday. The meeting today was the first by parliament at its old venue in west Beirut's Star Square since mid-1975. Lawmakers from various sects attended the session. About 16 mainly Maronite Christian deputies who do not feel secure in west Beirut remain in France to stay out of the reach of renegade Gen. Michel Aoun. Parliament was invited to a meeting at its old headquarters Sept. 22, 1988, to elect a successor to President Amin Gemayel, but a quorum could not be achieved for the presidential vote. A simple majority was needed to pass the bills today. The civil war between Christians and Moslems broke out April 13, 1975, and forced the legislature to move to a new headquarters at Beirut's dividing Green Line to aid participation by both Moslem and Christian deputies. ``The meeting at the old parliament headquarters is the first step toward patching up differences and reuniting the nation,'' the Moslem Voice of the Nation said in a commentary. Parliament returned to its old offices apparently to avoid meeting near Aoun's hostile troops. Aoun declared the legislature dissolved last November in an attempt to prevent the election of Hrawi, whom Aoun considers pro-Syrian. Lawmakers met at a hotel in the Syrian-policed Bekaa valley town of Chtoura Nov. 24 and elected Hrawi as president in line with an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end the civil strife. Aoun, backed by the 19,000-man mainly Christian half of the armed forces, has rejected Hrawi's election. He holds the shell-ravaged presidential palace in suburban Baabda, east of Beirt, the traditional home of Lebanese heads of state. Aoun's move forced Hrawi to establish offices in Moslem west Beirut, policed by about 3,500 Syrian soldiers. Syria, which backs Hrawi, has 40,000 troops deployed in predominantly Moslem sectors of Lebanon under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate from the 22-nation Arab League.

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lanka to Close Israeli Diplomatic Office
DOC.TEXT: The government said today it will close an Israeli mission that has been operating in Colombo since 1984 and it gave Israeli officials one month to leave. Sri Lanka severed diplomatic relations with Israel after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. President Ranasinghe Premadasa's predecessor, Junius R. Jayewardene, invited the Israeli government to open an interest section in 1984 because Israel provided military and intelligence assistance to help against a Tamil secessionist campaign. Jayewardene's decision was criticized by Arab nations and members of the non-aligned movement, but he defended the action by saying Israel was the only country that responded to his appeal for aid. Today's statement said Premadasa's decision to close the Israeli office was the fulfillment of an election promise made before he took office 14 months ago. Sri Lanka will resume diplomatic relations with Israel once ``she recognizes the Palestine Liberation Organization as the legitimate representative of the Palestinian people, withdraws from all occupied Palestinian territory and agrees to participate in an international conference on the middle east convened by the U.N.,'' the statement said. Ori Noy, head of the Israeli Interest Section in Colombo, could not be reached for comment. The interest section operated under the auspices of the U.S. Embassy. A U.S. Embassy official refused to comment on the closure order. An interest section, which operates under the flag of another country, is a step below full diplomatic relations. After the Israeli Interest Section was set up, Israel sent agricultural experts to help in northcentral Sri Lanka. Scores of Sri Lankan soldiers, maimed in the Tamil insurrection, were sent to Israel to be fitted with artificial limbs. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of the population, began fighting in 1983, alleging discrimination by the majority Sinhalese who control the government and the military. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. Some Tamil guerrillas have acknowledged receiving support from PLO groups, especially in the early days of the revolt.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Negotiate Return of Art Collection From Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: The Dutch government is negotiating for the return of hundreds of art works that ended up in Moscow museums after they were sold illegally to the Nazis in World War II, officials said today. The art works, worth between an estimated $79 million to $105 million, are part of the Konigs Collection of 2,200 drawings by old masters such as Rembrandt van Rijn, Peter Paul Rubens, Titian, Tintoretto, and Albrecht Durer. The works disappeared during the wartime occupation of the Netherlands. ``We have strong indications that about 500 drawings have been stored in the Pushkin Museum (in Moscow) and the Hermitage (in Leningrad),'' said Koos de Jong of the Netherlands Office for Fine Arts, a government agency charged with care of the Dutch state's huge art collections. ``We have asked the Soviet authorities to cooperate with us in locating the collection and in returning it to the Netherlands,'' De Jong said. De Jong said that the Soviet Union has expressed willingness to return the drawings to the Netherlands, from where they were taken in 1941 by German scouts.
