During World War II, many art works were taken from occupied Europe for the private collections of Third Reich leaders. The drawings were sold to German buyers by the Rotterdam's Boymans Van Beuningen museum, De Jong said, adding it was unknown whether it had been a forcible sale. The museum acquired the full collection from a Dutch bank that liquidated in the months before World War II. The bank had bought the 2,200 drawings from Dutch financier A. Konigs when he ran into financial trouble in 1931. The drawings sold to the Germans ended up in a museum in Dresden and presumably were taken from there in 1945 by Soviet occupying forces, De Jong said. Under a declaration signed by the four wartime allies, all transactions with the Nazi government were voided, De Jong said. ``We base our claim on that declaration,'' he said, adding that he hoped the art would be returned to the Boymans Van Beuningen museum ``tomorrow ... but it could also take decades from now.''

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Holds Police at Bay from Back Seat of Patrol Car
LaserPhoto MKN1 of March 19
DOC.TEXT: A bad-check suspect riding in the back of a police car pulled out a concealed handgun, shot at a patrolman and then held off officers for 1{ hours, threatening suicide. Billy Ray Youngblood, 38, of Muskegon, was being taken to police headquarters Monday afternoon when he pulled the .25-caliber semiautomatic from a handbag, police Lt. Dan Stout said. Youngblood demanded that Patrolman Louis Hood drive him to the Muskegon suburb of Norton Shores, but the officer escaped, Stout said. As Hood fled, Youngblood fired a shot through the cruiser's rear side window. The shattering glass and metal fragments injured Hood, who was treated for cuts and released from Hackley Hospital, according to Beth Taylor, an emergency room clerk. During the standoff that followed, Youngblood threatened suicide by pointing the gun into his mouth. The standoff ended when Police Chief Thomas Kelenske from nearby Roosevelt Park persuaded Youngblood to surrender. The incident began shortly after noon when police were called to the Harbor Hilton Hotel on a bad-check complaint, Stout said. ``Apparently, the suspect had a handbag with him and the officer hadn't searched him well enough before putting him in the cruiser,'' Stout said. Stout said Youngblood was being held in Muskegon County Jail pending arraignment on an attempted murder charge.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Seek Clues in Fatal Package Bombing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `The victim ..., and 12th graf, `Finlay's wife ..., to CORRECT spelling to Finlay sted Finley; INSERTS 1 graf after 13th graf, `They've been ..., to add background on Finlay; picks up 14th graf, `The family ...
DOC.TEXT: Investigators looked for clues today in the wreckage of an apartment where a shoebox-sized package bomb killed a man who had just moved to Florida a week before. The victim, 70-year-old Sherwin William Finlay, was returning to his apartment late Monday with his wife and daughter when the blast occurred at about 8 p.m. The family stepped over the package in front of the apartment and went inside their first-floor apartment, authorities said. ``He came back (out), picked it up and it exploded,'' said police spokesman Steve Weintraub. According to witnesses, the package resembled a shoebox and was wrapped in brown paper. It apparently was not sent through the mail, Weintraub said, adding ``you can't tell _ there's no package left.'' The blast was powerful enough to blow out the roof overhang of the two-story apartment building, Weintraub said. Willi Ellison, agent in charge of the Jacksonville office of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said the bomb was ``more or less a homemade device.'' He said the remains of the device would be sent to the ATF laboratory in Atlanta for analysis. Investigators do not believe the explosion is related to recent mail bombings in Alabama, Georgia and Jacksonville, which led to two deaths. ``At this point, I don't think there is a connection but we're looking into all aspects,'' Ellison said. Authorities knew of no suspects or motive for the bombing. The FBI was investigating but had no comment late Monday. Finlay's wife, Dorothy, 67, and 35-year-old daughter Gay Lynn Meek were not injured. The daughter was from Illinois, said Ellison. He said the Finlays were from Missouri, but he didn't know exactly where. ``They've been here since Dec. 1,'' said Weintraub. ``I don't know if they're down here to see if they wanted to live here or what.'' According to the yearbook of the Missouri Highway Department, Finlay was a highway engineer from Gravois Mills, Mo., who retired 10 years ago. The family reportedly moved into the apartment complex about a week ago and neighbors knew little about them. Philip Brown, who lived in a nearby apartment, said he was in his living room when he heard the blast. ``I ran outside and all I could see was smoke,'' he said. ``That's when I saw someone lying under the stairs and heard a woman screaming.''

DOC.HEAD: Namibia Prepares For Independence As Guests Pour In
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7 grafs for grafs 10-12 pvs, `Shops and...' to UPDATE with color, Shevardnadze and Tutu comments. Pick up 13th graf pvs, `Many Namibians...'
DOC.TEXT: Foreign leaders and diplomats streamed into Windhoek today, transforming the sleepy city into a mini-United Nations as Namibia counted down the final hours before independence. Seventy-five years of South African rule was to end with a speech by South African President F.W. de Klerk before the South African flag was lowered for the last time and replaced by the red, green and blue banner of a new nation. U.N. Secretary General Perez de Cuellar was to swear in former resistance leader Sam Nujoma as Namibia's first president, marking the midnight transition of Africa's last colony into its youngest state. ``This is a great time. It means we have freedom. We are going to celebrate all night,'' said Nicholas van Wyk, 21, a hotel worker. Nujoma's South-West Africa People's Organization (SWAPO) had waged a 23-year war to oust the South Africans, who captured the former German colony on Africa's south-west coast during World War I. In December 1989, South Africa agreed to grant the huge, arid territory of 1.3 million people independence under a regional peace plan that also calls for Cuba to withdraw its 50,000 soldiers from neighboring Angola by mid-1991. In November, SWAPO captured 57 percent of the vote in free elections. Representatives of dozens of nations attending today's celebrations were also using the occasion for some behind-the-scenes consultations, with the United States, Soviet Union and others holding an elaborate series of meetings. Among the foreign guests attending the celebrations were U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze; Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak; Libyan President Moammar Gadhafi; the leaders of at least 10 African nations; and the foreign ministers of Britain, West Germany, Romania, Indonesia and other nations. Shops and main streets were festooned with Namibian flags as workers put final touches on podiums, banners and other decorations. Excited youngsters put up flags and decorated walls with murals depicting peace and prosperity in the new nation. Tens of thousands of Namibians were expected to take part in the celebrations, which include fireworks, choirs and traditional dancing that was likely to last through the night. A parade through downtown Windhoek was expected to draw some 50,000 people Wednesday morning. Shevardnadze told Nujoma that gaining independence was just the first challenge facing the new nation, and that Namibia would have to work hard to avoid problems confronting other African nations. ``The main work lies ahead. We all know from experience, and especially in fellow African states, that there is often a more difficult struggle in development than in working toward independence,'' he said on his arrival. South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu, a leading anti-apartheid activist, said he hoped Namibian independence would help speed the end of apartheid in South Africa. ``It is exciting to be here in Namibia at this period in time. It means a lot to us that a country can achieve independence in the face of such elements against them,'' he said. Many Namibians expressed hope that the new nation would solve past racial differences and overcome the economic and political problems facing many poor African nations. ``Other African countries have had disappointments after independence. I hope we have learned from those economic and political mistakes,'' said Simon Ekanjo, a student. Some in the white minority expressed concern about the new black government, but said they wanted to support the new nation. Said Barney van der Schynn, a 41-year-old businessman, ``The economy could suffer and changes aren't easy, but we couldn't keep carrying on the way we were. Independence should have come earlier.'' Security for visiting guests was tight with police blocking off streets around the hotels where foreign delegations were staying. Windhoek's modest airport was thronged with police and security officers as officials prepared for the arrival of about 100 planes bearing guests. Sirens began wailing at dawn today as motorcades transported visiting leaders and diplomats across Windhoek. Baker had six separate meetings planned today, including talks with Perez de Cuellar and Shevardnadze. Among other issues, Baker and Shevardnadze expected to discuss a peace plan for Angola, which has suffered 15 years of civil war between the Soviet-backed Marxist government and U.S.-supported insurgents. The independence date was chosen to mark the 30th anniversary of the ``Sharpeville Massacre,'' when 69 unarmed demonstrators were shot to death in South Africa while protesting apartheid laws in a black township south of Johannesburg. ``The day was chosen as a sign of solidarity not only for the people of Namibia, but also with the people of South Africa,'' said Hifikepunye Pohamba, a SWAPO member who will become the home affairs minister in the new government. Namibia for decades has had the same apartheid laws of racial segregtion as South Africa, although most were scrapped in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Nuclear Plant Begins Startup Testing
DOC.TEXT: The Seabrook nuclear power plant's reactor began operating early today, five days after receiving an operating license. A sustained atomic reaction in the plant's uranium fuel began at 3:59 a.m., spokesman Ron Sher said. The first sustained chain reaction at the plant was during low-power testing last year. Sher said the plant will increase power to 100 percent over the next two to three months. Seabrook will begin to produce limited amounts of electricity at about 10 percent of full power, he said. The $6.5 billion plant, finished in mid-1986, got its Nuclear Regulatory Commission operating license Thursday, following lengthy regulatory battles and a preliminary court skirmish decided in Seabrook's favor. The U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington declined last week to block the license pending further court action, but still has before it an appeal filed by the plant's opponents.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges Enactment of Aid for Panama and Nicaragua
Eds. Inserts graf 7, House speaker, and adds last 6 grafs with lawmakers' comments.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush urged congressional leaders today to enact his $800 million aid package for Panama and Nicaragua, saying it would help increase pressure for democracy in Fidel Castro's Cuba. Bush, speaking at the outset of a White House meeting with the House and Senate leadership, said, ``I'm terribly disappointed that Castro seems to be firming up his totalitarian position instead of moving toward free and fair elections.'' ``I'd like to see him shift from that highly militarized island and let democracy have a chance,'' said Bush. ``I think if we are helpful to Nicaragua and Panama, it will simply increase the pressure in that marvelous island of Cuba for change.'' Bush is pressing for passage of $500 million to help Panama rebuild following the ouster of Manuel Antonio Noriega, and $300 million for Nicaragua, where citizens last month voted to replace Sandinista President Daniel Ortega with publisher Violeta Chamorro, who is strongly backed by the United States. Bush, addressing the congressional leaders and top administration officials gathered in the Cabinet Room, said he called the meeting to discuss the ``dramatic'' shifts toward democracy in Panama and Nicaragua. ``I know that the Senate and the House will come to grips with this problem,'' said Bush. House Speaker Thomas Foley said after the meeting, ``We're going to do whatever we can to expedite this process'' of enacting the aid package, but it may take ``a few weeks.'' With last week's ouster of a military ruler in Haiti, the United States regards Cuba as the sole holdout against democracy in the Western Hemisphere. Bush, in an interview Monday with Media General newspapers, criticized Castro for keeping some troops in Africa and for human rights abuses in Cuba. Asked what Castro could do to secure normal relations with the United States, Bush said, ``I think free and fair elections and a recognition of the democratic changes taking place, and a shifting from a highly militarized island to something that would be more helpful to his own people.'' He also called for economic changes, including shifting the highly socialized Cuban economy to market forces. He said Castro was ``digging himself in further, almost in splendid isolation, against the changes that are taking place around the world.'' Several lawmakers said the real pressure on Castro is emanating not from the White House, but from the dramatic changes elsewhere in Central America and Eastern Europe. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said, ``Cuba is being squeezed by world events. ... Just like we've seen in Eastern Europe, I think change is inevitable in Cuba no matter what we do.'' Leahy, chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that dispenses foreign aid, also questioned the importance of Cuba. ``We should be helping to stabilize and encourage the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. ... Cuba is interesting to us because it's 90 miles offshore. But does it really involve the strategic interest of the United States?'' Leahy said. ``It's a tiny little island country.'' Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the House Republican whip, said, ``Castro is ... a man who is denying the reality of history.'' ``We're not getting any tougher with Castro. We're staying where we are and hoping that Castro will decide to allow the people of Cuba to choose freely,'' said Gingrich.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Have Final Say in Primaries Featuring Ideology, Mudslinging
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf, `A larger ..., to UPDATE with voter turnout; picks up 4th graf, `Today also ...
DOC.TEXT: A conservative abortion foe and a pro-choice moderate squared off today in Illinois' Republican gubernatorial primary, while Democratic Reps. Gus Savage and Sidney Yates faced spirited challenges in their Chicago districts. State officials predicted about a quarter of Illinois' 6 million registered voters would cast ballots. A larger share of Chicago's 1.4 million registered voters was expected to turn out, largely because of an intense four-way Democratic primary contest for the powerful presidency of the Cook County Board. Early indications were that voter turnout was running according to projections. At 7 a.m., when polls had been open an hour, turnout was running at a rate of about 25 percent in suburban Cook county, according to the county clerk's office. Shortly before noon it was calculated at 43 percent in the city. Today also is Election Day in two New York City congressional districts with vacant seats. Republican City Council member Susan Molinari is expected to win the seat vacated by her father, Guy Molinari, who represented Staten Island until he quit to become borough president. Democratic Assemblyman Jose Serrano is favored to take the Bronx seat of Robert Garcia, who has been sentenced to prison for extorting payoffs in the Wedtech scandal. In the Republican race for the Illinois governor's nomination, two-term Secretary of State Jim Edgar _ who has led in the polls _ warned against complacency among his supporters, whom he billed as the real Republicans. ``We need to make sure that Republicans decide the Republican nomination for governor,'' Edgar said Monday at a Springfield rally, where he pledged to control state spending. Moderate temperatures today disappointed Edgar's opponent, conservative political organizer Steven Baer. He said at a Springfield campaign stop that he hoped for ``sub-zero weather'' to bolster his longshot campaign. ``The pro-life supporters will go to the polls anyway,'' said Baer, who has attacked Edgar for supporting abortion rights and extension of a temporary 20 percent state income-tax increase. State Attorney General Neil Hartigan, unopposed in the Democratic primary, faces the GOP winner in November. Four-term Republican Gov. James R. Thompson is not seeking re-election. Edgar has the support of President Bush and GOP National Chairman Lee Atwater, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday. A third GOP gubernatorial candidate, Dr. Robert Marshall of Burr Ridge, has ran a low-profile campaign. Age has been an issue in the challenge to 40-year House veteran Yates, 80, by first-term Chicago Alderman Edwin Eisendrath, 32, in the 9th Congressional District on the North Side and in some north suburbs. Yates complained Eisendrath had maligned him with a campaign pamphlet that ranked Yates with an antique typewriter and a vintage car. ``What I've said is he doesn't have the experience for the job,'' Yates said. Eisendrath contended Yates is just out of touch. ``Sid Yates is no Claude Pepper,'' he added, referring to the late Florida Democrat, a congressional champion of elderly rights. Savage, a 10-year House member from the predominantly black 2nd District, used a weekend rally to say his main challenger, educator and Rhodes Scholar Melvin Reynolds, 38, is taking money from pro-Israel donors outside the district. At a commuter-station campaign stop Monday, Reynolds said Savage wasn't focusing on issues. ``In the shuffle, it's clear that people lose out,'' he said. Only two other incumbents faced challenges in Illinois' 22 U.S. House districts _ Chicago Democrats Charles Hayes in the 1st and Cardiss Collins in the 7th. The top Cook County job opened up for the first time in 21 years when George W. Dunne, 76, announced he was retiring. There was intense last-minute campaigning by front-runners Richard Phelan, special counsel in the House ethics committee's investigation of former House Speaker Jim Wright, and Eugene Pincham, a former state appellate judge. Also seeking the Democratic nomination were Cook County Clerk Stanley Kusper and the party's endorsed candidate, state Sen. Ted Lechowicz, who placed third in a late poll. U.S. Sen. Paul Simon and his Republican challenger, U.S. Rep. Lynn Martin, were unopposed in their primaries. Two Republicans and four Democrats were seeking nominations to Martin's 16th Congressional District seat in northwestern Illinois.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Approves Tough Money Laundering Law
DOC.TEXT: Parliament has approved a law that makes money laundering a crime punishable by fines of up to $666,000 and five years imprisonment. The legislation, which takes effect July 1, was approved by the upper house Council of States late Monday and was hailed by a deputy as an international pace-setter. The National Council, or lower house, adopted the measure last November. Both votes were unanimous. Professionals in the financial sector who fail to exercise ``due care'' in obtaining the identification of customers risk drawing unspecified fines or terms of up to one year in jail. Rene Rhinow, head of the commission that wrote the bill, told the Council of States that the law would give Switzerland a leading position in the fight against organized crime. Justice Minister Arnold Koller said the government was examining measures that would require people crossing into Switzerland with large amounts of cash to declare the money to customs. He said this may involve amounts between $33,300 and $66,600. Switzerland has been rocked by several money laundering cases in the past two years. Last November, a parliamentary commission criticized prosecuting authorities for not doing enough to fight international crime, including the drugs and arms trade. Under the Swiss system, possible opponents of the law now have three months to seek a national referendum by collecting at least 50,000 signatures. Barring such move, which is not expected, the law would enter into force July 1.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Hopes for Peaceful Change for Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6 grafs after 4th graf pvs `We want ...' to UPDATE with comment from Foley, Gingrich. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `The United...' ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he hopes the breakaway republic of Lithuania will experience peaceful change and self-determination. Bush was asked by reporters at the outset of a meeting with congressional leaders if he was concerned that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev might order a military crackdown on the breakaway republic. ``I'm glad that they're still talking peaceful change. That's essential,'' Bush said. ``That's what everybody wants to see is peaceful evolution in Lithuania. ``We want to see democracy and freedom. We want to see self-determination and we also want to see peacful evolution, and that is in the interest of Eastern Europe as they begin to solidify their democracy,'' said Bush, who is welcoming the new non-communist prime minister of Poland, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, to the White House on Wednesday. After the meeting, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., praised Bush's response to the Lithuanian independence movement. ``I think the president's approaching that matter with caution and discretion,'' he said. ``I think the president and the United States has made it clear that we expect the Soviets to hold to their promise not to use force with reference to Eastern Europe or with reference to the Balkan states.'' Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the House minority whip, said it would be ``utterly stupid'' for Bush to be lecturing Gorbachev in public about what to do on Lithuania. ``The United States has never recognized the Soviet conquest of Lithuania. ... I presume that we are prepared to help those folks, but that we also recognize that militarily they're only going to become as free as the Russian military and the Soviet government permit,'' said Gingrich, a leading conservative. ``If the Soviets decide on force, if they decide on military occupation, then there is plenty of time to react. But as long as you have a hope that ... Gorbachev is genuinely maneuvering to find a way to accommodate Lithuanian desires without destroying the Soviet Union, I think it's prudent for us to be a little calm and a little patient. ``This guy's been amazing so far,'' Gingrich said. ``And I don't think we ought to try to pretend either that we have the military power to force anything or that we are dramatically smarter than the Lithuanians and Russians.'' The United States has urged the Soviet Union to respect the will of the Lithuanian people, but it has not formally recognized the breakaway republic. It says it will delay a decision on recognition until the new government in Lithuania establishes control over its territory. The Soviet government warned Lithuania Monday not to erect customs posts, introduce its own currency or take over Moscow-run factories without Kremlin permission. The televised announcement did not say what would happen if Lithuania ignored the warning, but Soviet troops in the past day have carried out military maneuvers in the republic that Lithuanians say are aimed at intimidation. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis denied that his Baltic republic plans to seize state enterprises and sell them to private owners, and called the harsh warning from Moscow a negotiating ploy.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Namibian History
With AM-Namibia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Highlights in the history of Namibia, which becomes the world's newest nation Wednesday: 1884 _ Declared a German protectorate. 1915 _ Occupied by South Africa on behalf of the Allies during World War I. 1920 _ League of Nations gives South Africa administrative mandate. 1966 _ United Nations cancels mandate. South Africa rejects the resolution. The South-West Africa People's Organization begins guerrilla war against South African rule. 1975 _ SWAPO acquires bases in Angola after that country's independence from Portugal. 1978 _ U.N. Security Council passes Resolution 435, calling for cease-fire, elections under U.N. supervision, and independence. 1982 _ South Africa agrees to grant independence if Cuban troops leave Angola, where they are support the Marxist government in a civil war against guerrillas aided by the United States and South Africa. 1988 _ The United States, the Soviet Union, Angola, Cuba and South Africa sign an agreement on Namibian independence, withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola, and an end to South African aid to Angolan anti-government guerrillas. February 1989 _ U.N. forces begin arriving. April 1, 1989 _ Independence process begins, but fighting breaks out between South African police forces and hundreds of SWAPO guerrillas crossing the border. More than 330 men die before a cease-fire is reimposed. July, 1989 _ More than 40,000 exiles begin returning home. November 1989 _ SWAPO wins the most votes in a U.N.-supervised election, but not enough to avoid compromising with other parties on a constitution which establishes a Western-style democracy. The last South African troops leave. Wednesday _ Namibia becomes independent.

DOC.HEAD: Dearborn School Apologizes for Survey of Arab Stereotypes
DOC.TEXT: A survey meant to assess high school students' attitudes toward Arab-Americans did more to inspire negative images than battle them, critics said. The survey was developed by teacher Ron Webb and 13 students in his advanced journalism class at Dearborn High School. Among other things, it asked non-Arab students whether they thought Arabs dealt drugs, had poor hygiene habits or avoided taxes. School officials issued a letter of apology Monday following an outcry from Arab-American students, parents and community leaders. ``We are disappointed with ourselves that, in attempting to measure anti-Arabic prejudice among non-Arabic students at Dearborn High School, we inadvertently insulted those whose problems ... we were attempting to expose, deal with and rectify,'' Principal Ann Superko wrote. The questions created tensions that hadn't existed at the school, where 10 percent of the 1,000 students are Arab-American. ``The survey didn't give them any chance to say good things,'' said freshman Ali Chami. ``Arabs don't pay taxes? We paid $4,600 in property taxes. I do not want to walk around the rest of my life apologizing for being Arabic,'' said Chami's mother, Fay, a Lebanese-American. Webb said he received threatening phone calls after the survey was distributed last week. He canceled an edition of the school newspaper that was to have reported its results. ``I didn't want to insult anybody,'' he said. ``That's the last thing I wanted to do.''

DOC.HEAD: 30 Anti-Abortion Protesters Invade Hospital
DOC.TEXT: About 30 anti-abortion protesters were led away by police Tuesday after forcing their way into the operating section of a hospital where abortions are performed. About half the protesters shut themselves inside an operating room of Huriez hospital and wrote anti-abortion graffiti on the walls while their comrades blocked the entrance to the room. After more than two hours, police removed the protesters and took them to a police station in the northern industrial city. They later were released, but hospital officials said they planned to file charges of vandalism. The officials said surgery had to be postponed because the protest required the operating room to be sterilized again. Abortion has been legal in France since 1975 despite opposition from the country's powerful Roman Catholic Church. Anti-abortion groups have been active politically, but there have been few previous incidents involving forced entry into hospitals, harassment of abortion recipients, or other aggressive tactics such as those used by some anti-abortion activists in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Says Hard-Line Policies Needed to Maintain Stability
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng on Tuesday reaffirmed China's hard-line policies stemming from last year's crushing of the pro-democracy movement, attacking Western ideas and praising the superiority of socialsm. ``As we confront pressure from abroad and difficulties at home, preservation of the country's stability is a matter of paramount importance,'' Li said in a state of the nation address to open China's annual legislative session. Li stressed the importance of maintaining correct ideology to combat ``bourgeois liberalism,'' or Western ideas, and the need for more central planning and control of the economy. ``A trend toward bourgeois-liberalization thinking had run rampant during previous years,'' he told the 2,705 delegates to the National People's Congress. But, he said, ``importance has been attached afresh to ideological and political work.'' Li noted the ``soul-stirring struggles'' of 1989, including the victory over the ``counterrevolutionary rebellion'' _ the government's term for the student-led pro-democracy movement crushed by military force in June. Hundreds and perhaps thousands of people were killed in the crackdown. He said the pro-democracy movement was led by hostile forces trying to turn China into a bourgeois republic dependent on capitalist countries. In contrast to recent developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, Li proclaimed that ``come what may, socialist China will stand rock firm in the East'' and reaffirmed the leading role of the Communist Party. ``Upholding socialism is inseparable from upholding leadership by the party,'' he said, equating it with national stability and unity. Li said class struggle would continue for a long time ``and may even become acute under certain condition.'' He called for ``intensive education,'' especially of young people, in ideology and political thought. ``It is essential to distinguish clearly between socialist democracy and bourgeois democracy,'' he said. ``We must ... maintain sharp vigilance and resolutely combat this corrosive trend of thought.'' There was little response from the floor as Li droned through the 59-page, 2{-hour speech, raising his voice at a few key points to elicit applause. A few delegates clearly had fallen asleep, chins propped on chests, while other struggled to stay awake, wiping their faces with wet towels, yawning and rubbing their eyes. Behind Li on the podium, China's aged leadership held whispered conversations with each other during the speech. Senior leader Deng Xiaoping was missing from the rostrum, his seat conspicuously empty beside party chief Jiang Zemin. Zhao Ziyan, Jiang's predecessor who was purged from all party posts last summer after being accused of supporting the student-led democracy movement, also was missing. Zhao is a deputy from Sichuan province and reportedly had asked for leave from the congress. Much of Li's speech was devoted to China's struggling economy, which flourished and then overheated under Deng's economic reforms of the past decade. Li imposed tough austerity measures in 1988 to combat excessive growth and runaway inflation. He reported that those measures had cut the inflation rate to 7 percent from 30 percent a year ago, and brought economic growth to a manageable level, but said many problems, including stockpiling, rising debt and factory closures remain. ``We must not look for quick success in either economic development or reform. Similarly, we must not look for quick success in current economic improvement and rectification,'' Li said. He announced some austerity measures would be eased, including relaxing curbs on the money supply, increasing loans to enterprises, adjusting interest rates for loans and savings deposits, and increasing investment in housing and key industries. Several times, Li said economic reforms would continue, but he also called for more state control on prices and money markets, construction projects and distribution of valuable materials rather than allowing market forces to rule. Li stressed the reforms are ``designed to demonstrate the superiority of the socialist system.'' One of Li's final points was that a ``clean and honest'' government that has the faith and respect of the masses was needed to achieve the goals set forth in his report. Corruption and bureaucracy has been a major complaint of the Chinese people and was one of the rallying cries of last year's democracy movement.

DOC.HEAD: Gadhafi Calls For Moslem Boycott Of U.S., Britain, West Germany
DOC.TEXT: Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi today urged a Moslem economic boycott against the United States, Britain and West Germany and said no Islamic country should have diplomatic ties with those nations. Libya has said it suspects the United States, Israel and West Germany are behind last Wednesday's fire at a Libyan plant that allegedly produced poison gas. The three countries have denied any involvement. Gadhafi's remarks, carried by the official Libyan news agency JANA and monitored in Rome, made no mention of the fire. But the report said Gadhafi accused the United States and its allies of conducting a campaign of subversion against Islamic countries. It quoted Gadhafi as saying that any peace with the United States is deception and hypocrisy. He also said there should be no U.S., British or West German embassies in any Islamic state. Libya has diplomatic relations with West Germany, but the United States and Britain severed ties with Libya years ago. Gadhafi was quoted as saying the Moslem world is facing a historic struggle with a ``hostile satanic force'' and that ``no Islamic country should establish relations with the U.S. government and its allies. Rather, we should have a decisive and perpetual boycott against them.'' Libya contends the plant near Rabta, about 60 miles southwest of Tripoli, produced pharmaceuticals, but the United States and West Germany say it produced poison gas. Libya's ambassador to Italy, Rahman Shalgam, told Italian journalists in Rome Monday that several people suspected of causing the fire had been detained. He also said a ``member of the technical staff'' apparently set the fire, which he said caused ``damage of great proportions.'' U.S. officials say the plant is now inoperable. JANA quoted Gadhafi as saying no ship or plane from the United States, Britain or West Germany should be allowed in ``the land of Islam.'' He appealed to Islamic countries to ``boycott completely the forces of evil on this planet.'' The United States attacked Libyan targets three times in the 1980s, twice shooting down Libyan fighter planes and in 1986 bombing Tripoli and Benghazi to retaliate for what it called Libya's support of international terrorism. Some of the U.S. warplanes that attacked Libya in 1986 came from bases in Britain. Britain broke diplomatic ties with Libya in April 1984 after a London policewoman was shot to death during a Libyan dissident demonstration. Britain said she was killed by a Libyan firing from inside the Libyan embassy. President Reagan ordered economic sanctions against Libya in January 1986. President Bush, citing Libya's continued support for terrorism, extended those sanctions last Jan. 4.

DOC.HEAD: Lovely Ethnic Styles Look Sexy at Ungaro
DOC.TEXT: Emanuel Ungaro's luxury ready-to-wear show Tuesday did more for the rich peasant look from the East than anybody since Yves Saint Laurent brought out folklore from the steppes in 1976. And Ungaro made it sexy in a Parisian way that only master tailor and colorist could pull off. It was his best ready-to-wear show in many seasons. Everything was there in an up-to-date melding of East and West. Ungaro took flower-printed long velvet skirts and topped them with shimmery lame blouses or flowered vests and rich, quilted velvet short jackets and Russian army hats or pillboxes with tassels. Color ran riot in this show that had plenty of sophisticated smooth-wool daytime suits with bicolor waist-fitted tops, in eye-catching shades like violet, carmine or peacock with charcoal, emphasizing feminine curves. But the sexy message was there, this time in good taste. A voluptuous model looked fancy but fetching in a decollete silk jersey blouse and wrapped flowered satin long high-waisted skirt ornamented by a bright pink taffeta bow and jeweled pin. The skirt was split to show plenty of leg. The whole thing was topped by a royal blue taffeta-lined multicolored velvet jacket. Ungaro used loads of metallic soft leathers in brief minis, sleek long pants, quilted anoraks. But he also mixed these up with colorful printed silk velvets, satin tunics, throwing in beautifully cut checked suits and straight pants. His lame-shot silk print chiffon blouses will be coveted by anybody with a yearning to shimmer and shine, at any time of day. A new fashion message beaming from Paris: it's OK to look fairly glitzy even for lunch, as long as you do it tastefully. Part of Ungaro's new exuberance was high, knee-covering boots worn with the minis, the most sensational in flowered prints and brocades. The glory of this collection was that one can choose. Pile on the opulence to flaunt it, or pare things down to the Ungaro details _ all excellent. Even the ``little black dress,'' a strapless short sheath, was perfectly dressed up by strands of pearls and cabochon stones, topped by an airy black organza shrug. At Guy Laroche, the boutique-line designer Guy Douvier got all the trends right in an upbeat collection full of the current colors and silhouettes. While Ungaro's ``Parallele'' line is expensive, a suit upward of $2,000 or more, the somewhat simpler but still fashionable Laroche offerings are well-made, and cost about half as much. He went in for flaring shortie coats, the mohair versions looking great with important patch pockets in primary colors or more subtle shades of vanilla, coral or violet. In the sporty lines, Douvier showed good long cable-knit collegiate pullovers or silver-buttoned cardigans over tiny tweed minis. There were also great tricolor knit dresses topped by black-edged shawls. Laroche offered the currently trendy bright quilted duffels. For evening, the gold versions opened up to reveal sexy split-skirt outfits or a wonderful brown and lame pleated lace cocktail dress. One classic but novel trouser outfit here teamed an apple-green bolero and jersey pullover with narrow khaki suede pants and a fringed violet and yellow shawl printed with a wild-animal pattern. Both Ungaro and Laroche showed versions of puffy iridescent bubble short evening dresses but they somehow looked a bit passe compared with the slinkier gowns split up the leg. Laroche brought out some nice short minks and fur-lined suede duffel coats. Frederic Castet, for 20 years the fur designer at Dior, displayed his fur-lined fashions in his runway debut. He will open a shop on the rue Bassano, in the fashion area known as the ``golden triangle'' near the Champs-Elysees, celebrating the event with golden triangle adornments on belts and sunflower motifs appliqued on silk blouses. Besides the most sumptuous duffels, parkas and swirly pyramid minks in natural or dyed ruby or indigo shades, chinchilla, fox and fisher, Castet also brought out a beautiful new fake fur in woven silk called ``Castiss.'' It's a dead-ringer for sheared mink or beaver, and looks fine as duffels, parkas, or taffeta raincoat linings. Valentino brought out his usual impeccably cut outfits, often featuring a new look in tiny ``Fortuny'' or crystal pleating all over dresses in flounces or palazzo pants. He piled on satin, lace and gold-leaf appliques for an opulent effect.

DOC.HEAD: Man Awarded Millions in Slander Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A man who was acquitted in 1986 of molesting his young daughter was awarded more than $5 million in damages for being defamed by members of the audience at Geraldo Rivera's talk show. U.S. District Court Judge Maryanne Trump Barry on Monday entered a default judgment granting Lawrence Spiegel $1 million in special damages and $4 million in punitive damages. Spiegel's attorney, Stephen Haft, said Faye Yeager of Atlanta and Lydia Rayner of Gulfport, Miss., defendants in the 1988 federal slander suit, failed to file answers or appear at Monday's hearing. Haft said his client was a guest on the nationally televised show in 1988 when the defendants _ wearing wigs and sunglasses _ began berating Spiegel from the audience. He said the women, who are associated with the national group Mothers Against Raping Children, had previously harassed Spiegel during a speaking engagement in California. Spiegel was indicted in December 1983 on charges of molesting his then-2-year-old daughter. He was cleared of the charges in January 1986. ``If nothing else, I hope this sends the message that I will not be a punching bag for anyone,'' Spiegel, a psychologist from Parsippany-Troy Hills, said of the judge's decision. There were no telephone listings for Ms. Yeager in Atlanta or for Ms. Rayner in Gulfport.

DOC.HEAD: Front Victorious in Latvia, Democrats Win in Moscow, Leningrad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Reformers also ...' with 2 grafs to ADD influence of victories in Baltic republics on Gorbachev's policies; SUBS 17th graf, `Elena Zelinskaya ...' to insert description of Northwest Information Agency.
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of democratic reform won victories across the Soviet Union, defeating old-guard Communists in runoff elections in the Slavic heartland and choosing independence activists in the Baltic republics. In Latvia, the People's Front claimed victory Monday in the republic's first free elections in 50 years, and a spokesman said the group came close to achieving the parliamentary majority needed to press for independence. In Estonia, pro-independence parties won at least 54 of the 105 seats in the republic's new parliament. Activists in Latvia and Estonia had hoped Sunday's parliamentary elections in the Baltics _ annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 _ would follow the lead of nearby Lithuania and bring independence supporters to power. But a spokesman for the Latvian opposition group, Kristian Rozenvald, said the People's Front will probably gain a majority in the next election round in April. The victories of the popular movements were a blow to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to slow their drives for independence. He has repeatedly condemned ``separatists'' and has refused to recognize Lithuania's self-proclaimed independence. Reformers also claimed victories in crucial runoffs Sunday in Russia, Byelorussia and the Ukraine. The Soviet Union's Slavic heartland accounts for 80 percent of the country's territory and two-thirds of its population. The reformers unseated local Communist officials who have been accused of blocking reforms advocated by Gorbachev. There were no immediate results from most towns in Russia, or from the Ukraine, and official tallies were not expected for several days. In Estonia, the Estonian People's Front won at least 38 of the 105 seats in the republic's new parliament, said Rina Lohmus, a correspondent for Estonian Radio. The radio said the Estonian Committee, a more radical independence group won at least 16 seats, and deputies from several small parties supporting the People's Front platform won several seats. Results from about 15 seats had still not been determined, Lohmus said. Although officials results were not expected until Friday, Lempi Tekone, a spokeswoman for the Estonian People's Front said the party expected to have the support of about three-quarters of the deputies. She said the Yedinstvo organization representing Russian-speaking residents would probably have about 25 percent of the seats, and Free Estonia, formed by the republic's Communist Party, won about 10 seats. Many activists said they expect the former Communist Party to cautiously support moves for independence. Throughout the Slavic republics, voters chose between candidates in 1,610 runoffs, held after no candidate gained 50 percent of the vote in the main round of parliament and local council elections March 4. According to Moscow's electoral commission, 55 out of the capital's 65 seats in Russia's parliament were won by candidates representing the reformist Democratic Russia alliance. The group also won 281 seats out of 498 in the city council, said Interfax, a news agency of Radio Moscow. In Leningrad, reformists from the Democratic Elections-90 bloc won 60 percent to 70 percent of the contested seats, the official Tass news agency said. Elena Zelinskaya of the Northwest Information Agency, an independent for-profit news agency focusing on the Leningrad area, said Communist Party members also scored some victories. They were mostly in the so-called closed electoral districts such as army units, where campaigning was not allowed. Initial results in Byelorussia showed gains for democrats, but new elections were expected in about one-quarter of the districts since none of the candidates gained 50 percent of the vote in the runoffs, Tass said. In Latvia, the People's Front said it won 118 spots in the 201-seat parliament, a large majority among the 171 delegates elected. Rozenvald said the front could get the support of 12 candidates from other parties and control 130 seats in parliament. Still, that would fall short of the two-thirds majority, or 134 seats, needed to change Latvia's constitution and declare independence. Tass reported that initial results showed the Front only won 108 seats. Lithuania's parliament declared the republic independent on March 11. Ever since, Lithuania has been engaged in a bitter conflict with Moscow, which declared the move illegal and on Monday warned it would not tolerate attempts to act on the independence declaration. Latvia followed Lithuania's example and legalized alternative political parties several months ago. No such move was made in Estonia but several parties competed there. The Soviet Congress legalized multiple political parties for the whole country last week.

DOC.HEAD: Williams Hopes to Ride Bush's Coattails into Texas Governor's Office
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 10 grafs new with visit to White House; picks up 4th graf pvs, The national party.
DOC.TEXT: Clayton Williams, the Republican nominee for governor of Texas, said today he hopes to jump on President Bush's coattails and ``ride them like a bucking bronco'' into office. Williams won a promise today from Bush to help him raise funds for November's gubernatorial election and to campaign personally for him. ``I have asked him to come and help whenever and wherever he can,'' Williams told reporters outside the White House. He said he needed Bush's help in financing an $11 million campaign. The wealthy Texas businessman told reporters he had already sunk $6.5 million of his own funds into his race and ``I'm about at the end of my rope. If I put any more in...the bankers will eat me alive.'' The candidate discussed the Texas race with Bush in the Oval Office and then had lunch with him. Williams told reporters the president ``has some wonderful coattails and I'd like to grab a-hold of them and ride them like a bucking bronco.'' Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater, who accompanied Williams, said Bush ``made it clear he will be coming to Texas and wants to help from a fund-raising standpoint. Mrs. Bush also wants to help.'' ``And let's face it,'' Atwater added, ``this is his (Bush's) home state. He loves Texas. He loves the politics of Texas.'' The RNC chairman called Williams' chances of winning the election ``much better than even....This guy is the political phenonomen of 1990.'' Williams was invited by Bush last week after he won the GOP primary for governor in a rout. He made the rounds of party offices here Monday, including a stop at the Republican Governors' Association to seek a campaign contribution. The national party didn't take sides before the primary, but association Executive Director Michele Davis said her group is ready to make a large contribution to Williams now. ``You bet,'' she said. ``I've got a request in to the executive committee for approval ... It's a chunk. ``We want to say, `Yep, we're with you,''' she said. Known as ``Claytie,'' Williams relied on a plain-spoken Texas appeal _ and a television campaign bankrolled with his own money _ to swamp his Republican opponents in the state's open primary. ``I had an old cowboy uncle who said, `Son, you don't learn anything while you're talking,''' Williams said Monday, explaining that he was doing more listening than talking during his two-day trip to Washington. With Democrats facing a bruising runoff election, Williams is the early favorite in the general election and the Republicans' hottest new political phenomenon. ``We've got a lot of new friends,'' quipped his press secretary, Bill Kenyon. Williams' success has given Republicans a boost in Texas, one of the three biggest states with governor's races this year and one the GOP places a priority on holding in anticipation of redistricting after the 1990 census. Wearing elaborately stitched black-and-white cowboy boots with his gray suit, Williams also paid calls at the Texas state office in Washington, the bipartisan National Governors' Association and the National Cattlemen's Association. Williams' cattle operations _ just one of his business ventures, along with oil and gas, banking and real estate _ make him the nation's seventh largest calf producer, Kenyon said. Williams also planned to meet with administration drug policy director William Bennett and Energy Secretary James Watkins during his Washington visit. Accompanied by his wife, Modesta, Williams first met with Republican Sen. Phil Gramm of Texas, who also is running for re-election this year, at Gramm's Senate office. They agreed last week in Houston to a joint get-out-the-vote effort. ``We talked about three things _ strategy, strategy and strategy,'' Williams said. ``I think Claytie is going to be a great partner. I know there are some that will write us off as just two pretty faces, but that's something I think we can overcome,'' Gramm quipped.

DOC.HEAD: 14 Fishermen Rescued After 12 Hours Adrift
DOC.TEXT: The navy rescued 14 fishermen who were adrift for 12 hours in a life raft on choppy seas Tuesday after their boat sank off the Madeira islands, a news agency reported. The fishermen were unharmed. They were brought aboard the patrol boat Cuanza after their inflatable raft was spotted by an air-se rescue plane, according to the Lusa news agency. Three French ships had joined the Portuguese naval and air force patrols in the search for the raft about 40 miles south of Porto Santo island, Lusa said. The fishermen sent out distress signals at dawn indicating they were abandoning their sinking vessel, the Marinho, the navy said. Madeira and Porto Santo are islands 625 miles southwest of Lisbon.

DOC.HEAD: Floods Surge Through Florida Panhandle as Alabama, Georgia Assess Damage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Restores AP logo; SUBS 13th graf, `The Pea...' to ADD river level. INSERTS three grafs after 19th, `The department...' to ADD more road closings, evacuations in Florida Panhandle. Picks up 20th graf, `Swollen rivers...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MY1A, MY2
DOC.TEXT: Muddy flood waters from last week's torrential rains in Alabama and Georgia coursed through the Florida Panhandle today, damaging homes and businesses and threatening supports for an interstate highway bridge over a raging river. Flood damage was expected to worsen in Florida, where at least 1,200 people fled their homes. Some rivers in the northern part of the state wouldn't crest until Wednesday, a National Weather Service forecaster said today. In Alabama and Georgia, authorities began assessing damage from storms that dumped up to 16 inches of rain Thursday and Friday. Flood-related accidents killed 17 people and about 4,000 fled their homes in those two states. Cold air followed receding flood waters in Alabama and Georgia today, the first day of spring. Temperatures dipped to 30 degrees this morning in Birmingham, Ala., and hovered just above freezing in Atlanta. Freezing temperatures also were recorded in Tennessee and Kentucky. A mixture of rain and snow was falling today in the nation's capital. The band of snow showers stretched from central Pennsylvania, through Maryland, central Virginia and into central North Carolina. In Virginia, 6 inches of snow fell in Lynchburg, 2 inches in Roanoke and 4 inches near Charlottesville. Alabama Gov. Guy Hunt asked President Bush for federal aid Monday for Coffee County, where the swollen Pea River burst a levee and inundated Elba, a town of 4,400 people. Hunt also requested federal aid for 25 other flooded counties in central and south Alabama, but said he would ask Bush to help Coffee County first. Some of Elba's evacuees returned Monday for their first look at the destruction. ``It didn't really hurt until I got here. Then it tore me up,'' said Mike Simmons, who returned home to find a waterline on his ceiling, overturned furniture and smaller items still floating in several inches of water. National Guardsmen and state troopers patrolled the streets enforcing a 7 p.m. curfew after some reports of looting in downtown Elba, which remained under several feet of water. Telephone, gas and electric service was out. There was another problem in Elba and elsewhere in the region: the high waters flushed out snakes, which could be seen swimming through inundated neighborhoods. The Pea River empties into the Choctawhatchee River in Florida, and its muddy water was already a foot deep in Billy Wayne Bailey's four-bedroom house in Caryville on Monday and was expected to rise another 3 feet before cresting today. The river was at 20.5 feet this morning, nearly 9 feet over flood stage. ``Well, it's already done the damage so it doesn't matter now far it goes,'' Bailey said as he looked down on his home from nearby U.S. Highway 90. ``We got out the night they showed Elba on television,'' Bailey said. ``I didn't wait for nobody to tell me. I just went ahead and left. I've been snatching other people out for the last two days.'' Washington County commissioners on Monday ordered all of Caryville's 630 residents and 200 people in surrounding communities to move to higher ground. Hundreds more fled voluntarily. A 20-mile stretch of west-bound Interstate 10, from Bonifay to DeFuniak Springs, was closed by state transportation officials Monday afternoon because of concern about erosion around the supports of the highway's bridge over the Choctawhatchee. The Choctawhatchee Bridge, a 2,000-foot span on I-10 West, will be closed until a contractor hired by the state Department of Transportation can repair the pilings, said state Transportation Department spokesman Tommie Speights. The department will hire another contractor to build a temporary crossover road connecting the westbound lane with another bridge that heads east on the interstate, allowing one-lane traffic in both directions, Speights said. Flooding in Caryville forced the closure of U.S. Highway 90, which parallel's I-10 two miles to the north, and State Route 279 which connects the two federal highways, said Ginger Vance, a spokeswoman for Washington County. In neighboring Holmes County, about 150 residents evacuated areas north of Caryville, said James Merchant, county emergency management director. Flooding also forced evacuations along the Apalachicola River near Bloutstown, Escambia River near Cantonment and the Blackwater River near Milton. Swollen rivers swamped sewage-treatment plants in Atlanta and Macon, Ga. Macon officials ordered residents to boil water after flood waters swamped a water-treatment plant. But Macon's levee, reinforced by sandbags, held. The Ocmulgee River crested 4 feet below the levee's top. ``We're glad we dodged the bullet,'' said Larry Brown, acting director of Macon's public works department.

DOC.HEAD: Independence Marks End of Colonialism in Africa
With AM-Namibia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The independence of Namibia, the last colony in Africa, marks the end of colonial rule on a continent once carved up and ruled by European powers hungry for imperial glory. Tuesday's end of South African rule in the vast arid territory after 75 years also marks the end of a process that began in 1957 when Ghana became the first European colony in Africa to become independent. In the years since, some 50 African nations have emerged from colonial rule to become independent. Namibia's peaceful independence after a 23-year bush war between South African forces and nationalist black guerrillas has added to hopes that South Africa's racial divisions may also be resolved peacefully. Nearly all of Africa except for Ethiopia and Liberia was divided up between the European powers in what historians call ``The Scramble for Africa,'' mainly in the 19th century. The colonization of Africa, according to the historian Basil Davidson, meant Africans ``had lost their independence, and, with this, their capacity to develop along their own lines.'' ``They had lost, in short, the command of their own history,'' he wrote. While European colonization of Africa began with the Portugese in the 15th century, most of the continent was carved up by Britain and France in the late 19th century. The two imperial powers took over huge tracts of territory across the continent, sweeping aside African resistance. Even minor powers such as Belgium, Spain and Portugal carved out colonies far larger than their own size. The king of Belgium ran the huge Belgian Congo as a private enterprise. Much of the territory gobbled up by the European powers was jungle, desert and swamps of little value. Few of the colonies ever did more than consume the funds of the colonial mother country and never produced the wealth predicted by colonial officials. The European officials and soldiers who served in these far-flung colonies in the early days had notoriously short lives. British officials in some fever-ridden West African colonies never booked return ship tickets, because so few completed their tours of duty. West Africa was called `The White Man's Grave.' ``Death was accepted as part of the day's work,'' said one British colonial civil servant. Despite the worthlessness of many of these colonies, the European powers competed frantically to snap up African territory. Empires and colonies gave enormous prestige and Europeans of all classes gloried in their nation's foreign possessions. The pursuit of colonies added to the international tensions that dragged Europe into World War I in 1914. When the war came, little colonial armies fought each other in Africa, with British and French troops seizing Germany's colonies. A German army of a few thousand men, mainly African troops, held out in East Africa until the end of the war in 1918, fighting off much larger English, Indian, South African, Belgian and Portuguese forces. Namibia, then called South West Africa, was a German colony captured by South African forces during the war. But the European powers gave up their African colonies relatively easily after World War II when colonialism started to go out of fashion and liberation movements sprang up in Africa. Britain and France released most of their African colonies. Only Portugal put up a long, bitter fight to try to retain Angola, Mozambique and its other possessions, but conceded defeat in the mid-1970s. South Africa also fought for years to retain Namibia, until its leaders concluded the war against the South West African Peoples Organization was no longer feasible. SWAPO won subsequent elections in 1989. Now South Africa is the sole portion of Africa that remains under white rule. But white South Africans reject radicals' assertions that their nation also is a colony. White settlement in South Africa dates back 350 years and the politically dominant Afrikaners of Dutch descent regard themselves as Africans with no other home. Recognizing the change in African history, South African President F.W. de Klerk has said whites must find a new way to live in their country and he has started to work toward the end of white-minority rule. De Klerk says South Africans must seek a peaceful solution, as in Namibia, or face the threat of a race war he warns would last for generations.
Editor's Note _ Barry Renfrew is the AP bureau chief for South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Government Concludes Its Case Against Poindexter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra prosecutors wrapped up their criminal case against former national security adviser John Poindexter today after 7{ days of testimony from 10 witnesses. Lawyers for Poindexter were to open their defense this afternoon. Videotaped testimony by former President Reagan, obtained at the request of Poindexter's lawyers, is expected to be shown in court. The government's last witness, a Senate staffer, said it seemed ``strange'' that Poindexter knew so little about a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Poindexter is accused of concealing from Congress the U.S. role in the Hawks shipment and Oliver North's military assistance and fund raising for the Contras. North was the government's main witness against Poindexter, but testified reluctantly against his old boss. The former White House aide said he watched Poindexter tear up a presidential document ratifying the 1985 Hawks shipment. Poindexter told Sens. David Durenberger and Patrick Leahy that he had learned of the Hawks shipment only in January 1986, Senate staffer Eric Newsome testified. Poindexter's discussion with Durenberger and Leahy took place just hours before the national security adviser destroyed the finding, a politically embarrassing document which depicted U.S. involvement in Iran arms sales as a straight arms-for-hostages deal. ``It did seem strange to me that he didn't know more than he did about the Hawks shipment,'' testified Newsome, who took notes in an hour-long discussion in Poindexter's White House office on Nov. 21, 1986. Poindexter also told Durenberger and Leahy that it was ``unclear whether there was prior knowledge'' of the shipment by U.S. officials, testified Newsome, reading from a memo he typed up after the meeting. Durenberger, R-Minn., was chairman at the time of the Senate intelligence committee. Leahy, D-Vt., was vice chairman of the panel. On Monday, Rep. Lee Hamilton testified that Poindexter failed to tell the House intelligence committee about a presidential document that approved the missile shipment to Iran. Then-CIA Director William Casey said the document didn't exist, said Hamilton. Poindexter said ``the U.S. government had not approved'' and ``did not know about'' the shipment, said Hamilton. He was chairman of the House intelligence committee, which met with Poindexter just before he met with Durenberger and Leahy. The trial was continuing today with the government's final witnesses. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene denied a defense motion for a mistrial Monday after some of Hamilton's testimony touched on statements that Poindexter gave Congress in 1987 under immunity from prosecution. Hamilton said Monday that ``almost the first words that Admiral Poindexter said'' when he walked into the meeting were that ``President Reagan ... wanted to tell the full story.'' ``When Mr. Poindexter was making statements about Iran arms you believed him?'' asked Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb. ``I did,'' Hamilton replied. Webb questioned the congressman about the presidential authorization document, called a finding. ``He didn't tell you at all about the 1985'' document? Webb asked. ``I didn't know there was such a finding,'' Hamilton replied. In a separate meeting the same day, Casey told the intelligence committee there was no document authorizing the shipment of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran, Hamilton said. ``Do you remember Casey in that testimony actually telling you there was no finding for that 1985 shipment?'' Webb asked Hamilton. ``I do,'' the congressman replied. A year before, Casey had sent the finding directly to Poindexter for President Reagan's signature. Casey attached a note to Poindexter saying the finding ``should not be passed around in any hands below our level.'' Hours after Casey's and Poindexter's discussions with Congress, Poindexter destroyed the politically embarrassing presidential document. It depicted U.S. involvement in Iran arms sales as a straight arms-for-hostages deal. The former national security adviser is accused of concealing from Congress Oliver North's military assistance to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua and the U.S. role in the missile shipment to Iran. Earlier in the day, Webb inadvertently brought out some of Poindexter's immunized congressional testimony in questioning Hamilton about the presidential finding. Had Poindexter ever reported destroying the document? Webb asked. ``He did,'' Hamilton said in front of the jury. The congressman, c-chairman of a special congressional committee that investigated the Iran-Contra affair, was referring to Poindexter's July 1987 testimony to the committee, during which he said he tore up the document. No part of the case against Poindexter may be derived from his testimony to Congress, given under a grant of immunity from prosecution. Webb rephrased the question, but defense attorney Richard Beckler asked for a mistrial, saying that Hamilton had specifically been instructed not to refer to Poindexter's immunized testimony. Greene denied the motion, saying that North testified last week that he watched Poindexter tear up the finding. Greene said Hamilton's testimony was ``cumulative rather than harmful.'' Beckler suggested the jury might not find North's testimony credible. But Greene also noted that ``both the government and the defense referred to tearing up of the finding'' in their opening statements to the jury. ``And you have great credibility,'' the judge told Beckler. The information about tearing up the finding ``is not new at all,'' Greene concluded. In his opening statement, Beckler said Poindexter tore up the document ``because it was not accurate'' in portraying the arms shipments solely as an attempt to free American hostages held in Lebanon. Beckler noted that it was replaced by another finding that portrayed the arms shipments as an attempt to establish a more moderate government in Iran as well as to further the release of the hostages.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Successfully Concludes Practice Countdown
DOC.TEXT: NASA today successfully concluded a two-day practice countdown for space shuttle Discovery's April flight to deploy the Hubble Space Telescope. Five astronauts were in the shuttle's cockpit for the final two hours of the launch day dress rehearsal, intended to train ground controllers and the flight crew. ``Overall, we had a smooth countdown, with nothing that would preclude launching Discovery and the Hubble Space Telescope on April 12,'' said George Diller, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``All space shuttle systems performed as expected,'' Diller said. April 12 is the target date for Discovery to begin its five-day mission to put the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. NASA officials will set a firm date early next month. From space, the telescope will have a clear view of faraway galaxies that scientist believe will provide detailed information about the formation of the universe. The 94-inch telescope is named for Edwin P. Hubble, an astronomer in the 1920s and 1930s. Discovery's crew members are Air Force Col. Loren J. Shriver, the commander; Marine Col. Charles F. Bolden, Jr., the pilot; and mission specialists Steven A. Hawley, Navy Capt. Bruce McCandless II and Kathryn Sullivan.

DOC.HEAD: Former DEA Agent Ordered Held Without Bail Pending Trial
DOC.TEXT: A former federal drug agent accused of narcotics trafficking and money laundering was denied bail pending his trial. U.S. District Judge Terry J. Hatter Jr. ruled Monday that Darnell Garcia was likely to flee and a danger to the community if bail were set. A Sept. 4 trial date was set for Garcia and two other former U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents, John Jackson and Wayne Countryman. Prosecutors contend the agents stole drugs confiscated during DEA raids. Authorities say the agents sold the drugs, laundered narcotics profits and leaked information to drug dealers about federal investigations against them. Garcia, of Rancho Palos Verdes, traveled around the world after he was suspended in 1987 during a corruption investigation, authorities said. Garcia reportedly spent time in Rio De Janeiro, Madrid, Paris, Frankfurt and Luxembourg before he was arrested last July for a passport violation. He was extradited from Luxembourg in February. Garcia originally was charged in 26 of the 42 counts in the indictment, but was extradited on six counts. He pleaded innocent Monday to one count of stealing heroin from the DEA and one of possession with intent to distribute heroin. Defense attorney Mary Gibbons said she will challenge the other counts involving money laundering and conspiracy because they were ``not within the extradition treaty'' between the U.S. and the tiny Western European country. In January, a judge ordered Jackson held without bail and set bond for Countryman at $120,000.

DOC.HEAD: Independence Attacts Celebrants From Around The Globe
With AM-Namibia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A white Briton quit his job in London to fly to Namibia. A black Namibian rose before dawn Tuesday to drive six hours across the desert. A teacher used the new Constitution to instruct students. Independence in Africa's last colony drew tens of thousands of celebrants in Windhoek, each for their own reasons. ``Independence doesn't mean you can be lazy, it means hard work, taking responsibility so that you can be a leader,'' said Usko Shivute, a history teacher. He uses Namibia's democratic, Western-style Constitution to teach the values of free speech and respect for the opinions of others, he said. He also tries to keep a lid on the rising expectations that come with independence. ``Nothing will be free,'' Shivute tells his students. ``But now we will have more opportunity.'' Shivute helped plan the weeklong independence celebrations in Windhoek, the modern capital and largest city with about 120,000 people. Nightly parties were planned. The new red, blue and green flag with a golden sun in one corner waved from virtually every shop on Kaiser Street, the main throughfare. ``Namibia, Free At Last,'' said bumper stickers. Posters on the roadside showed black and white children arm in arm under the heading, ``Our Free Nation.'' Dozens of foreign leaders and thousands of diplomats and journalists arrived in Windhoek, a city with less than 500 hotel rooms. The small airport, about 30 miles outside Windhoek in the scrub brush of the Namibian countryside, was expected to handle nearly 100 flights Tuesday, up from the usual average of six. Due to lack of space, planes dropped their passengers then took off again to park in neighboring countries. ``I want to see (Libyan leader) Moammar Gadhafi,'' said Ben Goagoseb, 26. ``We have heard so much about him and he has always identified with our struggle for independence.'' Goagoseb and other young black men said Gadhafi was the foreign figure they most wanted to see, even more so than South African black leader Nelson Mandela. Gadhafi was invited, but it was uncertain whether he would attend. Dokes Tjitombo and his brother, Alex, rose before dawn Tuesday and drove six hours from Namibia's northeast corner to Windhoek for the celebrations. ``We just came for a day because we wanted to see independence,'' said Tjitombo, a 35-year-old driver wearing a T-shirt with the new national flag emblazoned on the chest. David Maxwell quit his job at a London brokerage firm in October and came to Namibia to witness the independence process. ``There's a spirit of good will from blacks and whites. I think both sides are willing to bury the past,'' said Maxwell. Maxwell, 29, was living in South Africa in 1980 when neighboring, white-ruled Rhodesia became black-ruled Zimbabwe. ``There was much more hostility there than in Namibia,'' said Maxwell. ``Whites are a bit nervous (in Namibia), but they are much more positive about the future.''

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Says Government Can't Bar Clinics from Suggesting Abortion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `The Webster ..., to DELETE erroneous reference to Webster ruling upholding ban on counseling, since ruling did not uphold that portion of Missouri law; pick up 12th graf, `Judge Juan ...
DOC.TEXT: A federal regulation that prohibits government-funded family planning clinics from discussing abortion with clients is an unconstitutional infringement on freedom of speech, an appeals court has ruled. The 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, said in a ruling released late Monday that the speech at issue involves telling a woman about an activity _ abortion _ ``in which she has a constitutional right to engage.'' Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon and attorneys for various family planning groups challenged the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services for enforcing the family planning regulations in 1988. The regulations prohibited people in medical facilities that received money under the federal Title X program from counseling women about abortion and from referring pregnant women to any facilities that perform abortion. The court said in its 4-1 decision that the secretary of Health and Human Services has tried to use funding ``to limit public discussion on abortion rights. It is by now black letter law that such a restriction is a violation of the First Amendment.'' Lucy Eddinger, a spokeswoman for the HHS Office of Population Affairs, said this morning that the federal government had not had time to review the case. ``We understand there has been a decision, but no one has seen that decision, so we won't have a comment until we have read it,'' Eddinger said. The ruling is binding only in the 1st Circuit, which has jurisdiction over Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Puerto Rico. Other circuits can be expected to be influenced by it, however. The appeals court affirmed a decision by U.S. District Court Judge Walter Skinner. In May, three judges of the 1st Circuit ruled in favor of the state, upholding the injunction that blocked the ban on referrals from taking effect. But when the U.S. Supreme Court handed down a decision in the Missouri case of Webster vs. Reproductive Health Services two months later, the federal government asked the 1st Circuit to rehear the arguments. The Webster decision gave states broader discretion to set limits on abortion. Judge Juan Torruella, who dissented in Monday's ruling, cited the Webster decision. ``In my opinion, the secretary has merely refused to fund an activity which the government is not constitutionally required to support, without imposing legal obstacles to a citizen's choice of action in a protected area,'' Torruella said. Ruling in favor of the state were Chief Judge Levin Campbell and Judges Hugh Bownes, Stephen Breyer and Bruce Selya.

DOC.HEAD: Six Injured in Fire at Refinery in Northwestern Britain
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and fire struck a major oil refinery early Tuesday, injuring six workers, authorities said. Firefighters brought the blaze under control at the Shell chemical processing plant at Stanlow in northwest Britain, said a spokesman for Shell U.K. Ltd. The plant occupies a half-acre site inside the refinery, which is on the southern bank of the River Mersey and about 10 miles from the port city of Liverpool. Ten people were in the plant at the time of the blast, and six were injured, including one person with serious burns, the BBC reported. The BBC said nobody was evacuated from the area. The cause of the explosion was being investigated, the Shell spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Fear of Malpractice Slows Spread of New Heart Attack Treatment
DOC.TEXT: Many heart attack victims are being denied life-saving new treatment because doctors fear they will be sued if their patients suffer strokes, a rare but devastating complication of the therapy, specialists say. New clot-dissolving medicines can literally stop a heart attack if given within a few hours after the start of chest pains. But many heart doctors believe this treatment has been too slow to catch on in the United States. Heart attack victims often wait too long before going to the hospital to be able to benefit from the treatment. However, many others don't get the medicine even when they arrive at the emergency room in time. The reasons vary, but some advocates of aggressive treatment say their colleagues' fear of malpractice suits has played an important role. ``This has been one of the main impediments to the proliferation of treatment in the United States,'' said Dr. Robert Califf of Duke University. Califf raised the issue at this week's meeting of the American College of Cardiology. Many other heart specialists said they agreed. ``There is no doubt in my mind that it affects physicians' choice of therapy,'' said Dr. William B. Smith of Tulane University. ``The fear of lawsuits is real.'' When all goes well, the new drugs, known as thrombolytic agents, clearly save lives. A heart attack usually occurs when a blood clot gets stuck in the arteries that feed the heart. Within a few hours, a section of the heart muscle dies. But if given quickly, the drugs can dissolve the clot, preventing most of the damage. In studies, the treatment typically has reduced the heart attack death rate from 12 percent to 6 percent. But because the therapy interferes with the body's normal tendency to make blood clots, the treatment can trigger a major side effect: unwanted bleeding. In most parts of the body, such bleeding can be controlled. But if a blood vessel spews blood inside the brain, doctors are powerless to stop it, and the result is often a crippling stroke. Such strokes occur in about one in 200 or 300 people who receive the clot-dissolving drugs. Doctors routinely exclude people at high risk of bleeding from receiving the treatment. These include those with high blood pressure, the elderly and victims of prior strokes. Under current guidelines, about 25 percent of all heart attack victims are considered to be good candidates for clot-dissolving therapy. Estimates vary, but experts say that probably only about 5 percent actually get this treatment in the United States. Califf said he already has been sued because of a stroke resulting from the heart attack treatment. He added that many other doctors have said they are reluctant to offer the therapy because of fear of lawsuits. ``You simply can't have a bad outcome in the United States without someone asking, `Was it the doctor's fault?''' he said. Dr. Peter Rentrop of St. Vincent's Hospital in New York noted that a malpractice lawsuit can be professionally and financially damaging.
