So doctors consider the legal as well as the medical risks of clot-dissolving therapy. ``You always have to ask: `If the patient has a complication, do I have a strong defense?''' Rentrop said. ``If I have a weak defense, I have an obligation to myself and my family not to treat.'' Surgeons routinely accept the risk that some proportion of their patients will not survive operations. Dr. Jeremy Swan of the University of California, Los Angeles said internists, too, should be able to live with a small risk that their therapy will be lethal. ``They will not suffer malpractice suits if they can show that they followed accepted standards,'' he said. Dr. Keith Fox of the University of Edinburgh in Scotland cautioned that doctors who don't offer clot-dissolving drugs also may be sued for failure to properly treat heart attacks, and several such lawsuits have been filed in Europe. ``The evidence in relation to benefit is very clear,'' he said, ``and we are seeing this on both sides of the Atlantic.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawn Mower Crash Leads to Houdini-Style Escape
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested a man _ twice _ after he allegedly caused a four-car accident with a stolen lawn mower and then commandeered a patrol car while his hands were cuffed behind his back. Police Officer T.L. Bailey gave chase in a borrowed a pickup truck, spotted his parked cruiser and arrested Earl Thomas Pryce, 28, of High Point, after a chase on foot. The incident began Monday when a riding lawn mower that was being towed with a 10-foot rope began weaving and was hit by a truck. Two other cars collided as they tried to avoid the scattered parts. Police arrested Pryce, handcuffed him and belted him into the front passenger seat of a patrol car, according to Lt. T. Shuler. With Pryce in the car, Bailey began questioning the drivers of the other cars. At that point, Shuler said, Pryce ``got out of the seatbelt and slid under the driver's wheel and left the scene in the police car. It's wild.'' The cruiser was found about a mile away, parked behind a business. Shuler said Pryce ran, ``and we chased him for about another half-hour after that.'' Pryce initially was charged with driving while impaired, driving while his license was revoked and having improper registration. He later was charged with larceny of a motor vehicle, hit and run causing personal injury, and careless and reckless driving. He also was charged with larceny in connection with the theft of the lawn mower earlier in the day.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Buys War Medals Of French Resistance Heroine
DOC.TEXT: Seven medals awarded to a French Resistance heroine who smuggled out British agents and details of German V1 and V2 rockets have been bought by the Imperial War Museum for $28,500, it was announced Tuesday. Berthe Fraser was best known for smuggling the British agent code-named ``The White Rabbit'' through a German encampment in a mock funeral along with details of the secret German weapons. Christie's auctioneers said the museum's bid for the medals and accompanying documents was four times higher than its estimated value of $6,000 to $9,000. It said they were sold by private collector W. H. Fevyer. Mrs. Fraser began helping British servicemen in 1940 and soon was plotting escape routes for them. She organized a mock funeral to smuggle Cmdr. Forest Yeo-Thomas out of France in November 1943, hiding him in a hearse under flowers and the weapon plans inside the coffin. A German patrol inspected the cortege, but didn't find them. Mrs. Fraser was twice captured by the Germans, but refused to betray the Resistance despite torture and threatened execution. She was liberated by the Allies on Sept. 2, 1944. The French-born heroine was awarded Britain's George Medal for heroism, France's Legion of Honor, the senior award for gallantry and France's Croix de Guerre for military service. She never fully regained her health after her wartime imprisonment and died in 1956.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Union Members May be Entitled to Jury Trials in Suits
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that workers who sue their unions for allegedly failing to represent them fairly may be entitled to jury trials to settle the issue. By a 6-3 vote, the court said union members must be given jury trials if their suits seek monetary compensation such as back pay. The decision is a victory for 27 truck drivers who sued a North Carolina local of the Teamsters union. ``The money damages (the drivers) seek are the type of relief traditionally awarded by courts of law,'' Justice Thurgood Marshall wrote for the court. ``Thus, the (Constitution's) Seventh Amendment entitles (them) to a jury trial.'' Justices Anthony M. Kennedy, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia dissented. Lawsuits accusing unions of breaching their duty of fair representation usually are tried before judges without juries. Such suits generally seek to end some asserted unfair treatment or to force a union into taking some action. In most such cases, an employer also is sued and charged with breaching a collective-bargaining agreement. To win money damages, a union member generally must prove the employer violated the union contract and that the union breached its fair-representation duty. Local 391 of the Teamsters union was sued by 27 truck drivers in 1983, after they had been transferred from various locations to the McLean Trucking Co.'s terminal in Winston-Salem, N.C. The 27 had been laid off and recalled on several occasions after their move to Winston-Salem. Their lawsuit contends that McLean breached a collective-bargaining agreement by manipulating recall procedures so it could give other drivers preference, and that Local 391 failed to represent them fairly in the resulting grievances. McLean went bankrupt after the suit was filed and was dropped as a defendant. The suit seeks from the Teamsters, among other things, compensatory damages for lost wages and benefits. As a result of Tuesday's ruling, the suit will reach a jury. In a separate decision, the court unanimously reinstated a lawsuit by a black machinist who says he was fired illegally from his Arden, N.C., job in 1983 because of his race. The high court said John S. Lytle's Seventh Amendment rights were violated when he was denied a jury trial. The court also split 6-3 in ruling that Frances Dalm of Michigan waited too long to sue the government over $20,262 in tax overpayments. Kennedy wrote for the court in that case. Justices John Paul Stevens, William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall dissented.

DOC.HEAD: Herzog Asks Peres to Form Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Peres asked to form government; Picks up 9th graf, `An official ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Chaim Herzog today named Labor Party leader Shimon Peres as Israel's prime minister-designate and gave him the difficult task of trying to form a new government. Israel television broadcast live coverage of Herzog giving a letter of nomination to the 66-year-old Peres, who headed Israel's government in 1984-6. Israeli law left Herzog with the authority to choose a candidate for prime minister. Peres has six weeks to form a new ruling coalition, but it was not certain he would be able to bring together his leftist allies and conservative religiousd factions. Herzog met over the past two days with leaders of Israel's two major parties to decide who has the best chance of forming a new governing coalition. A reversal by a key religious faction Monday left Labor and the right-wing Likud at a draw, with 60-60 support in the 120-member Parliament. The Labor Party is technically Parliament's largest faction, with 39 legislators. Caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, whose Likud bloc has 35 seats, fell in a parliamentary vote of no confidence last Thursday, triggered by a dispute over Middle East peace moves. An official in Herzog's office, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the president's office has been inundated with phone calls from Israelis complaining that the wheeling and dealing has paralyzed the government. ``People say it is impossible to bear the political situation,'' the official said. Israel radio said Herzog, mirroring these sentiments, told some politicians Monday that ``the Israeli public is fed up with politicians.'' The radio said Herzog's office also received a number of anonymous telephone threats today, including one bomb threat. Police searched and found no explosives, the radio said. Much of the maneuvering has involved small ultra-Orthodox religious parties, notably the Shas faction whose spiritual leader, 69-year-old Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, caused the fall of Shamir's Likud-Labor coaltion last week. Yosef said he ordered Shas to withhold support from Shamir because his government was unable to move forward in the peace process. But he reversed his stand Monday after a talk with his mentor, 92-year-old Rabbi Eliezer Shach, and a scolding from the nation's two chief rabbis. In another development, Israel Monday welcomed the idea of peace talks with its most implacable foe, Syria, but said the goal should be an overall peace treaty rather than a proposed demilitarized zone in the occupied Golan Heights. Former President Jimmy Carter, who met Syrian President Hafez Assad last week, told reporters Sunday that Syria was ready for ``bilateral talks with Israel, including the Golan Heights.'' Peres told Parliament last week that he received information the ``Syrians are proposing peace negotiations, demilitarizing the Golan Heights.'' Israel seized the Golan Heights from Syria in the 1967 Six-Day war and annexed the 700-square-mile plateau in 1981. About 7,000 Israelis and 12,000 Druse Arabs live there. The strategic plateau overlooks northern Israel and the approach to Syria's capital, Damascus. Prior to the 1967 war, Syrian gunners used their positions on the heights to shell Israeli settlements in the northern Galilee. Syria has previously demanded the return of all the territory, but the latest hints raised the possibility of a troop withdrawal as an interim solution.

DOC.HEAD: Wilder Says Democrats Need Strong Presidential Candidate in '92
DOC.TEXT: L. Douglas Wilder, catapulted to national prominence as the nation's first black elected governor, said Tuesday that if the Democrats fail to put up a strong mainstream presidential candidate in 1992 ``we'll be locked out of the White House for a long, long time.'' The Virginia governor told The Associated Press that in the Democratic presidential primary campaign he would actively support a candidate who espouses ``mainstream values.'' Wilder never mentioned Jesse Jackson by name, but he made clear he does not believe Jackson shares those mainstream values. ``There isn't any single voice'' commanding the loyalty of blacks, Wilder said, adding, ``there isn't going to be,'' Wilder also spoke to the National Press Club, calling on Democrats to embrace the conservative economic policies he has pursued in his first few months as governor. ``Americans everywhere want to hold the line on spending and on taxes,'' he said. ``There was a time when Democrats were elected by campaigning against big government and high taxes. But for too long we have let the other party take these issues away from us _ indeed, we have allowed them to hammer us with these issues.'' In his speech, Wilder also urged Democrats to ``stop fighting each other'' long after primary battles are decided. ``We're doing the other party's dirty work for them _ and it must stop if we are to ever again be more than mere guests at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.'' Wilder has been one of the hottest properties in the Democratic Party, much in demand as a speaker, since his history-making election in November. He spoke at a party dinner in Chicago last week and is a featured speaker on the agenda of the Democratic Leadership Council meeting in New Orleans later this week. Many Democrats view Wilder as a mainstream alternative to Jackson, who has twice run for the party's presidential nomination from a base of overwhelming support within the black community. In the interview, Wilder suggested it was unlikely Republican Sen. John Warner would face strong opposition for re-election this fall. ``If you have somebody who is credible and can raise funds and attract people for a winning campaign, fine, let's do that,'' he said when asked about the prospects for a strong Democratic challenge to Warner. ``We have a committee out looking for those persons,'' he said. Then laughing, he added, ``They haven't come back yet.'' As for the next presidential election, Wilder said: ``It's essential that the Democrats put a strong candidate up in 1992.'' He said that whomever the party nominates would have to be someone who is ``close to mainstream values.'' If the party fails to do that, he said, ``we'll be locked out of the White House for a long, long time.''

DOC.HEAD: Parents, Though Smarter, Still Make Potentially Deadly Mistakes
DOC.TEXT: Parents have become a lot smarter about keeping medicines and hazardous chemicals from the mouths of their children, but even the best-meaning parents can do something dumb. Like those who cajole Junior into taking his medicine by telling him it's candy. That's an invitation to disaster, and it drives the poison prevention folks right up the wall _ as they made clear at a news conference Tuesday marking the 29th National Poison Prevention Week. An even worse mistake: Storing paint thinners, antifreeze, lighter fluid for the outdoor barbecue or household chemicals in a soda bottle, cup or drinking glass. Overall, however, the news regarding the threat to small children is good. As noted by President Bush in his annual proclamation marking the public awareness campaign, which began Sunday, there has been a 93 percent decrease since 1961 in the accidental poisoning deaths of children under the age of five. That year, the last before Congress enacted legislation creating Poison Prevention Week, 450 youngsters aged four and younger died. In 1987, the last year for which complete statistics are available, 31 perished. The decline has been especially dramatic since the advent of mandatory child-resistant closures, beginning with those for aspirin products in 1972. Since then, child-resistant caps have been required for various types of furniture polish, drain cleaners, oven cleaners, lighter fluids, turpentine, paint solvents, windshield washer solutions, antifreeze and iron-containing vitamins and dietary supplements. In addition, drug manufacturers and pharmacists are required to deliver all oral prescription drugs in child-resistant packages, unless an adult specifically requests an easy-open container. All too many, including grandparents, do just that, officials complain. At a news conference at Georgetown University Hospital, Jacqueline Jones-Smith, chairman of the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission, credited the child-resitant caps on oral medications with saving the lives of an estimated 340 children since 1974. Still, hundreds of thousands of children have what she termed ``near misses'' with poisons each year. In 1987, about 100,000 children were treated in emergency rooms for accidental ingestion of hazardous materials and poison control centers received more than half a million calls involving children. Toby Litovitz, poison control director at Georgetown and president-elect of the American Association of Poison Control Centers, said the 70 member centers reported 1.5 million poisonings last year _ ``just a fraction'' of the number believed to have actually occurred. She estimated the total at 4.7 million, of which she said 62 percent involved children. Litovitz said ``prescription medications, including antidepressants, cardiac medications, asthma therapies and iron _ especially iron in prenatal vitamins _ are a continuing cause of needless deaths in small children.'' The Poison Prevention Week Council, headed by David Almquist of the American Society of Hospital Pharmacists, urged parents to keep on hand a one-ounce bottle of syrup of ipecac, which induces vomiting, for each child in the home. But the substance should never be administered without first consulting a poison control center or physician, the group cautioned. It also warned that HUMCO brand ipecac syrup should be replaced with another brand, because that company has mistakenly labeled potentially deadly eucalyptus oil as syrup of ipecac. The council also urged adults who have no children in their homes to avoid the temptation to use easy-open containers for their medications. ``Accidents have happened when youngsters have visited homes where no children live,'' it noted. According to a safety commission study, 23 percent of the oral prescription drugs that were accidentally ingested by children belonged to someone who did not live with the child. About 17 percent involved drugs belonging to a grandparent or great-grandparent.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbent Quits Connecticut Governor's Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UDPATE with announcement. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill, his popularity sagging under the weight of a faltering state economy, announced today that he will not seek election to a third full term. O'Neill, 59, insisted that recent polls indicating voter approval of his performance at an all-time low weren't what drove him from the race. After much soul-searching, O'Neill said, he and his wife, Nikki, decided they didn't want to go through what promised to be a bruising campaign. ``I firmly believe I could win re-election,'' O'Neill said at a news conference at the governor's mansion. ``But the modern process of campaigning is a rigorous one. It exacts a toll on the body and the spirit which, at this point in my career, I do not choose to pay.'' O'Neill's announcement followed a week of intense speculation about his plans. Word leaked out that O'Neill would not seek re-election after he informed his staff of his decision during a meeting this morning. In consecutive years of service, O'Neill is the longest-serving Democratic governor in the nation. He took office Dec. 31, 1980, after Gov. Ella Grasso resigned in poor health. He was elected to full terms in 1982 and 1986. O'Neill had repeatedly said he would run again, barring an unforeseen health problem. But he met with his doctors earlier today and said his health was good and did not lead to his decision. During his nine years in office, O'Neill had a heart attack, heart bypass surgery and, more recently, colon polyps, one of which was cancerous. Two recent polls showed the governor finishing last in a three way match-up with former U.S. Sen. Lowell P. Weicker, who is running as an independent, and U.S. Rep. John G. Rowland, the front-runner for the Republican nomination. O'Neill faced a challenge from U.S. Rep. Bruce A. Morrison, a four-term congressman from Hamden, for this year's Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Other Democrats have said they'd be interested in the nomination, should O'Neill step aside. They include Larson; state Rep. William J. Cibes of New London; former West Hartford Mayor Christopher Droney, brother of state Democratic Chairman John F. Droney; and former state Rep. Timothy Moynihan of East Hartford, a former Democratic state chairman and now president of the Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce. U.S. Rep. Barbara B. Kennelly, a very popular four-term congresswoman from Hartford, has said she would not become a candidate even if O'Neill dropped out.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Prosecutor Says Exxon Pressured Witnesses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with prosecutor asserting Exxon pressured defense witnesses, picks up 3rd graf, ``Cole, the...'.
DOC.TEXT: The prosecutor at Joseph Hazelwood's trial suggested to jurors today that Exxon pressured crew members to give testimony favorable to the tanker captain blamed for the nation's worst oil spill. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole, in his final argument at Hazelwood's criminal trial, told jurors to notice ``the presence of Exxon in this case,'' and recalled the testimony of an Exxon executive who said that the company has an interest in the outcome of Hazelwood's trial. ``It doesn't take a brain surgeon to see Exxon's interest in this matter,'' Cole said. ``It's seeing Captain Hazelwood get acquitted.'' The prosecutor reminded jurors that crew members who testified supported their captain on many issues, and sometimes changed the stories they had originally given about the grounding of the Exxon Valdez. ``It's easy to see the pressure they were putting on these crew members,'' Cole said. Exxon lawyers have been present in the courtroom throughout the trial and were seated in the front row as Cole spoke. Cole portrayed Hazelwood as ``a gambler'' who took the risk of drinking before boarding the Exxon Valdez only to lose his ship. ``Captain Joseph Hazelwood chose to be a gambler,'' Cole said. ``He chose to be a risk taker. He chose to sit in the Pipeline Club and drink most of the afternoon before he sailed.'' Cole, the first attorney to speak in closing arguments at the 7-week-old trial, said Hazelwood risked his ship and the lives of his crew, and should be found guilty of reckless conduct. ``He gambled that drinking would not affect his judgment,'' Cole said. ``He was wrong, ladies and gentlemen, because alcohol never improves judgment. Captain Joseph Hazelwood gambled and lost, and it resulted in a captain's worst nightmare.'' As Cole spoke, Hazelwood sat calmly at the defense table. His wife and father, who recently arrived at the trial, sat in back-row seats of the crowded courtroom. Using a large blackboard on which he mounted a blow-up picture of the Exxon Valdez, Cole reminded jurors how the tanker ran aground, ``bubbling oil into Prince William Sound.'' And he told them to remember that a tanker captain's concern should be ``safety first.'' ``Captain Hazelwood did not have safety first in his mind when he sat in the Pipeline Club or he wouldn't have been there,'' Cole said. He recounted Hazelwood's actions in the hours preceding the tanker's grounding, ``They were the actions and judgments of a person whose mind was clouded with alcohol.'' Defense attorney Dick Madson was to argue for the skipper's total acquittal. Hazelwood is charged with a felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, he could receive 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. The Exxon Valdez ran aground on Bligh Reef on March 24, spilling almost 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil that wreaked devastation over hundreds of miles of shoreline rich with fish, birds and other wildlife. The intoxication charge is one of the most bitterly disputed points of the trial. When officials tested Hazelwood 10{ hours after the grounding, his blood-alcohol level was .061, below the .10 Alaska minimum to be considered a drunken driver. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone on Monday sided with the prosecution in ruling that the jury would consider only whether the 43-year-old Huntington, N.Y., man was ``impaired'' by alcohol. The defense wanted jurors to decide whether Hazelwood was ``noticeably impaired.'' The judge refused to add a proposed prosecution instruction in which jurors would be told the Coast Guard's blood-alcohol limit for operating a commercial vessel is .04, well below the state law. Johnstone said the Coast Guard standard is a federal regulation, not state law, and has not been admitted into evidence at the trial. Every crew member and investigator who saw Hazelwood on the crucial night was asked about his sobriety. They testified he did not stagger, slur his words or show any signs of intoxication, although three witnesses smelled liquor on his breath. ``There are a lot of people who canmask their impairment,'' Johnstone told lawyers, explaining his decision to strike the word ``noticeably.'' Madson appeared stunned by the ruling, saying, ``This is the first time I've ever heard of this.'' Madson said that in his years of defending drunken driving cases in Fairbanks, the term ``noticeably impaired'' always has been included in jury instructions. ``My gosh, it's been around for a long time,'' he told the judge. But Assistant District Attorney Sam Adams argued, ``All we have to prove is that he was impaired, not stumble-down drunk.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Wants Revised Regulations on Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon urged Congress Tuesday to give the military the authority to revise the way personnel are laid off, saying changes are needed so that forces remain balanced as a leaner Defense Department cuts back. ``We need to work together to get some package put together to provide us with the flexibility we need to manage the force drawdown we all know is coming,'' said Christopher Jehn, assistant secretary of defense for force management and personnel. Jehn and representatives of the military services stressed before a Senate Armed Services subcommittee the importance of quick approval of legislation the Defense Department proposed in July 1989. The bill revises certain restrictions involving voluntary and involuntary ``separation'' of commissioned officers. Among the proposed changes would be allowing military secretaries to convene selective early retirement boards to force retirement of lieutenant colonels and commanders who have failed to receive a promotion on one occasion. Previously, officers had to fail to gain promotion twice before they would be considered by the board for retirement. ``We are asking for additional flexibility to allow us to shape the officer corps in a balanced and equitable way,'' said Army Lt. Gen. Allen K. Ono, deputy chief of staff for personnel. Sens. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Armed Services subcommittee on manpower and personnel, and John McCain, R-Ariz., said Congress needs a report on the Pentagon's policy plans for its forces as it weighs the Defense Department request. Jehn said the report won't be completed until the end of the year, but the Pentagon will try to make much of the information available to Congress before it finishes its work on the fiscal 1991 defense budget. ``There's a sense of frustration here,'' McCain said. ``It's very difficult to enact these measures unless we have a blueprint for the future.''

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Parliament Demands No Negotiations on Hostages
DOC.TEXT: A majority of Iran's parliament members has demanded that the government not negotiate to gain freedom for Western hostages in Lebanon, Tehran radio reported Tuesday. The radio, monitored in Cyprus, said parliament issued a statement Monday night saying the fate of the captives should depend only on the Lebanese. The statement, signed by 170 members of the 270-member parliament, was the latest sign of a power struggle in Tehran over the captives. Moderates led by President Hashemi Rafsanjani have said the issue is moving toward a solution. Hardliners, whose stance was reflected in the parliament statement, oppose freeing the hostages. ``The fate of the Western hostages in Lebanon depends on what the Moslem people of Lebanon want _ an end to the U.S. plots in Lebanon and the clarification of the fate of the Lebanese and Palestinian hostages in prisons in the West,'' the statement said. The pro-Iranian Lebanese Shiite Moslem groups that hold most of the 18 Westerners have in the past demanded freedom for hundreds of Palestinian and Lebanese prisoners held in Israeli jails. Many Middle Eastern countries consider Israel part of the West. ``The arrogant mass media's propaganda on separating the fate of the Western hostages from the problems of Lebanon is strongly condemned,'' the radio quoted the statement as saying. The reference was to reports that a release of hostages may be imminent following alleged secret talks between Tehran and Washington. No concrete signs have emerged to support the speculation. The radio said parliament called on Iran's Foreign Ministry to deny clearly what the radio called rumors that Iran was involved in secret talks. Rafsanjani said March 7 there were no direct contacts with the United States on the hostages, and Foreign Ministry officials repeatedly have stressed that Iran is not directly involved. The United States also has denied any direct talks. The parliament statement urged the ministry to step up efforts to determine the fate of four Iranians who went missing in north Lebanon in 1982. Iran has ignored repeated statements by the Lebanese Forces, the main Christian militia in Lebanon, that the four are dead, although Rafsanjani has said if they were no longer alive their bodies should be returned to Iran. The statement by the members of the Majlis, or parliament, was the latest in a series reflecting an increasingly public fight in Iran over the fate of the hostages. The debate started with a newspaper editorial in the Tehran Times in February saying the hostages should be released without conditions. The parliament statement reflected the stance taken in a recent newspaper editorial by its leading hardline member, Ali Mohammad Mohtashemi, saying Iran would not interfere in Lebanon and encouraging the kidnappers to retain their captives. Hard-liners have said the rumours of U.S.-Iran contacts over the hostages are an attempt to sow domestic discord in Iran. They consider confronting the United States a cornerstone of the 1979 Islamic revolution. Rafsanjani's faction, however, seeks to improve contacts with the West, in part to gain much-needed foreign investment for Iran's post-war reconstruction. Most of the 18 hostages are believed held by groups linked to Hezbollah, or Party of God, a Shiite organization heavily financed by Iran. The hostages are eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who marked his fifth year in captivity on Friday. Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiite Moslem population, the largest of the 17 religious sects among the 4 million Lebanese, is related to that in Iran. The Shiite Moslems never achieved the political and economic power built into the government structure by the Maronite Catholics and Sunni Moslems. The structure cracked in 1975 with the start of the civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Truck Accident Causes Power Failure at Nuclear Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs final graf to CORRECT pronouncer.
DOC.TEXT: A truck accident caused a power failure today at the Plant Vogtle nuclear station, but the brief emergency did not affect the plant's safety, Georgia Power officials said. ``There has been no release of radiation and no danger to the public,'' said utility spokesman Tal Wright. One of the plant's two nuclear reactors was operating at the time of the accident, Wright said. Although a backup generator immediately supplied power, the operational reactor automatically shut down and was being maintained in a ``stable'' condition, he said. Another unit, which was not operating because of a refueling operation, was without power for 36 minutes, the spokesman said. He could not say why backup power was delayed to that unit. Wright said a heavy construction truck backed into a support column in a switchyard at about 8:45 a.m., knocking out power. Wright said non-essential personnel were evacuated. But at midday today, Georgia Power officials retracted that report, saying no evacuation took place. Wright said that in accordance with Nuclear Regulatory Commission regulations, the plant declared a ``site emergency,'' downgraded to an alert 15 minutes later. NRC inspectors headed for Plant Vogtle (pronounced VO-gul) in east Georgia.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Census Homeless Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Here's a look at Tuesday's effort to count the nation's homeless: Who: About 15,000 Census Bureau workers visit an estimated 11,000 shelters and an equal number of identified street locations. What: They interview homeless people if possible, and at the very least count them for inclusion with all other Americans in the 1990 census. This special homeless count is costing about $2.7 million. When: From 6 p.m. to midnight enumerators will visit shelters and low-cost hotels and motels. From 2 a.m. to 4 a.m. they go to predetermined street and other outdoor sites where the homeless are known to congregate. From 4 a.m. to 8 a.m. they are outside abandoned buildings to count those coming out. Where: The effort includes every city of 50,000 or more residents and smaller towns and rural areas where local officials reported having a homeless population. Why: Homelessness has become an increasingly noticed problem in America, but there are no good statistics showing the extent. Estimates of the number of homeless vary from 250,000 to 3 million. Results: The effort is to find out how many people are homeless. But the Bureau will not try and define that term. Instead, it will simply report finding so many people on the streets, so many in shelters or hotels, so many doubled up in apartments, etc. The results will be part of the general national population and housing analysis, expected to published in late 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Widens Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit widened sharply to $9.3 billion in January as record demand for foreign oil offset an all-time high in sales of American products overseas, the government reported Tuesday. The January gap between imports and exports was 20.5 percent larger than December's $7.7 billion deficit, which had been the best monthly showing in five years. The Bush administration, which is counting on further improvement in trade to boost economic growth this year, sought to play down the huge December-to-January swing. But private economists were more pessimistic, warning that America's trade woes could deepen this year due to a growing dependence on foreign oil and a stronger U.S. dollar. The rise in the dollar makes imports less expensive and therefore more attractive to U.S. consumers while making American products less competitive on overseas markets. At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater emphasized the robust growth in exports while minimizing the overall deficit figure. ``Everyone seemed to realize they couldn't maintain that low (deficit) level and so it was expected that there would be an increase in January,'' he said. Exports climbed to a record high of $32.07 billion in January, 4 percent above the December level. However, that gain was swamped by a 7.3 percent rise in imports, which increased to $41.32 billion. The increase in imports came primarily from a 44 percent surge in oil shipments, reflecting a rush by oil companies to replenish storage tanks depleted by unusually cold weather in December. The total volume of oil imports hit an all-time high of 291,278 barrels, surpassing the previous record set just last August. With the price per barrel rising as well, the total oil bill climbed to $5.86 billion, the highest total dollar amount since August 1982, when the volume was less but the price per barrel was higher. Foreign oil accounted for a record 54 percent of consumption in January, and with domestic production now at its lowest level in a quarter century, analysts are concerned that rising dependence on oil imports will make it increasingly difficult to reduce the trade deficit further. Michael Evans, head of a Washington consulting firm, predicted that this year's trade deficit could top $120 billion, up from a $109 billion deficit in 1989. ``Without a weaker dollar, we are just not going to get an improvement in trade,'' he said. David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, said the growing trade deficit would increase calls for protectionist trade legislation, especially in view of weakness in the overall economy. ``We are going nowhere in trade, and with the economy slowing down, people aren't willing to tolerate trade problems,'' he said. The administration has tried to fight off protectionist legislation with vows to open markets overseas, focusing on Tokyo because of America's $49 billion deficit with Japan, representing almost half of last year's total. President Bush met with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu last month to press the administration's case that Japan must do more to open its markets to American goods. The deficit with Japan did decline in January to $2.9 billion, its lowest level in five years, but it still remained by far the biggest imbalance with a single country. The January improvement came from a drop in imports to this country, not from a rise in U.S. exports. Other big deficits in January included a $1.1 billion imbalance with Taiwan, an $840 million deficit with China and a $628 million deficit with Canada, America's largest trading partner. Analysts were encouraged that the increase in exports stemmed in large part from a 13 percent jump in sales of manufactured capital goods, an area where the United States is regaining ground previously lost to foreign competitors. But on the import side, another factor swelling the deficit was a 31 percent jump in clothing shipments, which totaled $3.1 billion in January.

DOC.HEAD: Rule Would Give Increased Protection to Nursing Home Residents's Money
DOC.TEXT: Nursing home residents's personal funds would gain protection under a regulation proposed Tuesday by the Department of Health and Human Services. The proposed rule would prevent nursing homes from charging residents for any goods or services not requested by the resident. It also would bar nursing homes from requiring any applicant for admission or resident to request specific items or services as a condition of admission or continued stay. In addition, residents who request an item or service for which they will be charged _ for example, a telephone, television or radio for personal use _ must be told the amount of the charge, under the proposed rule. The regulation would implement a law barring nursing facilities from requiring payment from residents' personal funds for costs covered by Medicare or Medicaid. The rule defines the circumstances under which residents can be charged the difference between the Medicare payment and the customary cost of an item or service when this cost is higher than Medicare pays. Besides phones and TV sets, they include such goods and services as nonmedical personal comfort items, beauty and barber items and services that cost more than the Medicaid or Medicare payment, personal clothing and services, reading material, flowers and social and entertainment services. Also included would be special care services such as private duty nurses, private rooms except when therapeutically required and special foods that cost more than the foods provided to other residents. The proposed regulation was published in Tuesday's Federal Register. After a 60-day period for public comment, a final rule will be published.

DOC.HEAD: 5,000 Rail Workers Strike to Protest Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: About 5,000 rail workers went on strike Tuesday, demanding that 1,406 former workers of the state-run railway be given their jobs back. Those laid off by the Japanese Railways Liquidation Corp. are among 7,628 employees of the former Japan National Railways who were not rehired when the 277,000-member railroad was broken up into seven private firms in April 1987. After the breakup, the workers were placed in a three-year training program, scheduled to end this month. The plan was to have the private rail firms hire the newly trained workers. The unemployed workers were hired by the liquidation firm on the condition that they should find jobs in three years, said a company official. National Railway Workers Union Kazuhiko Watanabe said 5,000 workers will go on strike again Wednesday to press their demand. The union will strike again next week if its demand is not accepted, Watanabe said. The National Railway Workers Union, which had 130,000 members before the railroad became private, has only 37,000 members. Former rail workers now belong to the new Japan Confederation of Railway Worker Union, which has 140,000 members.

DOC.HEAD: Government Plans to Stem Flow of Refugees Through Poland
DOC.TEXT: The government is examining a plan to stem the flow of Third World refugees arriving through Poland on phony documents, officials said Tuesday. The proposed plan, submitted to a government committee, would make entry more difficult for refugees who arrive on their own initiative rather than on U.N. refugee programs and quotas. It also called for increased diplomatic pressure on Poland to check travel documents more closely. Sweden also may start returning refugees to Poland after receiving assurances they are treated in accordance with U.N. conventions. Hundreds of people from the Middle East and Africa have come to Sweden from Poland in recent weeks requesting asylum. Virtually all of them carry false documents, according to press reports. ``They are put in refugee camps pending individual handling of their case which, unfortunately takes as much six to eight weeks,'' said police duty officer Carita Stahl. These people are ``ruthlessly exploited by refugee organizations who have lured them into coming to Sweden at horrendous prices,'' said the Dagens Nyheter newspaper. The report said some refugees from Lebanon, Ethiopia, Somalia and Iran had bought blurred photocopies of Swedish visas for $600-$1,000 in Egypt, Turkey or Poland. In October, the government introduced visa requirements for Bulgarians to halt a stream of thousands of ethnic Bulgarian Turks that raised the number of asylum seekers in Sweden to the highest level since World War II. Under Sweden's traditionally liberal immigration policies, nearly 20,000 refugees move to Sweden every year.

DOC.HEAD: House Backs Designation of Voting Rights March Route As Historic Trail
DOC.TEXT: The House approved legislation Tuesday authorizing the National Park Service to determine whether the route of the 1965 voting rights march from Selma to Montgomery should be designated a national historic trail. Rep. John Lewis of Atlanta, who was severely beaten by Alabama state troopers at the outset of the march, said the designation would ``demonstrate our commitment to voting rights and ... dramatize the importance of going to the polls and voting.'' The legislation, which now goes to the Senate, was sponsored by Lewis and endorsed by the Bush administration. It was approved 400-0 just one day before the 25th anniversary of the start of the 54-mile march from Browns Chapel Church in Selma to the Alabama state capitol in Montgomery. The march, led by the late Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., began three weeks after Lewis and a group of 525 demonstrators were attacked by Alabama state troopers as they reached the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma while attempting to march to the state capitol. ``We were confronted by billy clubs, bullwhips and tear gas,'' Lewis said. ``Women and children were trampled by deputies on horseback. ``This day, which became known as Bloody Sunday, sent shock waves around the world, raised the nation's consciousness and convinced the political leaders that the time had come for voting rights legislation,'' he said. Congress normally insists that at least 50 years must pass before an event can be considered for historic designation, but Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., said Bloody Sunday ``was one of those events whose history, while infamous, was also instantaneous'' Vento, chairman of the House interior subcommittee on national parks and public lands, said the Selma-to-Montgomery march ``marks a passage in the social history of our nation.'' National Park Service officials enthusiastically endorsed Lewis' bill at a hearing before Vento's panel three weeks ago. They promised to find $150,000 in their existing budget to pay for the study so it can be completed within one year. The law creating the national historic trail system requires that the National Park Service conduct a study to determine if a trail is of sufficient historical value to be marked and included in the system before it can be so designated by Congress. Herbert Cables, deputy director of the park service, said the agency wants to explore the possibility of putting together an oral history of the march and creating exhibits and markers along the route to interpret its significance to the public.

DOC.HEAD: Carter Criticizes Settling Soviet Jews in Occupied Territories
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for JERUSALEM-dated story listed on AM-News Advisory.
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter said Tuesday that settling Soviet Jews in the occupied territories could result in an international backlash that would hinder future immigration. Also Tuesday, Soviet emigre and human rights activist Natan Sharansky urged the government to end its censorship of Soviet immigration figures, saying it was interfering with fund raising and publicity efforts. Asked about settling some of the thousands of Soviet immigrants coming to Israel in the occupied territories, Carter said: ``I believe that the number of Soviet Jews that will be permitted to come to Israel is going to be dramatically reduced in the future if these hopeful people coming to freedom are used to establish facts (of Israeli presence) in occupied territories.'' Carter added that he was concerned because such settlement was ``arousing animosity and opposition throughout the Arab world and other places, in the Soviet Union and even in the United States.'' Israel captured the West Bank and Arab east Jerusalem, along with the Gaza Strip, from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East War. Israel annexed east Jerusalem as part of its capital and has set up a military government to rule the 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza. Israeli leaders have said they expect up to 750,000 Soviet immigrants in the next few years. Carter made his comments at a news conference at Ben-Gurion Airport at the end of a three-day visit to Israel. He visited Egypt, Syria and Jordan earlier as part of a Middle East tour. Sharansky, a former Soviet ``refusenik'' who heads the Soviet Jewry Zionist Forum, said some self-censorship might be necessary to ensure the security of the immigrants. But he added: ``We need more support from world Jewry and, to make (Israeli) bureaucrats work more effectively, we need more public pressure. We can't do it under conditions of censorship.'' Sharansky was joined in his appeal against censorship by officials from the Jewish Agency, a quasi-government body that shares responsibility for resettling immigrants. The agency's spokesman, Gad Ben-Ari said the organization was appealing to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to have the broad censorship guidelines limited to two key issues: long-term immigration projections and new transit routes. ``The process of fund raising, especially in our Operation Exodus campaign for the Soviets, depends a great deal on a constant flow of accurate information about the immigration,'' Ben-Ari said. ``We are already having difficulties, not in fund raising but in being able to deliver necessary information.'' Operation Exodus aims to raise $200 million in each of the next three years from Jews in the United States and Europe. The ban on publication of immigration figures was imposed by the government on March 1 amid mounting Arab protests that the influx could lead to more Jewish settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, home to 1.7 million Palestinians. Israeli officials said the Arab statements raised the prospect of guerrilla attacks against the immigrants, making censorship necessary. Officials have said that Soviet Jews are not being directed to settle in the occupied territories. About 200 Soviets settled in the West Bank last year.

DOC.HEAD: Press Cooperative Protests Gov't Decision to Liquidate It
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Poland's largest press cooperative said Tuesday the Solidarity-led government had acted unfairly in deciding to liquidate it. Under Communist rule, the Workers' Publishing Cooperative muzzled unauthorized publications. On Monday, the Cabinet decided to do away with the group because it was seen as an organ of the now-defunct Communist Party. Parliament must still pass the law dismantling the group. Slawomir Tabkowski, chairman of the cooperative, said the government commission that developed the law had submitted to ``neo-Bolshevik pressure'' aimed at attaining ``political revenge.'' He said the cooperative had gotten only a brief chance to display its plans to reform itself, and the government had taken an arbitrary decision. Under Communist rule, the party owned 95 percent of the cooperative. Those assets were turned over to the Social Democracy Party, which was created in January after the Communist Party dissolved itself. A government statement carried by the PAP news agency said the cooperative was ``an element of the structure of the political monopoly of a single party.'' ``An often unobjective and manipulatory impact on the consciousness of the great masses of society ... was one of the basic elements of that system,'' it said. To maintin the cooperative in the hands of the Social Democracy Party ``would put it in a privileged position over the other currently existing parties, unions, and associations,'' it said. The cooperative published the vast majority of newspapers on the market, controlled the sale of newspapers through its monopoly on more than 20,000 kiosks in the country and owned several important publishing houses. Last year, the popularity of the cooperative's publications began to drop as new independent newspapers and dailies emerged in Poland's changing political climate. In a report published Monday in the Social Democracy Party's newspaper Trybuna, the cooperative said that in January it published 44 daily newspapers and a wide array of other publications in the provinces. Its profits were a steady source of revenue for the Communists and subsequently the Social Democracy Party. Tabkowski said the cooperative had posted a profit of $10 million in 1989 and had 13 printing plants. Its monopoly on newspapers, along with censorship, prevented the sale of underground literature which flourished after the 1981 martial law crackdown that crushed Solidarity. The kiosks began to distribute some independent publications, but their shelves are still covered by the cooperative's newspapers and magazines. Tabkowski said Tuesday that its abolition would reduce the array of titles available to Polish readers. He said he would seek to retain some titles and would continue business as usual. But he did not appear to have the support of the workers who run the kiosks. Tabkowski said the cooperative has 39,000 employees, and another 38,000 work in the kiosks. As for the fate of the Trybuna newspaper, the Social Democracy Party's official organ, party secretary Krzysztof Janik said it might have to start publishing underground.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Governor Hopeful Counts on Bush Coattails, Fund-Raising
DOC.TEXT: Texas Republican millionaire Clayton Williams said Tuesday he hopes to ride President Bush's coattails ``like a bucking bronco'' to victory in an $11 million campaign for the Texas governorship. The cowboy-oilman, who had lunch with Bush and Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater at the White House, said Bush promised to campaign actively for him and to help raise funds for his campaign. ``I have asked him to come and help whenever and wherever he can,'' Williams told reporters after his first-ever visit to the Oval Office. Atwater said the president had no political trips to Texas scheduled for the next month or so. But he said Bush ``made it clear he will be coming to Texas and wants to help from a fund-raising standpoint. Mrs. Bush also wants to help.'' ``And let's face it,'' Atwater added, ``this is his (Bush's) home state. He loves Texas. He loves the politics of Texas.'' Atwater called Williams' chances of winning the election ``much better than even... This guy is the political phenonomen of 1990.'' Williams, speaking to reporters in the driveway outside the White House, said he needed Bush's help in financing what he said would amount to an $11 million campaign. The Texas businessman said he had already sunk $6.5 million of his own money into his race and ``I'm about at the end of my rope. If I put any more in... the bankers will eat me alive.'' He said the president, who considers Houston his hometown, ``has some wonderful coattails in Texas and I'd like to grab ahold of them and ride them like a bucking bronco.'' Asked which Democrat he would rather face in Novemember, state Treasurer Ann Richards or Attorney General Jim Mattox, Williams said: ``We'll take any one of them on. They both have strengths and weaknesses. And we hope that each side will continue to point out the weaknesses of the other side.'' The two are in a runoff. Asked whether he would raise the issue of drugs if Richards wins the runoff, Williams said: ``It will depend... My son was involved in drugs. He spent 14 months in his rehabilitation. I admire any person recovering from chemical dependency.'' Richards, a recovering alcoholic, has refused to say whether she ever used illegal drugs. Williams said he was making an effort to reach out to blacks, Asian-Americans and Hispanics. ``I have an Anglo body but a heart that is Mexican-American,'' he said. ``I speak the language, working man's Spanish. I sing the music. I have Mexican-Americans in my upper management... I'm proud of my record in that arena.'' And, he added, ``I met my wife in a Mexican restaurant.'' Williams was invited to the White House last week after he trounced three opponents to win his party's nomination to replace retiring Republican Gov. Bill Clements. ``In a year like this, we can't afford to lose the governorship of a state like Texas,'' Atwater said. ``Texas-California-Florida, that is the three-mega-state anchor to our entire sunbelt political base.'' California and Florida, like Texas, have GOP governors whose terms are up this year.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Store Fire Could Be Arson
DOC.TEXT: Arson may have caused a supermarket fire in western Japan that killed 15 people, a police official said Tuesday. Sunday's fire at the five-story Nagasakiya supermarket in suburban Osaka, about 300 miles west of Tokyo, originated between a wall and a pile of cushions on the fourth floor, said a police official, who spoke on the condition he not be identified. ``We have not determined the cause of the fire yet, but the fire may have been caused by arson or someone throwing away a cigarette butt, considering the site where the fire started,'' the police official said. He said police and fire officials investigating the fire are questioning employees and shoppers who were on the fourth floor when the blaze broke out. About 120 shoppers and 58 company employees were in the store at the time. On Monday, police said they were investigating reports about a man telephoning two major national newspapers saying he was responsible. The Asahi Shimbun reported a man called their office in Kobe and said ``I set the fire. I didn't think it would turn into such a disaster. I was frustrated because I had been fired.'' The official would not comment Tuesday on the police investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Apologizes For Joking About Youth Poverty
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Terry Branstad apologized for joking that one solution to child poverty is for the rich to have more kids, but insisted he is not insensitive to the plight of the poor. The Republican governor said he doesn't regret having a sense of humor. But he told reporters Monday it was wrong to say ``the rich get richer and the poor have children.'' He made the crack several weeks ago during a Kiwanis Club meeting after he gave a more serious response about what could be done for children living in poverty. A columnist for The Des Moines Register publicized Branstad's joke Friday. After initially defending his remark at his weekly news conference Monday, Branstad changed gears minutes later. ``In retrospect, I think it was a mistake,'' said Branstad, who is running for re-election in November. ``It's not a funny topic. I'm sorry that I said that in humor.'' Democratic gubernatorial candidate Don Avenson claimed the remark reflected Branstad's lack of concern for the poor. But Branstad said his administration has started welfare reform programs and directed money to school programs for poor children. ``I'm committed to seeing that's done,'' Branstad said. ``I think we need to do all that we can.'' ``The state has taken significant action and will continue to take action to help people move from poverty and dependency to job opportunities and a higher standard of living,'' Branstad said. ``That's what this system is all about, to help people.''

DOC.HEAD: DEA Smoldering Over Citation For Cocaine Fire
DOC.TEXT: The Colorado Department of Health has cited the federal Drug Enforcement Administration for violating state air pollution standards by burning a half ton of cocaine in an incinerator last month. DEA officials expressed outrage Monday at being issued a ``notice of violation'' for burning 1,042 pounds of contraband cocaine on Feb. 23 in a U.S. Department of Agriculture incinerator in Lakewood, a suburb of Denver. ``What do they think we're going to do with it _ ship it back to Colombia?'' asked DEA spokesman Ron Hollingshead. Hollingshead said at first he thought a phone call about the alleged violation was a joke. Harry Collier, a state air pollution control specialist, said the department acted after receiving several complaints about a dense column of smoke when the cocaine was burned. The DEA used the incinerator because it could burn the drug at a temperature exceeding 800 degrees, Hollingshead said. The high temperature was needed to keep the cocaine burn from turning into ``the world's biggest crack cookout,'' he said. Collier said the DEA could have found other incinerators that would have complied with the clean air law.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Takes First Step Toward Atomic Reaction
DOC.TEXT: Eleven years later than they hoped, operators of the Seabrook nuclear power plant turned on its reactor Tuesday to begin running it up to full power. At 3:59 a.m., the 1,150-megawatt reactor achieved its first sustained chain reaction since low-power tests in 1989, spokesman Ron Sher said. He said the reactor operated at a fraction of 1 percent of full power shortly after engineers partially withdrew some of the 57 control rods. ``There is a real sense of accomplishment because everyone at Seabrook Station who has worked so hard can now continue the job that we have been organized to do: that's prepare to generate much-needed electricity for more than 1 million New England homes,'' Sher said. In a nuclear chain reaction, neutrons released by spontaneously dividing uranium atoms split other uranium atoms, releasing more energy and more neutrons. Control rods interrupt that process by absorbing neutrons. The reactor will be allowed to increase power to 100 percent during the next two to three months, Sher said. A limited amount of electricity will be produced at about 10 percent, but until then operators will shunt steam past the turbines that eventually will drive electrical generators. The $6.5 billion plant, finished in mid-1986 after years of protests, got its Nuclear Regulatory Commission operating license last week, following lengthy regulatory battles and a preliminary court skirmish decided in Seabrook's favor. The U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington declined last week to block the license pending further court action, but still has before it an appeal filed by the Massachusetts attorney general, Seacoast Anti-Pollution League and New England Coalition on Nuclear Pollution. Public Service Co. of New Hampshire proposed building a nuclear power plant on the New Hampshire seacoast in 1968. The company revived the project in 1972 with a plan to build two 1,150-megawatt reactors at Seabrook for a total cost of $973 million. The first was to operate in 1979, the second in 1981. Beset by construction delays, increased safety requirements after the partial meltdown of the Three Mile Island reactor in 1979, regulatory snags and opposition by neighboring Massachusetts, owners mothballed Seabrook's second reactor in the mid-1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Army Seeks to Trade Tank Output For New Arms Systems
DOC.TEXT: The Army is gambling that Congress will agree to end tank production while also approving money for controversial new weapons systems such as the LH attack helicopter, senior Pentagon officials said Tuesday. Steven Conver, assistant Army secretary for research and acquisition, told a House panel that the Army reluctantly proposed abandoning the M-1 Abrams tank production line and the Apache attak helicopter because of the overall squeeze on defense spending. Conver said he recognized that it might be difficult persuading Congress to halt tank production while also spending on new weapons systems such as the LH, or light helicopter, which the Pentagon itself has begun reassessing. ``I realize the political difficulty,'' Conver told the House Armed Services subcommittee on procurement. ``We're really throwing the dice on that one.'' The difficulty made itself apparent during the hearing. Legislators who stand to lose coveted military contracts for their districts protested the cuts in current Army programs. Others, concerned about the costs involved in new weapons programs, questioned the need for developing new tanks and helicopters. ``I sense a disconnect between where the administration is going and where the Congress is going on modernization,'' said Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis. Rep. Marvin Leath, D-Texas, who said he had no parochial interest in the cancellation of the M-1 or Apache, said, ``I don't know how you think it's fine to just destroy a production base.'' Gen. Donald Pihl, the Army's top acquisition officer, responded: ``It is not comforting to think about the United States of America not producing tanks.'' Rep. John Rowland, R-Conn., suggested that rather than spending $400 million to mothball the two existing tank factories in the United States _ one in Detroit and the other in Lima, Ohio _ the Army should continue to make a small number of M-1s and promote tank sales to foreign countries. The LH program would last into the next century and cost about $3 billion per year. Each helicopter, with the latest in target-seeking and radar-avoiding technology, would cost about $7.5 million. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney last week ordered a high-level Pentagon review of the need for the LH. Some members of Congress also are uncertain about the need for new light helicopters. ``How can you realistically expect the Congress to approve these levels of funding for a single helicopter program, particularly one of questionable value?'' asked Rep. Larry Hopkins, R-Ky. Conver replied that ``we are not even a little bit apologetic about asking Congress for this program.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Audrey Hepburn's recital from the diary of Anne Frank gave a wondrous glimpse into the young Holocaust victim's ``hopes, her youthful dreams, her reality,'' composer Michael Tilson Thomas said. The 60-year-old actress, who is goodwill ambassador for the United Nation's Children's Fund, read from the diary in the first of four ``Concerts for Life'' Monday night to benefit the world's needy children. The diary chronicled the Jewish girl's feelings as she and her family hid from the Nazis for two years in the attic of an Amsterdam office building. Published in 1947, it later was made into a play and then a movie. Miss Hepburn turned down both roles, saying they were too emotional upsetting. ``I couldn't deal with it, I could not exploit her,'' said Miss Hepburn, who lived in Holland during World War II and was the same age as Anne Frank. Miss Hepburn finally relented by collaborating on Thomas' musical tribute, ``From the Diary of Anne Frank,'' which premiered before an emotionally charged audience of 2,400 at the Academy of Music. ``This is certainly one of the best experiences of my life,'' Miss Hepburn said. ``The words of Anne Frank have lived this long; and in this music, they will live forever.'' ``It was as if you were listening to Anne Frank, her hopes, her youthful dreams, her reality,'' Thomas told reporters. Other concerts are planned for Wednesday in Chicago, Friday in Houson and Sunday at the United Nations.

Lou Diamond Phillips has been released from the hospital where he was treated for a broken arm. The actor suffered the injury after being thrown and dragged by a horse on the movie set of ``Young Guns 2.'' The Philippines-born actor received at least 20 floral arrangements, dozens of get-well cards and phone calls from fans during his weekend stay at University of New Mexico Hospital. Spokeswoman Gail Sutton said Phillips, 28, left the hospital Monday evening. A gunshot startled the horse Phillips was riding Friday on a movie set near Galisteo, 20 miles from Santa Fe. His fractured right arm required 2{ hours of surgery. Phillips, best known for his roles as singer Ritchie Valens in ``La Bamba'' and as a defiant math student in ``Stand and Deliver,'' was returning home Tuesday to Los Angeles, said his publicist, Eddie Michaels. Ms. Sutton said telephone calls to Phillips were carefully screened, but a few who falsely claimed to be relatives got through. ``A couple of little kids dropped off cards,'' she said. Phillips is playing Jose Chavez y Chavez, a friend of Billy the Kid, in the ``Young Guns'' movies. Emilio Estevez plays the Kid.

A judge ordered Billy Barty to pay one of his former writers $1,300, and the diminutive actor was jubilant. The 65-year-old Barty, who has starred in such films as ``Rumpelstiltskin'' and ``Willow,'' said he was happy with Monday's ruling because he didn't have to award 10 percent of future syndication profits for his show ``Short Ribbs'' to writer-producer Bill Winckler. ``It went fine, it went very good, I was very pleased at the judge's decision,'' Barty said being ordered to pay Winckler $1,300 in disputed salary and $28 in court costs. Barty said the publicity hadn't hurt his career. ``This has gotten about as much publicity as Zsa Zsa and I didn't even slap anybody,'' he said. ``But I wouldn't slap anybody. I'd hit them in the knee.'' Winckler, who sued Barty in small claims court for $2,000, said he also was satisfied. ``I would have liked to have had my 10 percent of the show, too, but I'm not overly upset about it because I don't know how marketable the show is now,'' he said. Thirteen episodes of ``Short Ribbs,'' described as a ``Saturday Night Live'' for ``Little People,'' were televised last fall on Orange County-based cable station KDOC. Winckler, a writer for television cartoons, said he agreed to the relatively paltry fee of $100 per episode because he figured he stood to make a good deal more with 10 percent of the syndication fee. But he said Barty wouldn't pay him anything after the two fell out over creative differences.

Bill Demby, a Vietnam War veteran who lost both legs in a rocket attack in 1971, tells youngsters that his disabilities don't stop him from enjoying life to the full. The former army private features in a television commercial by Du Pont, which manufactures a plastic used in his artificial legs. He travels around the country, often to cities with Du Pont plants, to offer hard-earned advice to high school students. ``I hope kids can find something in my story that will help them out when times get hard,'' he said during a visit Monday to Omaha Northwest High School. ``Maybe when they see my life, they'll realize that they're not so bad off.'' Demby said he cannot run as fast as before, nor can he jump as high. ``But I get out there and play,'' he said, ``and if you give me half a chance, I'll burn the nets off you.'' After returning from the war, Demby said he fell into a cycle of drug and alcohol abuse until, one night in a bar, a friend told him ``You don't need this.'' Since then, Demby said, he has made a slow, steady recovery. ``Sometimes you've just got to kick yourself in the rear and get going,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Says Czechoslovakia Won't Sell Weapons to Dictatorial Regimes
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia said Tuesday that his country's venerable arms industry will no longer sell weapons to dictatorial or totalitarian regimes. Czechoslovakia, a major arms manufacturer since before World War II, has sold sophisticated explosives to countries, and they have found their way to terrorists. ``Today, we stop all arms sales to dictatorial or totalitarian countries,'' Havel said at a news conference near the end of his two-day official visit to France. He did not say which nations he had in mind. ``We are studying reconversion of our military industry,'' Havel said. ``Don't hold it against us if we continue to furnish arms for a little while to democratic countries.'' Havel answered questions at the Elysee Palace at the side of President Francois Mitterrand. The visit was Havel's first to France since becoming Czechslovakia's leader in December. The Czech leader promised not to resort to autocracy to resolve the economic problems facing his country after four decades of Communist rule. ``The process before us does not have historic precedence,'' Havel said. ``There are different economic theories and different economists, so there is a divergence of points of view.'' Havel promised that a draft bill will be submitted to the country's Assembly for approval in coming weeks dealing with economic readjustment and the tricky question of private property. Mitterrand announced no new aid or foreign policy programs for Czechoslovakia beyond saying that France ``will without doubt assist President Vaclav Havel.'' The Czech president is trying to raise his country's profile in the West after decades of dominance by the Soviets. He visited the United States last month and travels to London on Wednesday for talks with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Urge Medical Services For All Pregnant Women and Children
DOC.TEXT: Providing health care for all pregnant women and children would lead to healthier babies with fewer needs for costly special care later in life, witnesses told a House subcommittee Tuesday. The short-term costs of expanding care would be high, medical and health policy experts agreed, but the long-term payoff would be lower costs for expensive high-tech care later on. ``It costs taxpayers and private businesses more money if pregnant woman can't get medical care,'' said former Sen. Lawton Chiles, D-Fla., chairman of the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality. Without adequate prenatal care, a woman is more likely to deliver a low birthweight baby that might need costly medical services to survive. Increasing the birthweight of one such infant from two pounds to 2.5 pounds would save $17,000 in acute inpatient hospital care, Chiles told the House Ways and Means subcommittee on health. Extending that savings to the entire U.S. population would result in immediate savings of as much as $90 billion, he said, ``and that does not even begin to address the long-term savings in health care, school failure and lost productivity.'' Sen. Pete Stark, D-Calif., subcommittee chairman, has introduced a bill that would provide publicly-financed health insurance to all children through age 22 and pregnancy-related health services for all women. The net cost of the package would be about $50 billion a year. ``When Medicare was passed in 1965, it provided publicly-financed health insurance for the elderly,'' Stark said. ``The time has come to provide similar coverage for the other most vulnerable groups within our society _ children and mothers.'' Fifteen percent of the 3.7 million women who give birth each year have no health insurance to pay for maternity care, Richard Schwarz, vice president of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, said in testimony submitted to the panel. Of those who do have insurance, about 330,000 of them have policies that don't cover maternity services, he said. An estimated 11 million children lack health insurance. Studies have shown that these children are about 20 percent more likely to be reported in poor health as are children who are insured or on Medicaid, Birt Harvey, president of the American Academy of Pediatrics, said in his testimony. About 300,000 infants die or are born with low birthweight every year, said Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., chairman of the House Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families. ``The answer is not difficult,'' Miller said in testimony before the subcommittee. ``This isn't a secret formula we're groping for. It's an attitude'' that pregnant women and children are entitled to health care, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Urge ABA Removal From Judicial Selection Process
DOC.TEXT: Four Republican senators say the American Bar Association, by endorsing abortion rights, has forfeited its role in selecting federal judges. ``The time has come to end the ABA's preferred role in judicial selection. We hereby strongly urge you take steps ... to terminate the official relationship with the ABA,'' the senators said in a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. The letter signed by Sens. Charles Grassley of Iowa, Orrin Hatch of Utah, Gordon Humphrey of New Hampshire and Alan Simpson of Wyoming was written Monday but was not made public until Tuesday. The ABA is the nation's largest lawyers' organization. Its policy-making House of Delegates voted last month to oppose legislattal action threatening a woman's right to abortion. Thornburgh subsequentlion or governmeny said the resolution could bias the ABA's ability to judge the professsional competence of judicial nominees. ``We share your publicly expressed view that positions such as these call into question the ABA's privileged role on judicial selection,'' the senators told Thornburgh. The four, all conservative members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, have been critical of the ABA's role in the fight over Robert H. Bork, nominated to the Supreme Court in 1987 by PreMaine, lawyer who heads the ABA federal judiciary panel, rejected the letter's premise. ``Our evaluation focuses, as it always has, only on three factors: professional competence, judicial temperament and integrity,'' he said. ``We have no `litmus test' and do not consider the views of the potential nominees on particular policy issues,'' Lancaster said. ``The ABA has adopted over 750 policy positions on legislative issues. None of these is now _ or will be _ a factor in the standing committee's evaluation'' of nominees. There was no immediate reaction from Thornburgh. But when Justice Department spokesman David Runkel was asked Monday to comment, he told reporters the controversy created by the ABA abortion vote ``is still an open issue.''

DOC.HEAD: Michener Threatens to Leave Random House
DOC.TEXT: Upset by recent developments at Random House, James Michener says he may leave the publisher in favor of what he calls ``some small house obedient to the old traditions.'' The prolific novelist, who has had more than 30 books published by Random House, issued a statement Monday in which he said he had been ``devastated by the series of hammer blows my company has suffered in recent months.'' The writer cited the forced resignation of Robert Bernstein as president of Random House; Bernstein's replacement with Alberto Vitale, whom Michener described as ``not a man reared in the traditions of American publishing;'' and the forced resignation of Andre Schiffrin as managing director of Pantheon Books, a Random House subsidiary. Michener also expressed concern about possible layoffs at Random House. Michener, author of ``Hawaii'' and many other best-sellers, described himself as ``one of Random House's oldest and most loyal writers.'' He urged Vitale and S.I. Newhouse, whose family owns Random House, to ``step forward and define their understanding of how the world's major English-language publisher should conduct its business.'' If they do, he added, ``I will sign a new contract with a sigh of relief.'' Vitale expressed dismay over Michener's remarks and said he was willing to discuss them with the writer. Newhouse said he had no comment on Michener's statement.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Audtiors Review Handling of Case Involving Tooth Fillings
DOC.TEXT: Environmental Protection Agency auditors are reviewing the agency's handling of an unusual case that put the bite on dozens of dentists because they sold old fillings whose toxic ingredients ended up in the soil. The case has attracted the attention of lawmakers because it tests how far the government can reach to hold parties accountable for toxic waste contamination. Last week, the EPA inspector general's office said it was assigning auditors to conduct a 60-day review of the case before determining whether additional study was necessary. The review comes at the request of a Pittsburgh dental supplier who claims the agency overstepped its authority. The case hinges on amalgam _ the stuff that fillings are made of _ and whether it can be considered a ``hazardous substance'' after it has been removed from peoples' teeth. Amalgam is a hard, durable alloy. Dentists often save old fillings or leftover amalgam and sell it to processors, who break it down into mercury or silver. The EPA alleged in 1987 and 1988 that Pittsburgh dental suppliers Roy Ott, his son Ken, and other companies sold amalgam to metal processor Eugene Bourdeaudhui. As a result of Bourdeaudhui's efforts to break the amalgam down, the agency said soil in Willington, Conn., became so polluted with toxic mercury that it required a $710,000 cleanup in 1985. In seeking out responsible parties to pay for the cleanup, the EPA stunned the nationwide dental community by going after not only Bourdeaudhui but also 58 dentists and several dental suppliers who did business with him. All the parties have settled with EPA, according to attorney Robert Ging of Confluence, Pa. His clients, the Otts, agreed last November to pay the government $30,000 because they said the expense of further legal challenges was too great. In announcing several of the settlements last year, the EPA said the agreements ``demonstrate that members of the dental community understand that they have a responsibility to make themselves aware of dental amalgam's ultimate disposal method and that the dental community _ which controls the disposition of waste amalgam _ rather than taxpayers, should bear the cost of cleanup.'' But Ging said in an interview Tuesday that the principle involved compelled the Otts last month to ask EPA Inspector General John C. Martin to review the case. ``Mr. Ott and his son were so offended by the waste and the injustice of the whole procedure that they felt it ws worth their time and effort to bring this to the attention of the Congress and the people,'' Ging said. Several lawmakers agreed with the Otts that the case raised basic fairness questions. ``The fact that dental amalgam is considered a hazardous waste under Superfund comes as a surprise to many,'' said Rep. Doug Walgren, D-Pa., in a letter last year to EPA. ``A substance which is in my mouth _ and the mouths of millions of Americans _ and is deemed `safe' by dentists and the American Dental Association hardly seems a candidate for Superfund coverage.''
