Walgren also said it ignored ``a common sense standard of reasonableness'' to hold Ott and the dentists responsible for the actions of a ``third party'' in Connecticut. Through the Freedom of Information Act, the Otts obtained EPA documents they said demonstrated excessive charges by contractors for the cleanup. ``We share your concern that contractors may be charging excessive fees under the Superfund law,'' Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich. and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said in a letter to the family several weeks ago.

DOC.HEAD: Shultz Urges Active U.S. Role in Reshaping Europe
LaserPhoto FX2
DOC.TEXT: Former Secretary of State George P. Shultz has joined critics of the Bush administration who say the United States should take a more active role in shaping the future of Eastern Europe. But Shultz cautioned against promoting independence movements in the Soviet Union beyond the Baltic states. In an interview at his on-campus office last week, he also warned against the United States aggravating the Middle East peace process, saying President Bush must make it clear he does not support dividing Jerusalem. Reluctant to criticize the Bush administration since leaving office last year, Shultz, 69, has busied himself on several projects at the Hoover Institution in Stanford University. He lives here with his wife, and still carries the worn brown leather briefcase, bulging with papers, that he hauled around the globe during 6{ years as President Reagan's secretary of state. Instead of meeting daily with world leaders, Shultz is writing about his years in Washington, discussing political and economic events with other Hoover scholars and Stanford students and developing material for a book and some television documentaries on foreign policy, called ``Statecraft.'' In a discussion of recent developments in foreign affairs, Shultz did not directly criticize Secretary of State James Baker's plan to allow participation of East Jerusalem Arabs in talks with Israel. But he indicated some dissatisfaction with the plan, which triggered a dispute and shakeup in the Israeli government, and comments by Bush suggesting East Jerusalem was part of occupied territory with Israeli settlers. ``I think it's very important for us not to condition the atmosphere by taking stands that tend to aggravate the situation unnecessarily,'' Shultz said. ``There is no point in giving anyone the sense that we in any way support dividing Jerusalem.'' Shultz said ``diplomacy has become a neglected dimension of the Arab-Israeli conflict.'' He suggested the United States take a lead in shaping events in Eastern Europe. ``It seems to me when things are changing in directions that are congenial to us, and the balls are up in the air in great multitude, it is a time to be leaning forward into the task of diplomacy and engaging with these problems,'' Shultz said. ``The United States has had a great part in creating these changes and we have a great stake in the way they work out,'' he said. ``So we're not an onlooker only. We have been a participant and we want to retain our ability to affect what goes on.'' Several Democratic leaders have complained the Bush administration has not responded vigorously enough to changes in Eastern Europe. Shultz said U.S. and European officials should heed the lessons of history. ``We should remember that at the end of World War I, the statesmen then designed a system (in Europe) that didn't work,'' he said. ``After World War II, the statesmen who were the most influential, and they were from the United States, designed a system that did work. ``That doesn't mean we have to thump our chests about it. Our friends had a lot to do with it, too,'' Shultz said. ``But the U.S. influence has been a very positive one. We have paid our dues.'' Shultz said the United States must tread delicately over whether to encourage independence movements among the Soviet republics. The United States has long encouraged or supported freedom efforts in other countries, he said. ``That doesn't mean we go around supporting armed insurrection everywhere, but we promote'' freedom, he said. ``That's what we stand for. I suppose that's one reason why the Chinese are always edgy about us. Aside from the Baltic republics, where the United States has a longstanding position of not recognizing their incorporation into the Soviet Union, ``it's not for us to promote any particular rearrangement of the Soviet Union,'' he said. ``But the people there will be better served if they have a right to ... self-expression about these matters.'' Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev has ``a whole set of tremendous problems,'' Shultz said. ``He clearly has to create a looser federal system in the Soviet Union than the one they've got.''

DOC.HEAD: No Motives, No Suspects in Fatal Package Bombing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT that Finlay just moved to the apratment, sted to Florida; Willi, 6th graf, cq
DOC.TEXT: Police and federal agents hunted for clues Tuesday in the wreckage of an apartment where a shoebox-size package bomb killed a 70-year-old man wintering in Florida with his family. Sherwin William Finlay, a boating enthusiast from Missouri, was killed when a package left at the door of his rented apartment exploded when he picked it up, said Sgt. Steve Weintraub of the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office. Finlay had just moved to the apartment about a week before with his 67-year-old wife, Dorothy, and daughter Gay Lynn Meek, 35, who were not injured. They said they had no idea why anyone would want to kill Finlay. Investigators do not believe the explosion is related to recent mail bombings that killed two people in Alabama, Georgia and Jacksonville. The blast Monday was powerful enough to blow out the roof overhang of the two-story apartment building. Willi Ellison, agent in charge of the Jacksonville office of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said the bomb was ``more or less a homemade device.'' Its remains were to be sent to the ATF laboratory in Atlanta for analysis, he said. All 10 agents at his office were investigating the bombing, along with the sheriff's office, he said. ``We want to find out who committed this crime,'' Ellison said. The brown-paper package was not delivered by the U.S. Post Office as were package bombs that killed a federal appeals court judge, Robert Vance, and Savannah, Ga., alderman Robert Robinson last December, Ellison said. ``At this point, I don't think there is a connection but we're looking into all aspects,'' Ellison said. Unlike the bombs that killed Vance and Robinson, the device did not contain nails as shrapnel, he said. Shrapnel devices also were sent to the Jacksonville office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta, but both were disarmed. The family is from Gravois Mills, Mo., where Finlay worked for the Missouri Highway Department for 20 years before retiring 10 years ago. A friend, Bryan Taylor, said he and Finlay had sailed together for more than two decades as members of the Lake of the Ozarks Yachting Association. Taylor described him as an unlikely target and said the Finlays had planned a boat trip through the Intracoastal Waterway to Jacksonville, where their son, Doug, is a boat salesman. Weintraub said the couple had been in Jacksonville since Dec. 1. They moved into the apartment complex about a week ago, and neighbors knew little about them. The FBI is monitoring the case, said George Wisnovsky, an agency spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Presses for Quick Action on Aid Package to Panama, Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf of further comment from Leahy after 15th graf pvs, `Eagleburger acknowledged...; picks up 16th graf pvs, `A spate...'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush pressed Congress Tuesday to move quickly on his $800 million aid package for Panama and Nicaragua, but it became increasingly clear that there were serious obstacles to action before the president's Easter deadline. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee that the aid is crucial to the survival of new democratic governments headed by President Guillermo Endara in Panama and President-elect Violeta Chamorro in Nicaragua. ``Early success ... is going to be fundamental to whether Mr. Endara and Mrs. Chamorro are going to make it,'' Eagleburger told the foreign aid subcommittee. At the White House, Bush gave visiting congressional leaders another reason to act quickly: to turn up heat on Cuba's Fidel Castro, the hemisphere's lone communist holdout. ``I'm terribly disappointed that Castro seems to be firming up his totalitarian position instead of moving toward free and fair elections,'' Bush said while reporters were present for a picture-taking session. ``I'd like to see him shift from that highly militarized island and let democracy have a chance,'' said Bush. ``I think if we are helpful to Nicaragua and Panama, it will simply increase the pressure in that marvelous island of Cuba for change.'' On Capitol Hill, Eagleburger sought to reassure senators about the need for the aid package and to press them on its urgency. For Panama, where the administration is seeking $500 million, the money is a one-shot economic boost, he said. The administration does not expect to come back next year for still more money, Eagleburger told them. Nicaragua's $300 million would not begin to flow until the current leftist government of Sandinista President Daniel Ortega fully turns over power to Chamorro, he added. But he seemed to acknowledge the tough job ahead, and several members of the panel pointed to a thicket of potential problems that could delay the package beyond April 5, when Congress recesses for Easter. ``We won. We got what we wanted'' in Nicaragua and Panama, Eagleburger said. ``Now we are going to see if we have what it takes to sustain what we helped to start. We may be about to learn that winning was the easy part.'' The most immediate problem is how the package will be paid for. The administration has proposed a list of cuts in Pentagon spending to free money for the aid bill, but is still negotiating with Congress over which programs should be cut. Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., said he believed those talks would be completed in the next two days. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., the subcommittee chairman, said it was almost certain that opponents of U.S. military aid to El Salvador would seek cuts in aid as a signal of displeasure over that government's failure so far to bring to justice the killers of six Jesuit priests. Nicaragua itself still must find a way to reintegrate the Contra rebels, who have fought the government for the past decade, into peaceful society. The U.S. government says there now are 15,000 Contra fighters and 45,000 family members, most of them in Honduras, who need to be repatriated. Eagleburger acknowledged that suspicions are deep on both sides and that all the rebels are unlikely to lay down their weapons and move back by Chamorro's April 25 inauguration. The package includes some $42 million for Contra repatriation, and anti-Contra lawmakers will likely want to debate that issue. And Leahy accused the administration of having its priorities wrong, suggesting he might seek to divert some of the money to help bolster fledgling democracies in Eastern Europe. Nicaragua and Panama are of ``slight economic, security and foreign policy importance'' compared to Europe, he asserted. A spate of other amendments also awaits the bill, including a Kasten-Leahy proposal to offer $400 million in housing loan guarantees to Israel to build accommodations for Soviet Jews moving there under the Soviet Union's relaxed emigration policies. Eagleburger seemed to soften the administration's position on that proposal, saying it would support the idea ``on the assumption that we can obtain adequate assurances with regard to those funds'' on Israel's plans for settlements in the occupied territories. The statement was less categorical about needed assurances than recent statements by Bush and by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. In addition, as the first must-pass legislation to come along in this year's congressional session, the Panama-Nicaragua bill will become a popular target for pet projects of lawmakers. Dozens of members already have indicated an interest in offering amendments. ``It seems to me we have to establish the emergency nature of this ... in a stronger way,'' said Kasten. ``Right now there is not enough of an emergency nature to this total package.''

DOC.HEAD: White House Expresses Concern About Soviet Troop Movements Near Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 11 and 14 to CORRECT first-name reference to Gorbachev and to quote administration as saying the Baltics were discussed at Malta
DOC.TEXT: The White House expressed concern Tuesday about Soviet troop movements around the breakaway republic of Lithuania, urging the Kremlin to avoid creating ``an atmosphere of intimidation and increasing tension.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We don't have any indication of forcible control being exerted.'' However, he added, the troop movements ``are cause for concern and they do precipitate a little higher level of interest on our part.'' The statement was triggered by Soviet military maneuvers in and around Lithuania and the beefing up of Soviet security around state-run factories and power plants. The Soviet moves apparently were designed to prevent Lithuanian leaders from carrying out their declared intention of taking full control of government property. The Bush administration's statement was met by a new pledge from Moscow that it would not use force in the Baltic republics, even though it rejects Lithuania's vote to secede from the Soviet Union. ``We are against the use of force in any region and particularly against the use of force domestically,'' said Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, standing alongside Secretary of State James A. Baker III in Namibia during a celebration of its independence from South Africa. Baker commented, ``The minister has said that on a number of occasions.'' The United States has never recognized the forced incorporation of Lithuanian or the Baltic states of Estonia and Latvia into the Soviet Union in 1940. On the other hand, the United States has not responded to Lithuania's declaration of independence by granting formal diplomatic recognition. Fitzwater referred in his statement to ``the Lithuanian government'' but said that was not intended to imply a change in policy. The U.S. course has been to urge Lithuania and the Soviet Union to negotiate a peaceful settlement for the future of the republic. In contrast to the expression of concern voiced by Fitzwater over the troop movements, President Bush praised Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for his restraint on Lithuania. ``I'm glad that they're (the Soviets) still talking peaceful change,'' Bush said, replying to reporters' questions during a meeting with congressional leaders. ``That's essential and they've been very good about it _ the Soviets have all through Eastern Europe.'' Bush added, ``We want to see democracy and freedom. We want to see self-determination. And we also want to see peaceful evolution.'' He said he had discussed the issue previously with Gorbachev. An administration official said Bush and Gorbachev, at their summit in Malta, talked about ``Soviet non-use of force in the Baltics and Eastern Europe.'' The official said Gorbachev assured Bush that force would not be used. The press secretary, reading from a prepared statement, said, ``We continue to urge a constructive dialogue'' between Lithuanian and Soviet leaders. ``This would be complicated by an atmosphere of intimidation and increasing tension,'' he said. ``In this regard, the activities and statements of the Soviet government over the past few days are cause for concern. We are watching the situation closely.'' Fitzwater said he did not expect the issue to mar prospects for a summit between Bush and Gorbachev this summer. ``I don't anticipate any cloud at this time in any way.''

DOC.HEAD: Opponents Hope to Overturn New Guam Abortion Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Wednesday time element is cq. Arraignment Scheduled for 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of the most restrictive U.S. abortion law are organizing in hopes of persuading voters in this territory to overturn the measure in November. A court test of a section of the new law already was under way Wednesday, less than 48 hours after Gov. Joseph Ada signed the bill, which was unanimously passed March 8 by the Pacific Ocean island's Legislature. The law prohibits abortions except when a pregnancy endangers the life of the mother. It makes it a third-degree felony to perform an abortion or aid in the procedure, a misdemeanor for a woman to solicit or have an abortion and a misdemeanor for a person to solicit a woman to have an abortion. Janet Benshoof, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Reproductive Freedom Project in New York, was to be arraigned Wednesday on a misdemeanor charge of solicitation to commit abortion. During a speech Tuesday at the Guam Press Club, Benshoof urged woman needing an abortion to travel to Honolulu for the procedure. ``I was very specific in my breaking of the law,'' Benshoof said. ``The information that I gave, which is now a crime, came from the Honolulu Yellow Pages.'' Two investigators from the territorial attorney general's office taped the speech, and Attorney General Elizabeth Barrett-Anderson filed the charge later in the day. Benshoof faces up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine if convicted. The attorney general had advised the Legislature before the vote that the measure is unconstitutional. After the governor signed it, she said, ``it is not my duty to decide the statute's constitutionality but to enforce it.'' A pro-choice group, Guamanians for Self-Determination, set an organizational meeting for Thursday and pledged to fight the law. The meeting was scheduled by about 35 women who met following Benshoof's speech Tuesday. The law sets a referendum for the 130,000 residents of this island about 1,500 miles east of the Philippines to decide whether to keep the law. The issue of giving advice about abortions also was involved in a federal appeals court ruling in Boston on Tuesday. The 1st Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals ruled that a federal regulation that prohibits government-funded family planning clinics from discussing abortion with clients is an unconstitutional infringement on freedom of speech. The court said the speech at issue involves telling a woman about an activity ``in which she has a constitutional right to engage.'' Elsewhere, Idaho's state Senate put off until Thursday a vote on what could become the most restrictive abortion law of any state. Supporters and opponents expect the bill to pass. Gov. Cecil Andrus has said he is anti-abortion but has refused to say whether he will sign or veto the measure. A filibuster in the Maryland Senate against an abortion-rights bill continued for sixth day on Tuesday. The bill would allow unrestricted abotions until a fetus is old enough to survive outside the womb. In Laredo, Texas, the City Council on Monday passed a resolution stating that life begins at conception. While a resolution is merely an expression of the council's opinion, an anti-abortion activist said he'll push for a city anti-abortion ordinance. Benshoof came to Guam on Sunday in hopes of dissuading Ada from signing the bill. She was unable to arrange a meeting with the governor. ``This is an issue that effects all women in the United States, not just Guam,'' she said. Guam residents are U.S. citizens but cannot vote in U.S. elections. It has an appointed governor and elected legislature.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Regulators Considering Bailout
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan regulators are considering a controversial program that would pump taxpayer dollars into ailing thrift institutions before they fail. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. on Tuesday chose eight states whose institutions would be eligible for open thrift assistance, but postponed until next week approval of the program itself. The states, picked because they are economically depressed, are: Alaska, Arizona, Arkansas, Colorado, Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas. Even if the FDIC adopts the program, the money for it would have to come from the Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board, a Treasury Department-led panel that controls the policy and pursestrings of President Bush's S&L bailout. The board has said in policy directives that it prefers bailout money be spent on closing failed S&Ls. Although it has not entirely ruled out open thrift assistance, the board was reportedly unhappy with the FDIC's draft proposal because in some cases the old managers of the assisted thrift would have been allowed to keep their jobs. Congress in last year's S&L law specifically authorized regulators to aid open thrifts in depressed states, but some members of Congress argue that propping up the institutions wastes money and does little more than postpone failure. Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of a House Banking Committee task force on the S&L bailout, and Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., a member of the banking committee, have written in opposition to the plan. A similar program in the past ``actually increased the ultimate cost of resolution and ... created unhealthy incentives in the entire industry,'' they wrote. However, Seidman said regulators would consider the assistance ``only _ I repeat _ only when the cost of the assistance is clearly less than the cost of closing the institution or any other alternative available.'' He said the FDIC would require that new capital be raised from private sources, in addition to the federal money, and that stockholders and creditors of an assisted institution be left no better off than if the institution were shut down. The managers, if they contributed to the institution's problems, would be thrown out. In the past, Seidman has argued that open thrift assistance is sometimes cheaper because seizing and selling an S&L so tarnishes its reputation that new buyers demand more government aid than would be required to revitalize the thrift under the old owners. In a separate development, the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision demoted its top supervisory official, transferring him to the agency's Indianapolis office. Darrel Dochow, who had been the thrift office's director of supervision, is swapping jobs with Indianapolis director John Downey. Dochow had been criticized by the House Banking Committee for his part in handling the failure of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Irvine, Calif. The top official of the thrift office, M. Danny Wall, left earlier this month. He had been preceded by the agency's senior attorney, Jordan Luke, who also was criticized in the Lincoln matter.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Namibia Becomes Independent Nation
DOC.TEXT: Namibia became the world's newest nation Tuesday, ending 75 years of South African rule as Africa's last colony with traditional tribal dances and choirs singing liberation songs. The South African flag was lowered for the last time at midnight local time and the new blue, red and green Namibian flag was raised as thousands of blacks and whites cheered and clapped at independence ceremonies. The huge, arid territory of 1.3 million people on Africa's south-west coast was a German colony until it was captured by South Africa during World War I. Representatives of dozens of nations attending the celebrations were using the occasion for some behind-the-scenes consultations, with the United States, the Soviet Union and others holding an elaborate series of meetings. Among the foreign guests attending the celebrations are U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze; Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak; the leaders of at least 12 African nations; and the foreign ministers of Britain, West Germany, Romania, Indonesia and other nations. South Africa agreed in December 1988 to grant independence to Namibia under a regional peace treaty that also calls for Cuba to withdraw its 50,000 soldiers from Angola by mid-1991. The independence date was chosen to mark the 30th anniversary of the ``Sharpeville Massacre,'' when 69 unarmed demonstrators were shot and killed in South Africa while protesting apartheid laws in a black township south of Johannesburg. ``The day was chosen as a sign of solidarity not only for the people of Namibia, but also with the people of South Africa,'' said Hifikepunye Pohamba, who will become the home affairs minister in the new government. Pohamba is a member of the South-West Africa People's Organization, the group that waged a 23-year war against South African rule and captured 57 percent of the vote in elections last November. Namibia for decades has had the same apartheid laws of racial segregtion as South Africa, although most were scrapped in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Angolan President Wants Cease-Fire, Talks With Rebels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 1st graf to include Cuban warning to UNITA; picks up 2nd graf pvs, bgng: In Namibia ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Baker
DOC.TEXT: Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos presented Secretary of State James Baker with a nine-point peace proposal on Tuesday, including a call for a cease-fire and direct talks with U.S.-backed rebels, sources said. The meeting took place as Cuba warned it would retaliate against the U.S.-armed rebels for an attack against a Cuban supply column in Angola last week. The rebels say the Cuban troops were escorting a resupply unit of the Angolan government. In its statement issued Tuesday, Cuba said one soldier was killed and six wounded in the March 17 attack. ``This new aggression against Cuban troops will not be left without punishment,'' the statement said. U.S. officials say Cuba is complying with an agreement to withdraw its troops from Angola by next year. In Namibia, where the meeting took place on the sidelines of independence celebrations for the former South African colony, a U.S. official said Dos Santos appeared more flexible on the cease-fire proposal than he had until now. Baker is expected to discuss the Angolan proposal with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze at meetings in Windhoek Tuesday and Wednesday. Shevardnadze, whose government provides Angola with weapons to fight the U.S.-armed Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA), also met Tuesday with Dos Santos in Windhoek. The nine-point proposal has not been made public but was obtained from sources on condition they not be identified. It appears loosely based on a peace plan Dos Santos outlined earlier this year. The plan appears to have some of the same problems that caused UNITA to reject it in the past _ it fails to allow for incorporation of the organization in Angola's political life. Instead, the proposal envisages ``the right of citizens to participate in political and social life.'' It also calls for the ``recognition of the legitimacy of the government and the state'' _ a proviso that UNITA also has rejected as a pre-condition for talks. The rebels want the government to be determined by elections in which UNITA can participate as a group. The change appears to stem from the plan's ninthpoint, which calls for ``direct contacts with a view to achieving a cease-fire and mechanisms of direct negotiations.'' In Windhoek, a U.S. official said Dos Santos ``appeared more inclined toward an early cease-fire than three months ago.'' A cease-fire negotiated last June by Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko broke down last summer and the Angolan government attacked inside UNITA territory in February. The sides have been locked in combat around the town of Mavinga in recent weeks. The Angolan plan also calls for: _ ``The neutrality and the positive attitude of third party governments.'' This appears to be a reference to ending arms supplies by the United States and Soviet Union; _ ``Special and adequate treatment of Jonas Savimbi's case.'' Savimbi has rejected past Angolan demands that he go into exile.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: This cat burglar has nine lives and 14 crimes on his rap sheet. And police aren't very happy about it. It seems the Meier family pet, Punkin', tripped a burglar alarm in his owners' home 14 times while the family was on a three-day vacation. The Tippecanoe County Sheriff's Department is willing to forget three of the trips made to the home to investigate, but it wants the family to pay $925 in fines for the other 11. Besides setting off the security system, Punkin's home alone stint left a pet gerbil dead and telltale traces of a litterless kitty in the family's house plants. ``I suppose we'll keep him,'' Cheryl Meier said.

The 1,237 citizens of Dover in north-central Tennessee are bracing for the 20th century _ the town's first traffic light. It's going up where U.S. 79 and state route 49 cross. ``I don't think we've had a large number of accidents per se at the intersection,'' said Police Chief Steve Watkins. ``However, we do have a traffic flow problem, sometimes lengthy waits and things like that ever since the state put the four-lane highway through.'' But Dover has no tickets to issue those who run red lights. ``I guess we can use the citations we have for running a stop sign for a while,'' said city recorder Jimmy Scurlock.

Ever had the urge to rip off those pesky tags on pillows and mattresses? Well it's legal in Colorado. Gov. Roy Romer put to rest consumer fears by signing a law Monday that deregulates the mattress and bedding industry, making it legal to tear the tags off bedding items. He formalized the law by gleefully tearing a label off a pillow at his state Capitol office. Ken Mesch, a legislative liaison for the Colorado Department of Health, said the laws were enacted half a century ago to certify that bedding materials were sterile. ``We have learned in the last 50 years a lot more about how people get sick,'' Mesch said. ``And we know now that they don't get sick from mattresses.'' Rep. Jim Pierson, who introduced the bill told Romer that as a child he was concerned, ``I might get in trouble by accidentally tearing that label off.'' ``I've been worrying about the mattress inspector jumping through the window for years, and I hope this removes that,'' the governor said.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Forms Volunteer Border Force Despite Kremlin Warning
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Lithuanian youths volunteered Tuesday to serve as the breakaway republic's customs and frontier guards despite a Kremlin warning not to change border security operations. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said the warning from Moscow actually marked the beginning of negotiations on the Baltic republic's demand for independence. He said Lithuania agreed with much of the Kremlin statement, including the order to maintain trade ties. Lithuania declared itself independent on March 11, 50 years after it was occupied by the Red Army and annexed to the Soviet Union. The Soviet Parliament declared the decree invalid but did not say what steps it would take to stop the republic from seceding. In a stern warning to Lithuania on Monday, the Kremlin ordered its own ministries to ensure there were no interruptions in customs and frontier procedures and in trade, transport and communications. Lithuania Tuesday moved ahead with plans to take charge of its borders, however, and youths volunteered to help. ``I served two years in the occupying army, and now I want to serve in my own country's,'' said a young man as he rushed to turn in his application in a cramped office in the Lithuanian capital's center. Lithuanian officials said there were no plans to arm the border force. The symbolic value of the force may help convince other governments that Lithuania is controlling its territory and should be formally recognized as a full-fledged country, said Edward Tuskenis of the republic parliament's information center. The small Baltic republic was quiet Tuesday, with none of the disturbing signs of Soviet troop movements that intimidated the population over the weekend. Officials said there also were no signs of an economic blockade by Moscow. ``We are still receiving gas and oil,'' Lithuania's two most critical imports from the Soviet Union, said Prime Minister Kazimera Prunskiene. Telephone communications between Lithuania and the West were restored on Monday after being cut off for 2{ days due to what Soviet officials said was maintenance work. However, Lithuanian Deputy Prime Minister Kazimieras Motieka said Soviet military airfields in the republic ``have an excessive number of helicopters and perhaps also military units.'' Lithuania, on the Soviet Union's Western front line, contains eight military bases and tens, if not hundreds of thousands of troops, according to emigre sources. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has said he does not intend to use force against the rebellious republic. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, speaking Tuesday in Windhoek, Namibia, reiterated that position. ``We are against the use of force in any region, and particularly against the use of force domestically,'' he said. The White House voiced concern about Soviet troop movements on Lithuania's borders, but spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Gorbachev had offered assurances the Kremlin would not resort to force. A Lithuanian activist said people still were worried that an attack might be staged on Soviet soldiers or their families to create an excuse for a military takeover. ``We are concerned for the safety of Russian officers and their families,'' said Virgilius Cepaitis, who served as a Lithuanian representative in the Soviet Parliament until the declaration of independence. He claimed that a provocateur attacked Soviet soldiers in Azerbaijan in January, helping set off a military invasion of Baku in which hundreds died as troops tried to end ethnic strife and restore Soviet power. ``We have knowledge that similar troops are in Lithuania,'' he said. ``But will they be used, or not?'' Cepaitis said Lithuanians also feared an embargo and that individual Soviets in positions of power would cut off supplies. With the Soviet economy already experiencing extreme shortages of nearly everything, he said it would be very easy for a manager who cannot fulfill all his orders to send his goods to the Ukraine rather than Lithuania. Lithuanian officials said the border force was intended largely to keep Soviet shoppers from stripping Lithuanian shelves bare in case of shortages. Mrs. Prunskiene said the government hoped to have 37 border posts within 10 days in spots where there are now traffic police on the Soviet boundaries and KGB troops on the frontier with Poland. ``It will be a very gentle regime,'' said Mrs. Prunskiene. ``There will be no visas on the Soviet side or great demands. But it will show there is a border already being observed and protected by our country.'' Many of the hundreds of youths who signed up serve on the force are recent deserters from the Red Army, said Ludwiga Pociuniene, who was taking the applications at the Lithuanian Parliament building. Lithuanians have been complaining since the push for independence began two years ago that their young men had been harassed and tortured and faced death in the ranks of the army. Motieka said the Lithuanian government was registering the deserters in hopes of protecting them from forcible return to their units. However, he said military authorities had warned the government that steps would be taken to arrest the soldiers and return them to the army beginning on Saturday. In another development, Mrs. Prunskiene said she and Deputy Prime Minister Algirdas Brazauskas met Tuesday with factory directors to assure them that Lithuania wants business to proceed as usual. The Kremlin order had warned Lithuania not to seize state enterprises and sell them to private businesses, and Landsbergis said the government had no intention of doing that.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Seeks to Form Israeli Government, Pledges Quest for Peace
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres pledged to make peace talks with Palestinians his first priority after President Chaim Herzog chose him on Tuesday to take on the arduous task of forming a new government. Peres said that if he succeeds, he will accept U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III's proposal to open a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue in Cairo. Peres' hard-line rival, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of the Likud bloc, rejected Baker's plan. ``I think there is a majority in the Knesset (parliament) for peace,'' Peres said. ``I will try to form a government as quickly as possible.'' The selection of Peres as prime minister-designate gave center-left Labor a distinct advantage over Shamir, whose refusal to accept the U.S. proposals led to the breakup of the Likud-Labor coalition. Shamir, 74, remains head of a caretaker government until a new governing coalition is assembled, He could get a crack at putting together a government if Peres fails to complete the task within the six-week limit. A statement from his office said Shamir respected the president's decision but would not give up his campaign to set up a Likud-led government. ``We will still make efforts to form a government under Likud after Peres definitely fails to form his own government,'' Shamir spokesman Yossi Ahimeir said. Peres, 66, conceded that he and Shamir each controlled 60 seats in the 120-member parliament, but said he believed he could win more support. ``There is no doubt that we need to make up with people. We need to find common ground,'' Peres said. He left open the possibility of joining hands with almost any parliament faction, even Likud. To do so, he must oversee a shotgun wedding of small leftist factions and ultra-Orthodox religious groups. That could undercut his ability to make the concessions needed to advance peace negotiations. Herzog's position as head of state is largely ceremonial. Israeli law left him with the task of breaking the tie between Peres and Shamir. Herzog said in a televised address after picking Peres that Labor was the largest faction and had the best chance after winning a no-confidence vote against Shamir in parliament, 60-55, last Thursday. Herzog said he saw no prospect for another Labor-Likud government because neither party would accept the other's leadership. ``Common sense obligates us to give a chance to a new direction, one other that which fell to a no-confidence vote,'' he said. He called for electoral reform to create more stable government, noting that the prime ministry changed five times, or once every 16 months, since he became president in 1983. Labor and Likud have shared power in a broad coalition since 1984, which was headed by Peres as prime minister for the first two years. Peres needs the backing of 61 members of parliament to form a new coalition. No candidate nominated by the president failed to assemble a government, although Peres in 1984 and Shamir in 1988 had to share the power. Peres had looked like a shoo-in to be tapped as premier-designated, but a last-minute switch by a small religious faction threw the nomination into doubt until the last moment. Israel television said Shamir had the edge because he was the incumbent and the religious factions would fit more readily with the conservative Likud. But Israeli newspapers said Peres remained Herzog's likely choice because the party was technically the largest faction with 39 legislators to Likud's 35.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Expects Lending Agency Pact by July
DOC.TEXT: A plan to create an international lending agency to aid the economic recovery of Eastern Europe may be completed by July, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said Tuesday. ``There is a sense of urgency among our European colleagues ... to get this job done ... by the economic summit this summer,'' Brady told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee. The summit is scheduled for July 9-11 in Houston. The leaders of the Group of Seven nations _ Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan, the United States and West Germany _ will attend. On another topic, Brady told reporters that he will meet later this week with Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto. Brady said the meeting would be in California, but did not give a specific date or location. Brady did not say what he and Hashimoto would discuss, but there was speculation the agenda might include efforts to defuse the growing trade friction between the United States and Japan. Brady told the subcommittee that the United States would contribute between 8{ percent and 10 percent of the $10 billion capital for the European Bank for Reconstruction and Redevelopment. The United States wants most of the funds aimed at private-sector initiatives for the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, he said. Participation by the Soviet Union should be limited to the amount of its contribution, Brady said. The Soviets tentatively are scheduled to contribute 6 percent to the bank's capital. Brady has said the United States would refuse to participate unless the Soviets are barred from borrowing any more money than they contribute. ``We feel ... the purpose should to be assist and aid Eastern Bloc countries,'' Brady said. ``We don't want to crowd out the needs of those Eastern Bloc countries by having an enormous participation by the Soviet Union.'' Representatives of the 39 nations involved in creating the agency plan to resume negotiations April 9 in Paris. One of the issues to be settled is the amount of capital the United States will contribute, which will determine U.S. influence on the bank's decisions. The Europeans will have 51 percent of the bank's votes, Brady said.

DOC.HEAD: McGruff, the Crime Dog, to Fight Drugs and Alcohol Among Children
DOC.TEXT: What better way to get a message to a young child than through coloring books and comics? That's the idea behind the National Crime Prevention Council's new anti-drug publications featuring ``McGruff, the Crime Dog.'' ``This prevention message is delivered each time a child picks up one of the books to read or color,'' said John A. Calhoun, NCPC executive director, as the coloring and comic books were presented Tuesday at a news conference. ``The message is received not once but many times per child,'' Calhoun said. The coloring book, called ``Crack Down on Drugs,'' is aimed at children who are in pre-school through third grades. In the book, McGruff tells children to refuse to drugs and encourages their efforts in sports, games, school and in helping friends. Children in third and fourth grades who face peers and slightly older youths who encourage them to use alcohol and drugs are the target of the comic book, called ``McGruff's Surprise Party.'' Two million copies of each book have been produced to be distributed free by the Office of Substance Abuse Prevention's nationwide alcohol and drug awareness resource centers, and by 46 state crime prevention organizations. The agency is part of the Department of Health and Human Services. The coloring book artwork was donated by the Noteworthy Corp., and the comic book was designed by Custom Comic Services. Single copies of the books can be requested from the National Clearinghouse for Alcohol and Drug Information, P.O. Box 2345, Rockville, Md. 20852. The phone number is 301-468-2600.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in South Hampering Crops
DOC.TEXT: Too much rain in parts of the South has hampered farm work while other areas have benefited from widespread precipitation, the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Tuesday. ``Heavy rains added to the already surplus moisture supplies in much of the Delta,'' the facility said in its report for March 12-18. ``Rain improved winter wheat prospects in most of the Great Plains and portions of the Pacific Northwest.'' The facility is operated by the Agriculture and Commerce departments. The weekly reports cover crop conditions but do not include production forecasts. Pastures were reported to be improving as a result of the widespread moisture. Livestock was said to be in good condition with spring lambing and calving continuing in most areas.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Close Out Poindexter Case, Defense To Play Reagan Tape
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 20 grafs new with judge denying motion for acquittal, Reagan videotape to be played starting Wednesday. Picks up 16th graf, In highlights
DOC.TEXT: U.S. District Judge Harold Greene denied John Poindexter's motion for acquittal Tuesday after the prosecution closed out its case against the man who was once President Reagan's national security adviser. Poindexter's lawyers said they would begin playing seven hours of videotaped testimony from Reagan on Wednesday in an effort to bolster their client's defense. Poindexter is accused of obstructing and lying to Congress to cover up the Iran-Contra affair. Greene said evidence garnered from 10 witnesses called by the prosecution in its 7{-day presentation against Poindexter suggests he adopted false information ``designed to obstruct Congress.'' Poindexter ``sent Oliver North to meet with'' the House intelligence committee, where North lied by denying he was assisting the Contras militarily, the judge said in rejecting the motion for a acquittal. There is evidence that the ``defendant destroyed'' a presidential finding as well as ``5,000 ... notes'' in his computer on the Iran initiative, said Greene. In addition, the judge said, the jury has heard evidence that ``Oliver North got permission from Admiral Poindexter to check out and cover up'' five memos showing North's military assistance to the Contras. Poindexter attorney Richard Beckler told Greene there is no evidence Congress had inquiries pending at the time Poindexter supplied information on the Contras and a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles. In urging acquittal, Beckler said Poindexter's destruction of a presidential document on the Iran initiative is ``the epicenter'' of the government's case. Yet the destruction of the document is never mentioned in the indictment, said Beckler. Greene replied that it isn't necessary for the document, a presidential finding, to be mentioned in the indictment. Poindexter is accused of covering up the U.S. role in the 1985 missile shipment and North's secret Contra resupply operation. He is charged with conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb said there is ``overwhelming evidence'' to proceed with the five criminal charges against Poindexter. ``People like Admiral Poindexter who engage in conspiracies ordinarily don't speak out, ... don't discuss what they are doing,'' said Webb. He asserted that a trail of documents shows that Poindexter conspired, obstructed Congress and made false statements. The prosecution's final witness, Senate staff member Eric Newsom, testified that ``it did seem strange'' how little Poindexter said he knew about the missile shipment when questioned a year afterward by members of Congress. The defense's first witness, former White House lawyer Dean McGrath, said on cross-examination that he ``wouldn't have cleared'' letters signed by Poindexter if he had known they were false. The letters embraced statements made the previous year by Robert McFarlane denying that North was raising money for or assisting the Contras militarily. ``You would have ... stopped'' the letters ultimately signed by Poindexter if they were false? asked prosecutor Louise Radin. ``I would have tried to,'' replied McGrath. The government's primary witness was North, who testified with evident reluctance for 3{ days against his former boss. Last week, North testified that he had watched Poindexter destroy the presidential finding which ratified the missile shipment. In highlights of the government's case against Poindexter: _Poindexter told the FBI three days after resigning his White House post as the Iran-Contra affair was becoming public in November 1986 _ and after the meeting with senators that figured in Tuesday's testimony _ that he had ``no working knowledge'' of early Iran arms shipments and ``no direct knowledge'' that profits had been diverted to the Contras, FBI agent Ellen Glasser testified. _Rep. Lee Hamilton testified Monday that Poindexter failed to tell the House Intelligence Committee about the Reagan finding relating to the missile shipment and then-CIA Director William Casey told the committee the document didn't exist. Casey sent Poindexter a copy of the finding a year before the CIA director denied its existence, according to documents introduced at Poindexter's trial. _North testified he was reluctant to go to an Aug. 6, 1986, meeting to answer lawmakers' questions, but that Poindexter sent him anyway, telling his aide that ``you can handle it'' or ``you can take care of it.'' North lied at the meeting by denying he was assisting the Contras militarily. North testified the decision to lie was his own.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Presses Kohl On Polish Border Guarantees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lede, inserts new 3 graf with quote from Fitzwater
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Tuesday to press the U.S. position that Poland's current borders should be guaranteed when Germany reunifies, Bush's spokesman said. The president telephoned Kohl on the eve of a visit to Washington by Poland's Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who is expected to raise the border issue with Bush. ``They did discuss the Polish borders question,'' Fitzwater said of Bush's call to Kohl. ``President Bush reiterated our position that we are strongly supportive of the Helsinki Final Act, which calls for the inviolability of the Polish borders.'' The Poles are still nervous about the issue even though Kohl, under pressure from the United States and internally, finally endorsed the idea of keeping the current borders. Bush called the German leader to talk about the move to reunify East and West Germany and to discuss Sunday's election in East Germany, said press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. The balloting was won by a coalition of conservative parties allied with Kohl's ruling Christian Democrats in West Germany. The results are seen as a good sign for the future of Kohl's party in a unified Germany. Kohl's government recently agreed that the Poles can be represented in the unification talks among the two Germanys and the World War II victors who divided Germany and ceded part of its territory to Poland. Poland has been worried that the looming reunification could mean a new unified Germany will demand its pre-war borders. Fitzwater said the administration is confident that Kohl's position is in line with what Bush has said. Initially, Kohl refused to endorse the current borders of Poland as permanent, saying that question could only be answered by a unified Germany. Despite his new position, Fitzwater noted, ``The Polish still have questions.'' He said Mazowiecki would raise the matter with Bush during his state visit on Wednesday. When that happens, the spokesman said, ``We listen to his concerns very closely and we look forward to talking with him, and we'll just have to see what the discussion leads to.' A senior administration official who briefed White House reporters on the Mazowiecki visit said Tuesday that administration officials ``are delighted'' that West Germany is endorsing having the Poles in on the unification talks regarding border issues. ``What has been done meets the concern'' of the United States, said the official, who spoke on condition his name not be used.

DOC.BYLINE: Broccoli-Hating Bush Encounters `The Broccoli Fellow' ^By CHRISTOPHER CONNELL
DOC.TEXT: President Bush may not like broccoli on his plate, but he got a big kick Tuesday out of seeing a lobbyist wearing a stalk of broccoli as a boutonniere. Bush broke into laughter when he spotted George S. Dunlop, president of the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association, wearing the leafy green vegetable dressed up like a carnation on his lapel. It was a jocular protest against Bush's reported edict banning broccoli from the menu aboard Air Force One, the presidential aircraft. The encounter came as Bush was shaking hands with farm lawmakers and lobbyists attending a ceremony at the White House where Bush signed a proclamation designating Tuesday as National Agriculture Day and urged Congress ``to help us pass a good, fair farm bill.'' When he came to Dunlop, Bush did a double-take, laughed and insisted his photographer get a picture of him with ``the broccoli fellow.'' Reporters at the ceremony could not hear the president's exchange with Dunlop, but the lobbyist said afterward that Bush told him, ``Hey, I like that! That's good!'' He said Bush added that folks who ``like the taste of broccoli really ought to eat it. It's good for them. Just because I don't care to eat it, it doesn't mean that others shouldn't.'' Bush's taste in food runs to pork rinds, taco salads with hot-pepper sauce and chocolate bars mixed with oat bran. Dunlop, a former Senate Agriculture Committee chief of staff who now represents the $60 billion produce industry, said he had a florist at a local supermarket make up the boutonniere. Broccoli is a $400 million crop for American farmers in California, the Carolinas and other vegetable-growing states, said Dunlop. But the produce pusher said he harbors no ill feelings at the president's disdain for the vegetable. ``It's a free country,'' the lobbyist said. ``There's plenty of things the president does like. If he doesn't care for broccoli, maybe he likes carrots or apples or potatoes.'' And what did Dunlop plan to do with his boutonniere? ``Well, I think I'll go home and eat it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Independence Movement Wins in Estonia Parliament
DOC.TEXT: Independence supporters won Estonia's parliamentary elections, giving secessionist movements a sweep of the three Baltic republics, according to preliminary results released Tuesday. In Moscow, activists of the Democratic Russia bloc that took control of the city council in Sunday's runoffs debated what to do with their power, but they appeared divided and lacked a platform. Estonia's initial results indicated candidates from the People's Front won at least 38 of the 105 seats in the republic's new parliament, said Rina Lohmus, a correspondent for official Estonian Radio. At least 16 seats were taken by the Estonian Committee, a more radical independence group. A group of small parties supporting the People's Front platform also won several seats, according to the radio. Results from about 15 seats still had not been determined, Lohmus said. The secessionists' win followed the electoral victories of independence movements in the neighboring Baltic republics of Latvia and Lithuania. In Lithuania, pro-independence lawmakers declared their republic's independence from the Soviet Union about two weeks after Feb. 24 balloting, widening their split with Moscow. Latvia's elections were Sunday, and the pro-independence movement won a majority. However, it remained unclear whether it could muster the two-thirds vote needed to declare independence. ``More people supported the People's Front than we expected,'' said Lempi Tekone, a spokeswoman for the Estonian group. She said the People's Front anticipated having the support of about three-quarters of the deputies. Official results were not expected until Friday. Yedinstvo, a group representing primarily Russian-speaking residents who strongly oppose the Baltic independence drive, would have about 25 percent of the seats, she said. Ms. Lohmus said Free Estonia, an election group created by the republic's Communist Party, had won about 10 seats. Among those who won seats from Free Estonia were the party leader Vaino Vyalyas and Premier Indrik Toome, she said. The Estonian Communist Party has not worked as hard for independence as many Estonian activists would like, but it is expected to support independence in any important legislative votes. However, Estonia is unlikely to follow Lithuania in pushing hard and fast for independence. Activists say the parliament is likely to discuss sharing power with the Estonian Congress, a citizens' gathering demanding independence, and press for talks with the Kremlin. Reformers also claimed victories in key runoff elections held Sunday in Russia, Byelorussia and the Ukraine, the Slavic heartland that accounts for about 80 percent of Soviet territory and two-thirds of its population. Some 1,610 runoffs were held in these republics after no candidate polled 50 percent of the vote March 4 in the main round of elections for local parliaments and councils. The Moscow electoral commission said 55 of the capital's 65 seats in Russia's parliament were dominated by candidates of the reformist Democratic Russia alliance. Democratic Russia won 263 seats in the 465-seat Moscow city council, ensuring itself a 60 percent majority. But it was unclear whether members of the alliance would be able to agree on a joint program. ``We came to the bloc from various groups because we all shared some democratic views,'' a councilman who gave his name as Fadeyev told a meeting of Democratic Russia activists at Moscow State University. ``But now this stage is over. We see that there are Communists, Socialists, Social Democrats and even Christian Socialists among us.'' ``We must be united. The only hope of the old party apparatus is to cause a split among us,'' said Sergei Sukhorukov, another councilman. Russian Parliament member Gavriil Popov, who presided over the tense gathering of about 150 activists, suggested the alliance appoint committees to work out the group's platform and proposals for reforms. The only immediate measures were a request to Moscow's prosecutor to investigate anti-Semitic leaflets that appeared during the elections and called Democratic Russia a ``United Jewish Front,'' and a demand that local newspapers include party affiliation when naming election winners. In Leningrad, reformists of a group called the Democratic Elections-90 bloc won 60 percent to 70 percent of the city council seats, the official Tass news agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Is Issue in Illinois GOP Gubernatorial Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `The State ...,' to UPDATE with afternoon turnout. Polls close at 8 p.m. EST in Illinois, 9 p.m. EST in New York; material below the dash will stand.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: An anti-abortion conservative challenged the Republican front-runner in the gubernatorial primary Tuesday, and Rep. Gus Savage fought to keep his job after allegations of sexual misconduct. Attorney Richard Phelan, whose ethics investigation led to the resignation of U.S. House Speaker Jim Wright, battled three opponents for the Democratic nomination for the powerful Cook County Board presidency. Chicago Alderman Edwin W. Eisendrath, 32, sought to deny 80-year-old Rep. Sidney Yates the Democratic nomination for a 21st term from the 9th Congressional District. Also in the race was James Newport-Chiakulas, 49, a National Education Association official. Late polls gave a wide lead to Secretary of State Jim Edgar, a pro-choice moderate, in the GOP primary race to replace retiring four-term Republican Gov. James R. Thompson. Steven Baer, abortion opponent and political newcomer, was Edgar's closest challenger. A third candidate, Dr. Robert Marshall, ran a low-profile campaign. The winner squares off in November against state Attorney General Neil Hartigan, who faced no opposition in the Democratic primary. In the 2nd Congressional District, representing parts of Chicago's heavily Democratic South Side and some suburbs, Savage faced his toughest primary since first winning election in 1980. Challenger Mel Reynolds said Savage embarrassed constituents when he was investigated for harassing a Peace Corps worker in Africa. Also in the Democratic primary was Ernest Washington Jr., a follower of extremist Lyndon LaRouche. Phelan spent thousands of his own dollars to finance a media blitz, but late polls showed him running only slightly ahead of R. Eugene Pincham, a black former state appellate judge. The two other contenders were County Clerk Stanley Kusper and state Sen. Ted Lechowicz, the Democrats' slated candidate. The State Board of Elections said just over 6 million Illinois residents were registered to vote. By late afternoon, turnout was running at about 43 percent in Chicago and 25 percent in suburban Cook County. Also Tuesday, New York City voters filled two vacant congressional seats in special elections. Republican City Councilwoman Susan Molinari was favored to win the seat given up by her father, Guy Molinari, who has become Staten Island borough president. And in the Bronx, state Assemblyman Jose Serrano was the front-runner to win the job vacated by Robert Garcia after his conviction in the Wedtech influence peddling scandal.

Edgar, 43, was state GOP leaders' choice as the best hope of retaining the Executive Mansion occupied 14 years by Thompson, who plans to join a Chicago law firm. Edgar picked up President Bush's backing on Monday. Baer, 30, flayed Edgar for his support of abortion rights and extension of last year's temporary 20 percent state income-tax increase. Baer had support from conservative activist Phyllis Schlafly, but Edgar, despite his pro-choice position, won the endorsement of a leading anti-abortion congressman, Rep. Henry Hyde. Savage, a 64-year-old black Congressman whose district is 70 percent black, invoked race to rally his troops, saying he was the victim of ``white-owned media.'' The U.S. House ethics committee this year ruled Savage made improper sexual advances to the woman during a 1989 trip to Zaire. No charges were pressed. Reynolds, a 38-year-old black Rhodes scholar making his second bid for the seat, was endorsed by Chicago's two largest daily newspapers. The top job in Cook County _ which includes Chicago _ came up for grabs when George W. Dunne, 76, announced he was retiring after 21 years. Phelan, 52, was staff attorney for the House ethics committee's investigation of Wright. The candidate has long been active in Democratic politics, but the contest for the patronage-rich post marks his first candidacy. Pincham, 64 _ an ally of the late Harold Washington, Chicago's first black mayor _ made headlines in 1987 when he said blacks who didn't vote for his friend ``ought to be hung.'' Kusper, 55, stressed his experience, but was dogged by reports he put county money in no-interest accounts in politically connected banks. Lechowicz, 51, was little known outside his Northwest Side district despite 20 years in the General Assembly. The uncontested GOP nominee for the board president's job was state Sen. Aldo A. DeAngelis. Voters in the 9th District, covering Chicago's North Side and suburbs, have given Yates high seniority in the House, where he serves on the Appropriations Committee. Eisendrath, a former teacher, stressed the need for new blood. Democratic U.S. Sen. Paul Simon was unopposed in the primary, as was the Republican he will face in November, Rep. Lynn Martin.

DOC.HEAD: New TV Miniseries Forces Boston to Recall an Old Racial Nightmare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `This is ...' to CORRECT name to `Pixie,' sted `Dixie,' and `Palladino,' sted `Pallandino;' picks up 9th graf, `It could ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX6
DOC.TEXT: Ted Landsmark can't forget the bloody anti-busing riots of the 1970s any more than people can forget the Pulitzer Prize-winning photograph taken of him under attack outside City Hall by angry whites wielding an American flag. But after previewing a television re-creation of the nightmare, the young, black attorney and others are asking: How well have we remembered? A brief silence spread over the audience after a private screening Monday of ``Common Ground,'' based on the best-selling book by Anthony Lukas. The docudrama will be broadcast Sunday and Tuesday on CBS-TV. The group of about 60 people sat quietly, perhaps fatigued by the 192-minute Hollywood re-creation of the racial drama that tore this city apart 15 years ago. Then the talk started. The voices _ many still bitter _ belonged to the people who inhabit ``Common Ground,'' the story of three families caught up in the riots that broke out when black students were bused into the white neighborhood of Charlestown. ``I don't think anyone views this as pure entertainment ... but it could be an opportunity for the commmunity to disuss what remains to be done,'' said Landsmark, who now directs the mayor's Office of Jobs and Community Services. Not everyone who attended the showing was of that mind. ``This is nothing but pornography!'' said Elveira ``Pixie'' Palladino, an anti-busing activist. It could have been any Boston high school auditorium more than a decade ago. But it was not, and that's what some found troubling. ``It's a shame that some people can't live with the pain and the same of the past,'' said George Walker, whose half-sister, Cassandra Twymon, was bused to Charlestown and whose family is featured in Lukas' Pulitzer Prize-winning book. ``Cassandra and I were just kids ... guinea pigs,'' said Lisa McGoff, whose Charlestown family's story was also chronicled. ``I'm not going to apologize to anyone for what this book is about.'' The book is about Alice McGoff and her stand against the forced desegration she felt threatened her children and mostly Irish community. It's also about Rachel Twymon and her belief that education could secure for her children a life better than that they'd known in the city's Roxbury section. Those two strongly held beliefs came at an enormous cost to the families and to the city. The public school system has never recovered and the racial battle lines, though at times less stark, remain intact. ``I don't think it's any stigma to Boston ... but even the mayor didn't come out as well as he'd like to and maybe the city didn't either,'' said Kevin White, who was mayor during the riots. ``Funny, none us were ever the same after the war was over.'' It was a war and, like any historic passage, should be examined with the distance only time provides, the producers said. ``Obviously there's a feeling among some of these people that they don't want this picture shown,'' said Daniel H. Blatt, who produced the miniseries for Lorimar Telepictures Co. ``But what occurred has to be faced.'' The producers and families featured in the film, all of whom had veto rights on the script, testified to its accuracy. Lukas said he only regretted that his 661-page book had been condensed to a four-hour script that largely overlooks his third family, the Divers, who tried to promote social justice amid a city in tumult. Mayor Raymond Flynn, who was an anti-busing activist in the 1970s, did not attend the private showing or return repeated telephone calls to discuss it. The producers said he refused to let the production company film the more incendiary scenes on location. ``He felt that shooting here would incite violence,'' said Blatt. ``I can't put myself into his shoes, but this problem of race and class and education is with us today. It's a reality.''

DOC.HEAD: Raytheon Becomes Fifth To Plead Guilty in Secret Documents Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Raytheon Co. pleaded guilty Tuesday to illegally obtaining secret Air Force budget documents and agreed to pay $1 million in fines and penalties. The plea in U.S. District Court made Raytheon, of Lexington, Mass., the fifth defense contractor to plead guilty to trafficking in classified Pentagon documents. Raytheon's guilty plea involves the actions of a former employee, John R. Kiely, who obtained a classified 1983 Air Force document. However, U.S. Attorney Henry Hudson said in a statement that Raytheon illegally obtained a wide range of Pentagon papers from 1978 to 1985. Under a plea bargain approved by the court, Raytheon will pay a $10,000 criminal fine and $990,000 in civil penalties and damages. The government said it has no evidence that anyone now associated with Raytheon was involved in the scheme or knew about it. Since November, four other contractors have entered guilty pleas and three other individuals have been convicted in the investigation code-named ``Operation Uncover,'' an investigation still under way. The key documents involved generally were Defense Department five-year spending plans. The others convicted were: _Boeing Co. Boeing paid fines and penalties of $5.2 million following its Nov. 13 guilty plea. Former Boeing employee Richard Lee Fowler was convicted Dec. 7 of 39 counts of conspiracy, conveyance without authority, mail fraud and conversion of government property. He received a two-year prison sentence. _RCA Corp., a subsidiary of General Electric Co. RCA pleaded guilty Feb. 5 and paid fines and restitution totaling $2.5 million. A current RCA executive, Ronald Stevens, and a former executive, Leonard Kampf, are awaiting sentencing on their guilty pleas to conveyance without authority. They each face possible sentence of 10 years in prison. _Hughes Aircraft Co., a subsidiary of General Motors Corp. Hughes entered a guilty plea March 9 and was ordered to pay $3.57 million in fines and penalties. _Grumman Corp. Grumman pleaded guilty last Friday and was ordered to pay $2.5 million in fines and penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua's Vice President-Elect Accused of Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Vice President-elect Virgilio Godoy said Tuesday that the Sandinista Front was engineering a campaign to discredit him by having him accused of fraud. The case could prevent his taking office next month. The allegations involve research foundation funds. Judge Ramon Rojas Mendez of 4th District Criminal Court rejected the charge on a technicality Tuesday, but the charge could be filed again. The judge said the accusers failed to inform police, as required before accusations can be presented in court. Godoy hinted that forces in his own United National Opposition coaliation were involved in what he called a ``campaign of calumny,'' in an internal power struggle to weaken his position when the government takes office April 25. He said he believes his life might be in danger if he is cleared in court. ``This shows the the Sandinista Front's interest in saying goodbye by kicking Virgilio Godoy ... (and also) the involvement of people from the private sector in this matter,'' Godoy said. He said later, when asked to expand on the private sector remark, ``It's an attempt on their part to weaken the figure of the vice president in order to obtain positions of power'' within the new government. He named no names. President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and Godoy were the winning ticket of UNO, a coalition of 14 parties and one native Indian organization. The UNO swept general elections on Feb. 25, unseating the Sandinistas after 10{ years in power. Four men filed a document in court Monday accusing Godoy of fraud. Two of them, Joaquin Mejia and Juan Manuel Gutierrez, belong to the Liberal Independent Party. Godoy is president of the party. The four allege Godoy failed to account for funds donated to a research center by the West German Friedrich-Naumann Foundation. In rejecting the charge, Godoy cites a letter from the foundation that brands the accusations as false. ``This is a new campaign to slander me,'' Godoy said in an interview on Radio Catolica. In expressing fear for his life, the vice president-elect said, ``While I'm under attack ... the danger of a physical aggression is still on the sidelines. (But) when this media terrorism ends, I'll have to take better care of myself because then I'll be closer to an attempt at personal aggression, including physical elimination.'' Should Godoy be arrested and tried, he could not take office until the judicial matter is settled. If convicted and imprisoned, he also could not take office. Last November, Godoy was stripped of his legislative immunity as a deputy of the Sandinista-dominated National Assembly as a result of the same accusations. That action opened the way for legal charges to be filed.

DOC.HEAD: New Costa Rican President Meets Bush
DOC.TEXT: The incoming president of Costa Rica, Rafael Angel Calderon, met with President Bush on Tuesday to discuss peace developments in Nicaragua and U.S. aid to Costa Rica. Calderon expressed interest in following the lead of outgoing President Oscar Arias to continue Costa Rica's involvement in working for peace and political stability in Central America, said one U.S. official. Arias won a Nobel peace prize for his work in spearheading the regional peace accord that led to last month's election in Nicaragua and the end to the Contra war. Arias and other Latin American leaders are engaged in talks on how to demobilize the U.S.-backed Contra rebels and arrange a peaceful transfer of power when Nicaragua's Marxist President Daniel Ortega leaves office April 25. Costa Rica also is seeking greater U.S. economic assistance, said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The new Costa Rican president is a conservative and a supporter of strong U.S.-Costa Rica ties. Calderon also met with Vice President Dan Quayle. Talks were also scheduled with Cabinet members and members of Congress. Calderon takes office May 8 for a four-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Maryland Banker Revises Lawsuit Against CIA
DOC.TEXT: A former official of a Baltimore bank said Tuesday he has filed a revised lawsuit which seeks $4 million from the bank, the CIA and other federal officials for allegedly ruining his life after he balked at handling arms transactions for a CIA front. Robert Maxwell charges that he was threatened, was forced to resign and suffered a nervous breakdown after he questioned the legality of certain dealings relating to an account held by the now-defunct Associated Traders Corp. at the First National Bank of Maryland, in Baltimore. Maxwell left the bank in late 1985, taking with him several documents which, he told a news conference Tuesday, linked Associated Traders with at least $23 million in covert arms shipments to Central America, Angola and Afghanistan. Published accounts by columnist Jack Anderson and others, dating to 1986, have identified Associated Traders, dissolved in the wake of that publicity, as a CIA front. According to Maxwell's suit, bank officials confirmed to him that it was. More than a year ago, Maxwell brought a $19 million damage suit against the bank in state court. The bank's attorneys, who succeeded in moving the case to federal court, filed legal briefs saying ``a relationship between First National and the CIA or Associated Traders and the CIA could be classified information which can neither be confirmed nor denied.'' Bank counsel Gary Sutton has declined further public comment on the case, as has the CIA. Maxwell's revision names the CIA and 10 ``John Does'' in other federal agencies as defendants. According to the new suit, another bank counsel, Joseph G. Finnerty, transmitted threats to Maxwell's attorney, Thomas J. Dolina, in behalf of unnamed government officials that if he didn't ``go easy'' on the suit, Dolina would be disbarred and Maxwell would be criminally prosecuted. Calls to Finnerty's office and home were not immediately answered. Maxwell talked to reporters Thursday at the offices of the Association of National Security Alumni. The group opposes clandestine operations and is backing Maxwell's legal effort.

DOC.HEAD: Service Personnel Chiefs Disagree on Test of Women in Combat
DOC.TEXT: The Army's top personnel officer said Tuesday he opposes a proposed four-year test of whether women can hold combat-related jobs. His Air Force counterpart disagreed, saying there probably isn't a war-time job in his service that women couldn't do. The test has been proposed in legislation put forward by Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo. ``I don't feel that a test is necessary,'' Army Lt. Gen. Allen K. Ono testified before the House Armed Services subcommittee on military personnel. ``The fundamental issue ... is (one of) national policy. There's no ducking that _ whether women should serve in direct combat, and that's for you to decide,'' Ono told the lawmakers in the first subcommittee hearing on women in the military. Ono argued that other nations, such as Canada, have wrestled with the issue of using women in combat-related jobs and that the United States can learn from their experiences. Although Canada recently offered infantry training to 80 women, only one became qualified, the panel was told. The general said that it would also be difficult to conduct such a test in peace time and that there is no military need to bring women into combat fields. ``The Army can't operate without its women soldiers _ but in regards to combat arms, we are able to recruit sufficient numbers of males,'' Ono said. However, Lt. Gen. Thomas A. Hickey, the Air Force's personnel chief, told the lawmakers that ``there probably isn't a combat job in the Air Force that women couldn't do. ``They're physically capable; they're emotionally capable. If you want us to put them there, it's up to you,'' Hickey said. By U.S. law, women in the Navy and Air Force are barred from serving in combat jobs. The Army is not covered under the same statute and has written its own policy to comply with the law. Ms. Schroeder submitted her legislation following the U.S. invasion of Panama in light of the fact that some of the 600 women who took part in the initial operation came under fire even though they were not detailed to units considered combat-related. Ms. Schroeder, who testified about her bill before the panel, argued that excluding women from combat-related jobs doesn't protect them from coming under fire on the battlefield and actually ``shuts off many routes of advancement'' for women who want to make the military a career. The congresswoman pointed out that one Army advertisement highlights a female soldier working in a communications van, directing other soldiers in the front lines of battle. Mrs. Schroeder said that even though women are allowed to enter communications jobs, they could be posted to one of the first sites targeted by an enemy eager to cut off an opponent's communications. ``It appears that women can be the first killed, but they're not allowed to be in the front lines,'' Ms. Schroeder said. ``I think that really shows you how tenuous many of these classifications really are.'' The congresswoman has proposed legislation directing the Army to conduct a four-year test of women to see how they would perform in the combat-related units. Rep. Beverly Byron, D-Md., the chairman of the subcommittee, said she is not in favor of opening combat jobs to women, but is interested in making sure that women in the military have promotion opportunities in their selected fields. ``I've got some misgivings about any change in the combat exclusion law,'' Mrs. Byron said. File Stored As:

DOC.HEAD: Group Decries Stores Putting Sugar Cereals at Kids-Eye Level
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs pvs 9th graf, Officials of, with 4 grafs of comment from Lucky Stores
DOC.TEXT: A consumer group complained Tuesday that supermarket displays putting sugar-laden cereals at kids-eye level are attracting children with ``candy ads masquerading as cereal.'' Such displays add to the problems of getting children to eat more nutritious foods, said the Center for Science in the Public Interest.
