Victoria Leonard said the center surveyed supermarket cereal displays and found child-oriented cereals in colorful packages generally lower than the more nutritious cereals marketed for adults. ``That makes it more likely to catch the attention of a child walking by,'' said Leonard. ``Children are being bombarded by candy ads that are masquerading as cereal.'' CSPI volunteers last November looked at the location of cereals displayed in 27 grocery stores in the Boston, San Francisco, Chicago, Baltimore and Washington, D.C. metropolitan areas. ``The average position of ten child-oriented brands was the next-to-bottom shelf, while the average position of ten adult brands was the next-to-top shelf of a typical four-shelf-display,'' the center said. All 27 stores displayed adult cereals such as Grape Nuts or Nutri-Grain which have an average of 10 percent sugar content on higher shelves than child-oriented products such as Froot Loops or Cap'n Crunch which contain an average 44 percent sugar content, the center said. Surveyors shopped at stores of several supermarket chains, including Giant Food Inc., Safeway and Lucky Stores, Inc. Officials of Lucky's had not received a copy of the survey but spokeswoman Judy Decker said the company has ``never had an objective to place cereals on shelves to attract children's attention.'' Decker said cereals are grouped according to manufacturer and how quickly they sell in the stores. ``The lower shelves usually have the fastest moving items,'' she said, explaining that the lower shelves are spaced farther apart and allow stock personnel to stack more cereal than in the middle and upper shelves. Officials of other stores and food marketing industry representatives did not immediately return phone calls. Leonard said the center has written the stores asking that they change the displays and elevate the children's cereals. ``Children are attracted by the brand names and flashy packaging and then plead with their parents to buy them,'' she said. ``We want parents to make the choice.'' She said display techniques and intense television advertising of sugary cereals during Saturday morning children's programming compound problems of parents. CSPI is a nonprofit, 200,000-member organization founded in 1971 to promote improved health policy.

DOC.HEAD: Pieces of Spy Satellite Falling Back to Earth, U.S. Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts one graf after third pvs, dates two pieces reentered
DOC.TEXT: Pieces of a spy satellite put into orbit over the Soviet Union by the space shuttle last month are falling back to Earth and burning up as they pass through the atmosphere, the Defense Department indicated Tuesday. ``Two of the items have already entered the Earth's atmosphere,'' said spokesman Pete Williams. ``The remainder are expected to decay within two to seven weeks.'' Williams did not identify the items as a satellite but said they were ``associated with'' last month's secret mission of the space shuttle Atlantis. NASA sources have said astronauts aboard Atlantis put a sophisticated $500 million spy satellite into an orbit that carried it over much of the Soviet Union. The Defense Department said one piece burned up on reentry on March 15, but it did not say where. A second piece made its fiery dive over the Gulf of Alaska on March 19. There were reports from the Soviets last week that the satellite had broken into four big pieces, which were being tracked by radar. The Defense Department acknowledged then that some debris from the shuttle mission would be coming back to Earth. U.S. officials would not confirm the specifics of the Soviet reports, saying merely that the Atlantis mission ``has achieved its goal.'' ``On the average one to two items in space from the hundreds of space launches each year reenter the atmosphere each day,'' Williams said Tuesday. He refused to answer more questions.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Holds Back Loan for China
DOC.TEXT: China's request for a $150 million loan for road improvements won't be presented to representatives of the World Bank, a bank spokesman said Tuesday. Peter Riddleberger declined to say why bank President Barber B. Conable decided to hold back the loan. A source familiar with the bank's work said Conable decided Monday to withhold consideration of the loan when it became apparent it would not be approved. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said last week that the United States would oppose World Bank loans that were not for basic human needs. The $150 million loan would have been used to improve roads and inland ways in Jiangsu province, in the east central part of China. Decisions on loans are made behind closed doors by the 22 members of the bank's Board of Executive Directors, most of whom represent several countries. The United States controls only 19 percent of the vote, but that is the largest single block. Usually enough other governments support the U.S. view to give it the needed majority. In June, Conable withheld consideration of nearly $800 million worth of loans to China after troops suppressed the pro-democracy movement. He said that decision was made on economic grounds. President Bush asked that loans be held up as part of the U.S. sanctions against the Chinese government. The board last month approved two loans to China worth $90 million, including one that had been delayed in June. The U.S. representative voted for approval, the Treasury Department said. The World Bank, with 152 member governments, is the largest single source of aid to the Third World, making loans of more than $22 billion a year.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Rebels Assail Another Group for Surrendering
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the National Liberation Army derided another leftist rebel group for surrendering to the government and pledged to keep up a sabotage campaign against the oil industry and U.S. businesses. At a meeting deep in the Andes mountains last Saturday with eight reporters, ELN commanders chided the April 19 Movement, known as the M-19, for laying down its arms and transforming itself into a political party this month. The M-19 won seats on city councils and one mayor's office in nationwide municipal elections on March 11. Its participation was considered a victory for President Virgilio Barco's peace plan. Barco has repeatedly exhorted other rebel groups to accept the plan. ``We were always uncertain about the M-19's ideological position,'' said one ELN commander, identifying himself only as James. ``Now it seems our doubts were justified.'' ELN, Colombia's most active leftist guerrilla organization, says it will never negotiate with the government and holds fast to a Marxist-Leninist plan to take and hold power. Its members denigrated the M-19. ``They fought for 16 years to win a mayor's office,'' said Ernesto, an ELN operative in Bogota. ``We control large sections of the countryside. Who is more intellegent?'' The ELN has long wreaked havoc in the rural areas through ambushes of security forces and sabotage campaigns. Now it appears to be launching a news media offensive. ``We are planning to increase our contacts with the press in order to clarify our positions and correct the lies of the government,'' said commander Argemiro. The reporters, contacted by ELN operatives at cafes and other public places in Bogota, were taken by different routes to a drop-off point, where rebels led them into the hills. To reach the camp, an Associated Press reporter, accompanied by two rebels, hiked nine hours in the dark across terrain ranging from dense jungle to rocky mountains. At the camp, on cleared land tilting down into thick mountain vegetation, 12 ELN soldiers shouted slogans as they raised Uzi submachine guns and assault rifles toward a television camara. They later performed training exercises for the camera's benefit before posing arm-in-arm with the television crew. After feeding the exhausted journalists soup made of animal intestines and dirty water, ELN commanders gathered them around a rickety table. They demanded a national commission be formed to accept the release of 14 soldiers kidnapped by the ELN in February. The commanders said freeing the soldiers would prove ELN's commitment to humane treatment of prisoners of war, and challenged the government to follow suit. They accused the military of murdering rebels captured in combat, a charge the government denies. They invited reporters to return to the mountains to witness the soldiers' releases at the end of this month. Although the ELN is still learning how to deal with the news media, it is highly skilled when it comes to attacking government security forces, kidnapping opponents, and sabotaging Colombia's oil industry. For years local radio has peppered Colombians with news of ELN attacks on army and police patrols. The group's armed forces are estimated at 1,000 to 2,000 rebels. ELN is said to finance part of its activities by ransoms paid by hundreds of cattle ranchers it kidnaps every year. The commanders would not discuss the ELN's strength or its financing. They had a simple message regarding petroleum facilities: they plan to keep attacking them until the government nationalizes the industry. The ELN has pulled off eight dynamite attacks this year against Colombia's main oil pipeline running 500 miles from the border with Venezuela to the Caribbean port of Covenas. The commanders bristled when asked about the government's view of them as terrorists costing the nation millions of dollars in foreign exchange each year. ``We are patriots who are saving the country money by preventing the export of petroleum that belongs to our people,'' said a commander called Dario. ``The crumbs given to the government by the foreign oil companies are just a fraction of the money the country could earn if the industry were nationalized.'' A month ago the ELN swore to attack U.S. business interests here as part of a ``sovereignty campaign'' to defend national interests. The ELN was founded in 1965 and took its inspiration from the Cuban revolution. Now it says it is tired of being linked to Fidel Castro.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Namibian History
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS first and last graf to UPDATE with independence, CORRECTS spelling of Namibia in slugword
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Namibia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Highlights in the history of Namibia, which became the world's newest nation Wednesday: 1884 _ Declared a German protectorate. 1915 _ Occupied by South Africa on behalf of the Allies during World War I. 1920 _ League of Nations gives South Africa administrative mandate. 1966 _ United Nations cancels mandate. South Africa rejects the resolution. The South-West Africa People's Organization begins guerrilla war against South African rule. 1975 _ SWAPO acquires bases in Angola after that country's independence from Portugal. 1978 _ U.N. Security Council passes Resolution 435, calling for cease-fire, elections under U.N. supervision, and independence. 1982 _ South Africa agrees to grant independence if Cuban troops leave Angola, where they are support the Marxist government in a civil war against guerrillas aided by the United States and South Africa. 1988 _ The United States, the Soviet Union, Angola, Cuba and South Africa sign an agreement on Namibian independence, withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola, and an end to South African aid to Angolan anti-government guerrillas. February 1989 _ U.N. forces begin arriving. April 1, 1989 _ Independence process begins, but fighting breaks out between South African police forces and hundreds of SWAPO guerrillas crossing the border. More than 330 men die before a cease-fire is reimposed. July, 1989 _ More than 40,000 exiles begin returning home. November 1989 _ SWAPO wins the most votes in a U.N.-supervised election, but not enough to avoid compromising with other parties on a constitution which establishes a Western-style democracy. The last South African troops leave. Wednesday _ Namibia gains independence.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Charges Prominent Jordanians With Corruption
DOC.TEXT: A closed session of parliament Tuesday charged 20 prominent Jordanians, including seven former Cabinet members, with financial and administrative corruption, lawmakers said. One lawmaker, speaking on condition of anonymity, said those accused included four members of the parliament, which was elected in November. The names were made available to The Associated Press and were confirmed by four deputies who attended Tuesday's session. They cannot be disclosed under a law that prohibits open allegations against private and public figures unless they are convicted by Jordanian courts. State television said the parliament turned the case _ said to involve 37 projects including construction of a desert highway and expired food projects _ over to the attorney general to pursue ``those who were responsible for mismanagement.'' The parliament has the power to charge officials with crimes. If convicted, the accused will face prison sentences and fines, and the government will permanently confiscate their property and cash. Seven of the former Cabinet members are members of parliament, the sources said. They confirmed an eighth person accused is a well-placed politician. Also accused were a former senior security official, two former senior Central Bank officials, three prominent merchants, a leading banker and five senior government department officials, among whom one is member of parliament. The deputy who discussed the case said the 37 projects were recently investigated by the parliament and ruled as ``tampering with public funds.'' He said a previous government spent $935 million on the construction of a desert highway, while the actual cost of the bid was $51 million. Another case involved selling expired food products. ``The lab tests proved that these expired products caused cancer if consumed, such as red meat, canned food and coffee, which were sold to Jordanian citizens for many years,'' the deputy said. The government of Prime Minister Mudar Badran backed the parliament's decision to bring charges, and the motion was adopted by a vote of 76-0 with four abstentions, one deputy said. The deputy said the abstentions in the 80-member chamber were the four deputies who were accused. Badran has promised to heed parliament's demands to fight the alleged corruption of the government of his predecessor, Zeid Rifai. Four days of rioting erupted in the kindom last April after Rifai's government raised the prices of basic food commodities and fuel. This led to the downfall of Rifai's government, which then was accused of corruption and restriction of political freedoms.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Hopeful for Progress in Angola
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with further Baker, Shevardnadze quotes; EDITS to CONFORM. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Namibia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III met Tuesday with Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos to find ways to end the African nation's 15-year-old civil war, and a U.S. official said dos Santos appeared more flexible on a proposed cease-fire. The administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it was the first meeting between a U.S. secretary of state and an Angolan president since independence from Portugal in 1975. ``President dos Santos appeared more inclined toward an early cease-fire than he was three months ago,'' the U.S. official said. Baker also met with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and said he was assured the Soviet Union would not use force to crush Lithuania's independence movement. ``The minister made it very clear to me that they are hopeful questions involving Lithuania will be handled through dialogue. That's what the central government would like to have happen and that's what they expect to have happen,'' said Baker, visiting Namibia to attend the celebration of independence from South Africa. ``And he, once again, as he has done before ... said that force would not be the solution to the problem as far as the Soviet Union is concerned,'' Baker said. Baker said the talks ``covered a wide range of issues starting with the fact that what is happening here in Namibia we both agree is a good example when the Soviet Union and the United States cooperate rather than compete.'' Shevardnadze said, ``I believe Namibia is the best example that this is realistic.'' The United States brokered an agreement between South Africa, Angola and Cuba that led to independence for Namibia, ruled by South Africa since it wrested control of the territory from Germany during World War I. The Soviet government also was involved in the negotiations. South Africa demanded the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola, Namibia's northern neighbor, as a condition of independence. Cuba has begun a withdrawal of more than 50,000 soldiers from Angola, but fighting continues between the country's Marxist government and anti-Marxist guerrillas. Sources in Washington said on Tuesday dos Santos presented Baker with a nine-point peace proposal, including a call for a cease-fire and direct talks with the American-backed National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA. Shevardnadze, whose government provides Angola with weapons to fight UNITA, met with dos Santos on Monday in the Angolan capital Luanda, before the two flew here for the independence celebrations. Baker was scheduled to go to Zaire on Friday for talks with President Mobutu Sese Seko and UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi, who already has declared his support for a cease-fire. Cease-fire negotiations mediated by Mobutu in June quickly broke down, and fighting has intensified in recent months. Dos Santos has insisted Savimbi's anti-Marxist guerrillas accept some conditions before a truce can be arranged. The U.S. administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity said a stalemate in the fighting could be a factor in dos Santos' apparent change of heart. Zaire reportedly serves as a transit point for the shipment of U.S. weapons to Savimbi. American officials have refused to comment on reports that U.S. aid to UNITA has increased. The U.S. official said Baker made it clear to dos Santos that American support for UNITA will continue until an end to the war is negotiated.

DOC.HEAD: Foreman Outraged, But Government Plans Retrial
DOC.TEXT: The jury foreman in U.S. District Judge Robert Aguilar's trial expressed outrage at the prosecution's case after jurors cleared Aguilar of one charge and voted in strong majorities to acquit him of most other charges. The Justice Department said Tuesday it plans to seek a retrial. ``I wish the government would go away and find something better to do,'' San Francisco bank executive Carl D'Amico said after the six-week obstruction-of-justice and racketeering trial ended Monday with only one charge resolved. Aguilar, a 1980 appointee of President Carter, was acquitted of one charge of trying to influence a friend's criminal case by approaching a fellow judge. Mistrials were declared on the other seven charges after seven days of deliberations, with reported jury votes leaning strongly toward acquittal on most of them. They included a 9-3 vote to acquit on an unprecedented charge that Aguilar had used his federal judgeship as a ``racketeering enterprise'' to obstruct justice. Defense lawyers accused the government of targeting Aguilar as a liberal judge, an accusation the Justice Department denied but which apparently hit home with some jurors. D'Amico said the case ``approaches a political trial.'' Saying he was speaking for a number of his fellow jurors, the foreman called a retrial ``an unfair use of taxpayer money and an affront to a great judge.'' But Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett said the government intends to retry Aguilar on the remaining charges. ``Each trial is different and each jury is different,'' Tillett said. ``We believe, as we always have, that we have a good case.'' Aguilar attorney Hugh Levine was not surprised by the decision. ``In a case that was not a cause celebre but an ordinary felony case, I really can't imagine that any kind of prosecutor, state or federal, who viewed this case dispassionately would seek a retrial,'' he said. ``But the government has made an enormous investment and an enormous commitment to this. It would be much more difficult for them to let go.'' U.S. District Judge Louis Bechtle, a Philadelphia jurist assigned to the case by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, scheduled the retrial for June 4. Aguilar, who remains free without bail, is returning to his San Jose courthouse, where he has kept a limited calendar of cases since his indictment last June. He answered no questions after the verdict but issued a statement thanking God and his lawyers and adding, ``I look forward to further acquittals.'' Even if acquitted, Aguilar could still be impeached and removed from office by Congress, which removed U.S. District Judge Alcee Hastings of Florida last year despite his acquittal on a bribery charge. But New York University law professor Stephen Gillers, an expert on judicial ethics, said if Aguilar is acquitted, his conduct should be viewed as less serious than that of Hastings. Aguilar has not been accused of seeking personal gain through his office, Gillers said. The jury verdict, though inconclusive, was a rebuff to the prosecution, which portrayed Aguilar as a judge blinded by his power and trying to throw his weight around the legal system on behalf of his friends. The heart of the case was an accusation that Aguilar improperly tried to lobby two colleagues for rulings favoring criminal defendants: Ronald Cloud, a friend and creditor facing trial for bank fraud, and Rudy Tham, a former Teamster leader and friend of one of Aguilar's relatives who was trying to overturn an embezzlement conviction. Aguilar was acquitted of trying to influence Cloud's case, and the jury deadlocked 9-3 for acquittal on the charge in Tham's case. Aguilar denied trying to sway either of his colleagues, saying he wanted only to appear as a character witness for Cloud, and merely asked about the Tham case's status. Another juror, Joan McErlean, said the prosecution failed to show motive. She said the jury voted 7-5 for conviction on one charge, that Aguilar had relayed word in 1987 to Abe Chapman, an ex-convict related to him by marriage, that Chapman was being wiretapped.

DOC.HEAD: Another 1,000 Indian Troops Evacuate Northern Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: Another 1,000 Indian soldiers left Sri Lanka on Tuesday ahead of a withdrawal of the peacekeeping force scheduled for completion this weekend, military officials said. The soldiers sailed for home from the Kankesanthurai port in northern Jaffna district, said a Sri Lankan military official who cannot be identified under briefing rules. The port on the northern tip of Jaffna Peninsula is 200 miles north of Colombo. With Tuesday's departure, northern Sri Lanka has been completely evacuated by the Indian troops who arrived in Sri Lanka 2{ years ago to disarm Tamil guerrillas, the officer said. Jaffna has been the center of the seven-year-old Tamil separatist campaign that was led by several guerrilla groups including the dominant Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. Most militant groups surrendered arms under a July 1987 accord that allowed Indian troops to be deployed in Sri Lanka's predominantly Tamil northern and eastern districts. But the Tamil Tigers, after an initial acceptance, turned their guns on Indian soldiers and continued the guerrilla war. At the height of the jungle war against the Tamil Tigers, about 125,000 Indian troops were deployed in the northeast. A phased withdrawal began last year after the new government of President Rane majority against the Sinhalese-dominated government for its efforts to make peace with the Tamils. Tamils, who are mostly Hindus, make up 18 percent of the island's 16 million people and claim they are discriminated against by the Sinhalese majority. Sinhalese, who are mostly Buddhists, comprise three-quarters of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead, About 160 Injured in Renewed Ethnic Clashes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE casualty toll, witnesses saying about 4,000 people involved in melee and that rampage continued into early Wednesday morning; pickup 7th graf pvs, `At the...'
DOC.TEXT: Street violence broke out between Hungarians swinging chains and club-wielding Romanians in a Transylvanian city late Tuesday, leaving at least two dead and 160 injured, hospital officials said. Gangs rampaged through downtown Tirgu Mures into the early morning hours Wednesday in the worst outbreak of violence since the December revolution that overthrew the late Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Tirgu Mures is 250 miles northwest of Bucharest. Dozens of casualties were brought into the central hospital as police and soldiers, armed only with clubs, appeared unable to halt the clashes, witnesses said. Hospital officials confirmed two dead and about 160 injured, many of them suffering from head wounds. Freelance photographer Kevin Harvey, a British national, was among those beaten and clubbed, and was being treated at a local hospital. Others told hospital officials of being struck by ethnic Hungarians swinging chains on the fourth night of fighting between ethnic Romanians and Hungarians. Witnesses said about 4,000 people were involved in the melee in the center of the town. It was the fourth night of fighting between ethnic Romanians and ethnic Hungarians seeking greater cultural autonomy since the overthrow of Ceausescu. At the root of the clashes are ethnic Hungarian demands for separate Hungarian-language public facilities and schools. Tirgu Mures is considered a cradle of ethnic Hungarian culture in Transylvania. The region was ruled by Hungary for centuries, but was granted to Romania under a 1920 treaty. Most of the estimated 1.7 million ethnic Hungarians in Romania live in Transylvania. Ethnic cultures were largely suppressed under the 24-year rule of Ceausescu and minority groups have become increasingly vocal in demanding cultural autonomy since his overthrow and Christmas Day execution. Ethnic Hungarians claim that discrimination has continued since the post-revolutionary government took power. The street violence occured despite the nation's provisional leadership warning that ethnic clashes could destabilize Romania. The clashes have left 102 injured in Tirgu Mures, including 22 on Monday. ``These kind of demonstrations, as well as any kind of extremist, nationalist or chauvinistic actions, irrespective of who they come from, are of the nature to destabilize the national and international situation of Romania,'' the statement said. ``We insist that you go back to your homes in peace,'' said the communique broadcast Tuesday night over national television and signed by the executive bureau of the provisional Council of National Unity, which is acting as a makeshift parliament. Late Tuesday night, a spokesman for the Defense Ministry also appealed for calm over national television. There were no reports of the violence in Tirgu Mures on Bucharest radio or national TV news. In Hungaria's capital Budapest, 50,000 people attended a demonstration to show solidarity with the ethnic Hungarians in Romania. The communique was issued after an emergency meeting of the ruling 21-man Executive Bureau, following earlier clashes in Tirgu Mures. The clashes have their roots in historical rivalries fueled by ethnic Hungarian demands that include the use of Hungarian street signs in areas where many Hungarian live, separate Hungarian-language television stations, schools and other social institutions that were largely suppressed under Ceausescu. Hungarian Foreign Minister Gyula Horn on Tuesday summoned Romania's ambassador to express his government's concern and asked for immediate United Nations mediation to restore order in the region, the Hungarian state news agency MTI reported in Budapest. Horn also relayed a message from Premier Miklos Nemeth to his Romanian counterpart, Petre Roman, saying he was ``shocked'' by news of the reported attacks against ethnic Hungarians in Romania, MTI said. On Monday, hundreds of ax-wielding Romanians attacked the local headquarters of the Democratic Union of Hungarians in Tirgu Mures, wounding at least 11. The national Rompres press organization said 11 other people were wounded in subsequent rioting and street fighting. Among the most seriously injured, MTI reported, was ethnic Hungarian writer Andras Suto, the local president of the organization who suffered broken ribs and an eye injury. MTI said he was flown to Budapest for treatment at the request of Hungarian authorities. At dawn Tuesday, Romania's army sent reinforcements to Tirgu Mures to protect the headquaters of the Democratic Union, MTI reported. There was no immediate confirmation. The Hungarian news agency said during the attack on the headquarters, army and police refused to intervene. The Democratic Union is leading the ethnic Hungarians' call for greater cultural and political autonomy. A government source said the administration was considering sending in a mediator to resolve the escalating conflict between the two ethnic groups. ``Every form of conflict is a threat to the revolution,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Governor Drops Re-election Bid To Avoid Nasty Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill, the dominant force in Connecticut politics for almost a decade, reversed himself Tuesday and said he would not seek a third term in November. O'Neill, who had been saying he was going to run, said he was loathe to enter what promises to be a nasty and negative campaign. ``The modern process of campaigning is a rigorous one. It exacts a toll on the body and the spirit which, at this point in my career, I do not choose to pay,'' O'Neill, 59, told a news conference. O'Neill said his poor standing in the polls had little to do with his decision. And he said his health, which he had previously said would be the only thing that might keep him from running, was not a factor; during his nine years in office, he has had a heart attack, heart bypass surgery and, more recently, colon polyps, one of which was cancerous. He said he and his wife, Nikki, had reached a final decision late Monday. He said he decided he could best serve the state ``by completing this term of office unfettered and unimpaired by the demands of a campaign for re-election.'' A former lieutenant governor, O'Neill became governor on Dec. 31, 1980, when Ella T. Grasso resigned as governor in failing health. He was elected to full terms in 1982 and 1986. Voters have given him poor job approval ratings. O'Neill attributed that Tuesday to record tax increases passed last year and lingering, although far less severe, fiscal problems this year. Polls released this month showed him as a weak contender in what will be a three-way race for governor this fall. In addition to a Democratic and Republican candidate, former Republican U.S. Sen. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has entered the race as an independent. Weicker said O'Neill was ``a class act'' and said he shared O'Neill's foreboding about a negative campaign. The immediate effect of the governor's announcement was to make U.S. Rep. Bruce A. Morrison, a liberal four-term congressman, the front-runner in what is expected to become a crowded field for the Democratic nomination. He has been campaigning for the nomination since last fall. The leading Republican contender is three-term U.S. Rep. John G. Rowland.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion at Missile Factory Injures Four, Gunmen Kill One
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to RECAST and conform; picks up 6th, `Later, the'
DOC.TEXT: Two IRA bombs exploded at a missiles plant Tuesday, slightly injuring four people, and police said in a separate attack that gunmen burst into the home of a Belfast Protestant and killed him in front of his wife. The blasts at the Short Brothers plant in east Belfast had been preceded by warning telephone calls from the Irish Republican Army, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. Police said the plant was evacuated while officers searched for more bombs, but no others were found. The IRA warnings were telephoned to Belfast media 18 minutes before the explosions, police said. Police said the slaying in north Belfast occurred Tuesday night. They said at least two masked gunmen broke into the home of Billy McClure, 43, and shot him to death as his wife watched. Later, the Irish People's Liberation Organization claimed responsibility for the slaying. In a message to Belfast news organizations, it said it killed him in retaliation for attacks by Protestant paramilitaries on Roman Catholic hard-liners. The organization is a breakaway faction from the Irish National Liberation Army, which in turn is a splinter group of the mainly Catholic IRA. Police said McClure had been convicted in 1974 for illegal possession of a gun, but it was not known if he had any links with Protestant paramilitary groups. Brian Feeny, an oficial with the moderate Catholic Social Democratic and Labor Party, denounced the slaying. ``This murder is going to increase tensions in north Belfast, which has now become a virtual killing ground for both sides intent on carrying out retaliatory shootings,'' Feeny said in a statement. ``They achieve nothing. All it does is guarantee that another Catholic will be killed in an equally sectarian fashion,'' he said. Northern Ireland minister John Cope said the IRA bombs were by ``terrorist gangsters ... set on a campaign of destruction for its own sake _ regardless of whose lives they put at risk.'' Short Brothers said three other IRA bombs have exploded at the company's nearby aircraft factory since July 1989. After last month's bombing at the aircraft hangar, the IRA warned there would be further attacks because the company was involved in government defense contracts. A Short Brothers spokesman confirmed the company had a British Ministry of Defense contract to build the new Starstreak missile. Security was tightened and high perimeter fences were built after the previous bombings, the spokesman said. The financially troubled company is the biggest employer in Northern Ireland. It was state-owned until last year when it was sold to Canada's Bombardier Inc., an aerospace company. The IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the predominantly Protestant province with the Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Injured in Bus-Truck Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Five other ...,' to CORRECT to `people,' sted `band members.'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY45
DOC.TEXT: Singer Gloria Estefan of the hit group Miami Sound Machine suffered a broken vertebra Tuesday when a truck ran into the band's bus on a snow-covered highway in the Pocono Mountains, authorities said. The 32-year-old singer was in stable condition at Community Medical Center in Scranton with a broken vertebra in the middle of her back, said hospital spokeswoman Nancy Parlo. Miss Estefan was not paralyzed, said Dr. William Pfeifer, who treated her. He refused to say if surgery was planned. Five other people and the truck driver were treated at the hospital and four were later released. They included the singer's husband, Emilio Estefan Jr., 37, who suffered head and hand injuries, and their 9-year-old son, Nayib, who suffered a neck injury, the hospital said. Band member Barbara Arecidia, 25, was in stable condition with back and neck injuries, the hospital said. The accident occurred on westbound Interstate 380 about 12:15 p.m. near Tobyhanna, state police said. The group was headed for Syracuse, N.Y., for a concert scheduled for Tuesday night. The rest of the band had already arrived in the city. The Estefans met Monday with President Bush at the White House to discuss her anti-drug work. Their driver, Ron Jones, said he had stopped on the highway when a tractor-trailer jackknifed in the snow and a truck and bus stopped behind it. Jones said the bus was pushed into the truck when another truck rammed it from behind. Miss Estefan was asleep on a couch and was thrown to the floor by the impact, said Jones, who suffered cuts and bruises. ``The road was wet and snow-covered,'' said Trooper Joseph Kearney, the second officer on the scene. ``It was light snow at that time and slippery. Traffic had stopped. ``He (the truck driver) came up on them and was unable to stop. ... He was unable to stop and he should have been. That's the bottom line.'' Kearney said the truck driver, identified as Heraldo E. Samuels, of Scarboro, Ontario, has been cited for driving at an unsafe speed. Miss Estefan was nominated in February for best pop vocal performance by a female for the single ``Don't Wanna Lose You'' in the Grammy awards. Her new album, ``Cuts Both Ways,'' a collection of dance songs and ballads, was 26th on the Cashbox magazine pop chart for the week of March 17. Being on the road is nothing new for Miss Estefan, who was just a baby when her family fled from Cuba in 1962. She grew up Glorita Fajardo, the shy daughter of a former bodyguard for the wife of deposed Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista. Music was at that time, literally, a dream; she would imagine herself on stage, dressed in black. For 10 years, she and Miami Sound Machine have toured the world, attracting millions of listeners with the sounds of salsa, samba and conga. With a string of hit singles, including ``Rhythm Is Gonna Get You'' and the No. 1 ``Anything for You,'' the schedule moves at the pace of their hottest music. She attended the University of Miami, where she met Emilio Estefan Jr. in 1974. Miami Sound Machine was formed in 1975 under his direction, and played Hispanic music as well as Top 40 songs in small halls in Miami. Miss Estefan, who coaxed crowds to ``come on baby, do that conga,'' quickly became the unquestioned star of the band, which plays Latin-flavored pop and dance tunes. The group burst into national prominence in 1985 with the double-platinum album ``Primitive Love'' and its hit single ``Conga.'' The band has played to sold-out arenas in recent years, and was recently formally renamed ``Gloria Estefan and the Miami Sound Machine.'' Miss Estefan said in an interview with The Associated Press last August she has no desire to follow the path of pop stars such as Diana Ross and Deborah Harry, who left their bands behind to pursue a solo career. The husband-and-wife duo complement each other, the singer said. Estefan, the group's manager and producer, has ``a lot of drive and I'm a couch potato,'' she said recently. ``He pushed me along and motivated me with a lot of things, and at the same time I keep him from having a nervous breakdown.''

DOC.HEAD: Assailants Shoot Tear Gas into Two Haitian Schoolyards
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Assailants in a white jeep shot tear gas canisters into two schoolyards Tuesday, causing hundreds of primary students to have vomiting fits and setting off panic downtown, radio stations said. It was the latest incident in a surge of violence in Haiti. The attackers hit Venezuela Co-Ed School in La Saline, a crowded seafront slum, at 9 a.m., said privately owned Radio Haiti Inter and Radio Antilles. They said many of the 700 elementary school pupils began vomiting from the tear gas, and parents rushed to the area to withdraw their children. The Roman Catholic Church's Radio Soleil said the assailants moments later shot a tear gas canister into nearby Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic primary girls' school, causing teachers and students to evacuate the building. Both schools were immediately closed. The incidents caused hundreds of pedestrians and peddlers to flee downtown streets and most other schools in the area closed, but this capital city of 1 million people returned to normal by noon. The Unity Assembly in a communique Monday night denounced attempts to undermine the civilian government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot. ``A forceful criminal movement has been generated to make a river of blood flow in the country,'' it said. The organization is a broad political and civic coalition that led national protests resulting in the ouster March 10 of military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. Late Monday gunmen killed a soldier and wounded seven civilians while committing several holdups and shooting at passers-by in the capital. Masked thugs beat eight nuns and slashed them with machetes Sunday at a Catholic girls' school in Port-au-Prince, drawing strong protests from the French Embassy. The U.S. Embassy in a communique Tuesday condemned ``in the strongest possible terms'' the ``barbarous'' attack. Private Radio Cap-Haitien said at least 10 peasants were wounded Monday in the north coast town of Borgne during a demonstration in favor of the Pascal-Trouillot government. The station said Tuesday that four of the peasants, hospitalized in nearby Cap-Haitien with bullet wounds, said soldiers fired on the estimated 2,000 demonstrators without provocation. The Unity Assembly chose Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, a Supreme Court justice, to succeed Avril and she was inaugurated as provisional president on March 13, a day after Avril flew into U.S. exile. Army chief of staff Lt. Gen. Herard Abraham pledged loyalty to the new government. But the Haitian military _ ill-equipped and infested with elements loyal to past dictatorships _ has almost never intervened to protect civilians from armed marauders. The army high command said Tuesday that Maj. Isidore Pongnon, accused by political and civic groups of responsibility for widespread human rights abuses, and six other military personnel were discharged from the army.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Approves Bill Allowing Free Travel Abroad
DOC.TEXT: Soviet citizens would be allowed to travel abroad freely under a bill approved Tuesday by a parliamentary committee. The official news agency Tass said the Supreme Soviet legislature now will debate the measure and committee members will insist it be adopted at the current session, which ends in late April. Under provisions of the bill, permission would not be required for Soviets to leave and return, either for short trips or permanent residence abroad, Tass said. ``A passport for traveling abroad will be issued for a period of five years to whoever applies for it,'' the news agency said. It said state security considerations, criminal proceedings and incarceration could prevent a person from being issued a passport. Access to classified materials would allow the Soviet government to deny an individual a passport for five years, Tass said. ``A citizen may lodge an appeal with any authority, up to the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, against a refussal to issue a foreign travel passport,'' Tass said. The bill was introduced by Fyodor Burlatsky, a Supreme Soviet deputy and well-known political commentator, who called it ``a major indicator of democratization in the Soviet Union.'' Members of the committee that approved the measure warned against delay in solving related issues, including rules on exchanging money and buying airline tickets. Unless flying on the state-run airline Aeroflot or its joint ventue partner Pan Am, Soviets who want to travel abroad must pay in hard currency. Under newly introduced tourist exchange rates, a $1,000 airline ticket would cost a Soviet traveler about 6,000 rubles on a foreign airline. The Aeroflot and Pan Am flights are sold out for more than a year in advance. Last year, 235,000 people left the country for permanent residence abroad and 2 million took short trips; 300,000 travelers visited the West, Burlatsky said.

DOC.HEAD: `Cheers' No.1, Matt Dillon Outdraws the Phantom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Here are ...,' to CORRECT ``In the Heat of the Night'' network to NBC, sted CBS.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Troubled CBS' call for help from Marshal Matt Dillon left NBC's ``Phantom of the Opera'' choking on trail dust and helped the network draw second place in the overall ratings released Tuesday. A ``Cheers'' episode on NBC about St. Patrick's Day bar jokes took first place in the A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings for the week ended March 18. ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' on ABC was second and ``Roseanne,'' also ABC, was third. ``Gunsmoke: The Last Apache,'' starring James Arness as the durable lawman, was No. 7 in the ratings, tied with ABC's ``The Wonder Years.'' ``Gunsmoke's'' Sunday night rival, the first half of the two-part NBC miniseries ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' was 40th, tied with ``Amen'' and ``Dear John.'' For the week, NBC finished first with an average rating of 13.8, its 22nd consecutive week of winning the ratings. CBS was in second place with 11.7, edging out ABC, which finished with 11.5. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. It was the second time in three weeks that CBS finished No. 2, the network pointed out. ``The Simpsons,'' Fox Network's cartoon family, finished 11th in the ratings with a 17.5 and won against the first half-hour of a new episode of CBS's ``Murder, She Wrote.'' It was the highest ranking ever for a regularly scheduled Fox show. Here are the Top 10 shows, their networks and ratings: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 22.1; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 22.0; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 21.9; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 21.8; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 20.4; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 20.3; ``CBS Sunday Movie _ Gunsmoke: The Last Apache,'' CBS, 19.7; tied with ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC, 19.7; ``Who's the Boss,'' ABC, 18.1; ``In the Heat of the Night,'' NBC, 17.9. ABC's ``World News Tonight'' was first in the news show average ratings for the 10th week in a row, with 10.6, followed by ``NBC Nightly News'' with 9.2 and the ``CBS Evening News'' with 9.1. Jane Pauley's NBC News special, ``Changes,'' was ranked a respectable 32nd, tied with ``Hunter'' for a 13.2 rating. A repeat of ``The Karen Carpenter Story,'' CBS' much-advertised effort to counter the Pauley show, was in 50th place with ``Anything But Love'' and a 10.8 rating. While Marshal Dillon did well, ``Kojak'' on ABC came in 75th for the Saturday night ``ABC Mystery Movie.'' ``Why, Charlie Brown, Why,'' a CBS special with the ``Peanuts'' gang dealing with serious illness, was 65th.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs; picks up 4th graf: ``Obviously, there,''
DOC.TEXT: Census officials were rebuffed Tuesday night when they tried to count residents staying at the city's largest shelter for the homeless. Activist Mitch Snyder refused to allow a team of census-takers in the Capitol Hill shelter operated by his advocacy group, the Community for Creative Non-Violence. Snyder, who on Monday broke a nine-day fast in protest of the city's cuts in spending for the homeless, told the canvassers there were 1,400 people in the shelter and that about 80 had completed census forms. ``You can't use this census with any degree of legitimacy,'' Snyder said. ``Politicians can use these figures to say anything that they want them to _ mainly that the problem of homelessness isn't as bad as the American people have been made to believe because there's no way that you can legitimately count how many homeless people that are in this city or in this country.'' He gave the completed forms to Valerie Lobban, a district office manager of the Census Bureau. Ms. Lobban said that Snyder's actions would not deter her. ``We kind of expected what happened here tonight. Mr. Snyder had publicized his intentions, that he wasn't going to let us in. But his actions in no way will affect what we're trying to do,'' Ms. Lobban said. She had 80 counters visiting shelters, abandoned buildings, sidewalks and other locations were the homeless might be found. ``Obviously, there will be some people who will fall through the cracks,'' Ms. Lobban said. ``It may be imposssible to account for each homeless person in Washington. We want to get a realistic estimate as to how many there are to make sure that the city gets its proper amount of federal funding.'' Wylie Williams, deputy mayor for economic development, estimated that the city's homeless population had increased 50 percent in the past eight years _ to approximately 7,500. Williams said that the number of homeless women in the city during that time had gone up from 1,000 to about 2,250 and that the D.C. government's funding levels for homeless service programs had more than tripled since 1982 from $8 million to $27.5 million. The census effort was important because ``only when we know how many homeless there are can improvements be made in the delivery of services,'' he said. The City Council on Tuesday refused to restore $19 million cut by a committee from the fiscal 1991 budget for homeless programs. Snyder added that it was unlikely that the enumerators would be able to find a representative sample of the total amount of homeless persons who live in the nation's capital. ``Homeless people are very resourceful,'' Snyder said. ``They have to be to survive on the streets. I doubt that the census takers will be going down every alley in the city, looking into every shanty and crawl space. These people should be allowed to have their dignity and not be disturbed in the middle of the night to accomodate government grandstanding,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany To Scrap Resettler Aid; Major Steps Toward Unity Forecast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Bush call to Kohl, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: West Germany said Tuesday it will scrap as outmoded a 40-year-old aid program for resettling East Germans in light of the fast pace toward unification. The Bonn government also stepped up pressure on its new East German allies to decide quickly on the future governing coalition in East Berlin. Volker Ruehe, chief of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, conferred in East Berlin with leaders of the three-party conservative alliance that placed first in Sunday's East German elections. Among them was Lothar de Maiziere, chairman of the East German Christian Democratic Union and likely new premier. Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said the Cabinet decided to end the resettlement program on July 1. Arriving East Germans then will stop receiving special treatment. West Germany has about 61 million people and East Germany about 16 million. Nearly 500,000 East Germans have resettled in West Germany in the last 14 months. The exodus has devastated East Germany's economy, strained West German housing and job markets, and worn out many West Germans' patience for the newcomers. Schaeuble said Bonn expects major steps toward unification following Sunday's election and improved conditions for East Germans would make special aid unnecessary. ``We assume that by summer we will be able to achieve a currency, economic and social community,'' he said. The two Germanys are negotiating a monetary union in which the West German mark would replace East Germany's currency. They plan other links as part of an ``economic union'' to help rescue East Germany's run-down economy and prepare for unification. West Germany further plans to provide massive social assistance to East Germans as the nations come closer together. Hans Klein, Kohl's chief spokesman, said the next steps toward unification were the main topic at the Cabinet meeting. He quoted Kohl as saying East Germany will have to undertake constitutional changes to achieve the planned ``currency, economic and social steps.'' Kohl reiterated that he does not expect elections for a united Germany to occur until after West Germany's Dec. 2 elections. He previously has said all-German elections are unlikely until sometime next year. President Bush called Kohl from Washington on Tuesday to press the U.S. position that Poland's current borders should be guaranteed when the two Germanys are united, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. ``They did discuss the Polish borders question,'' Fitzwater said. ``President Bush reiterated our position that we are strongly supportive of the Helsinki Final Act, which calls for the inviolability of the Polish borders.'' Poland's Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki is expected to raise the issue when he visits Bush this week. Schaeuble meanwhile said Tuesday that West Germany wants to send a ``psychological signal'' to East Germans thinking about moving west and that it is possible emigres would be encouraged to return voluntarily. Tuesday's Cabinet decision means new East German arrivals would be denied sudh special benefits as guarantees of a place to stay, ``starting-out money'' and low-interest loans. Saarland state said Tuesday it was immediately ending special resettlement procedures there and would send back any new arrivals. Bremen _ a city as well as a state _ already has taken that step. Kohl was under enormous pressure from leaders of West Germany's 11 states, the population and politicians from a broad spectrum to eliminate or drastically reduce the special aid. The resettlement procedures were designed to help East German refugees build new lives in West Germany in a Cold War climate when flights to the West were dangerous and rare. In East Berlin on Tuesday, the Christian Democratic Union confirmed it will nominate de Maiziere as their whip in parliament but that a decision on the future premier will be made later. Ruehe, the West German Christian Democrats' envoy, invited de Maiziere and other Alliance for Germany leaders to Bonn for talks with Kohl Wednesday and again called for a broad coalition that would include the Social Democrats. By including the Social Democrats, the conservatives would have a two-thirds parliamentary majority needed to declare a merger with West Germany under a provision in the West German constitution. Such a merger is favored by Kohl and would speed up unification. The conservative East German alliance led by the Christian Democrats fell short of gaining an absolute majority in the 400-seat parliament and needs a coalition partner. The Social Democrats, who favor a slower reunification process, have refused to enter a coalition government.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Marcos Complains About Her Prosecution in United States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, ``Cerezo was ...,'' to UPDATE with 10 potential jurors retained. ADDS 2 grafs at the end with Spence comment on letter to Bush. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY24
DOC.TEXT: Former Philippines first lady Imelda Marcos arrived in court for the start of her racketeering trial Tuesday and complained about being tried in the United States. ``I am a Filipino citizen. I should be tried in my own country, the Republic of the Philippines, not in a foreign country,'' Mrs. Marcos told a crush of reporters before entering the U.S. District Courthouse. ``I pray I will be treated and tried here like an ordinary American citizen, seeking for justice.'' Supporters carrying signs reading ``Marcos is Innocent'' and ``Stop Persecuting Mrs. Marcos'' greeted Mrs. Marcos when she arrived with her attorney, Gerry Spence. Other signs featured pictures of Mrs. Marcos and her late husband, Ferdinand, with ex-presidents Nixon, Carter and Reagan. Federal marshals did their part to treat her like anyone else, making Mrs. Marcos run her purse through a metal detector before allowing her upstairs to the third-floor courtroom, where jury selection began. Several of the prospective jurors said they had heard of the case but did not know the facts. They also said wealthy people should be treated equally under the law. Under questioning, several said they remembered that Mrs. Marcos had many pairs of shoes. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is accused of taking part in the illegal transfer of more than $160 million from the Philippines treasury to buy Manhattan real estate. The indictment also alleges she defrauded $165 million from banking institutions to finance the properties. She is being tried with Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, who is accused of helping the Marcoses hide their ownership of the real estate, including commercial buildings on Wall Street, Fifth Avenue, Madison Avenue and Herald Square. Marcos, the ousted Philippines president who was the central figure in the October 1988 indictment, died Sept. 28 in exile in Hawaii. Judge John F. Keenan began screening the first 25 of 150 prospective jurors who had filled out a preliminary questionnaire about their eligibility for service. Keenan spoke with each potential juror individually in a room behind the courtroom. Also in the room were the defendants, their lawyers, prosecutors and reporters. Samuel Cerezo, a 51-year-old Transit Authority manager from suburban Westchester County, was asked what he knew about Mrs. Marcos. He told the judge he had heard of a huge shoe collection she left behind when fleeing the Phillipines with her husband in early 1986. Keenan asked Cerezo whether he would hold that against her. ``No, my daughter also has a lot of shoes,'' he replied, prompting a laugh from Mrs. Marcos. Cerezo was one of 10 retained as potential jurors. Those not dismissed for such reasons as work obligations or personal bias were told to return to court next Tuesday when the final panel is to be chosen. Khashoggi, who arrived shortly after Mrs. Marcos, chatted with reporters at the defense table. In reply to a question about where he would rather be, he quipped, ``I'd rather be in Mecca, fasting.'' When asked whether America would be embarrassed by revelations at the trial, he said, ``No, America is too big to be embarrassed.'' Khashoggi also said he felt America had ``betrayed'' Mrs. Marcos. Mrs. Marcos is charged with racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice _ which carry a maximum sentence of 50 years in prison and a $1 million fine. Khashoggi, 54, faces charges of obstruction of justice and mail fraud, which carry a maximum sentence upon conviction of 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. The trial is expected to last three to four months. In Washington, meanwhile, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush had received a letter from Mrs. Marcos. Fitzwater would not elaborate, saying only that the president could not respond for legal reasons pertaining to the trial. When asked about the letter, defense attorney Spence said Mrs. Marcos had offered her cooperation in finding funds allegedly taken from the Philippine government on the condition the money be used for charity in the Philippines. He said Mrs. Marcos sent the letter recently and had received no reply. In return, she asked Bush for help in returning her husband's body to his homeland for reburial, Spence said. Marcos was buried in Hawaii after the present Philippine government refused to allow his body into the country.

DOC.HEAD: Flooding Forces More than 2,000 to Evacuate in Panhandle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Florida evacuations up to more than 2,000; picks up 5th graf, `The worst ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MY4,6
DOC.TEXT: Muddy water surged over Florida's Panhandle on Tuesday, forcing more than 2,000 people to evacuate and threatening a major bridge, and water surged into Selma, Ala., forcing more evacuations there. Flooding also continued in central Georgia. At least 11 people have died in Alabama since heavy rain _ more than 16 inches in some places _ doused that state last week. More than 1,500 people had to evacuate in three Florida counties flooded by the rising Choctawhatchee River. An additional 500 people had to be evacuated from other Panhandle river basins flooded by water flowing down from Alabama and Georgia. The worst Florida flooding has been in the small farming town of Caryville, about 100 miles west of Tallahassee. Most residents cooperated with the evacuation, but a few elderly people had to be forced from their homes, said Washington County Sheriff's Deputy Ronyon Campbell. ``They were kicking and screaming, but it's for their own good,'' he said. The Choctawhatchee, which inundated Caryville, was expected to crest during the night at about 21 feet, 9 feet above flood level. Three or four families who had boats or could demonstrate their ability to cope were allowed to remain in Caryville, Campbell said. But no one who left could return to the flooded area. Hardest hit by flooding was Elba, Ala., where a broken levee let in the Pea River and White Water Creek and forced about 2,000 residents to flee over the weekend. Water was receding there Tuesday, but few people were able to return to their homes as power and phone service remained out. Engineers announced Tuesday that the Elba levee had no structural flaws _ it just wasn't high enough. ``The flood wave was larger than it was designed for,'' said Alton Colvin, area engineer for the Army Corps of Engineers. He said water poured over the top of the earthen dam, eventually eroding its base and breaking it open. Mayor Fred Moore said the corps couldn't be blamed ``because they had never realized this much water was going to come in here.'' At Selma, Ala., between 450 and 500 people evacuated Tuesday as the Alabama River spread into a miles-wide lake curving around Selma, said Warren Rhodes, director of the Dallas County emergency management agency. Selma's central business district was just above the raging waters of the Alabama River, but other neighborhoods and homes and businesses on the opposite side of the historic Edmund Pettus Bridge were engulfed. At Selma's Elmwood Cemetery, about a half-dozen caskets floated out of the ground Monday when water crept over the grounds. City workers in rowboats tied the caskets to trees to keep them from floating off, but there was nothing more to do until the water receded. In the rural south Alabama town of Geneva, emergency workers fought against a break in a levee near the courthouse, with National Guardsmen helping pile sandbags. In the Florida Panhandle, westbound Interstate 10 was closed Monday from Bonifay to Ponce de Leon and will remain closed until next week because of erosion around the pilings of the highway's bridge over the Choctawhatchee, said Julian McCrary, district maintenance engineer for the Florida Department of Transportation in Chipley. High water also closed several other highways in the region. Flooding in Georgia wasn't expected to end before Friday. In Macon, water swamped the city's water treatment plant. Residents were advised to boil water before drinking it, and bottled water was sent to schools, where water fountains were shut off. The Ocmulgee River, with a flood stage of 18 feet, crested near 30 feet early Monday, about 4 feet under the top of a levee protecting much of Macon. The muddy Ocmulgee also inundated the Macon-Bibb County Water and Sewerage Authority's water treatment plant. In metropolitan Atlanta, Gwinnett County officials reported that two malfunctioning pumps at the Yellow River plant allowed sewage to overflow from a manhole for several hours.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Electoral College Votes for President Amid Reform Outcry
DOC.TEXT: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with voting begins, protest scuffle, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TPE1
DOC.TEXT: The electoral college, dominated by elderly deputies elected 40 years ago on mainland China, cast ballots Wednesday that are expected to give President Lee Teng-hui his first full six-year term. Protests continued for democratic change meanwhile as a student sit-in at a downtown Taipei park that began Friday with about 200 participants swelled to more than 5,000, including about 50 on a hunger strike. Lee, chairman of the ruling Nationalist Party, was the only presidential candidate before the assembly, but some members unhappy with the choice were expected to cast blank ballots in protest. The 752-member electoral college, or National Assembly, began voting at about 9 a.m. at a tightly guarded meeting hall in a rural suburb of Taipei. Final results were expected later in the day. The 11 assemblymen from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party were not allowed to vote because they refused to swear allegiance to the Nationalist government. The election has stirred great controversy because the assembly is controlled by old men who were elected on mainland China in the 1940s and then fled to Taiwan with the rest of the Nationalist government after losing a civil war to Communist forces in 1949. Those deputies, many in their 80s and 90s and in poor health, were frozen in office to boost the Nationalist claim to still be the legitimate government of all China. Several voted from wheelchairs or used canes to walk to the ballot box. Public pressure for the electoral college to be scrapped and replaced by direct presidential elections has dramatically increased, particularly after some deputies proposed increasing assembly powers and the members' salaries. About 300 protesters led by Huang Hwa, the opposition party's unofficial presidential candidate, marched to the main road to the suburban hall Wednesday morning to keep elderly assemblymen from voting. One delegate was pulled from his car but appeared unharmed. A plainclothesman was injured in a scuffle with demonstrators. A few dozen students got past about 2,000 police surrounding the hall. They gathered in front Wednesday to sing patriotic songs and unfurl protest banners. Premier Lee Huan early Wednesday visited the students demonstrating in Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Park and said the government would consider their demands. The day before, President Lee Teng-hui's office responded to the pressure by issuing a statement saying he agreed to convene an emergency conference to discuss changing the country's political system. It said Nationalist and opposition politicians and other leaders would be invited to take part. No date was set for the meeting. Wednesday's election was the first time the National Assembly was asked to choose as president someone outside the Chiang Kai-shek family, which ruled Taiwan for nearly 40 years after the Nationalist retreat from mainland China. The assembly elected Chiang Kai-shek president five times and his eldest son, Chiang Ching-kuo, two times. The younger Chiang died in office in January 1988 shortly after he began a political liberalization program that included the scrapping of martial law after 38 years and abolition of a ban on opposition parties. Lee Teng-hui was the handpicked vice president of Chiang Ching-kuo and finished his term as president. Lee, 67, is the first native Taiwanese to head the government and ruling party and is regarded with suspicion by many of the Nationalist old guard, who believe he is not sufficiently committed to their dream of one day returning victoriously to rule the Chinese mainland.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Blamed for Media Missing Start of Panama Invasion
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS 3 grafs ASNE criticism
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. news media missed the start of the American invasion of Panama because Defense Secretary Dick Cheney decided secrecy was more important than ensuring media coverage, according to a report released Tuesday. The report, sponsored by the Pentagon, also criticized Cheney's press secretary, Pete Williams, for not trying to convince Cheney to send a group of reporters and photographers to Panama in time to cover the critical opening battles Dec. 20. ``I take the blame for what happened in Panama,'' Williams said in response to the report. He said the Defense Department was fully committed to the idea of allowing the news media to cover military operations, and that steps already were being taken to correct problems described in the latest study. The report also said poor planning by the Defense Department and the U.S. Southern Command in Panama prevented the media from providing meaningful coverage of newsworthy events long after they arrived. Key problems were lack of transportation and too few briefings on military developments during the brief war. The report was written by Fred S. Hoffmann, a former reporter who until recently was a deputy Pentagon press spokesman. Hoffmann made 17 recommendations on ways the Pentagon can ensure the usefulness of media ``pools,'' or a pre-selected group of U.S. reporters and photographers who are to accompany a major military operation in remote areas. One of Hoffman's chief recommendations was that plans for military action include assurances that a pool travels with the U.S. forces involved. That recommendation was not immediately accepted, but instead referred for ``further consideration,'' along with five other suggestions. ``Because of a secrecy-driven decision by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, the pool was called out too late and arrived too late to cover the decisive U.S. assaults,'' the report said. Hoffmann said Cheney was unduly concerned that word of the invasion plan could leak out before the American troops arrived in Panama. ``Over the five-year history of Pentagon-sponsored pools, including a year-long series in the Persian Gulf, hundreds of newsmen and newswomen demonstrated they could be trusted to respect essential ground rules, including operational secrecy,'' the report said. ``Unless the Defense Department's leaders are prepared to extend that trust in hot war situations, the pool will probably be of little value,'' it said. Cheney told Hoffmann that his first priority was safeguarding the security of the military operation and that ``I was aware of the conflict'' between that need and the goal of getting the reporters and photographers to Panama in time. ``As Cheney's public affairs advisor, Assistant Defense Secretary Pete Williams should have foreseen the consequences of a late pool deployment,'' the report said. The American Society of Newspaper Editors criticized Cheney's delay in alerting the press pool. ``Cheney's decision to delay calling the pool until after the close of office hours and the broadcast of the evening news made assembling the pool difficult and actually increased the security problem,'' said Jean Otto, chairman of the ASNE's Press-Bar-Public Affairs Committee. ``Since the creation of the pool, there has been no security breach involving the press,'' said Otto, who is associate editor of the Rocky Mountain News in Denver. . ``Cheney's lack of trust has, instead, breached the right of the press to report, and of Americans to learn, what happens early in military actions.''

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Electoral College Votes for President Amid Reform Outcry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITS a0787, changing slug to avoid duplication
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Taiwan, Bjt
LaserPhoto TPE1
DOC.TEXT: The electoral college, dominated by elderly deputies elected 40 years ago on mainland China, cast ballots Wednesday that are expected to give President Lee Teng-hui his first full six-year term. Protests continued for democratic change meanwhile as a student sit-in at a downtown Taipei park that began Friday with about 200 participants swelled to more than 5,000, including about 50 on a hunger strike. Lee, chairman of the ruling Nationalist Party, was the only presidential candidate before the assembly, but some members unhappy with the choice were expected to cast blank ballots in protest. The 752-member electoral college, or National Assembly, began voting at about 9 a.m. at a tightly guarded meeting hall in a rural suburb of Taipei. Final results were expected later in the day. The 11 assemblymen from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party were not allowed to vote because they refused to swear allegiance to the Nationalist government. The election has stirred great controversy because the assembly is controlled by old men who were elected on mainland China in the 1940s and then fled to Taiwan with the rest of the Nationalist government after losing a civil war to Communist forces in 1949. Those deputies, many in their 80s and 90s and in poor health, were frozen in office to boost the Nationalist claim to still be the legitimate government of all China. Several voted from wheelchairs or used canes to walk to the ballot box. Public pressure for the electoral college to be scrapped and replaced by direct presidential elections has dramatically increased, particularly after some deputies proposed increasing assembly powers and the members' salaries. About 300 protesters led by Huang Hwa, the opposition party's unofficial presidential candidate, marched to the main road to the suburban hall Wednesday morning to keep elderly assemblymen from voting. One delegate was pulled from his car but appeared unharmed. A plainclothesman was injured in a scuffle with demonstrators. A few dozen students got past about 2,000 police surrounding the hall. They gathered in front Wednesday to sing patriotic songs and unfurl protest banners. Premier Lee Huan early Wednesday visited the students demonstrating in Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Park and said the government would consider their demands. The day before, President Lee Teng-hui's office responded to the pressure by issuing a statement saying he agreed to convene an emergency conference to discuss changing the country's political system. It said Nationalist and opposition politicians and other leaders would be invited to take part. No date was set for the meeting. Wednesday's election was the first time the National Assembly was asked to choose as president someone outside the Chiang Kai-shek family, which ruled Taiwan for nearly 40 years after the Nationalist retreat from mainland China. The assembly elected Chiang Kai-shek president five times and his eldest son, Chiang Ching-kuo, two times. The younger Chiang died in office in January 1988 shortly after he began a political liberalization program that included the scrapping of martial law after 38 years and abolition of a ban on opposition parties. Lee Teng-hui was the handpicked vice president of Chiang Ching-kuo and finished his term as president. Lee, 67, is the first native Taiwanese to head the government and ruling party and is regarded with suspicion by many of the Nationalist old guard, who believe he is not sufficiently committed to their dream of one day returning victoriously to rule the Chinese mainland.

DOC.HEAD: Counting the Non-Persons: Census Seeks Out the Homeless
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with comment by homeless, more details; picks up 2nd graf, `No one ...''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: A legion of clipboard-toting counters sought out shelters, subways and steam grates Tuesday in the broadest attempt ever to find out te extent of homelessness since it became a national disgrace in the 1980s. The tally went on into the night despite a spring storm that interrupted the count in Vermont by dumping up to 22 inches of snow and the refusal of some shelters to allow census-takers inside. Some homeless didn't mind the government intrusion. ``It shows that they're starting to recognize us as humans and not the scum of the earth,'' said Chester Broadwell, 21, who answered questions at the Waystation Shelter in Burlington, Vt. No one expects the $2.7 million, one-night U.S. Census Bureau effort to yield a precise tally of Americans with no fixed address. Critics fear an undercount will allow the government to justify cuts in services. ``We'll get the vast majority,'' said Barbara Bryant, director of the Census Bureau, which expected to hit 22,000 shelters and street sites nationwide. ``There are no believable numbers of homeless in America,'' she said at a news conference in New York. ``This is going to get an order of the magnitude of the problem.'' Some shelters offered free blankets and special meals to attract as many homeless as possible. Nationwide, 15,000 enumerators _ the federal euphemism for headcounters _ fanned out to visit an untidy world of shelters, roosts and hideouts. St. Paul's Community Shelter in Toledo, Ohio, lured the homeless with a party. ``The biggest fear all of us have is that the dollars will be allocated according to the numbers that they get, and the numbers will be significantly lower than the problem,'' said shelter director Ruth Beshalske. But Robert Allen, 28, of Toledo, walked away when counters approached him. ``What are they going to use the numbers for anyway? To tell us there ain't no homeless problem? Hell, I'm a living example that there is a problem,'' Allen said. ``We need jobs, not surveys.'' The homeless _ now estimated to number 250,000 to 3 million _ were asked their name, age, sex, race and marital status. It's part of the constitutional mandate for the country to take stock of itself every 10 years and a throwback to the days when the count was done with personal interviews instead of computerized mailings. But critics such as David Hayden of the Justice House Community in suburban Washington, D.C., refused to let counters inside and said the homeless could easily evade the census. ``It's akin to looking for needles in haystacks,'' Hayden said. ``If people with clipboards can find them, so can people with 2-by-4s who want to rob them. They should spend the money on decent, affordable housing.'' However, Christine Mulholland, census manager in Milwaukee, said: ``They remain invisible unless they're counted.'' The counters, many of whom are homeless and were paid $7.50 an hour, got six hours of training. In New York City alone, 2,167 sites were tagged as places where the homeless congregate. Cold, wet weather in New York City was expected to help census takers find and count more homeless people. ``I expect that it will drive more people indoor to the shelters and to the subway system,'' Dwayne Mayes, a homeless man working as a district supervisor for the homeless count. From 6 p.m. to midnight, the count was focused on shelters, armories, missions, church basements, flophouses and hotels charging less than $12 a night. A 2 a.m. to 4 a.m. phase 2 eroed in on bus stations, all-night restaurants, subway cars, underpasses, bridges, railroad trestles, cars, bank machine vestibules, park benches, trash bins and other homeless hangouts. In the third phase, lasting until about 8 a.m., counters were to interview people coming in and out of abandoned buildings. For their own safety, the counters have been told not to enter the buildings. No sleeping person was supposed to be disturbed. Estimates of age, race and sex would suffice. ``We don't want someone pulling a blanket off someone and find they are staring at a knife or a pistol,'' said Kenneth Meyer, assistant regional census manager in New York. Census officials say the count will help determine such things as congressional and state representation and how much taxpayers' dollars are doled out for homeless programs. ``There's no way we can count everybody, but it's to everybody's advantage to have these people counted,'' said Ray Bancroft, a census official. ``One obstacle is trying to gain the confidence of the homeless population to convince them it is to their benefit.'' Some homeless will elude the counters. ``Part of surviving on the street is being able to hide or being able to look like they are not homeless,'' said Kristin Morse, assistant director for the Coalition for the Homeless in New York. But one who plans to stand up and be counted is Steve Weber, 37, who sleeps between the skyscrapers of midtown Manhattan and begs money with a plastic foam cooler lid that says ``Homeless Man _ Please Help.'' ``Homeless people count, too,'' said Weber, sitting on a discarded cushion atop a plastic milk crate. ``Just because I ain't got no money don't mean I ain't a person.'' Activist Mitch Snyder of the Center for Creative Non-Violence in Washington has urged the homeless to snub the enumerators. He and others have burned census forms as a protest. ``It is impossible to locate and count more than a small fraction of America's homeless,'' Snyder said.
