DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s unions and biggest shareholder announced a $3.8 billion buyout offer for the airline company, a mostly cash deal worth about 40 percent less than a debt-financed effort that collapsed five months ago. UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf _ who helped lead last year's ill-fated buyout deal _ issued a statement Monday saying the board would consider the offer, which shattered a lull in the maneuvering for the parent of United Airlines. The outcome could help determine the shape of takeovers in the tight-money atmosphere that has prevailed since the collapse of the earlier $6.8 billion deal, which contributed to a plunge in the stock market.

The government said a new indictment of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond executive Michael Milken would be ready by mid-April. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood on Monday set a May 1 conference date to discuss when a trial would begin of one of Wall Street's most influential figures of the 1980s. Milken and two others were indicted last March 29 on 98 counts of criminal fraud and racketeering involving a range of alleged securities crimes. The government plans to bring a broader, or superseding, indictment against Milken that is said to include more charges and other defendants.

Interest rates have peaked and should start falling during the spring, a group of private economists predicted. Members of the Shadow Open Market Committee said Mpnday they believed a variety of consumer and business loans would decline in coming months, reflecting a sluggish economy and declining inflationary pressures.

The Bush administration sent Congress a $22 billion, five-year plan for commercial aviation to be funded by a new airport tax of up to $12 per roundtrip and 25 percent increases in other aviation taxes. Federal Aviation Administrator James B. Busey said Monday the reauthorization bill would help meet the growing demand for aviation, allow modernization of the FAA's air traffic control system and increase aviation safety.

Eastern Airlines announced it was cutting first class fares by about 40 percent in an effort to attract more business travelers and was sweetening travel agent commissions for sales of the new, cut-rate tickets. The lower fares, called ``Y-Not fares,'' are good for domestic travel through June 30, carry no penalties, are fully refundable and can be booked up to flight time, the company said Monday.

A new, voice-activated ``typewriter'' offers the promise one day of transcending one of the great mysteries of medicine: the physician's handwriting. The DragonDictate Voice-Typewriter, unveiled Monday, is billed as the first of its kind. The $9,000 system ``knows'' 30,000 words and adapts to individual voices, where previous systems could recognize no more than 5,000 words.

A member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission proposed creating an arbitration panel to help end the regulatory agency's jurisdictional disputes with the rival Securities and Exchange Commission. The compromise suggested Monday by CFTC Commissioner Fowler C. West called for setting up a five-member Inter-Agency Jurisdictional Arbitration Panel to resolve disputes at the request of either agency.

President Bush could grant the Soviet Union ``most-favored nation'' trading status at the July economic summit if the Soviets enact legislation permitting free emigration, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher said. Bush had announced at his summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last December the United States would begin negotiating a trade agreement with the Soviets wiping away nearly half a century of trade friction. Mosbacher said Monday most favored status could be granted in July under certain conditions.

President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is reportedly preparing a package of 17 drastic reforms in hopes of saving the Soviet Union's failing economy. In a separate report Monday, the Interfax news agency quoted a close adviser to Gorbachev as saying the situation is so serious that some in the Soviet leadership would no longer object to receiving massive foreign aid comparable to the post-World War II Marshall Plan.

The stock market finished higher Monday, as an afternoon rally more than erased an early decline. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials finished 14.41 points higher at 2,755.63, after being down as much as 28 points earlier. The dollar turned in a mixed performance. Bond prices were little changed. Soybean futures prices rose sharply; coffee, sugar and cocoa futures fell sharply; livestock and meat futures advanced; petroleum futures were mixed; and precious metals were higher.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Bill Yields Rise to Highest Level Since Summer
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in the latest auction to their highest level since last summer. The Treasury Department sold $8.1 billion in three-month bills Monday at an average discount rate of 7.97 percent, up from 7.96 percent last week. Another $8.0 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.92 percent, up from 7.89 percent last week. The rates were the highest since three-month bills sold for 7.99 percent on Aug. 21 and six-month bills averaged 8.08 percent on June 19. Six-month bills also were sold at a 7.92 percent rate last Oct. 2. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.25 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,798.50 and 8.36 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,599.60. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 8.42 percent last week, up from 8.34 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Coniston Returns To Join Unions in UAL Buyout Bid
DOC.TEXT: Coniston Partners, known for mounting proxy battles against corporate giants, is in the hunt again for UAL Corp., and some analysts believe the New York takeover trio will prevail. Coniston announced Monday it was joining with United Airlines' three unions in a fight using shareholder ballots to unseat UAL's directors and buy the company for more than $3.8 billion. The buyout plan by Coniston's Keith Gollust, Paul Tierney Jr. and Augustus Oliver mirrors their attack on UAL predecessor Allegis Corp. in 1987. Coniston also waged a proxy contest for Gillette Co. in 1988 that it lost, selling its stake in the personal care giant for a large profit. Coniston acquired a stake in Allegis and threatened to oust the directors if the company did not divest its non-airline businesses, which Coniston believed were hindering corporate earnings and depressing share price. Allegis eventually sold the holdings. Now Coniston is pushing for a sale of 75 percent of Chicago-based UAL to the company's employees, contending a buyout offers shareholders a chance to realize the full value of their stock. UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf said Monday that the board would consider the offer at a meeting to be held soon. A source said a meeting was scheduled for Wednesday, but UAL would not confirm the meeting date. Although the buyout group has not disclosed its plans for financing the bid, analyst Jack Hunter of Howe Barnes Investments Inc. predicted the board would agree to the sale, perhaps at a higher price. ``I don't think there's going to be a war,'' Hunter said. ``I think the board wants out.'' Morgan Stanley & Co. analyst Kevin Murphy said the group's ability to obtain financing was the key to their plan. ``It's going to be hard for them to win a proxy fight unless they can show the shareholders they've got some financial clout,'' he said. Analysts said UAL was worth at least $25 more per share than the $150 per share in cash and $25 per share in securities the Coniston-union group is offering. The new offer comes nearly seven months after Los Angeles investor Marvin Davis put UAL into play with a $4.3 billion offer, and two months after UAL's board offered to help the pilots, machinists and flight attendants unions develop a viable buyout bid, which has not materialized. Gollust said in a telephone interview that Coniston was mounting the proxy fight ``based on our disappointment that the board was unable to produce another transaction.'' ``Obviously, we reached a point where we felt it was in our interest and the interest of other stockholders to become more active,'' he said. Coniston, which owns 11.8 percent of UAL's approximately 21.8 million outstanding shares, previously had prodded the board with the threat of a consent solicitation to dump some of the directors. A consent solicitation is similar to a proxy fight but is harder to win. In a consent solicitation, the party initiating the action needs to win approval of a majority of all shares outstanding; winning a proxy fight requires approval of a majority of shares voting at a meeting. UAL's annual meeting is scheduled for April 26. Under the Coniston-union plan, stockholders also would receive non-voting common stock amounting to 25 percent of the total in the company. Based on the total shares outstanding, the offer would be worth about $3.8 billion. UAL's stock rose $12 to $154.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange Monday. The shares recently have traded as low as $121. The new offer is about 40 percent less than a $6.8 billion debt-financed buyout deal led by UAL's pilots and management that collapsed last Oct. 13. That fiasco sparked a 190-point drop in the Dow Jones industrials average and is considered a major event in the era of corporate takeovers because it instilled deep skepticism about whether such deals would continue.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Cuts First-Class Fares
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines is cutting first class fares by about 40 percent in an effort to attract more business travelers, but analysts said carriers on competing routes are unlikely to rush to make similar reductions. ``It will probably be a week before we see matching or lowering fares,'' said Andrew Geller, analyst with Provident National Bank in Philadelphia. ``It won't be instantaneous.'' In a related move, Eastern said Monday it would raise travel agent commissions for sales of the new, cut-rate tickets. The lower fares, called ``Y-Not fares,'' are good for domestic travel through June 30, carry no penalties, are fully refundable and can be booked up to flight time. Industry analysts expressed surprise at the size of the cuts, which put Eastern's first-class tickets about 15 percent below the industry's full coach fares. But they said they did not expect other carriers to immediately match or lower their rates. ``It's a marketing move, a promotional program,'' said Robert Decker, analyst with Duff & Phelps in Chicago. ``We might see some selective matching by other airlines but I wouldn't expect a widespread move at this point.'' Eastern is reorganizing under bankruptcy court protection from creditors, where it sought protection following a crippling strike by pilots, machinists and flight attendants a year ago. Eastern claims its 9,000 daily first-class seats are 65 percent full, although Eastern officials conceded that many passengers now flying first class on Eastern are frequent flier passengers upgraded from coach. Current industry first class fares between New York and Miami are $437 one-way, while the lowest full-coach fare is $333, according to figures supplied by Eastern. The new ``Y-Not'' fare on that route is $276 one way _ $10 above Eastern's current full-coach fare. Between Chicago and Atlanta, the current first-class, one-way fare is $537, full-coach is $360 and Eastern's ``Y-Not'' fare is $298. Eastern passengers with full-coach fare tickets will be able to exchange their tickets for first-class seats for $10 more. Eastern's full-coach fares, the lowest in the industry, are $10 less than the new fares. Eastern said it expects the lower fares to generate about $400,000 a day more in net revenue. The fares are good for travel in the United States, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. Geller said the increase in travel agent commissions would be an incentive for travel agents, many of whom have been wary of putting customers on Eastern because of the carrier's financial problems. Standard commissions industrywide amount to about 10 percent. Eastern will boost the commissions on ``Y-Not'' tickets to 15 percent.

DOC.HEAD: General Dynamics Launches $5 Million Advertising Blitz
DOC.TEXT: General Dynamics Corp., the nation's second largest defense contractor, is spending $5 million on a radio and newspaper advertising campaign aimed at Washington insiders and Capitol Hill decision-makers. The ads were created before democratic change swept Eastern Europe and make no mention of a perceived easing of world tensions. But the pitch is clear: The government should not turn its back on advances in defense capabilities. The campaign also comes as Congress begins debate on next year's defense budget at a time when pressure to reduce military spending is at its greatest in a decade. ``This is a fairly soft message, but the underlying text is: Keep the next generation of technology coming,'' said Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project, a non-profit analyst group based in Washington. ``I don't think any member of Congress is ever sold by an ad,'' Adams said Monday. ``What the ad does is put the issue on the table. It says, `This is important. Sit up and take notice.''' General Dynamics' first radio spot began airing last week. It recounts the historic voyage of the USS Nautilus, the nation's first nuclear submarine, beneath the North Pole on Aug. 3, 1958. ``The USS Nautilus creeps forward, threading between the arctic ice above and the shallow sea bottom below,'' the narrator says. ``The only thing more remarkable than the submarine itself is the submariner. ``Dedication to both has kept us improving submarines since we built the Navy's first 90 years ago. We're General Dynamics, a strong company for a strong country.'' The Nautilus ad is one of six radio spots prepared by Cleveland-based Wyse Advertising. Budgeted at $5 million annually, the effort will last at least two years and possibly much longer, said Chuck DeMund, a General Dynamics executive heading the campaign. Although the advertising budget is small for a Fortune 500 company _ General Dynamics was 41st on last year's list _ it is the first product-oriented campaign for the St. Louis-based defense contractor in 20 years. ``If you're in the defense business, most of the decision-makers are inside the Beltway, or so I'm told,'' DeMund said. ``The Washington emphasis is heavy and pretty obvious.'' An outline of the campaign distributed to top General Dynamics officials indicates it is an extension of a mid-1980s attempt to improve the company's image when its government contracting operations were under investigation. Although the probe later was dropped, ``Our corporate reputation was in disrepair and we were in the bull's eye of the media's target,'' wrote Bob Morris, a General Dynamics communications vice president. The earlier ad campaign promoted general topics such as education and voter registration as an image-booster. ``We decided it was time to start telling more specifically about what General Dynamics does for a living,'' DeMund said. General Dynamics gets about 90 percent of its business from U.S. government defense contracts, $6.89 billion in 1989. The company has more than 100,000 employees and makes Tomahawk cruise missiles in San Diego; nuclear submarines in Groton, Conn.; F-16 fighter planes in Fort Worth, Texas; and M-1 tanks in Troy, Mich., and Lima, Ohio. Print ads are appearing in The Wall Street Journal, U.S. News and World Report, Fortune, National Geographic, Smithsonian, the National Review and Washington Monthly. Robert Costello, chief military procurement official in the Reagan administration, predicted that as military budgets fall, other defense contractors will produce similar ads. ``Basically, their issue is keeping as much business for their company as possible _ at the expense of competitors,'' said Costello, now an analyst at the Hudson Institute, an Indianapolis think tank. ``Yes, they can have an impact.'' While its campaign germinated before the changes in Eastern Europe, General Dynamics is aware of the implications of democratic reform on military contractors. The cover of the company's 1989 annual report is a photograph of Cortland Bryant, a ship's rigger at General Dynamics' Electric Boat Division in Groton, Conn., where submarines are built. ``I really think this country's tough stand on defense helped to make all those good things happen over in Europe,'' Bryant is quoted as saying on the cover. ``Nobody wants a war _ I sure don't _ and as long as we've got these boats out there, I don't think we'll have one.''

DOC.HEAD: CFTC Member Proposes Compromise in Turf Battle With SEC
DOC.TEXT: A member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has proposed setting up an arbitration panel to iron out the regulatory agency's jursidictional disputes with the rival Securities and Exchange Commission. The compromise suggested Monday by CFTC Commissioner Fowler C. West called for setting up a five-member Inter-Agency Jurisdictional Arbitration Panel to resolve disputes at the request of either agency. The plan would require amending the federal laws that created the CFTC, which oversees the nation's futures markets, and the SEC, which regulates the stock and bond markets. A spokeswoman for the SEC said the agency had no comment on the proposal. The CFTC and the SEC have a long-simmering dispute over which agency should have the power to regulate so-called ``hybrid'' financial products that share characteristics of both a security and a futures contract. The dispute has heated up since a federal appeals court in Chicago ruled last year that the CFTC's regulatory authority extended to financial instruments with even a trace of futures-like characteristics. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals held that the SEC overstepped its authority in claiming jurisdiction over hybrid products created by exchanges in Chicago, New York and Philadelphia. The ruling forced those exchanges to stop or never start trading the products, known as index participations, which allowed investors to trade on indexes tied to a whole basket of stocks like the Standard & Poors 500 without actually buying the underlying stock. That prompted SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden to call for reform to prevent foreign markets from copying innovative U.S. financial products while their introduction in this country is held up by court battles. Last week Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said it's time to make some changes. He said the department was studying three scenarios: merging the CFTC and SEC; giving the SEC authority over all financial futures contracts or simply giving the SEC power to regulate stock index futures. And two House members, one from the committe that oversees the SEC the other from the Agriculture Committee that oversees the CFTC, said last week they were exploring possible legislation to create a new super regulatory agency with authority over both securities and financial futures markets. The Seante Banking Committee has scheduled a March 29 hearing on the jurisdictional dispute. Under West's proposal, each commission would appoint two qualified arbitrators, who, in turn, would select a fifth member. Jursidictional disputes between the CFTC and the SEC would be submitted to the panel, which would render a decision within 90 days. The panel's findings would be final and not subject to reversal. ``Federal courts have encouraged arbitration, and arbitration has been used even to settle disputes over international territorial boundaries,'' West said. ``I see no reason why arbitration could not be applied successfully to the gray area of jurisdictional disputes between these agencies.'' Rather than creating an expensive new federal bureaucracy, West said his proposal would be ``taking the current system and making it work.'' The arbitration panel could utilize the staff and facilities of either agency and West estimated it could operate for less than $1.5 million a year.

DOC.HEAD: No Sunshine for S&Ls in Healthy California, Either
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: In the late 1980s, Columbia Savings and Loan television ads showed a man in a suit standing high atop a graph. Lines on the chart zigzagged up to demonstrate the company's growth and strength. ``I'd say things are headed in the right direction,'' the pitchman said. If the ads ran now, the guy might have to stand in a junkyard _ a metaphor not only for Columbia, but also for other California S&Ls that diversified away from home-mortgage lending during the deregulated frenzy of the last decade. A third of the state's 21 biggest thrifts are in danger of failing, even in a state economy that is one of the largest and healthiest in the world. Why are so many California thrifts sick? A big reason is bad investments made under deregulation. Columbia's years of success, for example, were built on investments in junk bonds, securities that paid high interest because they funded risky ventures. Many were sold by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s junk bond purveyor Michael Milken to his friend and ally, Columbia Chairman Thomas Spiegel. Columbia's heap of junk, far bigger than any other thrift's, has fallen in value by at least $800 million. Because of that, the S&L no longer meets federal standards for capital reserves _ its cash cushion against risk. Spiegel has resigned. Drexel is in bankruptcy court. Milken is indicted. The market for the risky securities he helped pioneer has collapsed. Columbia's new president, Edward Harshfield, is trying to sell the whole $3.5 billion junk bond package. Many observers don't think he can. ``I just have a feeling Columbia may be too far gone,'' said Bert Ely, an Alexandria, Va.-based financial industry consultant. The No. 2 junk bond investor, San Diego's Imperial Savings and Loan, was seized Feb. 23, the same day regulators took over Huntington Beach-based Mercury Savings. Mercury had many problems, but fell into insolvency partly because of another bugbear for California thrifts _ a risky out-of-state loan. The number of thrifts in California boomed in the early 1980s after federal and state laws were loosened, permitting S&Ls to make a range of investments. Unlike banks, they originally had been allowed only to make loans for houses. California has about 12 percent of the country's population, but 29 percent of the S&L assets. The state hasn't suffered the economic shocks of Texas and other energy states, which could partly blame the skidding oil business for their S&L problems, or Arizona, where thrifts were buried when real estate prices slumped. Analysts, regulators and industry officials instead blame shoddy managers who courted big depositors with high interest rates and made ill-conceived investments well beyond the Golden State's borders. Besides junk bonds, California thrifts put money into duds ranging from stud horses to Yugo cars. Honcho thrift entrepreneurs with little experience used their newfound license to write not just adjustable rate loans, but commercial and industrial loans, loans on vacant land, ``all that goofy stuff,'' California S&L Commissioner William Crawford said. Making matters worse, many conservative lenders followed suit, often trying to recoup losses from early fixed-rate mortgage loans made at low rates. ``A lot of the good monkeys copied the bad monkeys,'' Crawford said. Crawford and Marion Sandler, president of World Savings and Loan Association, said trying to do business outside the state was the biggest problem. ``First, you don't know the territory, and second you're the latest pigeon,'' she said. Many California thrift managers wrongly assumed every market was as good as California, said Alex Sheshunoff, the head of an Austin, Texas-based firm that tracks the thrift industry. ``They thought they had geographical risk diversification,'' Sheshunoff said. ``What they wound up with was a piece of every bad deal no matter where it was.'' Some of the more prominent thrifts that ventured out-of-state include Great American Savings Bank of San Diego, now seeking an investor or buyer after losing $124 million in 1989, largely because of commercial lending in Arizona. Great Western's 1989 profits fell 60 percent because of a $200 million reserve for losses on commercial real-estate loans, most of them outside California. The company is regarded as healthy nonetheless. Irvine-based Lincoln Savings, the notorious thrift that regulators say will cost $2 billion to bail out, lost money on Arizona real estate and junk bonds. It is the biggest S&L collapse so far. Mercury said a soured loan on a hotel in Tulsa, Okla., helped push it into insolvency. With assets of $2.16 billion, it had a negative net worth of $33 million when seized. San Diego's Imperial had assets of $9.7 billion and a negative net worth of $60 million when regulators seized it. Besides big junk bond holdings, Imperial's problems included shaky car loans and backing the importer of the Yugo, a car U.S. drivers shunned. Ely attributes many of the problems to simply too many S&Ls with too few solid franchises. ``There's parallels to the steel industry,'' said Ely. ``What we're doing is trimming away obsolescence. ... It's the same trend you see in any mature industry.''

DOC.HEAD: SEC Exploring Price Quote System for Junk Bonds
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into developing a centralized price quote system for the market in high-yield, high-risk junk bonds. In a letter to a Senate committee, SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden said the agency needs to keep closer tabs on the junk bond market but cautioned against ``overly intrusive'' legislation. The letter accompanied an SEC report on junk bonds to the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, in which Breeden said he wanted to improve the availability of information on price and liquidity of the securities. The 84-page SEC report, delivered to the committee last week and made public Monday, contained information on events and data up through Fall 1989. The committee's chairman, Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich, requested the study after Campeau Corp. sought bankruptcy protection for its huge U.S. retailing operations, which it acquired mainly with money borrowed through junk bonds. The report does not deal with the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the junk bond pioneer whose parent sought bankruptcy court protection in February. Much of the data in the report came from Drexel, however. The report stated Drexel was the primary underwriter of junk bond issues with about a 43 percent market share in the first nine months of 1989. The report also estimated the size of the entire junk bond market at $300 billion to $350 billion. The SEC report conceded that much of its information _ including the numbers of new issues, the size of the secondary market and involvement of commercial banks in the junk market _ was based estimates rather than hard data because of what it called ``the persistent problem of obtaining quality research'' in junk bonds. Breeden said improved price information would assist investors, market participants and regulators and he has asked the SEC's Division of Market Regulation to study problems in developing a centralized price quotation system for junk bonds. The issue of price quotes for junk bonds was highlighted last week when Drexel, which is liquidating its holdings, stopped quoting prices on some 3,000 to 4,000 junk issues. The firm had been the market's biggest _ and for some issues the only source _ for junk bond quotes. Breeden also warned that ``an overly intrusive approach could create other risks and significant costs. ``Therefore, any steps to increase the direct regulation of trading in high yield securities should be carefully considered due to their potentially far-reaching implications,'' said Breeden in a letter to Riegle. There was no comment from committee, as the Senate was not in session Monday.

DOC.HEAD: L.L. Bean President Bound for Everest
DOC.TEXT: Leon Gorman is leaving his L.L. Bean boots at home when he joins climbers from three nations this week in scaling Mount Everest to promote world peace and environmental protection. Instead, the president of the outdoors outfitter famous for its duck shoes, plaid flannels and huge mail-order business is taking a pair of backpacking boots and some stiff plastic ones equipped with crampons for venturing onto glaciers. Bean's signature Maine Hunting Boot _ with its leather uppers and rubber bottoms _ wouldn't be appropriate on 29,028-foot Everest, the world's highest mountain, along the border of Nepal and Tibet in the Himalayas, he said. Gorman, 55, is participating in the climb as a ``trekker'' who will follow the nearly 50 expedition members to Camp 3, an advanced base camp at 21,325 feet where the technical phase of the ascent begins in earnest. ``That's the highest we expect to go,'' Gorman said. ``But if everything is perfect, we might go on the glacier a little higher ...'' It's the highest objective ever attempted by Gorman, a recreational hiker who did virtually all his climbing in northern Maine's Baxter State Park and the White Mountains of New Hampshire before joining Jim Whittaker on a climb of 14,410-foot Mount Rainier in Washington state three years ago. Whittaker, who in 1963 became the first American to climb Everest, organized this year's Everest Peace Club and enlisted Gorman's company as lead sponsor and official outfitter. Included on the expedition were opportunities for physically fit people with little or no climbing experience to follow in the footsteps of expedition members to the 17,100-foot base camp or to advance further up to Camp 3. The cost of the treks is nearly $10,000, with proceeds used to defray the expenses of the expedition _ figured at more than $1 million, with the United States, through corporate sponsors and individual donors, also paying to outfit Soviet and Chinese climbers. Organizers hope to conclude the ascent on April 22, the 20th anniversary of Earth Day, with one climber from each country advancing to the summit. The three-nation project is intended to promote international amity. Its environmental goal is to clean up some of the two tons of discarded tents, oxygen bottles and other garbage left by earlier teams of climbers. In addition to a $100,000 cash donation for the expedition, L.L. Bean is supplying climbers with gear ranging from rucksacks and altimeters to head lamps and wool mittens. The food, fuel and equipment, weighing more than 50,000 pounds, was transported 9,000 miles by ship from Seattle to Hong Kong, then another 5,000 miles by truck to base camp. The final leg, to advance base camp, is being made by a herd of 60 yaks, each of which carries roughly a 110-pound load per trip. Gorman said most of the equipment ``is off-the-shelf,'' except for high-altitude climbing suits custom designed by Bean's product development staff and three of its vendors for the Everest expedition. The suits are bright red, with yellow pockets and blue shoulder trim, representing the flag colors of the countries taking part in the climb, said Jeannie Parker, who coordinated the outfitting of the expedition for Bean. She said the Mount Everest 90 System suits will be offered by the company in its specialty catalog issued next fall. Gorman tuned up for the trip last September with a 4{-day climb of 19,340-foot Mount Kilimanjaro, Africa's highest summit. It was there he tested ``power breathing'' techniques designed to acclimate the body to high-altitude climbing.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Ambassador Wants U.S. Fishermen Out of Waters
DOC.TEXT: Canada's ambassador to the United States lashed out at American fishermen illegally plying his country's waters, saying the movements heightened the ``risk of injury'' from Canadian patrol boats. Ambassador Derek Burney on Monday cited recent incidents in which U.S. fishermen have been caught working Canadian waters and chased back into their own territory. ``Warning shots have been fired, but no shots have been fired at U.S. vessels,'' he told the Gulf of Maine Fisheries in the '90s conference. ``I would like to keep it that way. ``Unfortunately, the risk of injury has been heightened by the refusal of some U.S. fishermen to obey the legitimate orders of Canadian fisheries officials.'' Burney later denied he was threatening U.S. fishermen. ``I don't want there to be a situation in which shots are fired at fishing vessels from either country,'' he said. ``Please don't interpret what I said as saber-rattling.'' Burney also criticized legislation passed by Congress last year banning the import of undersized lobsters from Canada. A panel of officials from both nations is determining whether the law is an unfair restriction of trade. ``Why could we not have asked the panel to give us an advisory opinion on this issue before the legislation was adopted?'' Burney said. Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, said the legislation appeared necessary last year when Canada began increasing its minimum size for lobsters but then backed off. New England fishermen complain that Canada's lower size limit gives Canadian fishermen an unfair advantage. Canadian fishermen say their size limits are adequate to protect the supply of lobsters.

DOC.HEAD: Gerber Will Sell Three Sleepwear Plants
DOC.TEXT: Gerber Products Co. will restructure its children's clothing business and sell three North Carolina plants, the company said. Gerber Childrenswear Inc. will be streamlined to cut some products for older children, mainly private-label sleepwear lines that sold for low prices and brought low returns, said Kent C. Robinson, president and chief executive officer of Gerber Childrenswear. Robinson, who also is president of Gerber Apparel, said Monday the plants being sold are a small part of Gerber Childrenswear's total operations. He declined to give the total number of plants or total number of employees in the unit. But the three plants employ about 600 people in Yadkinville, Greensboro and Salisbury, N.C. Gerber said an after-tax reserve of $8.3 million, or 22 cents a share, would be established by a charge in its fourth fiscal quarter, ending March 31, to cover anticipated losses on the plant sales. Al Piergallini, Gerber Products chairman, president and chief executive officer, said fiscal 1990 earnings per share from continuing operations still were expected to be at least $2.75 a share, up about 25 percent from comparable earnings for fiscal 1989. Gerber Childrenswear is part of the Gerber Apparel Group, which also includes Buster Brown Apparel Inc. and Weather Tamer Inc. Gerber Products Co., also the country's leading producer of baby foods, employs nearly 15,000 people and reported earnings of $81.4 million on sales of $1.07 billion in its last fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Government Promises New Indictment By Mid-April
DOC.TEXT: The government said a new indictment of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond executive Michael Milken would be ready by mid-April. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood on Monday set a May 1 conference date to discuss when a trial would begin of one of Wall Street's most influential figures of the 1980s. Milken and two others were indicted last March 29 on 98 counts of criminal fraud and racketeering involving a range of alleged securities crimes, some related to insider trading and fraud during corporate takeovers. But the government plans to bring a broader, or superseding, indictment against Milken that is said to include more charges and other defendants. The new indictment first was expected last summer and prosecutors have repeatedly pushed back the date. After the first indictment, a March 1, 1990, trial date was scheduled. Wood said she called Monday's hearing ``in view of the fact that March 1 has come and gone.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney John K. Carroll said the new indictment would be ready ``no later than the week of April 16.'' Wood said the two sides would agree upon a definite trial date when they meet May 1. ``Obviously, until we see the superseder we're not in any position to talk about a trial date,'' Milken attorney Arthur Liman said. He said the new indictment would require additional preparation because other defendants were expected to be named. But lawyers involved in the case have said in the past they would need close to a year to prepare for what is expected to be a lengthy and complicated trial. That would push a trial date back to early 1991. Milken, his brother Lowell, and former Drexel trader Bruce Lee Newberg were charged with defrauding clients through insider trading and stock manipulation between 1984 and 1986. They have pleaded innocent. Michael Milken, 43, left Drexel last year and set up a investment management company. Drexel, which pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $650 million in penalties to settle its case with the government, is going out of business. Its parent company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors last month.

DOC.HEAD: BTR Chief: `Do I Look Ruthless?'
DOC.TEXT: British executive John C. Cahill, who wants to buy the 105-year-old Norton Co., calls his firm BTR PLC his family and Worcester's largest employer a prospective member. ``Do I look ruthless? Do I look like Attila the Hun?'' Cahill said Monday, brushing aside analysts' descriptions of his company as dogged in pursuit of cost targets. But Cahill didn't directly address the question of layoffs should he acquire the world's leading abrasives manufacturer, saying, ``I can't respond to that at this moment.'' Despite Cahill's words, employees of Norton voiced disapproval of the $1.6 billion hostile takeover bid as about 3,000 workers marched around city hall Monday. ``It's more than just $75 a share. It's our livelihood. It's our jobs,'' said John Schafer, an organizer of the rally timed to coincide with Cahill's visit. The show of force by Norton employees, enlivened by chants, renditions of ``God Bless America'' and even the torching of a Union Jack, didn't seem to deter Cahill, although he did change one meeting place to skirt the crowd. ``I think this is a very healthy sign. They're showing loyalty and support,'' said Cahill, adding that he had mingled with some of the earliest ralliers at around 6 a.m. In Boston, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said he was watching the Norton situation. ``I am very concerned. Every time we have one of these hostile takeovers it seems to be directed at one of our best employers, our best corporate citizens,'' he said. Cahill said he hoped the takeover would marry Norton's technical prowess with BTR's operating techniques. Norton Workers said they don't trust Cahill and fear that if his bid is successful they could be out of a job or forced to meet stringent profit ratios. BTR's bid made its first public appearance in an ad in Friday's Wall Street Journal. Among's those at Monday's rally was 87-year-old former chairman Milton P. Higgins, who was brought to city hall in a wheelchair. ``My grandfather was one of the founders of the company. It's the best company in the city and we don't like to have it sold out to somebody else. It's as simple as that,'' Higgins said. The employees cited BTR's purchase of Worcester Controls Corp. in 1978 as grounds for their fears. In 1986, the company's manufacturing operations were moved to North Carolina, although their corporate offices remain in Marlboro. But Cahill maintained that was a decision by management that had been in place before the BTR purchase and he insisted he had no such plans for Norton. Norton management has said its board is evaluating the offer and will advise shareholders by March 29. Over the weekend, Norton lined up a group of advisers, including the investment banking firm Morgan Stanley & Co.

DOC.HEAD: Economists See Possible Worsening of Trade Deficit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be led with 8:30 a.m. EST release of new report. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit, after two years of steady improvements, could worsen significantly in 1990, economists say. These analysts are concerned that a growing appetite for imported petroleum and stepped-up demand by consumers for foreign products will worsen the nation's trade problems. Analysts were anxiously awaiting today's report from the Commerce Department on the merchandise trade deficit in January. In advance of the report, many analysts were looking for the deficit to widen substantially from a $7.2 billion deficit in December, which was the smallest shortfall in five years. Robert Dederick, chief economist of Northern Trust Co. in Chicago, said he expected a January deficit of $10.5 billion. He said this would reflect a jump in petroleum imports as oil companies increased purchases to replenish heating oil supplies following unusually cold weather in December. The merchandise trade deficit showed an 8.4 percent improvement for all of 1989, dipping to $108.6 billion. That followed a 22 percent drop to $118.5 billion in 1988. But many analysts are concerned that the back-to-back deficits will be erased this year as imports of cars and televisions flood into the country because a stronger dollar has made those goods more attractive to American consumers. That increased demand, added to the jump in oil imports, could keep the monthly deficit hovering around $10 billion for the entire year, some economists said. Michael Evans, head of a Washington forecasting company, said he was looking for the deficit for all of 1990 to total between $120 billion and $125 billion, which would make it the second worst imbalance on history. The all-time high was a $152.1 billion deficit in 1987. ``Without a weaker dollar, we are just not going to get an improvement in trade,'' Evans said. ``We are destined to have bad trade numbers for some time.'' Such a forecast could spell trouble for the Bush administration, which is counting on further gains in exports to help boost the fortunes of American manufacturers and dampen protectionist sentiments in Congress. Last month, President Bush held a hastily arranged meeting in California with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to press demands that Japan do more to reduce its trade gap with the United States, which amounted to $49 billion last year. Kaifu promised to make reduction of trade tensions a top priority, but U.S. critics question whether the verbal commitments will be turned into significant market-opening moves. Sen. John Danforth of Missouri, the ranking Republican on the Senate trade subcommittee, said Monday that Japanese officials he met with in Tokyo last week appeared to be more willing to address U.S. complaints about their closed markets. ``There was a recognition that the time had come to redress the grievances we had,'' said Danforth, who has been a leading critic of both Japanese trade practices and the way Bush and former President Reagan addressed them. But Danforth told reporters, ``I remain skeptical that the ... talks are going to lead to the kind of concrete results we hope for.'' He said the talks will have to produce more specific sales of U.S. products to Japan as well as a broader general commitment by Tokyo to removing impediments.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Up Slightly At Midday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: will be led after closing
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rose modestly in light trading at midday Tuesday. Traders said gains on Wall Street late Monday gave the market a boost, but most investors remained on the sidelines ahead of the government's budget statement due out late Tuesday. At about 12:15 p.m. local time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 9.2 points at 2,247.2. Volume totaled 247.4 million shares, up from 175 million shares Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Central Bank Raises Discount Rate to 5.25 Percent
With PM-Japan-Markets, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan's central bank ended weeks of uncertainty for investors today by raising its key lending rate a full percentage point, but the move provided no quick fix for the sinking stock market and weakening yen. The Bank of Japan said it raised its official discount rate _ the interest charged on loans to commercial banks _ to 5.25 percent from 4.25 percent. While uncertainty over interest rates had been cited as one factor in stock prices' recent decline, the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index still fell 456.05 points, or 1.48 percent, closing at 30,807.19. It was its lowest closing since 30,678.39 on Jan. 9, 1989. That followed a decline of 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, on Monday, the index's third-largest single-day fall. Although higher interest rates generally tend to make a country's currency more attractive, the yen weakened further. Traders said the move did not spur yen-buying because the market had been expecting it soon. The dollar gained 0.10 yen Tuesday, closing at 153.65 yen, its highest closing in three years. The yen's failure to respond to the discount raise increase discouraged stock investors, traders said. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno said Tuesday the bank's move was ``pre-emptive,'' to maintain price stability, and would not appreciably slow Japan's economic expansion. While not providing an instant remedy, the rate increase would help both the yen and the stock market in the long run, he said. Hiroshi Saito, president of Nippon Steel Corp., told Kyodo News Service that the action would stabilize financial markets by making investors think the interest rate has reached its top. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto also said it would contribute to stability in financial markets while helping to sustain non-inflationary economic growth led by domestic demand. But Hideo Mori, president of Sumitomo Chemical Co., said the rate increase might damage healthy economic growth. Some analysts suggested the problem was waiting too long to raise the rate. ``If the discount rate had been raised when the dollar was about to surpass the 150-yen line, the dollar could not have risen this high,'' said Toshiaki Kakimoto, chief economist with Sumitomo Bank. ``Monetary actions should be taken in more flexible fashion.'' With signs of inflationary pressure growing, the market originally had expected the rise to come shortly after general elections on Feb. 18. Amid the uncertainty that followed, stock and bond prices and the yen all continued to weaken. So far this year, the dollar has risen by more than 10 yen, or 7 percent, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-share Nikkei Stock Average has fallen more than 8,100 points, or almost 21 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Introduces Big Mac
DOC.TEXT: Analysts said Apple Computer's new, more powerful and speedier Macintosh model shows the company is continuing its strategy of selling expensive computers with high margins. That's despite recent criticism from Wall Street and some of its customers that the company desperately needs a low-cost, updated version of its original Macintosh. Apple executives promised to soon get cheaper models of the enormously popular machines on the market. ``We will have new compact machines at lower price points and modular machines at lower price points,'' said Randy Battat, Apple's vice president for marketing, said at a news conference on Monday. He refused to say when those machines will be available. Apple's new Macintosh IIfx is based on a speedy version of Motorola Inc.'s 68030 microprocessor and is twice as fast as the Macintosh IIci introduced six months ago. It will enable the company to compete better in the $6 billion a year market for workstations, which are powerful and fast desktop computers. The IIfx costs from $9,696 to $11,497, nearly $3,000 more than the IIci and in the same range as competing workstations. While the new machine won't satisfy critics who blame the company's recent financial woes on the absence of a cheap Macintosh, Apple responded to the call for lower prices by announcing decreases of up to 50 percent on its memory expansion kits for almost all Macintosh systems, as well as LaserWriter printers. Apple also introduced video display cards that improve graphic display and will compete with those sold by other companies; a new release of its implementation of the Unix operating system; and new training programs for customers and authorized Apple resellers. The Macintosh IIfx is available in three configurations _ with a single floppy disk drive, with an 80-megabyte hard disk drive, or with a 160-megabyte drive. Each comes with 4 megabytes of internal memory, and the machine is expandable to 8 megabytes. Many of the people who developed the new system originally worked at such rival workstation makers as Sun Microsystems Inc. and Apollo Computer. William Lempesis, an analyst with Dataquest Inc., a San Jose market research company, said the new machine shows that Apple is continuing efforts to better position itself for a greater share of the high-end corporate computer market, where profits are higher. In the last year, Apple's sales have declined, but the company made more money per machine, indicating a switch in sales toward higher-priced, more profitable units. Lempesis said the Macintosh IIfx will compete with workstations used for such technical work as computer-aided design. ``One of the objections to the Mac has been pure speed and processing power,'' said Jennifer Aurand, a spokeswoman for Versacad Corp., a software maker in Huntington Beach, adding that the new machine ``allows the Mac to compete more directly with (Sun's) Sparcstation.'' The new version of Unix also is likely to assist Apple in the workstation area. Federal government agencies and universities generally use computers that run the Unix operating system. The Macintosh IIfx won a generally enthusiastic response among industry observers, but the company is still criticized for a lack of cheap products that has resulted in a loss of sales to companies selling less expensive IBM-PC compatibles. Apple slashed prices by up to 17 percent on its low-end computers in February after laying off 400 people because of slow sales. In the first quarter, which ended Dec. 29, profit fell 11 percent to $124.8 million. Revenue grew just 6 percent to $1.49 billion. Apple's troubles recently led to a major management shakeup, including the resignation of two division presidents, and appointment of a chief operating officer.

DOC.HEAD: Sale of Hussmann Corp. Mulled
DOC.TEXT: Whitman Corp., continuing a plan to focus on food and soft drinks businesses, said its board of directors would explore selling Hussmann Corp., an industrial and commercial refrigeration equipment maker. Whitman also announced Monday that it would use the net proceeds from any sale of assets to reduce long-term debt and pursue acquisitions in food and beverages. It said it also would study a plan of corporate reorganization designed to create an operating company in place of the current holding company. ``This plan is a strong step forward in the evolution of Whitman Corp.,'' Chairman and Chief Executive Officer James W. Cozad said in a statement. The announcement regarding Hussmann, which is based in Bridgeton, Missouri, follows a February statement that Whitman would concentrate on becoming a strong North American food and soft-drinks company and sell its investment in Northfield Laboratories. Among Whitman's food and soft drinks holdings are Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers. It also owns Pet Inc. with brands including Old El Paso Mexican foods, Progresso soups, Underwood meat spreads and Whitman chocalates.

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell Says Administration Has Rejected Rostenkowski Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has demonstrated it is not concerned about the budget deficit by rejecting a deficit-reduction proposal by Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell said today. ``They have opposed every single specific provision in the Rostenkowski plan'' while appearing to be conciliatory, Mitchell, D-Maine, told reporters. ``This again demonstrates the president is the cause of the budget deadlock and only the president can break it,'' Mitchell said. Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, outlined on March 11 a plan for raising taxes; freezing spending, including Social Security increases; and cutting the defense budget in order to wipe out the deficit by 1994. President Bush said he will consider Rostenkowski's proposal but repeated his opposition to raising taxes. Mitchell noted that Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, had spelled out the administration's opposition to specific parts of the plan in testimony before a congressional committee last week. Bush's State of the Union message ``said in effect that it (the deficit) is not a problem,'' Mitchell said. ``That is the problem. When that's changed, when there's some seriousness about it,'' Congress and the administration may be able to agree on significant deficit reduction, the Democratic leader said.

The stock market was mixed in early trading today. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 3.83 points at 2,759.46 at 10 a.m. EST. The broader market was lower, however. Declining issues outnumbered gains by around 3 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 590 issues down, 376 up and 484 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board totaled 23.5 million shares. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 0.09 at 188.57. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index had risen 0.14 to 364.26. Market sentiment was dampened by news that consumer inflation was 0.5 percent in February and the U.S. trade deficit worsened dramatically in January, climbing to $9.3 billion. In addition, the Tokyo stock market dived sharply again today as neither currency market intervention nor an interest rate boost by the central bank stopped the weakening of the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which plunged 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, on Monday in its third-largest single-day fall, tumbled another 456.05 points, or 1.48 percent, today. Wall Street had tumbled initially Monday in the wake of that day's slide in Japan, but later recovered in an afternoon rally. The Dow Jones average finished 14.41 points higher Monday at 2,755.63, its highest close since it stood at 2,760.67 on Jan. 11. Advancing issues nearly matched declines on the New York Stock Exchange, with 711 up, 720 down and 527 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 142.30 million shares, down from 222.52 million in last Friday's session.

DOC.HEAD: EC Budget Chief Sees EC Currency in Late 1990s
DOC.TEXT: EC Finance Commissioner Henning Christophersen said today he sees the EC introducing a single currency in the second half of the 1990s as part of economic and monetary union in the trade bloc. He said making the European currency unit legal tender across the EC could save up to $24.2 billion a year in bank charges on transactions among the European Community currencies. Christophersen said the ECU would not necessarily replace existing currencies but its corresponding value could be printed on one side of coins and bills now in circulation. ``I do not exclude that you can have a single currency and also protect the names of existing currencies,'' he told reporters. He added jokingly if consumers feel very European they can pay with the ``ECU side of bills and coins facing up.'' Alternatively, they can let the national denomination face upward, he said. Currently, the ECU is a basket of existing EC currencies weighted in favor of the largest economies in the Community. Christophersen released the Commission's recommendations for EC economic and monetary union, the topic of an intergovernmental conference. That meeting, due to start this year, will discuss the necessary amendments to the EC treaty. ``The benefits of the EC single market will be amplified by economic and monetary union and a single currency,'' Christophersen said. In addition to a single currency, his report proposes a central EC bank system, called Eurofed. It also recommends the EC states coordinate their budget policies more closely and that those with serious budget difficulties solve them before monetary union takes shape. Christophersen rejected a British plan for economic and monetary union under which currencies would float freely against each other. He said that would result in one currency emerging as the winner. But the Commission recommended looser controls on member states' budget policies than suggested by EC Commission President Jacques Delors last year. Christophersen said EC central banks could have some flexibility in following Eurofed's policy depending on, for example, regional circumstances. His report lists two key rules for monetary union: EC states cannot fund deficits by printing money and the EC will not automatically bail out a member facing serious budgetary problems. ``It isa clear message. If a member state is following the wrong policies it will have to pay the price,'' Christophersen said. The central bank system, modeled on the U.S. Federal Reserve System and the Deutsche Bundesbank, would develop EC monetary policy and be independent of EC central banks and of the EC institutions. It would comprise the governors of the 12 EC central banks, who would set monetary targets and interest rates, and a group of lower-level experts to monitor compliance with these. In addition to responsibility for price stability, Eurofed would have exclusive control over the issuing of ECUs. EC finance ministers will review Christophersen's plans at a meeting in Ireland on March 31. The single currency and the central bank would emerge in the last two stages of the drive to economic and monetary union. Under the first stage, starting July 1, the EC states would tighten their economic policy coordination, free capital movements and join the European Monetary System's exchange rate mechanism. Britain has not done the latter. The second stage would start after the EC treaty has been amended, which might be by Jan. 1, 1994. During the third stage, which may take another three years, the EC would institute a single currency and create a central bank.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Extend Gains; Strong Technical Signals Cited
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending their gains on buying inspired more by bullish chart signals than supply-and-demand factors. The rally in the soybean market surprised analysts who had predicted profit-taking after Monday's strong advance. Buying interest swelled as prices climbed, said John Frazier, director of the agricultural futures trading for Gerald Inc. ``It looks like everybody's got their bull horns out right now,'' he said of the soybean market. ``Everybody thinks it's going through the roof.'' Some soybean buying was prompted by private estimates that the Brazilian soybean crop now being harvested will be smaller than the 20.5 million metric tons forecast by the U.S. Agriculture Department. Wheat futures continued to be led higher by signs of relatively tight supplies for delivery against the March contract, which expires tomorrow. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent to 2{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.01 a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1 cent higher with March at $2.51} a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent lower with March at $1.48{ a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents to 3} cents higher with March at $5.91{ a bushel. Cattle futures were lower while pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .25 cent to .37 cent lower with April at 77.77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .40 cent lower with March at 82.70 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .12 cent higher with April at 53.62 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .27 cent to .45 cent higher with May at 52.30 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures rose on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Suspends Dividend
DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Store Inc., which in January announced it expected to post its first annual loss, has suspended the company's annual 10 cents a share common stock dividend. Directors of the Rocky Hill-based Ames said Monday that the dividend would not be paid until the company becomes profitable again. The company's last quarterly dividend of 2{ cents, was paid Thursday. Ames is expected to release its 1989-90 financial report within three weeks, and company officials have conceded the news will not be good. Retail analysts have predicted Ames might have lost more than $1 per share, or more than $37 million. Ames has attributed its financial troubles to a weak retail environment and problems at the Zayre chain of discount stores, which it acquired in October 1988. In January, Ames said it would post its first annual loss and that it would take a number of cost-cutting measures, including laying off 85 workers. Douglas Ewing, Ames director of investor relations, said the decision to discontinue the common stock dividend will save the company about $3.7 million a year. ``Given that dividends are really a distribution of earnings, and that we're operating at a loss for 1989, there's a rationale in that,'' Ewing said. ``No earnings, no dividend.'' The dividend suspension, announced about an hour before the stock market's close Monday, caused Ames stock to drop 37{ cents, to $5.62{ cents a share, on heavier-than-average trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock has been dropping steadily since January, when it was selling for about $9 a share.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 8.56 points at 2,764.19 at noon EST.
