DOC.HEAD: Donald C. Carter Pleads Guilty to $1 Million Theft
DOC.TEXT: A man who acted as an adviser in numerous corporate takeovers pleaded guilty today to stealing $1 million from his proxy solicitation firm between 1987 and 1989. Donald C. Carter, chairman of The Carter Organization Inc., also pleaded guilty to falsifying personal state income taxes and falsifying tax returns, said Ronald Goldstock, director of the state Organized Crime Task Force. Carter entered the plea before Justice George F. Roberts in state Supreme Court in Manhattan, although the announcement was made at the task force offices in Westchester County. Carter, 41, of Old Brookville, pleaded guilty to grand larceny, filing a false and fraudulent personal income tax return. He faces up to seven years in prison. Among the victims of Carter's thefts were many of the nation's largest and best-known companies, including Union Carbide Corp., Shell Oil and Caesar's World Inc. The Carter Organization represented leading takeover specialists such as Saul Steinberg, T. Boone Pickens and Carl Icahn. According to Goldstock, Carter routinely billed his clients for non-existent or inflated expenses between 1984-89, supplying false information to justify the bogus invoices. Carter has agreed to establish a $1 million escrow fund to make restitution to the victims, Goldstock said. He also admitted falsifying a New York state tax return in 1986, including charging hundreds of thousands of dollars in personal expenses as business expenses. The personal expenses included renovation to Carter's Manhattan apartment. He also owes New York State an estimated $2 million in taxes, penalties and interest, Goldstock said.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Divided Over Whether Rate Rise Will Stifle Inflation
DOC.TEXT: Japan's economy should slow due to Tuesday's hike in a key interest rate, but there are questions about whether another big increase is needed to douse inflationary fires, analysts said. The question for most was whether the discount rate hike would revive the sagging yen, a key cause of inflationary speculation and stock market instability. ``The latest discount rate will bite,'' said Richard Koo, senior economist at Nomura Research Institute. ``But this kind of thing operates with a lag.'' The Bank of Japan raised its discount rate by 1 percentage point Tuesday to 5.25 percent. It was the fourth hike of a series intended primarily to fight inflation. The rate _ the interest charged on loans to commercial banks _ was 2.5 percent last May. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno called the increase ``pre-emptive,'' saying it would ease latent inflationary pressures without appreciably slowing Japan's economic expansion. Japan already has some of the world's highest prices. Throughout the 1980s, Japan managed to keep consumer prices stable and wholesale prices tumbled in the late '80s as the yen's value shot up. Only land prices rose sharply, by as much as 90 percent annually. But recently, the costs of items ranging from beer to school tuition have been rising. Last year, Japanese inflation was about 3 percent, but fully half of the increase was attributed to a 3 percent sales tax imposed in April. Economists predict that, excluding effects of the tax, inflation will rise by about 1 percentage point to 2.5 percent this year. The Bank of Japan has blamed the weakening yen _ along with labor shortages and a growing money supply _ for much of the inflation problem. So far this year, the yen has fallen 7 percent against the U.S. dollar. The weaker yen fuels inflation by raising the cost of imports. Kenneth S. Courtis, senior economist with DB Capital Markets Asia, said the money supply growing twice as fast in Japan as in the United States. With the supply of yen far outstripping demand, the central bank's rate hike was inadequate, he said. ``Japanese rates will have to go up much higher to support the yen,'' he said. The dollar rose to 153.65 yen on Tuesday from Monday's 153.55 yen, the highest close since its 153.69 yen level of March 12, 1987. Courtis predicted the yen would fall to 165 against the dollar, pushing the Japanese inflation rate to about 2.5 percent. But others said inflation may have peaked, if the rate hike stabilizes the yen. Economist Atsuko Kitamura of Yasuda Trust Bank said hotels, taxis and other services were likely to raise their prices in April. But she noted the cost of golf club memberships _ an early indicator of land price trends in Japan _ was slipping. Koo said the central bank's action paved the way for an investment slowdown. He predicted the long-term prime rate would now go up half a point to 8 percent. ``How many people can afford to borrow at 8 percent to speculate in land?'' he said. But others felt the market had adjusted in advance to the widely anticipated rate increase. Jan VanDenBerg, an economist with Merrill Lynch, said larger companies would react to the higher cost of capital by laying off part-time workers, reducing orders to suppliers and cutting production. But despite this economic cooling, another increase might be required to trim land prices, she said. Jason James, a strategic analyst with James Capel Pacific, said the market continued to shun the yen because the cost of land and other assets in Japan was much higher than abroad, reducing investment yields. James speculated there remained ``a 50-50 chance'' that the Bank of Japan would have to raise the discount rate again this year.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Worsens in January
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 7-8, At the White House, with comment.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit, bloated by a record demand for foreign oil, worsened dramatically in January, climbing to $9.3 billion, the government said today. The Commerce Department said the January deficit was 20.5 percent larger than December's $7.7 billion imbalance. Most of the deterioration came from a 44 percent surge in oil shipments. The January deficit was an ominous beginning for the new decade. Many analysts believe America's trade woes will worsen in coming years as U.S. dependence on foreign oil grows. For January, exports climbed to an all-time high of $32.1 billion, 4 percent above the December level. However, this gain was swamped by a 7.3 percent surge in imports, which increased to $41.3 billion. The trade deficit, the difference between imports and exports, was the largest since a $10.1 billion imbalance in November. At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the January increase showed export growth has been outpacing growth in imports. ``These numbers are pretty much as expected due to the deficit drop in December, which was the lowest in five years. Everyone seemed to realize they couldn't maintain that low level, and so it was expected that there would be an increase in January,'' Fitzwater said. The U.S. trade deficit has been improving for the past two years, falling to $109 billion last year, down 8 percent from 1988. But many economists predicted the 1990 deficit could begin rising again because of the oil bill and gains in the value of the dollar. A stronger U.S. currency makes imports cheaper for Americans and U.S. products less competitive on overseas markets. The huge 44 percent surge in oil imports did not come as a surprise, with analysts blaming the rise on December's record cold weather, which caused oil companies to import heavily in January to restock depleted supplies. The total volume of oil, 291,278 barrels, was an all-time high, topping a previous record set in August. Prices shot up to $20.13 per barrel, pushing the total oil bill to $5.86 billion, the highest total dollar amount snce August 1982, a month when the volume was less but the price per barrel was higher. The American Petroleum Institute has reported that foreign oil accounted for a record 54 percent of consumption in January as domestic production fell to its lowest level in a quarter century. Another factor swelling the deficit in January was a 31 percent surge in imports of clothing, which totaled $3.1 billion in January. As usual, the deficit with Japan was the largest of any country. However, at $2.9 billion, it was at the lowest level since December 1984. The Bush administration has been pressing the Japanese to do more to purchase U.S. exports as a way of reducing the huge annual deficit of $49 billion that America is running with Japan. Other big deficits included Taiwan, $1.2 billion; China, $800 million; Canada, $600 million, and the countries of Western Europe, $300 million. Many economists are worried that the deficit will worsen even further in coming months. Michael Evans, head of a Washington forecasting company, said he was looking for the deficit for all of 1990 to total between $120 billion and $125 billion, which would make it the second worst imbalance on history. The all-time high was a $152.1 billion deficit in 1987. ``Without a weaker dollar, we are just not going to get an improvement in trade,'' Evans said. ``We are destined to have bad trade numbers for some time.'' Such a forecast could spell trouble for the Bush administration, which is counting on further gains in exports to help boost the fortunes of American manufacturers and dampen protectionist sentiments in Congress. Last month, President Bush held a hastily arranged meeting in California with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to press demands that Japan do more to reduce its trade gap with the United States, which amounted to $49 billion last year. Kaifu promised to make reduction of trade tensions a top priority, but U.S. critics question whether the verbal commitments will be turned into significant market-opening moves. Sen. John Danforth of Missouri, the ranking Republican on the Senate trade subcommittee, said Monday that Japanese officials he met with in Tokyo last week appeared to be more willing to address U.S. complaints about their closed markets. ``There was a recognition that the time had come to redress the grievances we had,'' said Danforth, who has been a leading critic of both Japanese trade practices and the way Bush and former President Reagan addressed them. But Danforth told reporters, ``I remain skeptical that the ... talks are going to lead to the kind of concrete results we hope for.'' He said the talks will have to produce more specific sales of U.S. products to Japan as well as a broader general commitment by Tokyo to removing impediments.

DOC.HEAD: Drop in Fuel Oil Holds Inflation to Moderate 0.5 Percent in February
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 6, At the White House, with reaction.
DOC.TEXT: A record increase in clothing costs helped push consumer inflation to a brisk 0.5 percent in February, despite the biggest one-month drop in fuel oil prices in 55 years, the government said today. The gain in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index came on top of a huge 1.1 percent rise in January, the steepest in 7{ years. A turn-of-the-year cold snap sent energy and food costs soaring in January. Fuel oil prices recovered with warmer-than-usual temperatures in February. However, food prices are taking longer to snap back and clothing costs posted the largest seasonally adjusted monthly rise in 43 years, accounting for about two-fifths of the overall gain. ``It's a nasty little number, worse than we thought it would be,'' said economist Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. ``The problems we had in January still appear to be lingering in February.'' At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said: ``We must remain vigilant against any increase in inflation. But the inflation level has been relatively steady for some time in spite of the weather-related and energy-related surges. Overall, we continue to believe that inflation is low and under control.'' Taken together, the first two months of the year represent an annual inflation rate of 9.9 percent. However, most analysts expect a succession of milder reports this year and look toward a 1990 rate just under last year's 4.6 percent. In a separate report, the Commerce Department said the U.S. trade deficit widened to $9.3 billion in January, up from $7.7 billion in December. The deficit worsened despite a 4 percent climb in exports to an all-time high of $32.1 billion. Many stock and bond prices fell in reaction to the reports. Although the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 3.83 points at 2,759.46 in the first half hour of trading, bond prices declined and the broader stock market was lower. Declining issues outnumbered gains by around 3 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange. In advance, most analysts had been expecting only half as much inflation. Traders took the price rise, coupled with the economic strength suggested by the export number, as an indication the Federal Reserve Board will not soon lower interest rates. In a related report, the Labor Department said U.S. workers earnings rose 0.3 percent in February after adjustments for inflation and seasonal factors. That followed a 1.2 percent drop in January, much steeper than an earlier government estimate of 0.7 percent. Energy prices overall were down 0.7 percent in February following a 5.1 percent gain in January. The department said fuel oil, which advanced 26.3 percent in January, fell back 18.7 percent in February, a record since 1935 when the government first began tracking the price. Gasoline rose 0.8 percent after a 7.7 percent rise. Natural gas and electricity rose 0.6 percent after a 0.3 percent increase. Food costs rose 0.5 percent in February after a large 1.8 percent rise in January. Dairy products rose 0.9 percent. So did fruit and vegetables, following a 10.2 percent rise in January after a freeze ruined crops from Texas to Florida. Tomatoes jumped 30.7 percent in February. For the two months combined, they were up 129.4 percent. There were declines for sugar and sweets and fats and oils. Excluding the volatile food and energy categories, prices rose 0.5 percent. This ``core'' number is generally considered a better indication of underlying inflation pressures. However, it was driven higher by an unusual 3.3 percent rise in clothing and upkeep prices. On a seasonally adjusted basis, it was the sharpest rise since 1947 when that series of numbers was first recorded. A department analyst said spring fashion lines were introduced earlier in the year than normal, throwing off the department's statistical adjustments. Infant's and toddler's clothing rose 10.3 percent. Women's and girls' clothing was up 5 percent, while men's and boys' clothes rose 1.2 percent. There was a 0.2 percent drop in new car prices as dealers tried a new round of incentives to stimulate lagging sales. The various changes left the Consumer Price Index at 128.0 before seasonal adjustments. That meant that a hypothetical selection of goods and services costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period would have cost $128 last month, up from $121.60 a year earlier. In other details, the department said services rose 0.4 percent, including a gain of 0.8 percent for medical care. For the year, analysts expect inflation to be stable. Low unemployment is keeping wage increases from abating. But sluggishness, particularly in manufacturing, is keeping inflation from getting out of control. ``The economy is too strong for inflation to go down, but it's still ... too weak for inflation to really be rising very much,'' said economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch.

DOC.HEAD: Three Submit Preliminary Bids For MiniScribe
DOC.TEXT: MiniScribe Corp., the financially troubled computer disk drive maker, has received three preliminary bids from potential buyers, chairman Richard Rifenburgh reported. Rifenburgh said Monday the company expects formal offers from at least two of the bidders later this week. Rifenburgh would not reveal the names of the bidders nor their preliminary offers, but he said he was optimistic a deal could be struck. ``I'm now convinced that one of these three offers will be the winning bid and the buyers will go forward with (MiniScribe's) product,'' he said. ``We're very, very pleased that it looks like we'll continue to have a going concern in MiniScribe.'' The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization on Jan. 1. MiniScribe must be sold by April 4 or face a court-ordered bank auction. Company officials have estimated that MiniScribe's assets would bring $35 million to $50 million in a liquidation sale. But officials say the company is worth substantially more if it is purchased as a going concern. The company's new line of 1-inch-high disk drives, now in limited production overseas, is viewed as its most valuable asset.

DOC.HEAD: ConAgra Reports Record Third Quarter, Nine-Month Earnings
DOC.TEXT: ConAgra Inc. Tuesday reported a 17.8 percent increase in its third-quarter profit, boosted by a significant gain in its prepared foods business. The Omaha-based food conglomerate said it earned $44.2 million, or 36 cents a share, in the three months ended Feb. 25, up from $37.6 million, or 31 cents a share, in the previous year's third quarter. Sales rose 33.5 percent to $3.63 billion from $2.72 billion. Through the first three quarters of ConAgra's 1990 fiscal year, the company had income of $158.2 million, or $1.28 a share, a 19.3 percent gain over $132.5 million, or $1.10 a share, a year earlier. Nine-month sales totaled $11.49 billion, a 37.4 percent increase over $8.37 billion the year before. The third quarter and nine month per share results reflect a three-for-two split on ConAgra's common stock effective Dec. 1, 1989. ``We've often emphasized the strength ConAgra derives from our strategy to grow across the food chain,'' said Charles M. Harper, chairman and chief executive officer. ``This year our company has abundant evidence of exciting food chain activity ranging from successful new consumer products to international growth.'' During the third quarter and nine months, ConAgra's largest industry segment, Prepared Foods, had a significant operating profit gain. The company said it also had growth in its frozen foods, fresh meat and poultry businesses, while earnings were down in turkey products and weak in pork product sales.

DOC.HEAD: Shaine Investors Settle 2{ Years After `Black Monday'
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 2{ years after the stock market collapse of 1987, creditors of a failed brokerage firm have reached a settlement with former options investors who lost $12.4 million on Black Monday. The 60 investors, enrolled in a high-risk options trading program with H.B. Shaine & Co. at the time of the Oct. 19, 1987, crash, will pay $3.4 million _ or an average of about $57,000 each _ of the $12.4 million worth of trading losses they piled up. The settlement was approved Monday by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Laurence Howard. Shaine, a locally based retail brokerage firm, was ordered liquidated by a federal judge on Oct. 20, one day after Wall Street's record collapse. It was taken over by Securities Investors Protection Corp., a federal agency that insures brokerage accounts. The remaining losses owed to creditors will be absorbed by the brokerage's large creditors or paid by its owners and directors. The largest single creditor is Options Clearing Corp., the Chicago clearinghouse that handles options transactions. Other creditors include banks that loaned Shaine money. The investors have accused the brokerage's management and two of its brokers with failing to warn them fully of the risks of the transactions. The settlement cancels all customer claims against the brokerage and its directors, including several lawsuits filed outside of the bankruptcy court. Cyril Moscow, the court-appointed trustee, said he plans to pursue the brokerage's owners and directors for additional damages. Attorneys for 41 of the customers said their clients had their assets in Shaine accounts, totaling $5.8 million, frozen after the brokerage's failure. With the settlement, those involved will have their accounts unfrozen and will get some money back after the settlement is paid, attorney L.R. Roegge said. The trading losses mounted as the 60 clients sold options in the Standard & Poor's 100 Index. The options, sold on the Chicago Board Options Exchange, were sold ``naked,'' meaning the customers did not own the underlying stocks for which they were selling options to purchase.

DOC.HEAD: Chase President Expects Rise In Non-Performing Real Estate Loans
DOC.TEXT: Chase Manhattan Corp. President Thomas Labrecque said Tuesday he expects to see a steady increase in problem real estate loans over the next several months as sluggishness in many commercial and residential markets continues. ``We had expected a cyclical market downswing for two years,'' Labrecque told a meeting of securities analysts. ``We took steps to limit our growth and tighten our underwriting and appraisal standards.'' Chase placed $783 million in domestic real estate loans on a nonaccrual basis at the end of 1989, a 49 percent jump from the $527 million the previous year. When loans are placed on nonaccrual status, banks no longer include on their statements the interest and other charges due on the loans until the money is actually received. As the current sluggish real estate environment persists, Labrecque said, the number of these non-performing loans is expected to increase moderately in the first quarter and ``somewhat more over the next quarters.'' Chase's domestic real estate loan portfolio totaled $9 billion at yearend, up from $7.1 billion in 1988. Despite the sharp rise in problem loans, Labrecque told analysts overall credit quality in the bank's real estate lending business was relatively good and should remain profitable. ``Our's is a well-diversified portfolio that has helped us withstand regional downturns,'' he said. Chase is the nation's second-largest bank holding company with assets of $107.37 billion at the end of 1989. Its individual bank, in which its real estate lending operations are included, accounts for around a third of total assets.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mostly Higher After See-Saw Session
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade after see-sawing through the session as traders searched for significant new developments. The markets extended the strong gains posted in the previous session, rallying near the close amid reports that the Soviet Union was making progress on resolving credit problems. The reports stirred speculation that the Soviets would soon return to the U.S. grain markets. Recent rumors of Soviet interest in buying U.S. grain have so far not been confirmed by purchases. The wheat market found additional support in indications of tight supplies for delivery against the March wheat contract, which expires Wednesday. Other grain and soybean futures for March delivery also go off the board Wednesday. At the close, wheat futures, were \ cent to 3} cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.02\ a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 2\ cents higher with March at $2.52\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1} cents lower with March at $1.48\ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 3 cents higher with March at $5.91{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Discount Rate Hike Failed To Halt Stock, Yen Declines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two new grafs for 5th pvs ``Although higher interest ...'' to ADD report of agreement to suspend issuance of new shares. Picks up 6th graf pvs ``The dollar ....'' Will be led with early Tokyo currency, stock trading.
DOC.TEXT: A long-awaited increase in a key lending rate Tuesday provided no quick fix for the sinking Japanese stock market and weakening yen, but analysts predicted the move would have a greater impact over the long term. The Bank of Japan raised its discount rate _ the interest charged on loans to commercial banks _ by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent. The increase was the fourth since last May, when the rate stood at 2.5 percent. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index, which has been slumping this year due to uncertainty over interest rates, continued to fall in reaction to the rate hike, dropping 456.05 points, or 1.48 percent, to close at 30,807.19. It was the Nikkei's lowest closing since 30,678.39 on Jan. 9, 1989. That followed a decline of 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, on Monday, the index's third-largest single-day fall. In another move aimed at supporting the stock market, major Japanese securities houses reportedly agreed to suspend the issuance of new shares. Nikkei Telecom, a Japanese news wire service, reported the suspension would last at least a month. In the currency markets, the yen weakened further despite the discount rate hike. Although higher rates tend to make a country's currency more attractive, analysts said traders discounted the move because they had been expecting it. The dollar gained 0.10 yen Tuesday, closing at 153.65 yen, its highest since the March 12, 1987 closing of 153.69 yen. The yen's failure to respond to the discount rate hike discouraged stock investors, who view currency stability as a key to a recovery in stocks, traders said. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno said Tuesday the bank's move was ``pre-emptive,'' to maintain price stability, and would not appreciably slow economic growth. While not providing an instant remedy, the rate increase would help both the yen and the stock market in the long run, he said. Hiroshi Saito, president of Nippon Steel Corp., told Kyodo News Service that the action would stabilize financial markets by making investors think the interest rate has reached its top. But Hideo Mori, president of Sumitomo Chemical Co., said the rate increase might damage healthy economic growth. Some analysts suggested the Bank of Japan waited too long to raise the rate. ``If the discount rate had been raised when the dollar was about to surpass the 150-yen line, the dollar could not have risen this high,'' said Toshiaki Kakimoto, chief economist with Sumitomo Bank. ``Monetary actions should be taken in more flexible fashion.'' With signs of inflationary pressure growing, the market had expected the rise to come shortly after the Feb. 18 general elections. Amid the uncertainty that followed, stock and bond prices and the yen all continued to weaken. So far this year, the dollar has risen by more than 10 yen, or 7 percent, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-share Nikkei Stock Average has fallen more than 8,100 points, or almost 21 percent. This triple decline _ yen, stocks and bonds _ led companies to shift money from stock and bond investments to bank accounts and forced many to abandon plans for raising capital. Kakimoto said the rate increase would show its effects slowly but surely, and would give the yen a chance for a gradual recovery. Since the interest rate gap between the United States and Japan has narrowed, reducing the relatively higher returns on U.S. securities, dollar-buying should slow, he said. Also, direct investments in the United States _ in factories, real estate and takeovers _ may slow because dollars will become more expensive for Japanese businessmen, Kakimoto said.

Wall Street has posted an impressive advance in recent weeks. ``It was just an overbought market that got a little bit ahead of itself,'' said Charles Jensen, a technical analyst at MKI Securities Corp. The government reported today that consumer inflation was 0.5 percent in February and the U.S. trade deficit worsened dramatically in January, climbing to $9.3 billion. The January trade deficit was 20.5 percent larger than December's $7.7 billion imbalance. Most of the deterioration came from a 44 percent surge in oil imports. In addition, the Tokyo stock market took a sharp dive again today, as neither currency market intervention nor an interest rate boost by the central bank stopped the weakening of the Japanese yen. The Bank of Japan raised its key discount rate by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent. It was the fourth hike of a series intended primarily to fight inflation. Hugh Johnson, senior vice president of First Albany Corp. in Albany, N.Y., suggested that the Japanese may have to increase the rate again in the near future. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which plunged 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, on Monday in its third-largest single-day fall, tumbled another 456.05 points, or 1.48 percent, today. The New York market had tumbled initially Monday in the wake of that day's slide in Japan, but later recovered in an afternoon rally. The Dow Jones average finished 14.41 points higher Monday at 2,755.63, its highest close since it stood at 2,760.67 on Jan. 11. Today, the NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 0.43 at 188.23. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index had fallen 0.78 to 363.34. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, IBM was down } at 108\, American Express had slipped [ to 27~, General Electric had declined [ to 64} and Boeing had lost ] to 71[.
