DOC.HEAD: Americans Are Told To Eat Their Vegetables _ For A Day
DOC.TEXT: Not everyone noticed, but Tuesday was the Great American Meatout, a day when soup kitchens went vegetarian in Pittsburgh and the mayor of Des Moines, Iowa, discovered a new kind of pork barrel politics. ``You're not my mayor,'' was among the kinder remarks greeting Des Moines Mayor John ``Pat'' Dorrian at the Iowa statehouse after he signed a proclamation recognizing the vegetarian holiday. ``This blows my mind,'' added Dorrian's non-constituent, state Sen. John Soorholtz. Dorrian half-heartedly defended his decision to support a one-day meat boycott in the nation's top pork-producing state, but even he conceded, ``It's probably something that should never have been signed.'' The Meatout was the idea of the Farm Animal Reform Movement, a national advocacy group opposed to ``factory farming'' and in favor of vegeterian diets. It was intended as a response to National Meat Week _ another of the nation's lesser-known commemorations. The Meatout was supported by such entertainment figures as Doris Day, Ally Sheedy and River Phoenix, and ``American Top 40'' radio announcer Casey Kasem. It also was observed, perhaps inadvertently, by about 500 people who ate vegetarian meals at three soup kitchens in the Pittsburgh area. The food was donated and served by volunteers from Animal Advocates and the Pittsburgh Vegetarian Society. About 165 people ate vegetarian chili, corn, fruit cocktail and bread at the Rainbow Kitchen in Homestead, a depressed former steel town just outside of Pittsburgh. ``They liked it. We do serve vegetarian meals from time to time,'' said Kevin Amos, the kitchen's food program manager. It was somewhat less of a success in Philadelphia _ birthplace of freedom and the cheesesteak _ where Meatout supporters targeted Jim's Steaks on South Street as their staging ground. A group of high school vegetarians stood outside the art deco landmark passing out anti-meat fliers, carrots and orange slices as the aroma of seared beef and fried onions wafted overhead. But they were evidently unable to cow any of the early lunch crowd into avoiding meat for a day. The usual stampede began shortly after 11 a.m. ``If they don't want to eat it, they don't have to,'' said Leon Schwartz, a 30-year-old Philadelphian ``weaned'' on the famed cheesesteak, a mound of sliced beef slathered with melted cheese served on a roll. ``I want to, and I eat it. That's what America is all about.'' ``What is this, save a cow?'' said Bernie Bartholome, a New York businessman as he chewed on a cheesesteak laden with peppers, onions and tomatoes. ``See _ I eat vegetables, too.'' Many passersby accepted the handout from the students and chomped on the carrots. ``As long as they read it and understand, that's a start,'' said Rachel Randolph, 15. ``People are being real receptive.'' ``This is a Philadelphia institution, so we decided to stand here,'' said Laura Kuperman, 16. ``We're trying to be friendly, not confrontational.'' What's their beef? The demonstrators said raising livestock is environmentally dangerous, wastes vital farmland and is cruel to animals. It's also bad for you, they said, reciting statistics about heart disease, saturated fat, cancer, hormones and other uncomfortable topics. ``Even if they don't convert, their eyes will be open,'' said Jane Edelstein, 15. ``We're trying to make people more aware,'' added Alix Hetherington, 16. Anything more, presumably, would be gravy.
The stock market declined today. Shortly before the close of trading, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 19.37 points at 2,736.26.

U.S. shares declined today following negative economic reports and another steep tumble on the Tokyo stock market. After shrugging off negative economic news to rise earlier in the session, stocks turned lower in the afternoon and lost most of the ground just before the close. Wall Street has posted an impressive advance in recent weeks. ``It was just an overbought market that got a little bit ahead of itself,'' said Charles Jensen, a technical analyst at MKI Securities Corp. The government reported today that consumer inflation was 0.5 percent in February and the U.S. trade deficit worsened dramatically in January, climbing to $9.3 billion. The January trade deficit was 20.5 percent larger than December's $7.7 billion gap. Most of the deterioration came from a 44 percent surge in oil imports. Still, Wall Street's decline wasn't nearly as severe as the sharp dive today in the Tokyo stock market. Analysts said the New York market drew some support from strong bond prices, which pushed interest rates lower. In Tokyo, the key Japanese stock index tumbled a second day as neither currency market intervention nor an interest rate boost by the central bank stopped the weakening of the Japanese yen. The Bank of Japan raised its key discount rate by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent. It was the fourth hike of a series intended primarily to fight inflation. Hugh Johnson, senior vice president of First Albany Corp. in Albany, N.Y., suggested that the Japanese may have to increase the rate again in the near future. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which plunged 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, on Monday in its third-largest single-day fall, tumbled another 456.05 points, or 1.48 percent, today. The New York market had tumbled initially Monday in the wake of that day's slide in Japan, but later recovered in an afternoon rally. The Dow Jones average finished 14.41 points higher Monday at 2,755.63, its highest close since it stood at 2,760.67 on Jan. 11.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Presents Cautious Budget
DOC.TEXT: The government, in growing trouble over the economy, presented a cautious budget Tuesday aimed at fighting inflation partly by encouraging Britons to save and hiking taxes on tobacco, alcohol and gasoline. In his annual spring budget statement to the House of Commons, Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major said the government would raise an addition 500 million pounds, or $805 million, from taxpayers in the year ended March 31, 1991. But he announced no drastic changes in the way the government raises its tax revenue, choosing instead to tinker with thresholds and allowances. His budget was expected to be highly popular with Britons who will benefit from the adjustments, mainly small savers, retirees, working mothers, and small businessmen. However, economists expressed disappointment in the statement, saying it was not austere enough to curb 7.7 percent inflation, which has been stubborn despite 15 percent interest rates. A tight budget would have increased tax revenue more than 3 billion pounds, and that would have been more effective in curbing consumers' spending power, the economists said. The financial markets had little reaction. Opposition Labor party leader Neil Kinnock called it a ``bits and pieces'' budget that ``won't save the government.'' This budget has been viewed as politically crucial for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, whose economic strategy has come under increasing fire. She needs to get the economy in the best possible shape before mid-1992, the deadline for the next election. The spring statement, in addition to outlining the government's revenue raising plans, is a principal platform for announcing economic policies and forecasts. The government, which announces its spending plans in an autumn statement, said in November it would spend 179 billion pounds in the coming year. The Treasury said a figure for total tax revenue was not available but that overall government receipts are expected to come to 219 billion pounds. Major announced new special savings accounts which will allow Britons to earn interest tax-free on up to 1,800 pounds a year for five years if they leave the capital unchanged during the entire period. The rises in excise taxes on gasoline, alcohol and tobacco were roughly in line with inflation, Major said. For example, a one-pound pint of beer will cost 2 pence more and a 1.60-pound pack of cigarettes will cost 10 pence more. The chancellor left Britain's two income tax rates of 25 percent and 40 percent unchanged. He reaffirmed the government's intention to bring the basic rate down to 20 percent, but did not say when. The corporate tax rate remains at 35 percent. ``This budget will take no risks with inflation,'' Major said. ``That beyond any doubt is the most urgent program before us today.'' Evelyn Brodie, senior British economist at the London investment firm Morgan Grenfell and Co. said the chancellor ``hasn't tightened policy at all.'' ``If you were bearish before, you're still bearish now,'' said Chris Dillow, an economist at Nomura Research Institute in London. ``We believe that the U.K.'s problems still remain.'' Major said British inflation was worse than in other countries because of heavy borrowing and strong consumer spending, but insisted the government's strategy of raising interest rates was working. ``It will worsen noticeably before it improves,'' he warned. He did not forecast the inflation rate's peak, which many economists are pegging at 9 percent. He said the rate might still be above 7 percent in the fourth quarter compared with the 5.75 percent he previously forecast, but that it should fall below 5 percent in 1991. ``My judgment is that interest rates will stay high for some time to come,'' he said. Later, at a news conference, he said he could not be certain interest rates wouldn't go up again. Britain's economy should grow 1 percent this year, and reach 2.75 percent in 1991, he said in Parliament. Growth was 2.5 percent last year and 4.4 percent in 1988. The trade deficit should shrink to 15 million pounds this year, and further thereafter, from more than 20 billion pounds last year, Major said.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: Jan. 11.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 16.89 points to 2,738.74. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 881 down, 598 up and 498 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 177.32 million shares, up from 142.30 million in Monday's session. The NYSE's composite index fell 0.95 to 187.71. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index lost 0.70 at 363.42.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rallies, Gold Lower
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rocketed higher in heavy trading Tuesday, benefiting from profit-taking in West German marks and in the Japanese yen. Intervention by several central banks aimed at shoring up the sagging yen failed to alter the dollar's course. The banks reportedly sold dollars on world foreign exchange markets and bought yen. Speculation that U.S. interest rates would not decline soon, which grew when the government reported an unexpectedly strong inflation reading for February, also encouraged dollar buying. Gold prices tumbled. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid of $392.40 for a troy ounce of gold as of 4 p.m. EST, down $8.40 from Monday's late bid. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for March delivery settled at $392.20 a troy ounce, $8.50 ower than Monday. Currency dealers in the United States described trading in dollars as brisk. They said the Federal Reserve sold dollars against the yen, following similar maneuvers by its foreign counterparts in Europe. ``We had a nice rally in the dollar,'' said John McCarthy, chief dealer at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank's office in New York. McCarthy said most of the momentum for the dollar's broad advance came from sales of West German marks to collect profits amassed during the currency's recent climb. Traders had scrambled to buy marks ahead of Sunday's Eas German elections and bought more Monday when the results indicated a faster move toward a unified Germany. But as the euphoria over the outcome of the voting eased, traders lightened their mark holdings. As trading ended in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.7048 West German marks, up from 1.6860 marks late Monday. The Japanese yen suffered despite an increase in a key lending rate. Dealers said the 1 percentage point hike in Japan's discount rate to 5.25 percent failed to evoke a favorable response because the move was widely anticipated. The rate increase failed to snap the Tokyo stock market out of its slump, further undermining the yen. One dollar bought 154.20 Japanese yen late in New York, more than 153.05 yen late Monday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 153.65 yen from 153.55 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 153.85 yen. A slightly larger than expected increase in the February Consumer Price Index and a widening in the U.S. merchandise trade deficit during January were bullish for the dollar. The CPI rose 0.5 percent and the trade gap grew to $9.3 billion from $7.7 billion in December. The British pound reacted negatively to the annual budget announcement delivered by Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major. But dealers said the budget wouldn't have a lasting impact on sterling and was considered neutral. One pound fetched $1.6005 late in New York, weaker than $1.6135 on Monday. Earlier in London, the British pound fell to $1.6105 from $1.6110 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Monday, included: 1.5225 Swiss francs, up from 1.5085; 5.7575 French francs, up from 5.7025; 1,258.00 Italian lire, up from 1,246.75; and 1.17765 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18225. Selected dollar rates late in Europe compared with Monday's late levels were: 1.6965 West German marks, up from 1.6829; 1.5157 Swiss francs, up from 1.5085; 5.7340 French francs, up from 5.6895; 1.9107 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8970; 1,253.50 Italian lire, up from 1,244.25; and 1.1792 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1836. Precious metals dealers said gold dropped in response to the dollar's rise. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $398 a troy ounce from $402.45 late Monday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $399.25 from $402.50 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.28 to close at a bid of $400.76. In New York, silver bullion for March delivery closed at $5.043 a troy ounce, down from Monday's settlement of $5.10. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $5.09 a troy ounce from $5.13 bid late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Prices Tumble On Dollar's Strength, Japanese Rates
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices skidded well below $400 an ounce Tuesday on New York's Commodity Exchange as a stronger dollar and a rise in Japanese interest rates prompted aggressive selling of gold by banks and Far Eastern investors. On other commodity markets, coffee futures surged; livestock and meat futures retreated; energy futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mostly higher. Gold futures settled $8.60 to $9.60 lower with the contract for delivery in April at $393.30 a troy ounce, a four-month low. Silver futures finished 5.8 cents to 7.7 cents lower on the Commodity Exchange with March at $5.043 a troy ounce; platinum futures dropped $8.50 to $8.70 on the New York Mercantile Exchange with April at $493.60 a troy ounce. Analysts said the gold market mainly took its cues from the dollar, which surged in value Tuesday against the British pound, Swiss franc, West German mark and the Japanese yen. A stronger dollar tends to discourage foreign demand for gold because it makes the metal, which is traded in dollars, more expensive in terms of other currencies. Further selling was prompted by the Bank of Japan's announcement of a 1 point increase in its discount rate to 5.25 percent, the fourth rate hike in a series intended to fight inflation. Tuesday's developments created uncertainty about the future of Japanese investment demand for gold, said Stephen W. Platt, metals analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. He said investment buying from Japan ``has been a big mover for the market and there are questions as to whether it will still be as formidable a source of demand as it has been.'' Coffee futures rallied strongly on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, erasing nearly half of the steep losses registered in the two previous sessions. Analysts tied the buying to perceptions that the market had sold off too sharply in reaction to the Brazilian economic reforms announced Friday. Traders initially speculated the reforms would spur sales of coffee from Brazil, the world's largest producer, but doubts about that prediction have surfaced. Coffee futures finished 1 cent to 3.52 cents higher with May at 91.21 cents a pound. The March contract expired at 88.46 cents a pound. Cattle futures fell sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in selling prompted by softer cash markets. Weak cash prices also pressured pork futures. Live cattle futures settled .50 cent to 1.33 cents lower with April at 76.82 cents pound; feeder cattle were .40 cent to .87 cent lower with March at 82.20 cents a pound; live hogs were .47 cent lower to .05 cent higher with April at 53.25 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .85 cent lower with March at 50.60 cents a pound. Crude oil futures slipped while refined products advanced on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventory report. The report, released after the close, showed smaller-than-expected U.S. supplies of crude oil and petroleum distillates _ including heating oil _ while supplies of gasoline were within market expectations. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures finished 9 cents to 32 cents lower with April at $19.28 a barrel; heating oil was .15 cent to .33 lower with April at 54.35 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .25 cent to .95 cent higher with April at 57.31 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures settled mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade after see-sawing through the session as traders searched for significant new developments. Wheat futures finished { cent to 3} cents higher with March at $4.02\ a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 2{ cents higher with March at $2.53 a bushel; oats were { cent to 2 cents lower with March at $1.46{ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cent to 3 cents higher with March at $5.92{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats: Collect More Taxes From Foreign Operations Here
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS $1.5 billion in income to losses in 4th graf: ``Foreign-controlled,''
DOC.TEXT: Foreign companies would have to pay more taxes on profitable operations in the United States under a bill introduced Tuesday by senior House Democrats. ``It is critical that we ensure that foreign-owned companies are not underpaying their taxes, thereby gaining a competitive advantage over American companies that are paying their fair share of taxes,'' Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said at a news conference. The bill, also sponsored by House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., grew out of Internal Revenue Service disclosures that more than half of 36,800 foreign companies that filed tax returns in 1986 reported no taxable income. The IRS is investigating whether foreign companies underpaid taxes by billions of dollars in the 1980s. Foreign-controlled corporations reported $542 billion in receipts and $1.5 billion in losses and paid $3 billion in U.S. income taxes in 1986. Gephardt said foreign automobile manufacturers had $7.7 billion in sales and paid less than $12 million in tax. ``No wonder ... (U.S. automakers) have had a hard time competing,'' Gephardt said. Gephardt and Rostenkowski said they are not worried that enactment of their bill would discourage foreign investment, which has played a major role in financing the U.S. budget deficit. ``All we are asking people to do is pay what Americans pay to do business in this country,'' Rostenkowski said. The bill would: _Expand IRS authority to investigate whether foreign companies have manipulated U.S. tax laws in dealings with their American subsidiaries and operating arms. For example, a foreign automaker could artificially inflate the price of parts coming into the United States so as to show little or no profit on the sale of the completed car. A 1989 law strengthened the hand of the IRS by requiring increased reporting and better recordkeeping by foreign companies, but it does not apply to past-year taxes. The bill would allow the IRS to use the stricter rules in investigating past-year problems. _Tax the capital gains realized when a foreigner sells stock in a U.S. corporation. The tax would not apply to residents of countries with which the United States has treaties prohibiting such taxation. Congressional analysts estimate the bill would boost taxes on foreign corporations and investors by about $200 million a year. Gephardt said other estimates are far higher.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline futures rebounded Tuesday while crude oil prices continued to sag, pressured by concern about short-term plentiful supplies and slowing demand. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the April contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, tumbled 32 cents to settle at $19.28 a 42-gallon barrel after trading as low as $19.07. Analysts said a late round of arbitrage buying helped lift the contract off its lows on the final day of trading before it expired. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for April delivery, which dropped 0.60 cents in Monday's session, rose 0.95 cent to 57.31 cents a gallon. And the April contract for No. 2 heating oil, which rose 0.08 cent in the previous session, slipped 0.19 cent to 54.35 cents a gallon. Energy analysts said crude oil started the day higher but gave way to fundamental factors as the session progressed. Demand has slowed in recent weeks due mainly to seasonal factors while production, particularly by OPEC countries, has remained strong. Projections are for demand to continue to slow in the second quarter, which is traditionally a period of weak demand. Analysts said the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' inaction at last weekend's monitoring committee meeting left the market under pressure. OPEC ministers adjourned a two-day session without making any new commitments to curb production, which currently exceeds demand by more than a million barrels a day, according to various estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department: Manischewitz Fixed Matzo Prices
DOC.NOTE: Eds: spelling of `matzoh' in company name in final graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's best-known matzo maker, B. Manischewitz Co., was accused Tuesday of scheming with its competitors to fix the price of $25 million of kosher Passover matzo from 1981 to 1986. An indictment filed by the U.S. Justice Department in federal court here accused the Jersey City-based company of conspiracy to restrain trade. No other company was named, nor were any individuals charged. The 101-year-old maker of kosher products issued a statement denying the charge and said its prices have been ``independently and fairly determined.'' ``Manischewitz will vigorously defend against the charges,'' said the company. Questions were referred to vice president Robert A. Mann. A secretary said Mann was out of the office until Wednesday and that the company would have no other comment. Kosher for Passover matzo is made specially for the Jewish holiday that celebrates the exodus of the Jews from ancient Egypt. The indictment, filed by the Justice Department's antitrust division, alleged that Manischewitz and co-conspirators discussed price increases and published price lists incorporating the agreed-on increases. Customers who were charged the allegedly fixed prices included kosher food distributors who sold to supermarket chains and grocery stores. The maximum penalty for the charge is a $1 million fine. Manischewitz earned $286,861 on $32.5 million in sales in the fiscal year ending July 31, 1989. The annual report said an 8.1 percent increase in sales resulted from higher average selling prices, plus modest volume increases. The company has about 225 employees. At Streit's Matzos in New York City, a Manischewitz competitor, a man who answered the phone and also declined to give his name said company officials who could comment had left for the day late Tuesday afternoon. The office manager at Goodman's Matzoh Inc. in Elmwood Park, who declined to give her name, said Manischewitz has taken over its matzo production.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Introduces New Computer ``Workstation Servers''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, The new... to CLARIFY; SUBS 6th graf pvs Four of... to DELETE reference to microprocessor being made available last year. SUBS 9th graf, Two of... to DELETE reference to SCSI.
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. introduced six new personal computers Tuesday that allow quick transfer of information among a network of microcomputers. The machines, which include new versions of IBM's Model 80 plus a new machine called the Model 65 SX, are IBM's first workstations or file servers based on jazzed-up personal computers. Analysts said they will enable the computer giant to catch up with the rest of the personal computer market in that field. IBM had not introduced a new top-end Model 80 since 1987. File servers are computers that can quickly disperse individual files to a number of other computers. in contrast to a stand-alone computer that does not have such capability. IBM already makes larger computers that can be used as file servers for networks of machines. The new Personal System-2(a) models are variations of IBM's Personal System-2 desktop computer line, offer twice as much memory as earlier Model 60s and 80s and include high-performance fixed disks as standard equipment. Four of the new machines are based on versions of Intel Corp.'s 80386-series microprocessor. A new system, the IBM Personal System-2 Model 65 SX, is designed around the Intel 80386SX microprocessor. All are equipped with microchannel card adapters called Small Computer System Interface that will enable the user to attach up to seven devices such as printers, disk drives or optical scanners through a single system expansion slot. Previous adapters allowed only one hookup. ``They are as good as the competition but I wouldn't say they're any sort of showstopper,'' said Daniel C. Benton, computer analyst with Goldman Sachs & Co. Two of the machines run at 25-megahertz and include a 64 kilobyte memory cache and four megabytes of random access memory. Two others run at 20-megahertz and come equipped with two megabytes of RAM and either 120 megabytes or 320 megabytes of hard disk capacity. Two versions of the Model 65 SX come with a two megabyte memory and either 60 megabytes or 120 megabytes of hard disk capacity. Companies increasingly have been hooking together their personal computers so employees can share a data base. That allows workers to access and update the same documents or to share computer files electronically rather than by transferring computer disks manually from one machine to another. File servers function as the central data repository for a network of personal computers. They have a much greater storage capacity and can get at data more quickly than an ordinary desktop computer. But the capabilities of a file server are as much a function of the hardware as the software, the program that runs the computer, said Peter Burris, an analyst with the consulting firm International Data Group. IBM's chief competitor in the personal computer file server business will be Compaq Computer Corp., which last fall introduced machines that analysts considered impressive. Compaq makes IBM-compatible computers. The four Model 80s are priced between $7,495 and $13,195 and the Model 65 SX machines at $5,295 and $5,995. IBM also announced price reductions between 15 percent and 24 percent on all existing PS-2 Model 80s, Model 60s, Model 30-001s and Model 30-021s. For example, the Model 80-071 has been reduced to $6,095 from $7,995 and the Model 30-021 has been marked down to $1,925 from $2,255. Other new devices announced by IBM include a new IBM PS-2 laserprinter Model P70 386-031 that is 25 percent faster than the current industry leader made by Hewlett Packard. The laserprinter with color display is also competitively priced with the HP printer at $1,495.

DOC.HEAD: Smith Corona Rearranges Staff At Two Locations; 350 To Lose Jobs in NY
DOC.TEXT: Smith Corona Corp., citing a market shift to lower priced electronic products, has cut 350 positions at its Cortland, N.Y. manufacturing plant, the company announced Tuesday. The company said it would offset the Cortland layoffs by adding 300 positions to its Singapore manufacturing facility. ``Any cut in the work force is regrettable,'' said G. Lee Thompson, Smith Corona's chairman and chief executive officer. ``But it is necessary to meet the changing market conditions and to balance inventories, enabling the company to make a smooth transition to our new product line which will be introduced this summer.'' Thompson said the demand for higher priced products, such as those produced at the Cortland facility, has weakened and the demand for the cheaper products has increased. The New Canaan-based company manufactures portable electronic typewriters and personal word processors. It also markets office supplies including file folders, office forms and paper.

DOC.HEAD: Outboard Marine To Acquire Grunman Boats
DOC.TEXT: Outboard Marine Corp. said Tuesday it was acquiring Grumman Allied Industries' boat manufacturing plants and equipment in three states. Under terms of the agreement, Outboard Marine would take over Grumman Boats plants in Marathon, N.Y., Arkadelphia, Ark., and Minong, Wis. Grumman Boats is a division of Grumman Allied Industries Inc., a subsidiary of Grumman Corp. Outboard Marine also would obtain all current inventory of Grumman Boats and the exclusive license to use the Grumman name on a worldwide basis to market aluminum recreational boats. The company did not provide financial details on the agreement. ``This acquisition provides us with additional manufacturing capacity for aluminum boats in the northeastern and southern regions of the country,'' said James C. Chapman, Outboard Marine president and chief executive officer. ``It also gives us another brand of outboard powered aluminum boats to satisfy demand for these products among our Johnson and Evinrude outboard motor dealers,'' Chapman said in a statement. Outboard Marine manufactures and sells boats, marine engines marine accessories and services. It currently markets Lowe, Sea Nymph and Suncruiser aluminum boats in the U.S., along with eight brands of fiberglass boats. Outboard Marine had net sales in 1989 of $1.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Union Accuses American Airlines of Asking for FAA Scrutiny
DOC.TEXT: A pilots union said American Airlines' request that federal regulators monitor its flight crews is raising tension between the two sides. The Allied Pilots Association, which represents the 8,100 pilots at American, said the airline asked the Federal Aviation Administration to monitor its flights in order to determine if pilots are slowing down. A federal mediator is scheduled next week to join contract talks between American and the pilots, which started last September. In a letter to U.S. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner, APA President Fred Vogel said FAA monitoring violates the Bush administration's policy of not intervening in labor disputes. Vogel's letter contained what he said was an FAA memo advising air traffic controllers to keep a record of American's flights. ``It appears that some flight crews are flying their aircraft at less-than- expected altitudes and speeds. American Airlines has asked, to the extent possible, that we record the flight call signs, dates and times for forwarding to the airline,'' the FAA memo said, according to Vogel. Vogel warned Skinner that the FAA will bear some responsibility if negotiations break down and pilots strike American, the nation's largest airline. The letter asks Skinner to ``take the necessary steps'' to stop the FAA monitoring. The pilots union referred questions about details of its request to Scott Peterson, who did not immediately return a call Tuesday. Al Becker, a spokesman for Fort Worth-based American, said the airline has seen ``absolutely no evidence of a systematic slowdown.'' A DOT spokesman said Monday it was a common practice for air traffic controllers to closely monitor airlines that are locked in tough contract talks with their pilots. But, he added, ``During these types of negotiations, it's not uncommon for individual pilots to conduct themselves in a way that is not in the best interest of the company.'' To slow down flights, pilots can fly and taxi at slower-than-normal speeds and cancel flights because of minor mechanical problems.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Credit Rating Drops as Nationwide Drivers' Strike Continues
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp. on Tuesday downgraded Greyhound Lines Inc.'s credit rating, citing a 20-day-old drivers strike and a $380 million debt from a 1987 leveraged buyout. Standard & Poor's, a credit rating agency, said the company's new management has improved revenue generation and operating efficiency, but interest on the debt and rentals on leased buses remain a heavy burden. It also said the strike by unionized drivers that began March 2 ``initially halted most bus operations and has caused substantial losses.'' Standard & Poor's said it had lowered Greyhound's rating to B-from B. It said the company remained on its CreditWatch list pending a further review. George Gravley, a spokesman for Dallas-based Greyhound, said: ``We don't have anything to say about that. We have a good financial condition, and we're not at all concerned.'' Meanwhile, the company and the drivers union, Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, said there was no movement toward reopening contract talks that stalled Sunday. Each has accused the other of not negotiating in good faith. Unions representing 6,300 drivers and an estimated 3,000 other Greyhound workers walked out over wages, job security and grievance procedures. A Greyhound spokeswoman Monday said the proposal union leaders offered Saturday was ``three times more than Greyhound could afford.'' A union spokesman said the company has offered a plan that included no guaranteed pay raises, but would have made raises contingent on increased profits and ridership. During the strike, there have been at least 14 shooting attacks on Greyhound buses, 46 bomb threats and numerous other incidents of vandalism or threats during the walkout, company officials say. Greyhound operates the only nationwide intercity bus service.

DOC.BYLINE: Anheuser-Busch Launches New Attack Against Miller
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TA1
DOC.TEXT: Anheuser-Busch Inc., the world's largest brewer, announced a new product Tuesday that looks and sounds a lot like the popular, cold-filtered beer made by rival Miller Brewing Co. The new beer, called Busch Cold Filtered Draft, will be sold in clear, longneck bottles just like Miller's Genuine Cold Filtered Draft. ``Imitation is nothing new for Anheuser-Busch,'' said Susan Henderson, a spokeswoman for Milwaukee-based Miller. ``Miller coined the term cold filtered in 1985 to describe its exclusive non-heat pasteurization process and Anheuser-Busch wants to turn it into a generic term.'' Anheuser-Busch plans to test market the new beer for one to two months in Tulsa, Okla. to determine whether it's a viable product. Michael Roarty, director of marketing for Anheuser-Busch, said the company has wanted to use a clear bottle for some time, to serve beer drinkers who like to see what they're drinking. Miller Genuine Draft, the fastest-growing premium beer in the country, last year supplanted Anheuser-Busch's Michelob as the nation's 10th most-popular beer. A big difference between the two beers is that Busch Cold Filtered Draft is sensitive to light and could spoil if the bottles are taken out of the box and left, for example, on a shelf or in a tub of ice in the backyard. Anheuser-Busch hasn't sold beer in clear bottles for at least 100 years because beer made by its methods spoils when exposed to light. Anheuser uses the entire hop blossom when it makes beer, while Miller extracts the important oils and resins from the blossom separately and adds them to the brew kettle. Miller's process protects the beer from taste-altering light, Busch's does not. The two have had a long-running dispute over their brewing processes. ``We really had a dilemma because we wanted to use a clear bottle but we also wanted to continue our tradition of using only natural ingredients,'' said Klaus Zastrow, brewmaster for Anheuser-Busch. The company compromised by brewing Busch Cold Filtered Draft with its usual methods while packaging the clear bottles in a light-proof cardboard box. But once the beer comes out of the box it's susceptible to spoilage, Zastrow said. ``If you're talking about a bright, sunny day, it could be a matter of minutes before the beer develops this off-flavor,'' Zastrow said. ``If you're inside it could take hours.'' Because of this uncertainty, Anheuser-Busch in its test marketing initially will sell the beer only in restaurants and taverns. Zastrow said some people may enjoy the light-induced change in the taste. ``The exposure to light will enhance the hoppy flavor and the beer will taste more European,'' said Zastrow. Anheuser Busch sells 17 other brands of beer including Busch and Busch Light. The company uses a cold filtering process to make Busch Light and Bud Dry, which is scheduled to be rolled out nationally in two weeks. All beer is cold-filtered, but beer that advertises the ``cold filtered process'' undergoes a second, highly pressurized cold-filtering to remove yeast cells. That second process takes the place of pasteurization. Stock analysts said the new beer offered the world's largest brewery another opportunity to grow in an industry that has been experiencing flat sales for several years. ``I guess you could call it copying, but in every business if something is successful you're going to see people jump on the bandwagon,'' said Bob Bernstein, a stock analyst for Edward D. Jones Co. in St. Louis. ``Companies don't stand back and applaud their competitor's success. They try to come up with something even better.''

DOC.HEAD: Company Names New Directors After Proxy Battle
DOC.TEXT: XTRA Corp., which came under new control after dissident shareholders won a proxy fight last week, announced appointments to top positions Tuesday and said the new board of directors would begin a review of the company's operations. The trailer leasing company confirmed Monday that the dissident group's nominees were elected to the board. The group, called the XTRA Independent Stockholders Committee, was led by Connecticut investor Robert Gintel, who now will serve as the company's vice chairman. The new chairman will be Robert Goergen, replacing Charles Kay. The company president will be Lewis Rubin. In a statement, the firm said the newly elected board was trying to ensure a smooth transition while it reviews the company and its operations.

DOC.HEAD: GM, Saab Finish Setting Up Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. and Saab-Scania AB have have completed setting up a joint automaking venture in Europe, the Swedish company said Tuesday. GM, the world's largest automaker, and Saab-Scania, Sweden's second-biggest vehicle maker behind Volvo AB, agreed Dec. 15 to form a joint automaking company, called Saab Automobile AB. Ownership of the new company is split 50-50 between Saab and GM, which is spending about $600 million to acquire half of the corporation's auto business. Saab-Scania's automobile business has been struggling financially and draining profits from the corporation's other businesses, including trucks and airplanes. The move is seen as a way to financially bolster the automotive business and to give GM a manufacturing foothold in Sweden. The new company will manufacture and distribute cars under the Saab nameplate through Saab's dealer network and make GM cars for European distribution.

DOC.HEAD: United Brands Becomes Chiquita Brands
DOC.TEXT: United Brands Co. on Tuesday changed its name to Chiquita Brands International Inc., saying it wants to be publicly identified with the bananas it sells internationally. The company changed its stock symbol to CQB from UB on the New York, Boston, and Pacific stock exchanges. The Cincinnati-based company sells and distributes fresh and prepared foods, including fruits and vegetables, in the United States, Europe, the Middle East and the Far East. American Financial Corp., a holding company controlled by financier Carl Lindner Jr., owns 82 percent of United Brands' common stock. It approved the name change and no further shareholder action was required, company spokeswoman Sandra Heimann said.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Holds Back Loan for China
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank on Tuesday held back a $150 million loan to China that was to go before representatives of the 152 member governments for approval, a bank spokesman said. A source familiar with the bank's work said World Bank President Barber Conable decided on the move when it became apparent the loan would not be approved. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady last week said he would oppose loans by the bank to China that were not for basic human needs. The proposed loan was earmarked for roads and inland ways in Jiangsu province in east central China. Decisions on loans are made behind closed doors by the bank's 22 executive directors. The United States controls 19 percent of the vote, the largest single block. Usually enough other governments support the U.S. view for a majority. Conable last June withheld consideration of nearly $800 million in loans to China after troops suppressed a pro-democracy movement. He said his decision was made on economic grounds. President Bush, however, asked that loans be held up as part of the U.S. sanctions against the Chinese goverrment. Last month the board approved two loans to China worth $90 million, including one that delayed in June. The Treasury Department said the U.S. representative voted for the loans. At a Congressional hearing last week, Brady took note of opposition to the loans by many members of Congress, and said the U.S. position was taken on behalf of them as well as the Bush administration. The bank is the largest single source of aid to the Third World, making loans of more than $22 billion a year. Its charter, and those of other intergovernment banks that help the Third World, try to prevent political matters from being considered in granting loans. But Brady said the United States will insist that progress toward democracy be made a condition for loans under the rules of the projected European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Brady said he had made it clear to the Soviet Union that any loans from the new bank to them would leave less for other east European countries the United States considers further along on the road to democracy. The World Bank does not lend to the Soviet Union, which is not a member.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf to CORRECT bond reference to $1,000 sted $10; picks up 10th graf pvs bg'ng, In Tokyo, ...
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. stock market showed resilience but finished lower Tuesday in the face of negative economic reports and another steep tumble on the Tokyo exchange. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 16.89 points to 2,738.74. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 892 down, 598 up and 495 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled 177.32 million shares, up from 142.30 million in Monday's session. After shrugging off negative economic news to rise early in the session, stocks turned lower in the afternoon and lost most of the ground just before the close. Wall Street has posted an impressive advance in recent weeks. ``It was just an overbought market that got a little bit ahead of itself,'' said Charles Jensen, an analyst at MKI Securities Corp. The government reported that consumer inflation was 0.5 percent in February and the U.S. trade deficit worsened dramatically in January, climbing to $9.3 billion. The January trade deficit was 20.5 percent larger than December's $7.7 billion gap. Most of the deterioration came from a 44 percent surge in oil imports. Still, Wall Street's decline wasn't nearly as severe as the sharp dive Tuesday in the Tokyo stock market. Analysts said the New York market drew some support from strong bond prices, which pushed U.S. interest rates lower. The Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond finished about ~ point higher, or up $8.75 for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which falls when the price rises, slid to 8.45 percent from 8.53 percent late Monday. In Tokyo, the key Japanese stock index tumbled a second straight day as neither currency market intervention nor an interest rate boost by the central bank stopped the weakening of the Japanese yen. The Bank of Japan raised its key discount rate by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent. It was the fourth hike of a series intended primarily to fight inflation. Hugh Johnson, senior vice president of First Albany Corp. in Albany, N.Y., suggested that the Japanese may have to increase the rate again in the near future. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which plunged 1,353.20 points, or 4.15 percent, on Monday in its third-largest single-day fall, tumbled another 456.05 points, or 1.48 percent, Tuesday. The New York market had dropped initially Monday in the wake of that day's slide in Japan, but later recovered in an afternoon rally. The Dow Jones average finished 14.41 points higher Monday at 2,755.63, its highest close since it stood at 2,760.67 on Jan. 11. Among actively traded issues Tuesday on the NYSE, IBM fell 1 to 108, General Electric was down { at 64], Boeing dropped 1 to 70{ and AT&T slipped | to 41}. Philip Morris was unchanged at 39, General Motors was up [ at 47| and Bank of New England rose ~ to 5[. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 212.70 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $15.55 billion, or 0.47 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.95 to 187.71. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 2.35 to 396.45, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 1.96 at 341.57. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 2.83 to 440.08. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index lost 0.70 at 363.42.

DOC.HEAD: Cannell Communications Says It Will Acquire WUAB-TV
DOC.TEXT: Cannell Communications Inc. announced Tuesday that it will acquire WUAB-TV in Cleveland from Gaylord Broadcasting Co. of Ohio Inc. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The station, which has its studios in the Cleveland suburb of Parma, is the leading independent in the Cleveland area which ranks as the nation's 11th largest TV market, the Atlanta-based Cannell said. ``WUAB represents a truly unique opportunity and clearly indicates the type of properties we are looking to acquire,'' said William A. Schwartz, president and chief executive officer of Cannell Communications. Bill Scaffide, the station's general manager, said no staff changes were expected. A joint announcement of the acquisition was made at the station Tuesday, he said. The deal is subject to Federal Communications Commission approval. Cannell Communications, which was formed in November, is the broadcasting affiliate of The Cannell Studios, an independent producer of television programming.

DOC.HEAD: Salad Dressing Trial Pits Paul Newman, Deli Owner
DOC.TEXT: A delicatessan owner testified Tuesday that Academy Award winner Paul Newman reneged on a promise of stock in exchange for helping the actor launch his spaghetti sauce and salad dressing business. Newman, dressed in a blue pinstripe suit and shiny black boots, sat in the back of the courtroom, took notes and talked to a business partner as testimony began in the second trial in the case. Westport deli owner Julius Gold sued Newman in 1983, claiming he was promised stock in Newman's Own Inc. A mistrial was declared in 1988 when the jury mistakenly received depositions not admitted as evidence. Newman and A.E. Hotchner, a friend and fellow Westport resident, started Newman's Own to sell the salad dressing Newman had been making and bottling for friends. The company, which also makes popcorn and lemonade, donates all profits to charity, $28 million so far. Gold, 65, testified that he received a call from Hotchner in 1979 asking for help in distributing the dressing to six or eight stores in Westport. ``I did nothing immediately after that phone call, nor did I do anything for a period of many months,'' Gold said, adding he had doubts about the venture. But he said he got a second telephone call from Hotchner in January 1980, and set Hotchner up with three distributors. The last was David Kalman, who eventually distributed the products nationwide. Gold also said he performed other services to help the business and sat in on many meetings, including a May 1982 meeting with Newman's attorney, Leo Nevas, at which he and Kalman were promised 8 percent of the stock. Newman winced when Gold testified said the actor offered him a ride home in a Volkswagen after an August 1982 meeting at Newman's New York apartment to discuss kickoff plans for the salad dressing. Newman drives and races Nissans. At the end of the ride, Gold said he thanked Newman for giving him 8 percent of the stock, and the actor said, ``That's fine, you're very welcome.'' Newman shook his head. Gold, who is seeking unspecified damages, also claims he performed other services to help with details such as packaging and labeling. He was the first witness in the trial in Bridgeport Superior Court. Newman's lawyer, W. Patrick Ryan, said he plans to produce witnesses and evidence disputing Gold's claims. ``Nobody's saying he wasn't looking for stock. Of course he was looking for stock,'' Ryan said in opening arguments Tuesday. ``The only thing is, he was told no. He asked again, he was told no.'' Security at Bridgeport Superior Court was tight. A television camera and a still camera have been allowed in the courtroom, but only to photograph the judge, witnesses and lawyers. During a break, Newman said a bandage on his right hand was for an injury he got when his finger stuck in the collar of his dog, Griggs. But he declined to discuss the lawsuit, saying, ``I don't think it's appropriate at this time.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Tougher Auto Amendment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; minor editing; Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: The Senate rejected efforts Tuesday night to toughen auto pollution controls in a compromise clean air bill as opponents successfully argued the provision was ``a prescription for deadlock.'' The vote was 52-46 to table, and in effect kill, an amendment which would have required considerably tighter emissions controls on automobiles than a compromise bill crafted by Senate leaders and the White House. It also called for 1 million vehicles capable of burning fuels other than gasoline toward the end of the decade. Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., and other backers of the amendment argued that additional restrictions on automobile pollutants were needed because autos ``are the biggest source of pollution in our cities.'' But Senate leaders and supporters of the compromise bill characterized the tougher requirement as threatening enactment of clean air legislation altogether this year because of the strong opposition from the Bush administration. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the amendments ``a prescription for deadlock'' on the bill before the Senate. ``Do we want 13 more years of speeches or do we want a bill? Do we want to make statements or do we want to make law?'' Mitchell asked his colleagues. Meanwhile, the compromise was under attack on another front Tuesday in a dispute over whether the federal government should provide assistance to coal miners who lose their jobs because of the bill. Wirth said on the floor that the coal miner assistance proposal ``appears to have a majority of the votes.'' Negotiations have been under way with the Bush administration to see if all parties could agree on help for miners. The White House has objected to the plan's $700 million price tag and has characterized it as a ``deal breaker'' if some compromise cannot be reached with the sponsor, Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va. Deadlock on the Byrd amendment caused the Senate to turn its attention to auto controls. Byrd is trying to help miners of high-sulfur coal who would lose jobs because of new curbs of sulfur dioxide emissions by Midwest utilities. His plan calls for four years of assistance to miners. Byrd's state produces both high-sulfur and low-sulfur coal. Mitchell had refused Byrd's repeated calls to bring his amendment to a vote. The amendment was to have been the first order of business when the Senate reconvened after a week recess, but consideration was postponed for a second time early Tuesday. Senate sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed Wirth's assertion that Byrd appears to have enough votes for the amendment. Senate leaders fear the amendment would prompt the White House to withdraw support for the legislation and threaten passage of a clean air bill this year. Some of Byrd's support may come from senators who oppose the overall bill for various easons and see a push for coal miners' assistance as a chance to stall the legislation, Senate and industry and environmental lobbyists suggested Tuesday. Byrd met Monday with Roger Porter, President Bush's chief domestic policy adviser, in an attempt to reach a compromise, but sources said little progress was made. The Senate bill would set tough new pollution controls on industry and automobiles to reduce urban smog, cut toxic chemical emissions from industry, and require electric utilities to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons by the end of the decade. Byrd says that provision, which is aimed at reducing acid rain, would cost the jobs of thousands of coal miners, including many in his state where many jobs depend on high-sulfur coal. Wirth noted in Tuesday's debate that President Bush said last year the clean air bill should ``reconcile the automobile with the environment.'' But Wirth said the compromise backs off from that promise. In the House, meanwhile, the Energy and Commerce Committee edged toward consideration the first of several amendments to a somewhat different clean air bill. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., introduced an amendment Tuesday that would tighten controls on urban smog from industry. ``I don't think we're that far apart,'' said Waxman, suggesting he's ready to compromise on the proposal and predicting a possible vote within days. The committee, chaired by Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., hopes to push a clean air bill to the House floor by May.

DOC.HEAD: GM Delaying Part of Van Production Moves
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. will delay moving production of full-size vans to Flint from Scarborough, Ontario, for one year to provide more time for retooling in Michigan, GM officials said Tuesday. GM announced late last year it would make a series of moves in late 1991 that would result in idling its Scarborough plant and a production reduction at its truck factory in Lordstown, Ohio. The moves are designed to consolidate full-size van production at GM's Flint truck plant. Full-size vans now are made at Scarborough and Lordstown. GM of Canada spokesman Nick Hall said Tuesday that the Scarborough plant would stay open through at least late 1992 and continue making full-size vans. About 2,400 hourly and 300 salaried employees work at the plant. GM Truck & Bus Group spokeswoman Kari Hulsey said moves are still planned for late 1991 that will transfer production of Chevrolet Blazer and Suburban and GMC Jimmy vehicles from Flint to Janesville, Wis., and production of full-size vans from Lordstown to Flint. She said specific dates for the production changes have not been set. About 2,500 Lordstown workers are to be laid off when the move occurs.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Dispute Hazelwood's Alleged Drinking; Exxon Accused of Interference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf, `Madson told ...,' to CORRECT that Madson said `not all' the 21 witnesses were Exxon employees, sted `not one.'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AG3
DOC.TEXT: The case of Joseph Hazelwood went to the jury Tuesday after a defense attorney called the Exxon Valdez skipper a scapegoat of political powers and a prosecutor portrayed him as a reckless drunk. A defense attorney argued that the 7-week-old trial was a political action in which the state seeks to shift blame for the disaster. ``Maybe the state hopes the people will look the other way when it comes to their responsibility,'' defense attorney Dick Madson declared in his final argument. Madson said crew members were not the only ones who saw that Hazelwood wasn't impaired aboard the Exxon Valdez when it struck a charted reef a year ago Saturday. He pointed to 21 witnesses at Hazelwood's criminal trial who said the captain was sober and showed no signs of being impaired by alcohol. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole said it was not necessary to show that Hazelwood looked intoxicated to have been impaired by drink. ``The state has to prove he was under the influence of intoxicating liquor,'' Cole said. He said this did not mean that ``a person is stumbling, falling down, and needs support.'' Instead, Cole argued, impairment means ``when your physicial and mental abilities are impaired.'' Cole asked jurors to determine that Hazelwood was impaired from his actions and from a blood test taken 10{ hours after the ship ripped its hull open on a reef in Prince William Sound. Following arguments, Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone instructed jurors on the law for about an hour, then told them to select a foreman and begin their deliberations. They spent about 10 minutes behind closed doors, then retired for the day. They were to resume Wednesday morning. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with one felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, he could receive 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. After the ship ran aground, it spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska North Slope crude oil, blackening hundreds of miles of shoreline and killing fish, birds and other wildlife. Madson urged jurors to ignore efforts to make Hazelwood out as the villain. ``Alaska is known as the last frontier,'' he said. ``We don't have vigilantes or lynch mobs. What this frontier does is grant a fair trial to everyone _ even people who transport what they call black gold. ``Captain Hazelwood is entitled to that fairness,'' Madson said. He reminded jurors that their verdict cannot change or improve what happened in Prince William Sound. ``That is over and done,'' Madson said. Many parties had an interest in seeing Hazelwood blamed for the disaster, and among them might be Exxon itself, Madson said in response to prosecution claims that Exxon wants the skipper acquitted. Madson ridiculed any reliance on the delayed blood test. He said the calculations presented by a prosecution expert on how drunk Hazelwood might have been were hard to believe. ``Under the testimony you heard, Captain Hazelwood would have had to be dragged up there (on the ship) by the collar. He would have been so high at that blood alcohol level,'' Madson said. He held up a picture of the ship's precarious gangway, which the skipper negotiated without a missed step, and declared, ``this is probably the toughest sobriety test you're going to see.'' Cole said crew members who testified that the captain was sober were probably influenced by Exxon to back up the skipper. He asked the jury to notice ``the presence of Exxon in this case,'' and recalled the testimony of an Exxon executive who said the company has an interest in the outcome of Hazelwood's trial. ``It doesn't take a brain surgeon to see Exxon's interest in this matter,'' Cole said. ``It's seeing Captain Hazelwood get acquitted.'' The prosecutor reminded jurors that crew members who testified supported their captain on many issues, and sometimes changed the stories they had originally given about the grounding of the Exxon Valdez. Witnesses, for example, told the National Transportation Safety Board that the skipper tried to move the ship off the reef, but some said on the stand that they did not know if he was trying while others said he was not, Cole contended. ``It's easy to see the pressure they (Exxon) were putting on these crew members,'' said Cole as Exxon lawyers maintained their daily front-row vigil. Exxon spokesman Joe Tucker in Anchorage said he was not authorized to comment on Cole's allegations and that Exxon officials in Houston were not available. Cole said Hazelwood risked his ship and the lives of his crew, and should be found guilty of reckless conduct. Madson told jurors they could not ignore the testimony of the 21 people, not all Exxon employees, who said he was sober. He said jurors could not discount the opinions of experts who said that, if the skipper's instructions had been followed, the ship would have missed Bligh Reef by two miles. Hazelwood sat calmly at the defense table. His wife and father, who recently arrived at the trial, sat in back-row seats of the crowded courtroom.
